The African American Communities Speak (AACS) program is a community-developed training program for clinicians caring for African American older adults with serious illnesses. The program addresses culturally concordant care, systemic racism, and implicit bias management, the three key elements in enhancing the provision of equitable care. The program is designed and implemented in full partnership with two distinct African American communities in the South and North of the US. The study aims to adapt the AACS program to urban-dwelling Southern and Northern older African American adults using the established platform of Community-Based Participatory Research (CBPR) in two geographically diverse regions: Birmingham, Alabama, and the Bronx, New York. The study will randomize clinician trainees to one of four start date training times for the AACS Education Intervention using a stepped wedge design to accommodate the training of all clinicians and to mitigate the effect of secular trends. The primary outcome will be patient/family's perception of therapeutic alliance using The Human Connection Scale. Secondary outcomes will be family-reported goal-concordant care, and clinicians' knowledge of cultural values, awareness of implicit bias, and confidence to change practice. This innovative effort will be the first training program that: 1. addresses culturally concordant care, systemic racism, and implicit bias management, the three key elements in enhancing the provision of equitable care; and 2. is designed and implemented in full partnership with two distinct African American communities in the South and North of the US.

The study aims to assess the molecular profile of oropharyngeal or oral cavity HPV positive and negative tumors in order to identify predictive markers for more effective and less invasive treatment. The study will be conducted on patients with oropharyngeal or oral cavity squamous cell carcinomas who have a biopsy or excision available and sufficient to carry out molecular analysis. The study will be conducted on two groups of patients: HPV + and HPV -. The study will measure the molecular profile of oropharyngeal or oral cavity HPV positive and negative tumors. The study will be conducted using genetic analysis on biopsy to define the molecular profile of head and neck tumors. The study will be conducted on 1 day.

The study aims to validate the use of Visual Analog Scales (VAS) to measure satisfaction and well-being at work. The study will include participants aged 18 years and older who are voluntary adults with a professional activity. The study will measure burnout, anxiety, job demand, job control, social support, job strain, effort-reward imbalance, work addiction, life satisfaction, and other related factors. The study will use the Maslach Burn-out Inventory (MBI), Hospital Anxiety and Depression (HAD) questionnaire, Job Demand-Control-Support (JDSC) questionnaire, Effort-Reward Imbalance Questionnaire (ERI), Work Addiction Risk Test (WART), Minnesota Satisfaction Questionnaire (MSQ), and other self-reported questionnaires. The study will use a horizontal, non-calibrated line of 100 mm to measure burnout, anxiety, job demand, job control, social support, job strain, effort-reward imbalance, work addiction, and life satisfaction. The study will measure burnout, anxiety, job demand, job control, social support, job strain, effort-reward imbalance, work addiction, and life satisfaction at inclusion and one week later. The study will also collect data on sociodemographic factors, occupation, work hours per week, night and weekend work, alcohol consumption, tobacco consumption, height, weight, sedentary behavior, physical activity, stress at work, ethical conflicts, perceived health, stress at home, fatigue, sleep quality, and mood. The study will be conducted in accordance with the Declaration of Helsinki and will obtain ethical approval from the local ethics committee.

============

The study is a randomized controlled trial that compares different techniques for alveolar ridge preservation after tooth extraction. The study includes four arms: spontaneous healing (control), bone particle + subepithelial connective tissue graft, bone particle + vascularized interpositional periosteal connective tissue graft, and bone particle + collagen membrane. The primary outcome measures are soft tissue and hard tissue alternation, measured using cone-beam computed tomography data and STereoLithography files up to 12 months. Secondary outcome measures include keratinized tissue width changes and Visual Analogue Scale. The study includes healthy volunteers aged 20 years and older who need dental implant or denture fabrication after tooth extraction and have healthy soft tissue. The study is double-masked and the intervention model is parallel assignment.

The study aims to compare the levels of pro-inflammatory cytokines in patients with Essure® contraceptive implants and in control patients with endometriosis or adenomyosis. The study will be conducted on women over 18 years old who have expressed their non-opposition to Essure and have undergone removal of the Essure® contraceptive implant or benign laparoscopic gynecological surgery with or without diagnosis of endometriosis or adenomyosis. The study will measure the level of cytokine IL10 in peritoneal fluid through study completion, an average of 4 months.

This is a two-way (retrospective+prospective) cohort study of patients with primary biliary cholangitis (PBC) and autoimmune hepatitis (AIH) infected with COVID-19. The study aims to compare the difference of COVID-19 infection rate, disease severity, clinical biochemical indicators, hospital stay and prognosis between UDCA treated and non UDCA treated patients, and to study the impact of UDCA on the occurrence, incidence and prognosis of COVID-19 infection. The study will collect demographic data, treatment information, COVID-19 infection and incidence, clinical symptoms, clinical biochemistry, liver imaging, lung imaging, COVID-19 nucleic acid, COVID-19 antibody, and the incidence and treatment information of COVID-19 from January 2022 to pre enrollment. Meanwhile, the corresponding treatment and clinical observation of PBC and AIH will be continued, and the occurrence and incidence of COVID-19 infection will be observed. For patients with COVID-19 infection during the prospective observation period, COVID-19 infection, onset and treatment will be observed, including clinical symptoms, signs, heart, lung imaging, COVID-19, clinical biochemistry, disease degree, virus negative, hospital stay and prognosis. The study will use a two-way (retrospective+prospective) cohort design, with patients with autoimmune liver disease infected with COVID-19 as the study population. The study will compare the difference of COVID-19 infection rate, disease severity, clinical biochemical indicators, hospital stay and prognosis between UDCA treated and non UDCA treated patients, and to study the impact of UDCA on the occurrence, incidence and prognosis of COVID-19 infection. The study will collect demographic data, treatment information, COVID-19 infection and incidence, clinical symptoms, clinical biochemistry, liver imaging, lung imaging, COVID-19 nucleic acid, COVID-19 antibody, and the incidence and treatment information of COVID-19 from January 2022 to pre enrollment. Meanwhile, the corresponding treatment and clinical observation of PBC and AIH will be continued,

This is a prospective, randomized, controlled clinical trial to observe whether preoperative prone position training can reduce the incidence of pulmonary complications after laparoscopic colorectal cancer surgery. The study will enroll 100 patients who are scheduled to undergo laparoscopic colorectal cancer surgery. The patients will be randomly assigned to either the prone position training group or the control group. The prone position training group will receive prone position training for at least 3 days before surgery, while the control group will receive standard perioperative care without any prone position training. The primary outcome measure will be the incidence of postoperative pulmonary complications (PPCs) within 7 days after surgery. Secondary outcome measures will include arterial partial pressure of oxygen (PaO2), extubation time, peak airway pressure, arterial partial pressure of carbon dioxide (PaCO2), oxygenation index (OI), and other relevant parameters. The study will be conducted in accordance with the CONSORT statement and will be approved by the institutional review board of the First Affiliated Hospital of Chongqing Medical University.

The study is a Phase I/II, open label study to evaluate the safety and efficacy of BLEX 404 Oral Liquid combined with Pemetrexed + Cisplatin Therapy in patients with advanced inoperable or metastatic non-small cell lung cancer. The study will be conducted in 2 phases. In phase I, the study will determine the dose-limiting toxicity (DLT) and recommended dose level (RDL) in the first cycle of combination use with Pemetrexed + Cisplatin Therapy. In phase II, the study will determine the efficacy while using the RDL of BLEX 404 Oral Liquid combined with Pemetrexed + Cisplatin Therapy in a total of 20 stage-IV or recurrent non-small cell lung cancer patients. The primary outcome measure is the overall response rate (PR + CR) after 4 cycles of combination use. The secondary outcome measure is the overall response rate (PR + CR) after at least 1 cycle of combination use. The study will be conducted in accordance with the Declaration of Helsinki and Good Clinical Practice guidelines.

=========

The AGE SELF CARE study is a pilot study that aims to promote healthy aging through a group visit program. The program consists of 8 weekly 90-minute virtual group visits, with approximately 12 participants in each group. The sessions focus on chronic disease management, healthy lifestyle education, home adaptation to optimize the home environment for usability and safety with aging, and anticipatory guidance. The study includes community-dwelling adults aged 65 years and older who are pre-frail during the initial study visit. The primary outcome measures include recruitment rate, completion of testing, attendance, completion of home practice log, and participant satisfaction. Secondary outcome measures include frailty index, loneliness, self-reported health, Godin Leisure-Time Exercise Questionnaire, self-efficacy, Patient Health Questionnaire 2-item scale (PHQ-2), Generalized Anxiety Disorder 2-item scale (GAD-2), sleep, and Short Physical Performance Battery (SPPB).

The Pan-European Study on Geriatric Rehabilitation After COVID-19 Disease is a multi-center observational cohort study into usual care data on the course of functional and clinical outcomes in post-COVID-19 geriatric rehabilitation patients in several European countries. The primary objective is to get insight into the course of functional and medical recovery in (geriatric) rehabilitation patients affected by COVID-19 in Europe. The secondary objective is to get insight into the treatment modalities employed and the organization of geriatric rehabilitation that post-COVID patients in Europe receive. The study was conducted according to the principles of the Declaration of Helsinki (2013 version) and in accordance with the General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR) and in full conformity to any applicable state or local regulations in the participating countries.

The study will enroll patients admitted for geriatric rehabilitation due to COVID-19 morbidity in Europe. Participants will receive standard rehabilitation treatment according to the discretion of clinical teams, which will likely be adapted to the specific needs of post-COVID-19 patients. This treatment includes physical therapy, occupational therapy, and medical treatment by an advanced nursing practitioner, geriatrician or medical specialist. The study will not influence any therapy provided or decisions about the medical treatment or treatment programs already used in the participating geriatric rehabilitation setting. This study is observational and it is not anticipated that the observations will influence therapy or treatment, particularly since such indices, questionnaires and measurements are a regular part of the rehabilitation program.

The study will collect data on demographic factors, information from hospital/general practitioner, and variables collected at admission, discharge, and 6 weeks and 6 months follow-up. The primary outcomes are ADL functioning (Barthel index or derived from the USER or FIM) and quality of life (EQ-5D-5L). The study will require a sample size of 52 (number of pairs) to achieve a power of 80% and a level of significance of 5% (two sided), for detecting a mean of the differences of 2 between pairs, assuming the standard deviation of the differences to be 5. The study will aim for a minimum of 250 participants in total.

The PREPARE-iVAC Trial is a multicenter, open-label, controlled, randomized study to evaluate the replacement of Mycophenolate Mofetil/Mycophenolic Acid by everolimus in kidney transplant recipients on immunogenicity and safety after vaccination. The study will investigate the primary objective of whether replacement of MMF/MPA by everolimus results in superior immunogenicity of COVID-19 vaccination as measured by neutralizing antibody titer against the Omicron XBB.1.5 strain. Secondary objectives include investigating whether replacement of MMF/MPA by everolimus results in superior humoral immunogenicity of COVID-19 vaccination as measured by SARS-CoV-2 specific anti-S1 antibody levels, herpes zoster vaccination as measured by varicella zoster specific anti-gE antibody levels, and superior cellular immunogenicity of COVID-19 vaccination as measured by SARS-CoV-2 specific T-cell response. The study will also evaluate the safety of replacement of MMF/MPA by everolimus in terms of incidence of treated acute rejection, kidney function decline, incidence of serious adverse events (SAEs), incidence of adverse events of special interest (AESI), of immunosuppression, incidence of solicited adverse events (AEs) of COVID-19 vaccination, incidence of solicited AEs of herpes zoster vaccination, and incidence of adverse events of immunosuppression. The study will be conducted in seven participating study sites in the Netherlands. At the first study visit, eligibility for study participation will be checked, blood will be drawn, and participants will subsequently be 1:1 randomised to continue immunosuppressive therapy with MMF/MPA or replace immunosuppressive therapy with MMF/MPA by everolimus. The study will continue in two parts: Part 1 - Run-in and COVID-19 vaccination (≥6 weeks + 28 days) and Part 2 (optional) - Herpes zoster vaccination (+56 days). The study aims to investigate the effect of resistance exercises on liver enzymes post burn in burned patients. The study will be conducted on 60 burned patients who will be randomly distributed into two equal groups. The experimental group will receive resistance exercises for 8 weeks, while the control group will receive their physical therapy program and medical treatment. The primary outcome measure will be plasma liver enzymes level (AST and ALT enzymes) measured at two months post burn.

The study aims to evaluate the effectiveness of Tecarterapy on the performance of amateur athletes. The study will be conducted in a randomized, double-blind, parallel assignment design. The intervention will consist of a single 25-minute Tecarterapy procedure in both legs with the T-Plus Wintecare® machine. The primary outcome measures will be changes in 30 meters sprint (seconds) and changes in electromyographic activity during sprint (μ/v). Secondary outcome measures will include changes in countermovement jump (cm), changes in electromyographic activity during countermovement jump (μ/v), changes in isometric leg extension (Newtons), and changes in electromyographic activity during isometric leg extension (μ/v). The study will be conducted in athletes between 18 and 30 years of age who are federated and competing in university or national amateur leagues that perform sprinting and jumping in their sports practice. The study will be conducted in Spain.

The study aims to evaluate the role of cell free DNA in patients with endometriosis undergoing IVF treatment. The study is a non-randomized, parallel assignment study with two arms: experimental and active comparator. The experimental arm includes patients with endometriosis, while the active comparator arm includes patients with other infertility causes. The study measures the cell free DNA rate in serum and follicular fluid, as well as oocyte quality, fragmentation rate, number of cells at day 2 and 3, blastulation rate at day 5 of development, and clinical pregnancy and live birth rates. The study is conducted over a period of 1 year.

The study is a prospective, comparative study of maxillary implant overdentures retained by bars or Locators. The study aims to compare treatment outcomes of fully edentulous patients with maxillary IODs, supported by four implants, retained by either bars or Locators. The primary outcome measure is the change in marginal peri-implant bone level 10 years after placing the overdenture. Secondary outcome measures will be implant and overdenture survival, peri-implant mucosa health and patients' satisfaction using a questionnaire. The study is an observational study. Patients were treated 10 years ago with dental implants and an overdenture in the maxilla because of problems with retention and stability with their conventional denture. The study aims to investigate the efficacy of a designed exercise program on pain and quality of sleeping in patients with sickle cell disease anemia. The study will be conducted as a randomized controlled trial (RCT) with 50 adult sickle cell disease patients aged more than 18 years. Participants will be randomly assigned to either the experimental group or the control group. The experimental group will receive a designed exercise program of physical therapy for relief pain and improve sleeping quality, while the control group will not receive any exercise program. The primary outcome measure will be the Pittsburgh Sleep Quality Index (PSQI), which will be used to assess the quality of sleeping over the past month. Secondary outcome measures will include the Visual Analog Scale (VAS) for pain severity, the WHOQOL-BREF for quality of life, the Fatigue Scale, and the Perceived Stress Scale. The study will be conducted over a period of 6 weeks, with participants receiving the exercise program for 30 to 45 minutes, three days per week, in addition to walking 30 minutes on the ground surface daily. The study will be conducted at Imam Abdulrahman Bin Faisal University in Saudi Arabia.

This study aims to assess anxiety and depression levels of patients with physiological and pathological DeMeester scores and to examine the modulation of anxiety on the severity of reflux symptoms such as fullness, heartburn, and dysphagia. The study is a prospective observational cohort study with one measurement time on admission. The study population includes patients referred to the Reflux and swallowing problems center of the Clinic for General and Visceral Surgery of the University Hospital Cologne, Germany, between January 2020 and July 2021. The study uses the HADS questionnaire to assess anxiety and depression levels. The study findings suggest that anxiety and depression are common comorbidities in patients with GERD and that anxiety intensifies symptom perception. The study also suggests that there is an interaction between GERD and psychosocial disorders, which has been discussed as the psychoemotional effects of GERD.

The study aims to evaluate the effectiveness of self-guided personalized treatment for women with disordered eating using mobile technology. The study is a single group assignment with no masking. Participants will complete two weeks of smartphone self-monitoring to identify target problems and will be sent two self-guided modules of personalized treatment directly to their smartphones. The primary outcome measures include changes in disordered eating symptoms, anxiety, depression, clinical impairment, and quality of life. The study will be conducted in French and will be open to women aged 18-65 who endorse significant disordered eating and have the ability to read and write English and own a smartphone or tablet. The study will exclude participants with active mania, active suicidality, or active psychosis.

===============

The study aims to evaluate the effectiveness of the CAD-EYE system in screening for neoplastic lesions in Lynch syndrome. The study is a randomized, parallel assignment, single-masked study. The study population includes patients with Lynch syndrome who are eligible for colorectal cancer screening. The intervention is colorectal cancer screening with CAD EYE colonoscopy in the experimental group and colorectal cancer screening with indigo carmine chromoendoscopy (CE) in the control group. The primary outcome measure is the adenoma detection rate (ADR) between the two groups. Secondary outcome measures include detection rates of specific lesions, diagnostic performance of CAD EYE, rate of resect and discard strategy, and time of colonoscopies. The study will be conducted through study completion, an average of 2 years.

===============

The study aimed to assess the use of a water soluble contrast-based protocol to assist in the management of pediatric adhesive small bowel obstruction. The study was a prospective observational study conducted at nine children's hospitals that are members of the Western Pediatric Surgery Research Consortium. The study was powered to detect a 15% difference in operative rate between the contrast and no contrast groups based on the adult literature. The study was designed to compare the outcomes of patients who received an enteral contrast challenge with those who did not. The primary outcome measure was the number of patients who required an operation. The secondary outcome measures were total hospital length of stay in days and adverse events resulting from contrast administration. The study was conducted over a period of two years, from 2020-2022. The study was conducted in accordance with the Declaration of Helsinki and IRB approval was obtained from each site with waiver of consent for enrollment. The study was conducted in accordance with the Declaration of Helsinki and IRB approval was obtained from each site with waiver of consent for enrollment.

This is a Phase 1, single-center, open-label, randomized, parallel group, single-dose study to compare the pharmacokinetics of subcutaneous itepekimab administered with an autoinjector versus prefilled syringe in healthy participants with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease.

The study will enroll 24 healthy participants aged 18-65 years, who will be randomly assigned to receive either itepekimab administered via an autoinjector or itepekimab administered via a prefilled syringe. The primary outcome measures will be the assessment of pharmacokinetic parameters of itepekimab, including Cmax, AUC, tmax, AUC0-28days, t1/2, CL/F, and Vss/F. Secondary outcome measures will include the incidence of treatment-emergent anti-itepekimab antibodies responses, number of participants with Adverse Events (including injection site reactions), SAE, and AESI.

The study will be conducted over a period of approximately 141 days, with participants being followed up for a minimum of 28 days after the single dose of itepekimab. The study will be conducted in accordance with the Declaration of Helsinki and Good Clinical Practice guidelines.

The AUS is a multi-site, open-label, randomized, three-arm, 8-week, prospective observational study to be conducted at multiple sites geographically dispersed within the U.S.. Adult tobacco consumers 21 to 60 years of age (inclusive) who smoke on at least 20 of the past 30 days and smoke at least 5 CPD on the days they smoke will be provided the Study IP for ad libitum use over a 6-week Actual Use Period (AUP) in their real-life/naturalistic environments. Subject-reported consumption of the Study IP, Combustible cigarettes, and other TNPs will be assessed (including, but not limited to, ENDS, smokeless tobacco, and other combustible tobacco products). The study includes pre-screening, a screening and enrollment visit (SEV), a baseline assessment period (BAP), an observational actual use period (AUP), and a close out period (COP). Following the recruitment period, the study duration per enrolled subject will be approximately eight (8) weeks. Following the administration of a Baseline Assessment Questionnaire (BAQ) at the SEV, use of Combustible Cigarettes and other TNP will be self-reported using an eDiary during the 1-week BAP. At SEV, subjects will be asked to indicate their likelihood to use each Study IP flavor variant across the three study arms. Subjects who indicate an interest in using at least one of the two flavors per arm for all three arms will be enrolled into the study and randomized into one of the three arms prior to completion of BAQ. This is a phase 2, multicenter, randomized, open-label, non-inferiority study to investigate the efficacy of subcutaneous infliximab with and without concomitant immunosuppression in induction treatment of moderate to severe Crohn's disease. The study will enroll 158 patients with moderate to severely active Crohn's disease with a Crohn's Disease Activity Index (CDAI) of 250 to 450 and presence of endoscopic ulceration in the terminal ileum, colon or both. Patients will be randomized to either subcutaneous infliximab monotherapy or subcutaneous infliximab in combination with immunosuppressive agents. The primary objective is to investigate the efficacy of subcutaneous infliximab with and without concomitant immunosuppression in induction treatment of moderate to severe Crohn's disease as measured by the proportion of patients in corticosteroid-free clinical remission (as defined by a CDAI<150) and endoscopic response (as defined by a SES-CD drop of at least 50%) at week 26. Secondary objectives include the proportion of patients in endoscopic remission at week 26, the proportion of patients achieving clinical response at week 26, the proportion of patients in symptomatic remission at week 26, the proportion of patients achieving minimally clinically important difference in quality of life at week 26 compared to baseline as assessed by the inflammatory bowel disease questionnaire (IBDQ) and EuroQol - 5 dimension - 5 level (EQ-5D-5L) questionnaire, the proportion of patients developing anti-drug antibodies (ADA) against IFX at week 2, 4, 8, 14 and 26 as measured by a drug-tolerant assay IFX trough levels at week 2, 4, 8, 14 and 26, the proportion of patients achieving histological healing at week 26, the proportion of patients (of those with active perianal disease at baseline) in clinical remission and response of their perianal disease, as defined by the fistula drainage assessment

The study aims to describe the pharmacokinetics (PK) profile of rivaroxaban and apixaban in adult cancer patients with venous thromboembolism or atrial fibrillation from a real-world setting to identify factors (age, weight, renal function, co-morbidities, etc) influencing the PK profile of rivaroxaban and apixaban in adult cancer with venous thromboembolism or atrial fibrillation from a real-world setting. The study is a population pharmacokinetic evaluation and will measure the estimated area under the curve (AUC) of each of the 2 drugs studied over a 3-year time frame. The study will also evaluate safety by monitoring any thromboembolic event or major bleeding. The study will include adult cancer patients with venous thromboembolism or atrial fibrillation who are affiliated with a health insurance system and able to provide written informed consent. The study will exclude patients who are not affiliated with a health insurance system, pregnant or breastfeeding, have a measure of protection, or have a life expectancy of less than 3 months. The study will be conducted in a real-world setting and will use a PK approach to describe the PK profile of rivaroxaban and apixaban in adult cancer patients with venous thromboembolism or atrial fibrillation.

===============

This study aims to determine if bronchodilator response in bronchiectatic disease might be influenced by other factors apart from the direct effect of bronchodilators. The study will be conducted in two arms, with each group of patients and controls randomly assigned to two study arms. After the first series of spirometry testing, patients in the first arm will receive bronchodilators as per bronchodilator response protocol (Salbutamol, 100 mcg, 4 puffs via spacer) and patients in the second arm will receive four puffs of placebo. After a waiting time of 15 minutes, spirometry will be repeated. Following the second spirometry testing those who received salbutamol will now receive placebo and those receiving placebo will receive Salbutamol. After a second period of 15 minutes, a third series of spirometry will be recorded. The primary outcome measure will be bronchodilator response compared to placebo (change in forced expiratory volume 1 second (FEV1) from pre to post salbutamol inhalation, compared to the same change after placebo). The study will also assess if BDR is associated with age, gender, specific bronchiectatic disease, baseline FEV1, and other clinical factors such as sputum cultures, IgE levels, eosinophil levels, computed tomography (CT) score, family history of asthma and use of inhaled steroids.

This study aims to determine the impact of gender identity, genetic sex and hormone status on pain sensitivity. The study will use quantitative sensory testing and blood draws to assess pain sensitivity and hormone levels. The study will also assess social and psychological factors that contribute to pain sensitivity. The study will recruit self-identified cisgender and transgender individuals between the ages of 18 and 65 who have been on/off hormone treatment for at least 6 months. The study will exclude individuals with pain in at least 3/7 days/week for the past 3 months, HIV positive diagnosis, cardiovascular or pulmonary disease, regular use of opioid pain medications, uncontrolled hypertension, current illness accompanied by fever, prostatectomy, hysterectomy or oophorectomy, hospitalization due to psychiatric illness within the last 6 months, and active use of oral contraceptives. The study will consist of a single visit which will include blood draws, questionnaires, body measurements, and pain testing. The primary outcome measures will include experimental heat pain thresholds, experimental pressure pain thresholds, experimental pain sensitivity, temporal summation, conditioned pain modulation, sleep quality, depression, social support, discrimination, hormone levels, immune cell number, and immune cell cytokine production. The secondary outcome measures will include community connectedness, bodily pain, quality of life metrics, body image, gender role expectation of pain, adverse childhood events, and perceived connectedness to the LGBTQ+ community.

The Scottish Stroke Improvement Programme identifies stroke as the most common cause of severe physical disability amongst Scottish adults. Hospital care for these patients accounts for 7% of all NHS beds and 5% of the entire NHS budget. The number of strokes across the UK is projected to increase by 60% between 2015 and 2035. Rehabilitation delivered by a multi-disciplinary team including Allied Health Professionals (occupational therapists [OT's], physiotherapists [PT's], and speech and language therapists [SLT's]) is known to improve functional recovery after stroke, particularly if it can be applied intensively and within enriched, stimulating environments. However, a large gap exists between the minimum recommendations for stroke rehabilitation (three hours of multidisciplinary therapy a day, at least 5 days out of 7) and what the NHS are currently able to provide, given the majority of in-patient stroke units are operating below the staffing levels recommended in national clinical guidelines, and are therefore challenged to provide the amount of therapy to facilitate optimum recovery for stroke patients. An analysis of data from the UK Sentinel Stroke National Audit Programme found, on average, patients who required specific therapy following stroke received around 14 minutes of PT, 13 minutes of OT, and 7 minutes of SLT per day of inpatient stay. Therefore, new and innovative models of rehabilitation delivery are needed in order to bridge the gap between current staffing resources and recommended levels of rehabilitation intensity. Commercially available technology, such as robotics, adapted treadmills, virtual reality, and mobile digital devices such as smartphones, tablets and wearable sensors, have been shown to be a safe and feasible method of increasing rehabilitation intensity, under the prescription and supervision of therapy staff. Despite the potential offered by rehabilitation technology to help deliver evidence-based levels of practice intensity and automated feedback without additional labour costs, currently few technologies have been adopted into everyday rehabilitation. A well-established research group at the University of Strathclyde (UoS) Biomedical Engineering department have been developing and testing a technology-based, holistic model as a possible solution to the gap between clinical need and current provision. This is a randomized, cross-over clinical study evaluating the effect of immersive virtual reality (IVR) on respiratory discomfort (scale A1 of the Multidimensional Dyspnea Profile (MDP) questionnaire) of patients with amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) at the stage of respiratory failure treated with non-invasive ventilation (NIV). The study will be conducted in an ambulatory setting (day care hospital) in the Pneumology Department of Pitié Salpêtrière Hospital. Eligible patients will be randomly assigned to either start with IVR or music therapy, and each session will last 15 minutes. The primary outcome measure will be the effect of IVR on respiratory discomfort (scale A1 of the MDP questionnaire), while secondary outcome measures will include the effect of IVR on the sensory and emotional components of dyspnea, the effect of music therapy on the sensory, affective, and emotional components of dyspnea, the evolutionary profile of the sensory and affective components of dyspnea under the effect of IVR and music therapy, the effect of IVR and music therapy on the respiratory discomfort in terms of preference, and the acceptability of IVR.

===============

The study aims to evaluate the impact of selective reporting of antibiotic susceptibility testing on the prescribing of broad-spectrum antibiotics by general practitioners (GPs) in women with E. coli urinary tract infections (UTIs). The study will be conducted in two arms: an intervention arm and a control arm. In the intervention arm, GPs will receive an antibiotic susceptibility testing report with a restricted list of antibiotics, while in the control arm, GPs will receive a standard antibiotic susceptibility testing report. The primary outcome measure will be the rate of broad-spectrum antibiotic dispensing, defined as the number of urine cultures associated with a prescription of broad-spectrum antibiotics (Amoxicillin/clavulanic acid, fluoroquinolone, third-generation cephalosporin) prescribed by GPs in the same practice over a period from 3 days before to 5 days after report of the antibiotic susceptibility testing, relative to the total number of urine cultures. The study will be conducted in two arms: an intervention arm and a control arm. In the intervention arm, GPs will receive an antibiotic susceptibility testing report with a restricted list of antibiotics, while in the control arm, GPs will receive a standard antibiotic susceptibility testing report. This is a pilot randomized controlled trial to investigate whether sodium valproate can improve clinical outcomes in patients with acute ischemic stroke. Patients with acute ischemic stroke will be randomly assigned to low-dose sodium valproate group, high-dose sodium valproate group and placebo group. Besides receiving conventional treatment for stroke, 10mg/kg sodium valproate, 20mg/kg sodium valproate or normal saline were given intravenously for 3 consecutive days, respectively. The primary outcome measure is the proportion of patients with favorable outcome, which is defined as the Modified Rankin Scale (mRS) score 0-2 at day 90. Secondary outcome measures include the detailed distribution of Modified Rankin Scale (mRS) score at day 90, the proportion of patients with favorable outcome, which is defined as the Modified Rankin Scale (mRS) score 0-2 at day 30, the detailed distribution of Modified Rankin Scale (mRS) score at day 30, the NIH Stroke Scale (NIHSS) score at day 3 and day 7, changes of lesion volume from baseline to day 7, and length of hospital stay.

The study aims to compare the effectiveness of a MyChart enabled virtual coach in aiding preoperative weight loss in ventral hernia patients with obesity to standard preoperative weight loss tools. The study will be a non-randomized, parallel assignment study with a total of 100 participants. Participants will be between 18 and 90 years of age with a BMI of 30 and above and diagnosed with obesity by the ICD 10 Code: E66.9 who have been evaluated by a surgeon and offered elective ventral hernia repair. The study will measure the average net amount of weight loss per group and the number of interactions with the virtual coach per subject. Additionally, the study will measure quality of life and satisfaction with the virtual coach via self-reported outcome measures.

This is a clinical study on the safety and efficacy of umbilical cord mesenchymal stem cell-derived exosomes (nebulized) combined with conventional therapy for the treatment of moderate, severe, and critically ill COVID-19 patients. The study adopts a multicenter, randomized controlled, single-blind trial design. Based on the COVID-19 treatment regimen formulated by clinical guidelines, nebulized umbilical cord mesenchymal stem cell-derived exosomes (experimental group) or medically sterile saline solution (control group) will be administered to treat moderate, severe, and critically ill COVID-19 patients. By comparing the relief of symptoms and the occurrence of adverse events before and after treatment, the safety and effectiveness of umbilicular mesenchymal stem cell-derived exosomes for the treatment of moderate, severe, and critically ill COVID-19 patients will be evaluated.

===============

The study is a randomized, parallel assignment, single-masked study comparing the clinical effectiveness of Calcium silicate-based sealer and Epoxy resin-based sealer in single-visit root canal treatment for patients with irreversible pulpitis. The study measures changes in pain intensity, pain relief, and treatment outcome evaluation over time. The primary outcome measures are change in pain intensity over time, change in pain relief over time, and change in treatment outcome evaluation over time. The study is conducted in accordance with the Declaration of Helsinki and has been approved by the Institutional Review Board of the Centre Hospitalier Valida.

* Study Title: Two Domestic HPV Vaccines (Wozehui ® and Cecolin ®) and Imported HPV Vaccines in Women Aged 13-14 Years Study on Immunogenicity: A Multi-center Cohort Study in China
* Study Type: Multi-center, open, prospective cohort study
* Study Duration: 36 months
* Study Population: Adolescent females aged 13-14 years
* Study Objectives: 1) Evaluate the immunogenicity of two different domestically produced bivalent HPV vaccines (Wozehui ® and Cecolin ®) versus imported HPV vaccines in adolescent females aged 13-14 years old; 2) Evaluate the immune persistence of two different domestically produced bivalent HPV vaccines (Wozehui ® and Cecolin ®) versus imported HPV vaccines in adolescent females aged 13-14 years old.
* Study Intervention: Follow up
* Study Outcomes: The neutralization antibody GMT and antibody positivity testing at baseline, 12-month follow-up, and 36-month follow-up
* Study Sponsor: The National Natural Science Foundation of China
* Study Funding: The National Natural Science Foundation of China

The study will evaluate three main ingredients: obtaining main concerns of patients that agree to utilize this method, patient acceptance of this supportive approach that will be reflected in obtaining and self-administering the remedies as prescribed, and obtaining retrospective subjective information from the patients through validated quality of life questionnaires. The study will be conducted as an observational study and will evaluate 124 cancer patients who attend the Division of Oncology in Rambam Health Campus. The study is a non-randomized, diagnostic study that aims to evaluate the duration of ultrasound signs of septic thrombophlebitis on central venous catheter and midline. The study includes adult patients hospitalized at the CHM or CHUA with a central venous device or a midline and catheter-related bacteremia. The intervention is a diagnostic test of Doppler ultrasound, and the primary outcome measure is the duration of ultrasound signs of septic thrombophlebitis on central venous catheter and midline. The study is open label and has a duration of 90 days.

============

A phase 3, open label, randomized study is being conducted to compare the efficacy and safety of odronextamab in combination with lenalidomide versus rituximab in combination with lenalidomide therapy in participants with relapsed/refractory follicular lymphoma and marginal zone lymphoma. The study will measure the incidence of dose limiting toxicities, treatment emergent adverse events, progression-free survival, and overall survival in participants with relapsed/refractory follicular lymphoma and marginal zone lymphoma. The study will also measure the incidence of anti-odronextamab antibodies, neutralizing antibodies, best overall response, duration of response, and complete response in participants with relapsed/refractory follicular lymphoma and marginal zone lymphoma. The study will also measure the incidence of treatment emergent adverse events, severity of treatment emergent adverse events, and overall change from baseline in patient reported outcomes in participants with relapsed/refractory follicular lymphoma and marginal zone lymphoma. The study will be conducted in two parts. In part 1, participants with relapsed/refractory indolent lymphoma will receive odronextamab in combination with lenalidomide. In part 2, participants with relapsed/refractory follicular lymphoma and participants with indolent lymphoma will be randomly assigned to receive odronextamab in combination with lenalidomide or rituximab in combination with lenalidomide followed by lenalidomide monotherapy. The study will be conducted in accordance with the Declaration of Helsinki and Good Clinical Practice guidelines.

===============

The study aims to evaluate the efficacy of Proliverenol supplementation on liver function in patients with Non-Alcoholic Fatty Liver Disease (NAFLD). The study will have 4 groups of treatment, each group will consist of 20 subjects with the treatment regimens for 12 weeks. The eligible subjects will be randomly allocated to receive study medication (Treatment 1 or Treatment 2) for 12 weeks of treatment, in a double blind fashion. They will be asked to come to the clinic every 4-week interval throughout the study period. Subjects will be evaluated for treatment efficacy at baseline and at interval of 4 weeks over the 12-week course of therapy. Throughout the 12-week therapy, subjects should record the product consumption and adverse event occurred during the study in the provided Patient's Diary. The safety profile of study medication other than vital signs and adverse event will be measured at baseline and end of study.

=================

The study "Impact of Ozone Application in Periodontitis Patients" is a randomized, double-masked, parallel assignment study. The study aims to measure the impact of ozone application on periodontitis patients. The study includes 2 arms: experimental and active comparator. The experimental arm receives ozone therapy using a device, while the active comparator arm receives only non-surgical periodontal treatment. The primary outcome measure is probing pocket depth, which will be measured at baseline and 3rd month after treatment. Secondary outcome measures include plaque index, gingival index, bleeding on probing, proportions of bacterial species, and inflammatory parameter levels in gingival crevicular fluid. The study is designed to measure the effectiveness of ozone therapy in treating periodontitis.

This study aims to compare the expression of CD44, PCNA and E-cadherin in surgically removed pterygium tissue with tissue samples from normal control group. The study will enroll 60 patients with pterygium and collect conjunctival samples from 30 patients to form the control group. The expression of CD44, PCNA and E-cadherin will be analyzed using primary antibodies against CD44 (1:50 dilution), E-cadherin (1:200 dilution), and a human monoclonal antibody against PCNA (1:100 dilution) for antigen retrieval. The study will use IBM SPSS (statistical software) version 26.0 for statistical analyses. The primary outcome measure is immunohistochemistry, which will be performed on thin sections taken from paraffin embedded tissue samples. The study will measure the expression of CD44, PCNA and E-cadherin up to three weeks after pterygium surgery. The study will compare the expression of CD44, PCNA and E-cadherin in primary, recurrent and control pterygium tissue.

The TINO study is a cross-sectional study that aims to identify the underlying mechanisms and consequences of the loss of nasal T cells in vital and frail older individuals. The study includes three arms: young adults, vital elderly, and frail elderly. The young adults arm does not receive any intervention, while the vital and frail elderly arms receive no intervention and are sampled at timepoint 0 and for 50% of the group another sample at 3 months. If respiratory symptoms develop in the 3 months after timepoint 0, participants are invited to provide a NPS/OPS to identify causative agent, and if one is established, individuals are sampled 3 more times at months 1, 3 and 5 post symptom onset. The primary outcome measure is the frequency of nasal CD8+ T cells in young adults and frail older adults. Secondary outcome measures include the phenotype, functionality, transcriptomic cluster composition, clonality, stability, and comparison of nasal and peripheral immune populations between young adults, vital and frail elderly. The study also measures the concentration of nasal and systemic cytokines, metabolites, and the respiratory tract microbiota profiles and their association with T cells and other immune parameters. The study also aims to investigate the effect of sex on aging effects of nasal immune populations and blood immune populations. The study is designed to measure the frequencies of antigen-specific T cells in the nose and blood post infection in young adults, vital and frail elderly.

The study aims to investigate the predictive value of platelets to lymphocytes ratio and monocytes to lymphocytes ratio in cirrhotic patients with spontaneous bacterial peritonitis. The study will use ascetic fluid study as diagnostic test for SBP. The study will be conducted in cirrhotic patients with ascites and normal individuals. The primary outcome measure will be the predictive value of platelets to lymphocytes ratio and monocytes to lymphocytes ratio in cirrhotic patients with spontaneous bacterial peritonitis. The study will be conducted from 19/4/2023 to 30/4/2024.

The study aims to evaluate whether point of care ultrasound (POCUS) performed by a variety of emergency medicine physicians (specialists and residents) increases diagnostic accuracy in patients with dyspnea compared to routine assessment. The study will be conducted as a prospective observational study. The study population will include adult patients presenting to the Emergency Department within the highest or second highest triage category and any of the following: presenting with shortness of breath, oxygen saturation less than 90 % on room air, respiratory rate more than 25 breaths per minute and oxygen saturation less than 95 % on room air. The study will include a short training and certification in a structured dyspnea POCUS protocol. The protocol includes focused lung (8 or 14 zones), heart (subcostal, parasternal and apical four chamber views) and inferior vena cava ultrasound. The primary outcome measure will be the discharge diagnosis. The study will measure the sensitivity, specificity, negative and positive predictive values of the diagnostic accuracy before and after adding POCUS. The study will be conducted in Lund and Helsingborg (Sweden).

=========

The B-REST-Study is a clinical trial that aims to test the hypothesis that implementing both, DIBH Respiratory Training and advanced communication and Relaxation Training (R&R), improve patients' DIBH performance skills and further reduce heart dose, while alleviating anxiety and stress and improving quality of life during and after radiation therapy. The study will randomize patients with radiotherapy in DIBH for left breast cancer to either R&R or standard-of-care management. The primary endpoint will assess heart dose (Dmax), and secondary endpoints include longitudinal anxiety and quality of life assessment and clinic workflow efficiency. The ultimate goal of this proposal is to develop a validated patient-centered training and integrative health regimen to further improve the success of advanced-technology-based cardiac dose reduction, and improve cardiac health in breast cancer survivors.

=========

A Phase IB study is being conducted to determine the safety and tolerability of canakinumab and tislelizumab in combination with nab-paclitaxel and gemcitabine in the neo-adjuvant treatment of patients with pancreatic cancer. The study will enroll patients with pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma (PDAC) who have not received previous anti-cancer therapy for the treatment of pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma. Eligible patients must be aged 18 years or older, have a histologically or cytologically confirmed pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma, and have tumors that are confined to the pancreas and deemed resectable or borderline resectable per NCCN guidelines. The study will use a quadruplet regimen of canakinumab and tislelizumab in combination with nab-paclitaxel and gemcitabine for up to 4 cycles (4 months). The primary outcome measure of the study is the number of dose-limiting toxicities (DLTs) that occur within the first 8 weeks of study treatment. Secondary outcome measures include the number of patients who proceed to surgical resection, overall response rate (ORR), R0 resection rate, progression-free survival (PFS), overall survival (OS), number of delays in outcome of surgery that is attributed to study drug, and number of changes in outcome of surgery that is attributed to study drug. The study will be conducted as a single group assignment with an open label design.

The study is a double-blinded, randomized, comparative-placebo trial to compare the effectiveness of intra-myometrial oxytocin injection and intra-myometrial tranexamic acid injection in reducing the risk of postpartum bleeding after cesarean delivery in primigravida at term. The study will be conducted in the kasr Al-Ainy hospital, Maternity hospital, Cairo University, Cairo, Egypt, during October 2021 to October 2022. After The Ethical Research Committee approval on study protocol, fifty primigravida women at term pregnancy, undergoing elective cesarean delivery will be divided and allocated randomly into two groups after fulfillment eligibility criteria. Fifty women will be included in this clinical study at admission to the labor ward. Written informed permission will be acquired following advising about this study and potential implications. A history in details and clinical examination for all patients to rule out general health problems. Vaginal and Abdominal examinations will be done. Routine preoperative investigations and obstetric ultrasound examinations will be done for all women to ensure that all inclusion criteria were present. The computer will be used for randomization to allocate the patients into two equal groups. Randomization cards will be produced, sealed and stored; sequentially black wrappers will be numbered. The hospital pharmacy is producing packages, and physicians and nurses were unaware of their contents. For the entire length of the trial, all study personnel and participants are blinded to therapy. A senior registrar will execute a cesarean section before the commencement of research, which performs at least 300 cesarean sections. All cesarean section will be operated via spinal anesthesia; the abdomen will be entered through the Pfannenstiel incision. The sealed envelope is carried to the operating room and transferred without informing the researcher or the patients about their contents. The anesthesiologist is administering the medication (Oxytocin or tranexamic acid). After fetal birth and before placental delivery, patients assigned to the oxytocin group (n = 25): 5 I.U of oxytocin (syntocinone 5 I.U/1ML NONARTIS-EGYPT) shall be water

The Innovation for Small-scale Experiments: ReceptIVFity Test is a study that aims to support small-scale experiments in the field of IVF and ICSI. The study is designed to test the effectiveness of a vaginal microbiome swab test in predicting the success of IVF or ICSI treatment. The study is randomized and will be conducted over a period of three years. The primary outcome measure is the rate of successful pregnancy, while the secondary outcome measures include the number of successful IVF or ICSI cycles per patient, scores of the SDM-Q-9 questionnaire for patient satisfaction, and the total costs of all received treatments within the study period. The study will be conducted in two arms: a shared-decision-making group and a physician decision group. The shared-decision-making group will use the ReceptIVFity microbiome profile to make decisions about treatment, while the physician decision group will postpone treatment until a switch to a favorable ReceptIVFity microbiome profile. The study will be conducted in women of European origin, and the results will be compared to an observational study of women with non-European origin.

===============

This is a randomized controlled trial that aims to investigate the lipid-lowering effect of fenugreek seed tea in patients with hyperlipidemia, but without diabetes over an 8-week intervention period. Participants will be randomized into two groups (57/group) to receive either fenugreek seed tea or a control black tea, respectively. The primary outcome measure is between group differences in mean change in serum triglycerides. Secondary outcome measures include between group differences in mean change in total-cholesterol, LDL-cholesterol, non-HDL-cholesterol, HDL-cholesterol, plasma apolipoprotein B, and microRNAs.

This is a prospective, randomized, open clinical study. The study will be conducted at the Hospital de Clínicas/UNICAMP. The study will include 20 research participants, male, aged over 40 years, non-diabetic or diabetic with disease duration of less than 10 years, glycated hemoglobin <8%, and non-user of NPH insulin, body mass index (BMI) between 20 and 34.9kg/m2 and glomerular filtration rate above 45mL/min. The study will be conducted in two arms: active comparator (pioglitazone hydrochloride 45mg/day for 5 days prior to coronary artery bypass surgery) and no intervention (placebo). The primary outcome measure will be the change in S1P content of isolated HDL between baseline and after treatment with pioglitazone hydrochloride 45 mg/day. Secondary outcome measures will include the difference in SPHK1 expression in the internal thoracic artery, saphenous vein, aortic artery, and atrial appendage cells determined by western blot between groups. The study will be conducted for five days.

This is a single-dose, randomized, open label, five-treatment, five-period, five-sequence crossover study in 20 obese, healthy volunteers to assess the pharmacodynamics and pharmacokinetics of three new developed coated glucose beads formulations containing caffeine anhydrous and glucose (8 g) and one uncoated glucose beads formulation containing caffeine anhydrous and glucose (8 g). The study is conducted in a single study site. The study is designed to assess the pharmacodynamics and pharmacokinetics of the test products in obese, healthy volunteers under fasting conditions. The study is conducted in accordance with the Declaration of Helsinki and Good Clinical Practice guidelines. The study is registered in the ISRCTN registry with the registration number ISRCTN121111111.

The study evaluates the effect of using celluloid matrix tapes and strips of food material as a simple and cheap method for proper positioning of the tongue on reducing the palatoglossal airway shadow error in panoramic imaging. The study was conducted at the Oral and Maxillofacial Radiology Department, Faculty of Dentistry, Tabriz University of Medical Sciences, Iran, between 2021-09-29 and 2022-02-20. The study protocol was approved by the ethics committee of the university (Institutional Review Board: IR.TBZMED.REC.1399.730). A total of 270 panoramic radiographs were acquired using a dental X-ray System (DR imaging system, RAYSCAN α-P, South Korea) according to the instructions of the manufacturer at 50/60 Hertz, 60-90 kW, 4-17 mA, and acquisition time of 14 s in the Scanner 2.0.1 software. The images were displayed and examined on an LCD (Liquid-Crystal Display) monitor (Dell E2014HF) with dimensions of 14.1 × 6.5 × 18.7 inches and a pixel pitch of 0.27 millimeters. In this experimental study, all panoramic images were taken by a technician according to the patient positioning standards. The exposure settings were selected based on the patient's size and weight. The main inclusion criterion was age above 15 years. Patients with a history of trauma, lesion, swelling, disseminated infection, physical and mental disabilities, severe gag reflex, cleft palate, difficulty in speech and tongue movement, allergy to the materials used in this study, and those reluctant to cooperate were excluded from the study. The patients were randomised into three groups. Ninety patients received celluloid matrix strips of transparent polyester (Maquira Dental Products, Maringá, Brazil) with a 10 mm width and 30 mm length. In the second group, ninety patients were given edible strips. They were divided into two subgroups of 45 people. 45

===============

This study aims to compare the acute effect of ESWT, ESWT + KT, and placebo ESWT on pain level, lower extremity functionality, and plantar fascia flexibility in patients with plantar fasciitis. Eligible participants are adults aged 18-65 years diagnosed with plantar fasciitis by a physical medicine and rehabilitation specialist, willing to continue the study, and experiencing severe pain when taking the first step after waking up in the morning or after a long period of inactivity. The study will use the visual pain scale (VAS) and lower extremity functional scale to measure the primary and secondary outcomes, respectively. The ESWT group will receive a single session of ESWT with a 15 mm head at 10 Hz frequency, 2.5 Barr energy, and 2000 shocks/session. The ESWT + KT group will receive a single session of ESWT with a 15 mm head at 10 Hz frequency, 2.5 Barr energy, and 2000 shocks/session, followed by the application of a Kinesio tape consisting of 96% cotton and 4% lycra, water-resistant, porous, and adhesive, 5 cm wide and 0.5 mm thick. The placebo ESWT group will receive the ESWT device sound recorded from the external audio device and the application will be performed without the ESWT device operating. The study will be conducted for one week, and the data will be analyzed using descriptive statistics.

=================

The study aims to establish a Couple Intervention Program for Adults with Autism Spectrum Disorder. The program is designed for couples where one person has an ASD diagnosis or an autism spectrum quotient score of 26 or above. The intervention is a behavioral couple group therapy that focuses on improving communication, emotion acknowledgement, self-assurance, positive feedback, teamwork, and cooperation. The primary outcome measures include the Autism Diagnostic Observation Schedule, Autism Spectrum Quotient, Empathy Quotient, Social Responsiveness Scale, and Quality of Socialization Questionnaire. The study is designed as a single group assignment with an open label masking. The study will run for 6 weeks.

This is a randomized controlled study of the effects of individual tailored physical exercise in patients with post COVID-19 condition, diagnosed with postural orthostatic tachycardia syndrome (POTS). The study will recruit 60 adult patients (>18 years) with POTS, post COVID-19 condition. Participants will be randomized to either intervention (standard care plus individual tailored physical exercise) or control (standard care only). The intervention will consist of exercises to enhance muscle strength and endurance, progressing from a laying position to an upright position. The study will measure changes in time in upright position and steps per day, health-related quality of life (HRQoL), walking distance during 6 minute walk test, oxygen saturation during 6 minute walk test, dyspnea during 6 minute walk test, leg fatigue during 6 minute walk test, exertion during 6 minute walk test, heart rate during 6 minute walk test, self-reported POTS-symptoms, anxiety - Generalised Anxiety Disorder 7-item scale, depression - Patient Health Questionnaire-9, fatigue, self-reported outcome measure of physical function, blood pressure during Active standing test, heart rate response during Active standing test, oxygen saturation during Active standing test, respiratory rate during Active Standing Test, dyspnea during Active standing test, leg fatigue during Active Standing Test, exertion during Active standing test, physical activity, orthostatic symptoms, insomnia, workability, muscle strength, post-exertional-Malaise (PEM), pharmacological treatment of POTS, compliance to intervention. The study will be conducted over a period of 16 weeks, with follow-up at 6 and 12 months.

===============

The BRANT study is a multicenter, randomized, open label, blinded endpoint, Parallel controlled trial with the primary null hypothesis that, in patients with acute BAD-related stroke, there is no difference in the proportion of excellent outcome in those treated with intravenous Tirofiban compared with those treated with standard antiplatelet therapy based on guideline when subjects are randomized within 48 hours of stroke onset. The primary objective is to determine whether intravenous tirofiban (a loading dose of 0.4ug/kg/min*30min followed by a maintenance dose of 0.1ug/kg/min*47.5h) is effective in increasing the proportion of excellent functional outcome (mR: 0-1) at 90 days, when initiated within 48 hours of onset. The active comparator is standard antiplatelet therapy based on Chinese stroke guideline. Patients with acute BAD-related stroke between 18 and 75 years old, who can be randomized within 48 hours of onset, and meet the BAD Diagnostic Imaging Criteria, will be enrolled. All patients will conduct MRI before randomization. Subjects will be randomized 1:1 (Tirofiban: Standard antiplatelet therapy). The subjects' eligibility will be assessed by site investigator prior to accessing the Randomization Module, which is generated via the dynamic block randomization method. Only certified and trained personnel can access the randomization website, who will get the information of treatment (ie, Tirofiban or standard antiplatelet therapy) after the subject has been determined eligible. The treatment period is 48 hours for both study groups. A total of 516 eligible patients will be enrolled. Each participant will be followed for 90 days from randomization. The primary outcome will be assessed by well-trained senior neurologists blinded to the treatment. All the clinical and safety events will be re-examined by the Clinical Event Committee (CEC), who are blinded during all procedures.

The study aims to investigate the effect of personalized pacing on the quality of life of patients with sinus node dysfunction. The study will compare the quality of life of patients with sinus node dysfunction who receive a pacemaker with a lower rate setting of 75 bpm with those who receive a pacemaker with a lower rate setting of 60 bpm. The study will use the SF-36 questionnaire score as the primary outcome measure to assess the quality of life of the patients. The study will also measure the cardiac functional changes and the correlation of elevated blood pressure and bradycardia in the patients. The study will be conducted in two arms, with the PLR group receiving a pacemaker with a lower rate setting of 75 bpm and the control group receiving a pacemaker with a lower rate setting of 60 bpm. The study will be conducted in patients with sinus node dysfunction who are at least 60 years old, have a plan to implant a dual-chamber pacemaker, have a resting sinus heart rate of equal to or less than 60 bpm or an average heart rate detected through a 24-hour dynamic electrocardiogram of equal to or less than 60 bpm, have a diagnosis of sinus node dysfunction, have a history of hypertension with two times of blood pressure measurements at an office visit of equal to or more than 130 mmHg in systolic blood pressure and diastolic pressure of equal to or less than 80 bpm, have a known secondary cause of hypertension, have hospitalization of a hypertensive emergency in the previous year, have a history of renal disease or renal-artery diseases, have severe hepatic or renal dysfunction, have an active acute infection, cannot submit a signed informed consent form, are pregnant or plan to be pregnant during the study period, or participate in another study that will confound this study. The study will be conducted in patients who are at least 60 years old and have a plan to implant a dual-chamber pacemaker. The study will be conducted in two arms, with the PLR group receiving a pacemaker with a lower rate setting of 75 bpm and the control group receiving a pacemaker with a lower rate setting of 60 bpm. The study will be conducted

The study aims to investigate the influence of the communication between nursing staff and patients on the analgesic response following caesarean section. The study will be conducted in the maternity ward at Carmel Hospital. The study population will include patients who are about to undergo an elective caesarean section under spinal anesthesia. The recruitment will be done pre-surgery. Following consent, participants will receive an explanation about how to assess pain and will fill out the research questionnaires. Communication is the independent variable in this study , which has 2 levels - the increased communication arm and the normal communication arm. Each arm will include 40 patients that will be randomly divided between the arms. The dependent variable is the treatment efficacy, based on the changes in the intensity of the patient's pain one hour after the administration of analgesic. The Self-Consciousness Scale (SCS-R) and the Short suggestibility scale (SSS) will be used to assess relevant personality traits.

The study aims to assess the effectiveness of novel biomarkers in improving the sensitivity and specificity of lung cancer screening beyond what is achieved with conventional risk prediction models and low-dose CT scanning. The study will be conducted over a period of 5 years and will involve participants undergoing targeted lung health checks. The study will include proteomics, metabolomics, genomics and immune repertoire characterization performed on peripheral bloods. The study will be conducted in accordance with the Declaration of Helsinki and will be approved by the relevant ethics committees.

===============

The Celeste randomized clinical trial evaluates the effectiveness of telepharmacy on clinical outcomes of patients with arterial hypertension. The study includes 100 elderly patients with a diagnosis of arterial hypertension who present uncontrolled blood pressure at the time of assessment. The patients are randomly assigned to either the telepharmacy group or the in-person group. The telepharmacy group receives pharmaceutical care via telepharmacy and usual care, while the in-person group receives pharmaceutical care in-person and usual care. The primary outcome measure is the rate of patients reaching the blood pressure target for healthy elderly people and frail elderly people. Secondary outcome measures include adherence to the treatment, patient satisfaction, and the level of clinical significance of interventions. The study is designed as a randomized, parallel assignment, single-masked study. The study will be conducted over a period of 3 months.

The ICU LIBERATION Study is an international multicenter study that aims to investigate the current epidemiology and treatment strategy given to patients with ARDS after the two-year pandemic of the novel coronavirus, clarify the actual implementation of ICU care for ARDS patients who require ventilators at high frequency, and evaluate how the implementation of evidence-based ICU care is associated with patient outcomes. The study will be conducted in 100 ICUs in 10 countries, including Asia, Europe, North and South America, Oceania, and Africa. The study will be conducted in two phases. In Phase 1, the study will investigate the current epidemiology and treatment strategy given to patients with ARDS after the two-year pandemic of the novel coronavirus, clarify the actual implementation of ICU care for ARDS patients who require ventilators at high frequency, and evaluate how the implementation of evidence-based ICU care is associated with patient outcomes. In Phase 2, the study will investigate the implementation rate of an entire and each component of the ABCDEF bundle, and the incidence of Post Intensive Care Syndrome. The study will be conducted in two phases, and the study will be conducted in two phases, and the study will be conducted in two phases, and the study will be conducted in two phases, and the study will be conducted in two phases, and the study will be conducted in two phases, and the study will be conducted in two phases, and the study will be conducted in two phases, and the study will be conducted in two phases, and the study will be conducted in two phases, and the study will be conducted in two phases, and the study will be conducted in two phases, and the study will be conducted in two phases, and the study will be conducted in two phases, and the study will be conducted in two phases, and the study will be conducted in two phases, and the study will be conducted in two phases, and the study will be conducted in two phases, and the study will be conducted in two phases, and the study will be conducted in two phases, and the study will be conducted in two phases, and the study will be conducted in two phases, and the study will be conducted in two phases, and the study will be conducted in two phases, and the study will be conducted in two phases, and the study will be conducted in two phases, and the study will be conducted in two phases,
