The Effect of Pomanox® on Skin Ageing (POMASKIN) is a randomized, parallel, placebo-controlled, triple-blind clinical trial with a 1:1:1 ratio between interventions with 66 participants. The study aims to evaluate the effect of consuming two doses of Pomanox®P30 on hyperpigmented skin spots in humans through the modulation of the metabolism of collagen, hyaluronic acid and the inflammatory system, the inhibition of the production of reactive oxygen species and AGEs, and/or changes in the intestinal and skin microbiota composition. The main objective of the study is to evaluate the effect of consuming two doses of Pomanox®P30 on hyperpigmented skin spots in humans. The secondary objectives of the study are to evaluate the effects of consuming two doses of Pomanox®P30 on other parameters related to skin ageing (wrinkles, elasticity, erythema index, hydration, pores, acne and keratin), on different markers of collagen and hyaluronic acid metabolism, oxidative stress, the anti-glycan effect and the inflammatory system, and on the composition of the intestinal and skin microbiota. A randomized, parallel, placebo-controlled, triple-blind clinical trial with a 1:1:1 ratio between interventions with 66 participants will be conducted. Each participant will make 4 visits: A pre-selection visit (to check inclusion/exclusion criteria), and if the eligibility criteria are met, 3 study visits during the consumption of the treatments, which will take place on the first day of the study (V1), at 29 days of treatment (V2) and at 85 days of treatment (V3).

Prostate Medication, Metabolism and Gut Microbiota
====================================================

The study aims to investigate the role of gut microbiota in prostate cancer (PCa) and prostatic hyperplasia (BPH) treatment. The study will include two cohorts: BPH and PCa. The BPH cohort will receive 5-alpha-reductase inhibitors (finasteride, dutasteride, or combination of dutasteride and tamsulosin) and the PCa cohort will receive androgen deprivation therapy (ADT) with LHRH antagonist (degarelix). Gut microbiota and metabolic characteristics will be collected before and after treatment. The primary outcome measures will be gut microbiota signatures before and after treatment. Secondary outcome measures will include gut metabolic characteristics in the gut and systemic circulation after use of prostate medication. The study will provide insights into the role of gut microbiota in PCa and BPH treatment and the potential impact of medication on gut microbiota and metabolism.

=========

The study aims to investigate the use of magnetic resonance spectroscopy (MRS) as a diagnostic tool for glioma genomics. The study will recruit patients with glioma who are scheduled for surgery or have been diagnosed with glioma and have not received any other treatment. The study will use MRI as the diagnostic tool and will measure the concentrations of 2-hydroxyglutarate and cystahionine by MRS. The study will also measure diffusion MRI metrics and will compare the changes in metabolism, tumor volumes, and clinical response during an anti-tumor treatment. The study will use the 1p19q codeletion status derived from ex vivo analyses in tumor tissue samples as a reference for the MRS and diffusion MRI measurements. The study will be conducted as a single group assignment with no masking. The primary outcome measure will be the correlation between the concentrations of 2-hydroxyglutarate and cystahionine measured by MRS and the IDH mutational status and 1p19q codeletion derived from ex vivo analyses in tumor tissue samples. The secondary outcome measures will be the correlation between the diffusion MRI metrics and the 1p19q codeletion status derived from ex vivo analyses in tumor tissue samples and the changes in metabolism, tumor volumes, and clinical response during an anti-tumor treatment. The study will be conducted over a period of 1 year.

This study is a phase 3, open-label, single-arm, long-term study to evaluate the efficacy and safety of the combination therapy of hydroxyurea and thalidomide in beta-thalassemia patients. The study is designed to assess the response of patients to the combination therapy at different time intervals, as well as the changes in laboratory levels, liver and spleen size, and XmnI polymorphism. The study is conducted in patients with clinical and genetic diagnoses of beta-thalassemia major and intermedia who showed partial response or a decline in response to hydroxyurea and are not candidates for bone marrow transplant. The study is conducted over a period of 1-3 years, and the primary outcome measure is the frequency of good responder, responder, and non-responder. The secondary outcome measure is the comparison of XmnI polymorphism with outcome among patients who completed 1-year, 2-years, and 3-years of combination therapy. The study is conducted in accordance with the Declaration of Helsinki and has been approved by the Ethics Committee of the University of Rome "La Sapienza".

The study aims to determine the role/position of diagnostic imaging in the patient journey for a patient with active or healed ulceration. The study will be conducted through a questionnaire based study for primary care practitioners and a Delphi consensus for vascular scientists. The primary outcome measures will be determined through the questionnaires. The study will be conducted over a period of 3 months for primary care practitioners and 6 months for vascular scientists.

The study aims to enhance prospective thinking in early recovery by using virtual reality. The study will be conducted in two groups: experimental and control. The experimental group will receive a virtual reality avatar experience, while the control group will receive treatment as usual. The primary outcome measures will be reduced use of drug using days, increased length of abstinence, increased abstinence, future self-identification, future time perspective, and delayed reward preference. The study will be conducted over a period of 6 months, with follow-up visits at 30 days and 6 months.

* Short implants are defined as implants of 6 mm in length.
* Standard length implants are defined as implants of 10 mm in length.
* The study aims to evaluate the stability of short implants versus standard length implants placed with internal sinus floor elevation in the posterior maxilla.
* The study is a randomized controlled clinical trial.
* The study will measure the crestal bone level at 1 year.

The study is a dose escalation study of Wharton Jelly Mesenchymal Stromal Cell (WG-MSC) infusions as GVHD prophylaxis in Hematopoietic Allogeneic Stem Cell Transplantation With an Haplo-identical Donor. The study aims to determine the maximum tolerated dose of WG-MSC infusions in 3 weekly infusions. The primary outcome measure is the occurrence of any adverse event (AE) reasonably related to the injection of CSM-GW grade 3 to 5 according to the NCI-CTCAE classification version 5.0, or part of the Important Medical Event list, or having a severity criterion within 7 days following one of the three injections. The secondary outcome measures include acute and chronic GVHD incidence, toxicity-related mortality (TRM), relapse incidence (RI), overall survival (OS), and GvHD and relapse free survival (GRFS). The study is open to patients with AML/ALL/SMD/SMP or lymphoid neoplasm requiring allogeneic stem cell transplantation in complete response (CR) for AML/ALL or CR, partial response (PR) or non pre-treated for SMD/SMP and lymphoid neoplasm without a HLA matched related donor available and with identification of a haploidentical donor (brother, sister, parents, adult children or cousin) with usual criteria for HSCT: ECOG ≤ 2, no severe and uncontrolled infection, cardiac function compatible with high dose of cyclophosphamide, adequate organ function: ASAT and ALAT ≤ 2N, total bilirubin ≤ 1.5N, creatinine clearance ≥30ml/min (except if those abnormalities are linked to the hematological disease), requiring a RIC or non myeloablative conditioning: (i) >50 years old; (ii) heavily pre-treated; (iii) comorbidities according to Sorror et al. Blood 2005;106(8):2912-9, namely HCT/CI≥ 3 (JAMA. 2011 Nov 2;3

The study aims to rapidly deploy a clinical decision support tool (eCARTv5) within the electronic health record of multiple medical-surgical units to identify patients at increased risk for intensive care (ICU) transfer and death. The investigators hypothesize that implementing such a tool will be associated with a decrease in ventilator utilization, length of stay, and mortality for high-risk hospitalized adults. The study will be a parallel study with an intervention group of medical-surgical patients where the tool will be used by providers, and a control group wherein the tool will run silently in the background. The primary analysis will utilize a delta-delta design comparing the intervention hospitals' pre vs. post results to the control hospitals' pre vs. post results. The primary outcome measure will be hospital mortality for elevated risk patients. Secondary outcome measures will include total hospital length of stay (LOS) for elevated risk patients and 30-day ICU-free and ventilator-free days following an eCART elevation.

===============

The African-American Social Support Effectiveness Treatment-Partners alleviating Perinatal Depression (ASSET-PPD) is a pilot randomized controlled trial (RCT) that aims to evaluate the effectiveness of an intervention targeting fathers' support of mothers' mental health treatment and their active engagement in the family to reduce maternal stress during the prenatal period. The study will enroll 50 parent dyads (100 individuals total, 25 romantic or non-romantic partners per arm) and will be randomized into the ASSET-PPD intervention group or the comparator group. The ASSET-PPD intervention will be designed to have 4 active modules that address key factors to reduce maternal stress during the prenatal period and 2 postpartum review sessions. The modules will be individual sessions constructed to provide training, information, and behavioral assignments to increase fathers': 1) prenatal and postpartum family involvement; 2) mental health psychoeducation; 3) interparental communication and relationship skills; and 4) balanced division of family tasks. The primary outcome measure will be maternal depression, assessed using the Inventory of Depressive Symptoms-Self-Rated (IDS-SR16). Secondary outcome measures will include maternal anxiety, breastfeeding, and parent-infant interactions. The study will be conducted at Centre Hospitalier Valida in Montreal, Canada.

The study aims to evaluate the effectiveness of a proactive identification and digital mental health intervention approach to address unmet psychosocial needs of individuals living with cancer. The study will compare the effectiveness of a behavioral activation therapy app (Moodivate) to treatment as usual. The study will measure the proportion of Illic eligible for the trial who accrue to the study. The study will be conducted over a 6-7 month period or until recruitment is reached.

The study will include individuals with elevated depressive symptoms, defined as a score of ≥ 10 on the PHQ-936 ILLIC (as determined during manual chart review), age 18+, currently own an iOS- or Android-compatible smartphone, report willingness to utilize a mobile app for the treatment of depressed mood (response of yes on yes/no item), have a valid e-mail address that is checked regularly or have regular access to text messages (to access follow-up assessments), English fluency, and no severe cognitive impairment that precludes completion of informed consent or current suicidal ideation on the PHQ-9 at screening or final study eligibility.

The study will be conducted over a 6-7 month period or until recruitment is reached. Participants will be randomly assigned to either the Moodivate condition or the treatment as usual condition. Participants in the Moodivate condition will be instructed to utilize Moodivate regularly, at least once per day, for the treatment of depressed mood among cancer survivors. Participants in the treatment as usual condition will be provided educational material about mood management available via the EHR with the suggestion to discuss questions with their oncology provider. Participants will be asked to complete questionnaire measures weekly for 4 weeks following study enrollment.

The primary outcome measure will be the proportion of Illic eligible for the trial who accrue to the study. The study will also measure the effectiveness of the Moodivate condition compared to the treatment as usual condition in addressing unmet psychosocial needs of individuals living with cancer. The study will be conducted over a 6-7 month period or until recruitment is reached.

Summary of Study Objectives
=================

* The primary objective of this study is to evaluate the effectiveness of new algorithms for detecting insulin pump malfunctions that result in reduced or interrupted insulin delivery in individuals with type 1 diabetes.
* The secondary objective is to assess the sensitivity and false positive rate of the proposed algorithms.

Summary of Study Methodology
=================

* This study is a pilot study for the evaluation of algorithms for the detection of subcutaneous insulin pump malfunctions in subjects with type 1 diabetes.
* The study consists of three phases: Phase 1: Preliminary Data Collection (Free-living Data), Phase 2: Induction of Hyperglycemia, and Phase 3: Retrospective Data Analysis.
* In Phase 1, data related to glycemic trends and insulin administration in free-living conditions are collected.
* In Phase 2, the patient visits the clinic, where insulin infusion is temporarily suspended to simulate a pump malfunction, and the resulting episode of hyperglycemia is closely monitored under medical supervision.
* In Phase 3, the collected data is retrospectively analyzed to evaluate the effectiveness of the proposed algorithms in detecting insulin suspension, simulating a pump malfunction.

Summary of Study Results
=================

* The study results are not available as the study has been completed.

Summary of Study Conclusions
=================

* The study results are not available as the study has been completed.

Summary of Study Limitations
=================

* The study is a pilot

This is a cross sectional epidemiological study comprised of children (n=887) with mean age 4.64 ± 1.56 who attended kindergartens of different cities in Jordan, this sample received questionnaires to fill data related to their demographic, socioeconomic, oral hygiene, oral health, nursing and nutritional habits. These children were also examined to determine early childhood caries prevalence in Jordan. Among this sample there was a number of children (n=159) with the mean age 4.8 ± 0.85 who were planned to be involved in a sample of a randomized controlled trial to study silver diamine fluoride efficacy in caries control. The sample consisted of two groups; the study group (children who received single spot application of 38% SDF) and control group (children who were examined only). Application of SDF started after distribution and receiving back approval letters from children's parents accompanied with questionnaires for data related to the approval/disapproval of the application. The sample were followed up for 1 year.

A retrospective study evaluating the effectiveness of Pfizer's ABRYSVO vaccine against severe respiratory syncytial virus (RSV) infection in older adults. The study will use a retrospective case-control design with test negative design (TND) and a retrospective cohort design. The primary outcome measure is vaccine effectiveness (VE) against RSV-related hospitalized lower respiratory tract infections (LRTI) cases and controls, adjusted for confounding factors using logistic regression. Secondary outcome measures include VE estimates against RSV-related severe LRTI, RSV-related hospitalized LRTI stratified by age, RSV subgroup, frailty index, chronic medical condition risk category, RSV-related hospitalized LRTI stratified by CHF and COPD, RSV-related emergency department (ED) admission (without subsequent hospitalization), RSV-related hospitalized or ED visit (without subsequent hospitalization), RSV-related death, RSV-related hospitalized acute respiratory tract infection (ARI), RSV-related hospitalized LRTI stratified by age, RSV-related hospitalized LRTI stratified by frailty index, RSV-related hospitalized LRTI stratified by chronic medical condition risk category, RSV-related hospitalized LRTI stratified by CHF and COPD, RSV-related all-cause LRTI hospitalization, RSV-related severe all-cause LRTI, RSV-related all-cause LRTI hospitalization stratified by age, RSV-related all-cause LRTI hospitalization stratified by frailty index, RSV-related all-cause LRTI hospitalization stratified by chronic medical condition risk category, RSV-related all-cause LRTI hospitalization stratified by CHF and COPD, RSV-related all-cause LRTI hospitalization stratified by CHF and COPD, RSV-related all-cause LRTI hospitalization stratified by CHF and COPD, RSV-related all-cause LRTI hospitalization stratified by CHF and COPD, RSV-related all-cause LRTI hospitalization stratified by CHF and COPD, RSV-related all-cause LRTI hospitalization

The OSsIRIS Study is a post-market clinical follow-up investigation to confirm the performance and safety of the bone substitute b.Bone in extremities and pelvis. The study will enroll patients undergoing a standard of care bone grafting with b.Bone for the treatment of surgically created bone defects or bone defects resulting from traumatic injury in the extremities and pelvis. The primary outcome measure is the performance of b.Bone by determining the radiographic healing/union after surgery. Secondary outcome measures include clinical outcomes measured by patient-reported outcomes - Pain and Quality of Life, and the safety of b.Bone during the clinical investigation period - AE and SAE, rate of reinterventions. The study will be conducted in accordance with the applicable regulations and guidelines.

The study aims to study the change in liver and splenic stiffness values at day 7 from baseline at day 1 between those with or without transplant free survival at Day 90. The study will evaluate the association of baseline and change in liver and splenic stiffness with different etiologies of ACLF, severity of ACLF by AARC-ACLF score, CLIF-C-ACLF score, MELD-Na and CTP at presentation, grade of esophageal varices in ACLF patients, pattern of organ failures, and changes in level of biochemical inflammatory markers. The study will use a prospective cohort study design and will enroll 200 patients with ACLF. The primary objective is to study the change in liver and splenic stiffness values at day 7 from baseline at day 1 between those with or without transplant free survival at Day 90. The secondary objectives are to study the change in liver and splenic stiffness values at day 14 from baseline at day 1 between those with or without transplant free survival at Day 90, evaluate the association of baseline and change in liver and splenic stiffness with different etiologies of ACLF, evaluate the association of baseline liver and splenic stiffness with severity of ACLF by AARC-ACLF score, CLIF-C-ACLF score, MELD-Na and CTP at presentation, evaluate the association of baseline liver and splenic stiffness with grade of esophageal varices in ACLF patients, evaluate the association of baseline and change in liver and splenic stiffness with pattern of organ failures, evaluate the association of changes in level of biochemical inflammatory markers with change in liver and splenic stiffness, evaluate the association of change in liver and splenic stiffness with change in AARC-ACLF score, and evaluate the association of change in liver and splenic stiffness with change in CLIF-C-ACLF score. The study will use a prospective cohort study design and will enroll 200 patients with ACLF. This is a randomized study evaluating the efficacy of onabotulinumtoxinA neurotoxin injected at a depth of 2mm versus 4mm for the improvement of glabellar lines. The study aims to compare the efficacy of the two depths and determine any adverse effects. The study will use the Merz aesthetics scale to assess the efficacy of the treatment. The study will enroll 100 patients aged 18 and older who are able to understand the requirements of the study and sign a consent form. The study will be conducted over a period of 120 days. The primary outcome measure will be the efficacy of onabotulinumtoxinA neurotoxin injected at the depth of 2mm versus 4mm for the improvement of glabellar lines using the Merz aesthetics scale. The secondary outcome measure will be the incidence of any adverse effects of onabotulinumtoxinA neurotoxin injected at the depth of 2mm versus 4mm. The study will be conducted in a double-blind, randomized, placebo-controlled design. The study will be conducted in accordance with the Declaration of Helsinki and will obtain ethical approval from the Institutional Review Board.

* Music therapy is a technique of care, accompaniment and support, which aims to improve health and well-being.
* The study aims to evaluate the impact of music therapy on anxiety in breast cancer patients undergoing adjuvant or neoadjuvant chemotherapy.
* The study will be conducted in a randomized, parallel assignment, open label design.
* The primary outcome measure will be changes in anxiety before the first and third chemotherapy sessions using the State Trait Anxiety Inventory (= STAI etat score).
* The study will be conducted over a period of 5 months.

=================

The study aims to evaluate different conditioning regimens for HLA matched donor transplantation in severe aplastic anemia. The study is a prospective, multicenter, randomized controlled study. The study includes 100 patients who are diagnosed with severe aplastic anemia and are eligible for hematopoietic stem cell transplantation. The patients are randomly assigned to either the experimental group or the control group. The experimental group receives busulfan and conditioning regimens based on the patient's risk factors of regimen related cardiotoxicity. The control group receives conditioning regimens based on the patient's risk factors of regimen related cardiotoxicity. The primary outcome measure is failure free survival, which is defined as survival with a response to therapy. The secondary outcome measures include the incidence of mixed chimerism, regimen related toxicity, myeloid and platelet engraftment, the incidence of graft versus host disease, the incidence of CMV and EBV reactivation, transplantation related mortality, and overall survival. The study is expected to be completed in 1 year.

A study to test a medicine (fitusiran) for preventing bleeds in people with severe hemophilia who previously received preventive treatment with emicizumab. The study is a single-arm, open-label treatment study. Participants will receive fitusiran prophylaxis once every 2 months (Q2M) or once monthly (QM) from Day 1 until Month 18. The study will measure the safety and tolerability of switching from emicizumab to fitusiran prophylaxis in male participants aged ≥18 years of age with severe hemophilia A, with or without inhibitors. The study will also measure the annualized bleeding rate (ABR) while receiving fitusiran prophylaxis.

The study aims to translate and validate the Malay version of the painDETECT questionnaire (PDQ-M) for use in measuring neuropathic and nociceptive pain in the Malay population. The study will recruit participants with stable disease conditions and pain duration of at least 4 weeks. Participants will be excluded if they have acute illness, poor mental health status, or cultural or language barriers. The study will involve administering the PDQ-M questionnaire, along with socio-demographic data collection, to participants with neuropathic and nociceptive pain. The primary outcome measure will be the total PDQ-M scores. The study will be conducted in two arms, one for neuropathic pain and one for nociceptive pain.

This is a randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled, dose-finding study to evaluate the safety, efficacy, pharmacokinetics, and pharmacodynamics of ABBV-552 in participants with mild Alzheimer's disease. The study includes 4 arms: ABBV-552 Dose A, ABBV-552 Dose B, ABBV-552 Dose C, and Placebo Comparator. Participants will receive ABBV-552 or placebo for 12 weeks. The primary outcome measure is the change in the Alzheimer's Disease Assessment Scale-Cognitive Subscale (ADAS-Cog 14) score from baseline to Week 12. The study aims to assess the safety, efficacy, pharmacokinetics, and pharmacodynamics of ABBV-552 in participants with mild Alzheimer's disease.

The study aims to evaluate cases of acute liver disease (ALD) and acute on chronic liver disease (ACLD) according to guidelines. The study will determine the most likely causes of disease in a patient of each age, assess complications of disease, and evaluate mortality and morbidity rates. The study will also assess in-hospital and six-month follow-up outcomes according to guidelines. Participants will be contacted over the phone for either a telephone interview or a follow-up visit in the outpatient clinics. All patients presented with severe acute liver disease, acute liver failure (ALF), and acute on chronic liver disease (ACLD). Inclusion criteria include reduced conscious state, jaundice with abnormal liver function tests, coagulopathy, and multiorgan failure. Exclusion criteria include known cardiac cirrhosis and known pre-existing renal disease. The study will use a variety of tools to assess liver function, kidney function, fluid overload, mortality rates, and morbidity rates. The primary outcome measures will include the assessment of liver function in individuals with ALF admitted to intensive care units, the assessment of kidney function in individuals with ALF admitted to intensive care units, and the assessment of fluid overload in individuals with ALF admitted to intensive care units. The secondary outcome measures will include the assessment of mortality rates and morbidity rates in individuals with ALF admitted to intensive care units. The study will use special scores such as CLIF-SOFA, CLIF-C OFs, DF, ABIC, GAHS, MELD, MELD-Na, and CHILD to assess the severity of the disease. The study will be conducted over a period of two weeks after admission to intensive care units.

The study aims to determine the predictive effects of impulsivity and coping skills on quality of life in patients with bipolar disorder. The study will be conducted in Adıyaman Besni State Hospital between October 2023-February 2024. The sample will consist of individuals who applied to the Psychiatry Outpatient Clinic of Adıyaman Besni State Hospital on the dates of the study, who received outpatient treatment with the diagnosis of bipolar according to Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders-5 and who were in the euthymic period according to the doctor's control. The data will be collected by applying the Personal Information Form, Brief Quality of Life in Bipolar Disorder Scale, Barratt Impulsivity Scale -11 Short Form and Coping Attitudes Evaluation Scale prepared by the researchers. The study will use descriptive statistical methods (frequency, mean), t-test, one way Analysis of Variance, correlation and regression analyses in Statistical Package for the Social Sciences 22 package programme. The primary outcome measure will be the effect of impulsivity level on quality of life in bipolar disorder patients. The secondary outcome measure will be the effect of coping skill level on quality of life in patients with bipolar disorder. The study will be conducted in accordance with the Declaration of Helsinki and will be approved by the Ethics Committee of Adıyaman Besni State Hospital.

=============

This is a double-blind, randomized, controlled trial that aims to compare the clinical performance of two different single-color universal composite resin materials (OMNICHROMA and Zenchroma) in the restoration of non-carious cervical lesions with the control group (Filtek Z250, 3M), which is a multi-color composite resin material, using modified USPHS and FDI criteria. The study includes 30 participants with at least 3 teeth with cervical abrasion. The primary outcome measures are clinical performance according to the modified United States Public Health Service criteria and secondary outcome measures are clinical performance of restorations according to the World Dental Organization criteria. The study will be conducted over a period of 36 months.

============

The study aims to compare the time to the first available neurologic assessment after endotracheal intubation in critically ill patients who receive either sugammadex or neostigmine. The study will be conducted in three arms: sugammadex, neostigmine, and control. Patients will be randomized to one of the three arms. The primary outcome measure is the time from administration of the neuromuscular blocker to the first available neurologic assessment. Secondary outcome measures include the time from administration of the neuromuscular blocker to the first available spontaneous eye opening, changes in Patient State index (PSi) values, changes in regional cerebral oxygen saturation (O3) values, time from intubation to extubation, total length of hospital stay, total length of intensive care unit (ICU) stay, in-ICU mortality, and in-hospital mortality. The study will be conducted in accordance with the Declaration of Helsinki and will obtain ethical approval from the local ethics committee.

=========

The study is a randomized crossover trial that aims to evaluate the effectiveness of a behavioral weight loss intervention in promoting primary prevention and uterine preservation in premenopausal women with obesity and endometrial hyperplasia. Participants will be randomly assigned to either the experimental arm, which will receive the levonorgestrel-releasing IUD and the telemedicine behavioral weight intervention, or the active comparator arm, which will receive the levonorgestrel-releasing IUD and enhanced usual care. The primary outcome measure is the number of participants with atypia-free biopsy with uterine preservation at 2 years. Secondary outcome measures include time to resolution of hyperplasia, change in weight, and change in Cancer Worry Impact Events Scale (CWIES). The study will follow participants for an estimated 4 years.

=========

The study "THE COCONUT TECHNIQUE - A NEW METHOD TO PERFORM SAFE CHOLECYSTECTOMY FOR ACUTE CHOLECYSTITIS: Our Initial Experience" is a study on cholecystectomy for acute cholecystitis. The study uses the coconut technique to perform the cholecystectomy. The study includes two females and one male with a mean age of 50 years who were diagnosed with stage II acute cholecystitis according to the Tokyo guidelines and were operated on within three days of symptom onset. The study measures the effectiveness of the coconut technique in performing subtotal cholecystectomy over a period of two years. The study uses the terms "acute cholecystitis," "cholecystectomy," and "cystic duct" as keywords.

===============

The study aims to examine the effectiveness of the Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (CBT) protocol (CBT+VR) enriched with the contribution of virtual reality (VR), which the investigators prepared to intervene in psychological problems that arise after ACL operation. The study will be conducted with 60 athletes who meet the inclusion criteria. The CBT+VR protocol will be tested, and if it is found effective, it will make a significant contribution to both the literature and practice. The main peculiarity of this study is that a holistic protocol including virtual intervention will be developed for the solution of psychological problems encountered in the rehabilitation process of sports injuries for the first time. The research will be conducted with 60 athletes who meet the inclusion criteria. In the study, which is planned as a 4X5 (groupXmeasurement) mixed factorial design model with four groups (intervention1-intervention2-intervention3, control), the athletes will be filled with psychological assessment scales in order to collect the first data within the first week of starting physical therapy after ACL operation. The CBT+VR protocol will be applied to the first intervention group. Only the behavioral intervention part of the protocol in the VR environment will be applied to the second intervention group. The CBT protocol will be applied without the VR environment for the third intervention group. It is planned that for all intervention groups and the control group, there will be 10 sessions in total once a week, and each session lasts 50 minutes. There will be conversation in the control group sessions; in addition, images that give calmness from nature will be watched for 5 minutes with VR glasses. The remaining 45 minutes will continue with a conversation with encouragement and emotional support, which will not create a therapeutic effect. The scales will also be filled in three more times. The data obtained will be analyzed with multi-level statistics. Whether the anxiety levels of the athletes increase in the VR environment will be monitored with the biofeedback system, which will provide concrete data as well as subjective scales.

The study is a stepped-wedge implementation of the PT-PENCIL tool, which is a patient-level clinical decision support tool to guide optimal treatment frequency. The primary goals of the study are to assess the development and implementation strategy for the PT-PENCIL and analyze its effect on improving the proportion of patients who discharge home. The study will use a pilot hybrid type 2 design, informed by the PRISM and RE-AIM frameworks. The study will measure the effectiveness of the evaluation on discharge home vs facility, reach, adoption, acceptability, appropriateness, and feasibility of the PT-PENCIL. The study will be conducted in two arms: a PT-PENCIL cohort and a control cohort. The PT-PENCIL cohort will receive the PT-PENCIL tool, while the control cohort will not. The study will measure the effectiveness of the evaluation on discharge home vs facility, reach, adoption, acceptability, appropriateness, and feasibility of the PT-PENCIL. The study will be conducted in two arms: a PT-PENCIL cohort and a control cohort. The PT-PENCIL cohort will receive the PT-PENCIL tool, while the control cohort will not.

The study is a single-arm, prospective, exploratory study to evaluate the feasibility and effect of medical Tai Chi exercise healing in treating mCRC patients. The study will include 20 patients with histologically or cytologically documented adenocarcinoma of the colon or rectum, ECOG Performance Status of 0-2, life expectancy of at least 6 months, adequate bone marrow, liver, cardiac and renal function as assessed by the laboratory required by protocol, and who are able to complete the treatment and follow-up on schedule according to the research plan. The intervention will be a 7-form of medical Tai Chi exercise healing for colon cancer patients, which will last 60 minutes three times a week for eight weeks and will be led by a Tai Chi instructor with more than 5 years of teaching experience. The primary outcome measure will be the adherence rates, which will be measured by the number of tai chi sessions performed divided by the total possible tai chi sessions. The secondary outcome measures will include the Brief Fatigue Inventory (BFI), the Pittsburgh Sleep Quality Index (PSQI), EORTC - Quality of Life, self-rating anxiety scale (SAS), and self-rating depression scale (SDS). The study will be conducted in accordance with the Declaration of Helsinki and will be approved by the Ethics Committee of the Affiliated Hospital of North Sichuan Medical College.

The Survivorship ECHO Project is a health services research study that aims to determine the effectiveness of the Survivorship ECHO's platform by assessing provider knowledge of cancer survivorship best practices using pre- and post-enrollment surveys. The study evaluates implementation of survivorship best practices into clinical practice and documentation after enrollment in our Survivorship ECHO. Participants attend 6 sessions of Survivorship ECHO educational intervention over 1 hour each, every 2 weeks for 12 weeks. Participants may optionally participate in a one-on-one interview to give feedback about the sessions over 30 minutes. The primary outcome measures include change in level of understanding in key survivorship knowledge areas, met and unmet needs, acceptability of current structure, and barriers to accessing ECHO. The study is designed as a single group assignment with no masking (open label). The study measures provider comfort and knowledge with core cancer survivorship competencies using a Likert survey with higher scores associated with higher levels of knowledge and comfort. The study explores content, participant needs, and aspects of delivering the Survivorship ECHO platform using qualitative analysis. The study is a health services research study with a primary purpose of health services research.

=================

The study is a randomized, controlled trial that compares the effectiveness of Maitland mobilization and post facilitation stretch in improving range of motion in post-traumatic stiff elbow patients. The study includes 32 participants, aged 18-35 years, with a limitation of elbow joint range of motion greater than 30 degrees in extension and less than 120 degrees in flexion. The intervention consists of Maitland mobilization and post facilitation stretch, applied for 4 weeks. The primary outcome measures are changes in numeric pain rating scale, range of motion of elbow joint flexion and extension, and range of motion of forearm supination and pronation. The secondary outcome measure is changes in disability, measured through the DASH questionnaire.

The study aims to evaluate the effectiveness of a multidisciplinary approach for early diagnosis of heart failure in high-risk patients. The study will randomize 1000 patients to either the ACTIVE investigational arm (NT-proBNP + AI-ECHO) or the CONTROL routine care arm. The primary endpoint is a diagnosis of heart failure within 6 months from randomization. Secondary endpoints include diagnosis of HFrEF within 6 months and patients receiving GDMT within 6 months. The study will be conducted in Canada.

The study is a naturalistic, open, multicenter, cost-effectiveness trial. The study aims to evaluate the effectiveness and cost-effectiveness of eMeistring, a therapist-guided internet-based cognitive behavioral therapy program for moderate depression, social anxiety disorder, and panic disorder. The study will recruit 180 patients from four hospitals/locations. The study will measure depression severity, social phobia, panic disorder symptoms, health-related quality of life, work and social adjustment, anxiety severity, system usability, depression severity in social anxiety and panic disorder groups, cost of health care services, patient-reported use of medication, work participation, and sickness absenteeism. The study will use PHQ-9, SPIN, PDSS-SR, EQ-5D-5L, Work and Social Adjustment Scale, GAD-7, System Usability Scale, and a separate questionnaire for medication, work participation, and sickness absenteeism. The study will use intention-to-treat and completers analyses for effectiveness and predictor analyses for dropout and adherence. The study will analyze location-specific differences stratified by patient groups. The study will be conducted in accordance with the Declaration of Helsinki and will obtain ethical approval from the local ethics committees.

===============

The study is a randomized controlled trial that compares the perioperative analgesia efficacy between Thoracolumbar Interfascial Plane Block (TLIP) and Erector Spinae Plane Block (ESP) for patients with lumbar spine fusion surgery. The study includes 3 groups: TLIP group, ESP group, and control group. The TLIP group received TLIP lumbar block under ultrasound with 20ml of ropivacaine 0.25% anesthetic on each side before surgery, followed by general anesthesia. The ESP group received lumbar (L3) ESP block method under ultrasound with 20ml of Ropivacaine 0.25% anesthetic on each side before surgery, followed by general anesthesia. The control group received regular endotracheal anesthesia, then the incision was anesthetized with 15ml of 1% lidocaine mixed with 1/200,000 adrenaline on each side before surgery. The study measures the blockade area of TLIP block and ESP block methods, the perioperative effectiveness of TLIP block and ESP block methods, and side effects. The primary outcome measure is the perioperative effectiveness of TLIP block and ESP block methods. The study is a single-center study conducted in France.

The study aims to evaluate the accuracy of a wearable melanin-adjusted blood oxygen sensor (MABOS) in patients of color. The study will enroll 12 participants, 4 of African descent, 4 of East Asian descent, and 4 of European descent, and will compare the accuracy of the MABOS device to an FDA-approved pulse oximeter. The study will measure the accuracy of the MABOS device in estimating blood oxygen levels and epidermal melanin concentration, as well as assess the safety and comfort of the device. The study will be conducted over a 90-minute testing period, with two 10-minute sessions, one 2 days after the testing session, and one 4 days after the testing session. The study will be conducted in accordance with the Declaration of Helsinki and will be approved by the Institutional Review Board.
This is a phase 1/2 study to evaluate the safety, feasibility, and efficacy of FP-1201 (intravenous interferon-beta-1a) to prevent toxicities after CD19-directed CAR T-cell therapy.

A Phase III, randomized, open-label, multicenter study of camrelizumab plus chemotherapy in combination with or without famitinib as neoadjuvant therapy in participants with triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC). The study aims to assess the efficacy and safety of camrelizumab plus chemotherapy in combination with or without famitinib as neoadjuvant therapy in participants with TNBC. The primary outcome measure is the pathological complete response (pCR) rate at the time of definitive surgery. Secondary outcome measures include event-free survival (EFS), disease-free survival (DFS), distant disease-free survival (DDFS), and objective response rate (ORR). The study will enroll 500 participants with TNBC who are eligible for neoadjuvant therapy. Participants will be randomly assigned to one of two arms: experimental arm (camrelizumab plus chemotherapy and famitinib) or active comparator arm (camrelizumab plus chemotherapy). The study will be conducted over a period of approximately 2 years.

The study aims to investigate the early prediction of postpartum glucose metabolism abnormalities in gestational diabetes mellitus (GDM) based on gestational metabolic profile and lipid profile. The study will recruit pregnant women with GDM who plan to have routine prenatal examinations and give birth in the research center. The study will use a questionnaire survey and specimen collection to collect data on serum lipidomics and serum metabolomics. The primary outcome measures will be serum lipidomics and serum metabolomics. The study will be conducted in two arms: Abnormal postpartum glucose metabolism (GDM with positive OGTT results at 6-12 weeks postpartum) and Control (GDM with negative OGTT results at 6-12 weeks postpartum). The study aims to assess the sleep quality of hospitalized patients treated with EEG-guided protection procedures in the intensive care unit. The study will be conducted in two arms: sham comparator and experimental. The sham comparator will receive usual care, while the experimental group will receive EEG-guided sleep protection. The study will measure sleep quality, sleep fragmentation, environmental noise and environmental light, sleep interruptions by caregivers, workload assessed by nurses, patient agitation, performance of the algorithm, patient reported sleep quality, anxiety level, respiratory status, presence of delirium, unit care length of stay, and safety of the procedure. The study will be conducted in two phases: phase 1 will measure sleep quality on day 1, while phase 2 will measure sleep quality on days 2 to 4. The study will be conducted in the medical intensive care unit of the University Hospital of Poitiers. The study will be conducted in accordance with the Declaration of Helsinki and will be approved by the Ethics Committee of the University Hospital of Poitiers. The study is a phase 2 randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled, dose-ranging, efficacy and safety study of SAR441566 plus MTX in adults with moderateto-severely active RA. The study will evaluate the efficacy and safety of SAR441566 in combination with MTX in adult patients with RA who have failed to achieve an adequate clinical response to MTX at a dose of 10-25 mg/week. The study will enroll 120 patients who will be randomized to one of four SAR441566 dose regimens or placebo. The study will evaluate the efficacy of SAR441566 in improving disease activity in patients with RA, as measured by the American College of Rheumatology (ACR) score and the Disease activity score - C-reactive protein (DAS28-CRP). The study will also evaluate the safety of SAR441566 in combination with MTX. The study will be conducted over a period of approximately up to 149 days.

The study is a prospective clinical performance evaluation of the in-vitro diagnostics medical device MaGIA IBC for the combined screening of HIV, Hepatitis B and Hepatitis C. The study is designed as a single arm study with a diagnostic intervention model and open label masking. The primary outcome measures are the performance measurement for the diagnostics of HIV, HBV or HCV and the proportion with positive test result among participants with HIV, HBV or HCV. The secondary outcome measures are the concordance of the diagnostic results obtained when it is performed in different matrices and the number of participants with study related adverse events. The study is conducted at Hôpital Européen de Marseille and is open to male and female participants aged 18 years and above who are taken care at the hospital and respond to at least one of the following conditions: known or suspected having HIV infection, known or suspected having HBV infection, known or suspected having or having had HCV infection. The study is not accepting healthy volunteers. The study is measuring the performance of the MagIA IBC test in capillary blood and other matrices such as veinous blood, serum and plasma. The study is measuring the sensitivity and specificity of the MagIA IBC test in capillary blood and other matrices. The study is measuring the concordance of the diagnostic results obtained when it is performed in different matrices. The study is measuring the number of participants with study related adverse events.

The study is a feasibility study to evaluate the use of nasogastric tubes and water-soluble contrast in the management of small bowel obstruction. The study will enroll patients who decline NG tube intubation and have adhesive small bowel obstruction. The study will have three arms: SBO treated without NG tube, SBO treated with NG tube and water-soluble contrast, and SBO treated with NG tube and placebo. The primary outcome measure will be patient-reported outcomes using the PROMIS-29 HRQOL instrument. The study will be conducted at Centre Hospitalier Valida.

A clinical trial is being conducted to evaluate the efficacy and safety of a novel combination therapy for chronic hepatitis B virus infection. The study will enroll 100 patients who are naive or experienced with NAs and will receive anti-PD-1 antibody, NAs, and Peg-IFNα. The primary outcome measure will be sustained HBsAg loss at 48 weeks after the end of treatment. The study is a phase 2 study and is currently active.

The study aims to explore the feasibility and utility of in-home body weight support harness system use in children with spinal muscular atrophy. The study will be conducted as a pilot study and will include 10 participants. The study will measure the caregiver survey, change in The Neuromuscular Gross Motor Outcome (GRO) scale, change in Hammersmith Functional Motor Scale Expanded (HFMSE), change in Revised Hammersmith Scale (RHS), change in Bayley Scales of Infant and Toddler Development 3rd ed. (Bayley-III), gross motor subtest, and change in World Health Organization Motor Milestone Checklist. The study will also document the frequency and duration of harness system use. The study will be conducted over a 6-month period.

The study aims to evaluate the serious complication rate and visual efficacy of DMEK (Descemet Membrane Endothelial Keratoplasty) in patients with a history of anterior or posterior segment surgery. The study will measure the occurrence rate of at least one serious DMEK post-op complication, including rebulling, graft failure, graft rejection, macular cystoid edema, and intraocular hypertension, at 12 months. Secondary outcome measures will include the occurrence rate of each of these complications, as well as the surgeon's subjective assessment of surgical complexity, duration of surgical procedure, evolution of visual results, evolution of refractive results, evolution of endothelial loss, evolution of corneal thickness, and evolution of posterior keratometry. The study will use a composite endpoint made of 4 serious post-op complications, including rebulling, graft failure, graft rejection, and macular cystoid edema. The study will use a Likert scale to evaluate the surgeon's subjective assessment of surgical complexity, and will use Nidek® autorefractometer measurement to evaluate refractive results. The study will use central and peripheral specular microscopy to evaluate endothelial loss, and will use OCT - Avanti® type cornea to evaluate corneal thickness. The study will use Scheimpflug corneal topography (Pentacam®) to evaluate posterior keratometry. The study will use Avanti OCT-cornea to evaluate rebulling, graft failure, graft rejection, and macular cystoid edema, and will use slit-lamp biomicroscopic examination to evaluate graft rejection. The study will use pneumotonometer or applanation tonometer to evaluate intraocular hypertension. The study will use the best monocular visual acuity (decimal scale converted to logMAR) to evaluate evolution of visual results, and will use the sphere (in dioptres), cylinder (in dioptres), spherical equivalent (in dioptres), and cylinder axis (in degrees) to evaluate evolution of refractive results. The study aims to analyze the mechanism of the efficacy of oral antibiotic prophylaxis in elective colon and rectal surgery with primary anastomosis. The study will be conducted at two hospitals: Uzsoki Hospital and the Department of Surgery at the University of Debrecen, and Csolnoky Ferenc Hospital in Veszprém. The study will include 100 patients, who will be randomly assigned to two groups: oral antibiotic prophylaxis + mechanical bowel preparation and oral antibiotic prophylaxis - mechanical bowel preparation. The primary outcome measure will be the correlation between septic complications and the microbiome, measured postoperatively for 30 days. Secondary outcome measures will include the relevant factors influencing the microbiome, such as comorbidities, previous operations, oral antibiotic prophylaxis, and systemic intravenous prophylaxis. The study will be conducted in accordance with the Declaration of Helsinki and will be approved by the Ethics Committee of the Uzsoki Hospital and the Csolnoky Ferenc Hospital.

The study aims to evaluate the safety and symptom burden optimization of tocilizumab in autologous stem cell transplant (ASCT) following high-dose melphalan conditioning in patients with multiple myeloma. The study is a randomized, parallel assignment, open-label study. Patients will be randomly assigned to receive tocilizumab or no tocilizumab. The primary outcome measure is the MDASI questionnaire, which will be administered on day -7 and day 100 after stem cells transfusion. Adverse events will also be recorded according to CTCAE5.0. The study will be conducted in accordance with the Declaration of Helsinki and Good Clinical Practice guidelines.

The study aims to compare the clinical pregnancy rate and the number of utilizable blastocysts obtained in couples with high Sperm DNA fragmentation undergoing TESA-ICSI or Zymot-ICSI. The study will include men with high DNA fragmentation (>20%) undergoing TESA-ICSI or Zymot-ICSI. The study will exclude couples with advanced maternal age (>40 years) and egg donation cycles. The study will compare the clinical pregnancy rate in couples with high Sperm DNA fragmentation using TESA-ICSI and Zymot-ICSI. The study will also compare the number of utilizable blastocysts obtained in couples using TESA-ICSI vs Zymot-ICSI. The study will be conducted over approximately 8 weeks and 20 days.

The study aimed to investigate the effect of stabilization and stabilization-related parameters on shooting performance at the cervical, lumbal and scapular levels in archery athletes. A total of 40 archery athletes aged between 10 and 18, who have been professionally engaged in archery for at least 1 year were included in the study. Demographic information and musculoskeletal system evaluations of the athletes were done. Performance of the athletes via Upper Extremity Closed Kinetic Chain Stability Test, Hand Grip Strength test; presence of scapular dyskinesia was evaluated via the Lateral Scapular Slide Test. Cervical region stabilization was evaluated via Craniocervical Flexion Test, scapular level stabilization was evaluated via Scapular Muscle Endurance Test, lumbar region stabilization was evaluated via Abdominal Drawing-in Test and Sahrmann's Core Stability Test. As the parameters related to stabilization, postures via Corbin Postural Rating Scale; balances via Stork Balance Test, Upper Extremity Y Balance Test; pain was evaluated via the Shoulder Pain and Disability Index. Shooting performances were evaluated with 72 target shootings and a total of 720 points.

=========

The study aims to develop an AI communication training tool to improve reproductive health encounters for adolescent-mother dyads. The study will be conducted in three stages. In Stage 1, the investigators will characterize communication content and styles of pediatricians and adolescent-mother dyads on contraception discussions with 50 real-life clinical encounters. In Stage 2, the investigators will develop and refine the AI communication training tool through prompt engineering and performance evaluation with adolescent, parent and pediatrician advisory boards. In Stage 3, the investigators will test how an AI communication intervention tool can improve reproductive health encounters by comparing evaluation results of 50 pre-training and 50 post-training real encounters. The study will advance pediatrician communication training, empower adolescent sexual health, support mothers' priorities, and test how AI communication training chatbots can improve triadic interactions.

This study aims to estimate the cumulative lifetime risk of vitiligo in the population overall and by important sociodemographic groups, including age, sex, ethnicity and deprivation. The study will also perform a subgroup analysis in the vitiligo population to identify health-related disparities across people in different deprivation, sex and ethnic groups. The disparities that will be considered are: Mental health conditions; healthcare utilisation; and work impact (time off work and unemployment). The study will use survival models, Cox proportional hazards models and generalised linear models to assess any associations with baseline characteristics and the outcome of interest. The study will be conducted using the Open Patient Care Record Database (OPCRD) and will be a population-based cohort study in the UK. The study will measure the total disease burden of vitiligo using cumulative lifetime incidence against age and will also measure the incidence and prevalence of mental health conditions, primary care encounters, dermatology referrals, mental health referrals, unemployment and time off work within patients with vitiligo. The study will be conducted over a period of 2 years.

The study aims to investigate the effects of behavior modification by hybrid mode on stress, self-efficacy, relationships, and conflict for caregivers of children with developmental delay. The study will use a randomized controlled trial design, with caregivers of developmental delay children being randomly assigned to a hybrid group or a self-learning group. The hybrid group will receive Atomic Habits (20-minute audiobook format), a role structure, and a game structure, online schedule reminders more than twice a week, and individual counseling sessions (online and physical) with one to two total interventions. The self-learning group will receive a description of the goals of the course and a reading of the Atomic Habits book. The study will use a blinded assessor to assess the outcome measures, including Intervention Fidelity, Parenting Sense of Confidence, Parenting Stress Index: Short form, The Conflict Tactics Scales: Parent Version, habit schedule record, satisfaction questionnaire. The study will be conducted over an 8-week period, with data collected at the end of the post-test. The study will be analyzed with Mann-Whinney U test, the Wilcoxon Signed Ranked Test, and Spearman correlation analysis by SPSS version 20.0, and alpha level was set at 0.05.

This is a phase 1/1b study of trotabresib in combination with vinorelbine and radiation therapy in patients with HER2-positive breast cancer with brain metastases or leptomeningeal disease. The study aims to assess the safety and efficacy of the combination therapy in this patient population. The study will be conducted in two phases. In phase 1, the study will assess the safety and tolerability of the combination therapy in a small number of patients. In phase 1b, the study will assess the efficacy of the combination therapy in a larger number of patients. The study will be conducted in two cohorts. Cohort I will receive radiation therapy, trotabresib, and vinorelbine. Cohort S will receive surgery, trotabresib, and vinorelbine. The study will be conducted in two sites. The primary outcome measure for this study is the incidence of dose limiting toxicities in phase 1. The secondary outcome measures for this study are the incidence of adverse events, progression-free survival, overall survival, and objective response rate.

* Aim 1: Modify and adapt a validated program to be a culturally-relevant digital health tool for binge eating and weight management for Black women (BMI > 30 kg/m^2) who binge eat.
* Aim 1a: Identify the barriers and facilitators to detecting and treating binge eating in Black women with obesity, and identify strategies for optimizing digital health tools to engage and retain this population.
* Aim 1b: Conduct usability testing with a group of stakeholders to guide content and design refinements; refine tool.
* Aim 2: In a randomized clinical trial, examine the feasibility and preliminary efficacy of the digital health appetite awareness + behavioral weight program in primary care.

The proposed study aims to investigate the effect of acute dietary nitrate ingestion on neuromuscular performance during resistance exercise performance when compared to supplementing the diet with a nitrate-depleted beetroot juice placebo. The study will provide insight to practitioners (coaches/athletes) aiming to enhance performance in settings where muscular power and speed are key determinants for success, as well as to scientists exploring the efficacy of beetroot juice as a form of dietary nitrate supplementation to improve muscle contractile function. The study will be conducted in a double-blind, randomised, crossover design, with participants assigned to four experimental trials to consume a total of 4 beetroot juice shots during each condition: (a) 4 x 70 ml of nitrate-depleted beetroot juice for placebo (PL), (b) 1 x 70 ml of nitrate-rich beetroot juice 3 x 70 ml nitrate-depleted beetroot juice for a low dose of nitrate-rich beetroot juice (BR-LOW;  6.5 mmol of nitrate total), (c) 2 x 70 of nitrate-rich beetroot juice and 2 x 70ml of nitrate depleted beetroot juice for a moderate dose of nitrate-rich beetroot juice (BR-MOD;  13 mmol of nitrate total), and (d) 4 x 70 ml of nitrate-rich beetroot juice for an elevated dose of nitrate-rich beetroot juice (BR-HIGH;  26 mmol of nitrate total). The primary outcome measures will be plasma nitrate and nitrite concentrations, neuromuscular performance during countermovement jumps, and mood. Secondary outcome measures will include peak power, mean power, mean velocity, peak velocity, and fatigue. The study will be conducted over a period of at least 1 year.

The study aims to investigate the effect of two different intra-operative intra-abdominal pressure levels applied to patients who underwent laparoscopic cholecystectomy under general anesthesia on 'Mechanical Power (MP)'. The study will be conducted on patients with ASA 1-2 who are willing to participate in the study voluntarily. The patients will be divided into two groups: Group 12 mmHg and Group 14 mmHg. The patients in Group 12 mmHg will be operated with an insufflation pressure of 12 mmHg during laparoscopic cholecystectomy surgery, while the patients in Group 14 mmHg will be operated with an insufflation pressure of 14 mmHg during laparoscopic cholecystectomy surgery. The mechanical power values of the patients will be measured before insufflation (baseline value), 0 min after insufflation, 15th min after insufflation, 30 minutes after insufflation, 45th minute after insufflation (if insufflation continues), 60th minute after insufflation (if insufflation continues), and intraoperative after insufflation. The primary outcome measure of the study is ventilator-induced lung injury (barotrauma). The study will be conducted in accordance with the Declaration of Helsinki and will be approved by the Ethics Committee of the Centre Hospitalier Valida.

=========

The study aims to evaluate the use of MRI as an alternative to CBCT for the assessment of furcation involvement in molars. The study includes patients with FI grade II or III who need a CBCT and are not pregnant. The primary outcome measure is the horizontal furcation defects according to Hamp 1975, measured on day 1. Secondary outcome measures include horizontal and vertical bone loss, also measured on day 1. The study uses MRI and CBCT to compare the accuracy of the two methods for assessing furcation involvement in molars.

The study aimed to compare the plaque removal efficacy of electric and manual toothbrushes in children with ADHD and healthy children. The study was conducted in two groups: ADHD-Electric Toothbrush Group and ADHD-Manual Toothbrush Group. The children in the ADHD-Electric Toothbrush Group were diagnosed with ADHD and applied to the Aydın Adnan Menderes University Faculty of Medicine Child Psychiatry Clinic. The children in the ADHD-Manual Toothbrush Group were healthy children who applied to the Pediatric Dentistry Clinic of ADU Faculty of Dentistry. The children in both groups were randomly assigned to either the electric or manual toothbrush subgroups. The study used the Löe-Silness Gingival Index, Mira-2-Ton Plaque Staining Solution, Approximal Plaque Index, and Turesky Modification of Quigley-Hein Plaque Index to evaluate the plaque removal efficacy of the toothbrushes. The study was conducted for 3 months, and the results were compared between the two groups at the end of the study.

Keywords: Attention Deficit Hyperactivity Disorder, Electric Toothbrush, Manual Toothbrush, Plaque Removal Efficacy, Children.

===============

The study is a prospective, single-arm, open-label, non-randomized, multi-center study to investigate the feasibility and stability of left bundle branch area pacing (LBBAP) for ventricular pacing in symptomatic bradycardia patients with a conventional bipolar, active fixation pacing lead. The study will enroll 120 consecutive patients while considering a 20% dropout rate, an approximate sample size of 150 patients is needed. The study will be conducted in seven clinical investigational sites across Taiwan. The study will use the Solia S lead with any BIOTRONIK pacemaker system delivered through a preshaped sheath (Selectra 3D) via left cephalic, left subclavian, or left axillary venous access. The available lengths of Solia S are 45, 53, and 60 cm. The study will follow the subjects for 12 months or until lead failure (dislodgment, high capture threshold, or inadequate sensing requiring revision of the lead) or death. During follow-up, a determination will be made whether the system is able to provide appropriate pacing and sensing.

=========

The PRE-IOP study is a randomized clinical trial that compares the effectiveness of two sonic electric toothbrushes and two manual toothbrushes in reducing gingival inflammation in pregnant women aged 18 to 40. The study uses a parallel assignment model and is double-blinded. The primary outcome measure is the incidence of gingival bleeding from baseline during pregnancy, while secondary outcome measures include the effect on gingival inflammation, dental plaque, gingival attachment, periodontal pocket, and customer satisfaction score. The study uses a manual toothbrush as a placebo comparator. The study is conducted over a period of 3 months, with measurements taken at T1 (baseline), T2 (+ 1 month), and T3 (+ 3 months). The study is conducted in accordance with the Declaration of Helsinki and is registered with the ClinicalTrials.gov registry.

=================

The study aims to investigate the effect of yoga-based breathing styles on the human brain, specifically on memory performance in adult persons without relevant prior experience in yoga, meditation or similar disciplines and without existing health problems which could hinder the performance of the breathing exercises. Participants will complete a memory test while performing controlled nasal and oral breathing. They will complete a two-week training period after the test with daily nasal or mouth breathing training or no training at all, depending on the group assignment. Researchers will compare the nasal breathing group to the mouth breathing and the comparison group to see if the nasal breathing results in a significant improvement of the memory capacity. The primary outcome measure is the improvement of learned images, measured by the percentage correctness of the given answers in the memory test, which takes place promptly after the learning phase and 2 weeks later. The secondary outcome measure is the reduction of subjective stress level, determined by a subjective stress statement, before and after each learning and retrieval phase, at the first appointment and at the second after 2 weeks.

The NutriCim study is a feasibility study designed to investigate the effects of an oncology-tailored nutritional intervention on the bioavailability and immune-activity of PD-1 immune checkpoint inhibitors in patients with lung cancer. The study will recruit 50 patients with non-small cell lung cancer who have not received prior systemic therapy treatment for their advanced NSCLC. The patients will start with the daily nutritional intervention prior to the start of the first infusion of anti-PD-1 ICI immunotherapy and will continue this nutritional support for 12 weeks. Blood samples, questionnaires, and faecal specimens will be collected on several time points during this treatment. The primary aim is to investigate the variability of clearance during a 12-weeks nutritional intervention period. The secondary aim is to investigate the feasibility for the subjects to comply with the study protocol. The investigators aim to study the feasibility of gathering data on a number of exploratory parameters that may link nutritional intake to clinically relevant outcomes.

===============

The study "Integrins and Protocadherins in Glutamatergic Circuits: Identification of Common Signaling Pathways and Molecular Targets in Anxiety and Major Depressive Disorders (GAPsy)" is a neuroimaging and murine model study aimed at identifying common signaling pathways and molecular targets in anxiety and major depressive disorders (MDD-AD). The study is structured into two parts. In the first part, 10 patients with MDD-AD and 10 healthy controls will be recruited and evaluated by a team of experienced psychologists and clinicians, administering structured clinical interviews to assess the presence/absence of axis I and II psychiatric disorders and measuring the degree of depressive/manic dysintomatology through clinical scales and psychopathological tests. Additionally, clinical data will be extrapolated from medical records and interviews with psychiatrists. The neuroimaging session, performed during the third visit (within one month of the second visit), will include T1-weighted image acquisition to study the volumetric differences of white and gray matter between subjects in the prefrontal-limbic pathway, fMRI to assess functional connections between prefrontal cortex and limbic system, and 1H-MRS to study glutamatergic neurotransmission within the anterior cingulate and dorsolateral prefrontal cortex. The second part of the study will involve murine models. More specifically, to assess whether Pcdh9 deficits affect the number and morphology of excitatory synapses, electron microscopic analyses will be performed in Pcdh9-knockout mice. Glutamatergic signaling will also be studied at the biochemical level: the expression levels of all major glutamate receptor subunits (ionotropic and metabotropic) will be investigated by analyzing cortical protein lysates (total lysates) in adult mice (3-4 months). In addition, to identify finer changes in glutamate receptor expression, their intracellular and surface expression will be analyzed using the BS3 crosslinking assay. The investigators will also proceed in the characterization of the interaction between integrin β3 and Protocadherin9 using co-immun

① The study aims to investigate the association analysis of cardiovascular and nervous system diseases and intestinal microbiome based on multi-omics big data and related applications. ② The study plans to use multi-omics big data (host genome, transcriptome, metabolome, metagenomic and metabetomic data), combined with cardiovascular disease cohort (idiopathic ventricular tachycardia, restenosis after coronary artery stenting injury) and nervous system disease cohort (carotid atherosclerosis, Moyamoya disease), and use machine learning to integrate data from different omics. ③ The study will collect fecal and blood samples from cohorts of patients with cardiovascular and neurological diseases and from healthy people. ③ The study will use genome and transcriptome sequencing, metagenomic sequencing, metabetomic sequencing, and metabolomic sequencing to process the collected samples. ③ The study will use machine learning methods to conduct association analysis of candidate host genes and bacteria. ③ The study will construct and interpret relevant pathways to rise to the recognition of patterns for the construction of predictive models for early disease prevention and disease diagnosis.

The study aims to evaluate the prognostic value of a combined approach based on KEAP1/NFE2L2 mutations and pre-therapeutic FDG-PET/CT radiomic analysis in advanced non-small-cell lung cancer (NSCLC) patients with PDL1 expression ≥ 50% treated with pembrolizumab. The study will include patients with stage IV NSCLC and stage III NSCLC that is unresectable and not amenable to radiotherapy. The primary outcome measure will be progression-free survival (PFS) through study completion, an average of 1 year. Secondary outcome measures will include overall survival (OS) through study completion, an average of 1 year. The study will exclude patients with PD-L1 expression <50%, neuroendocrine tumors, and secondary metastatic patients. The study will also exclude patients who have previously been treated or who have expressed opposition to the study. The study will be designed as a single-arm study, with patients receiving pembrolizumab as the treatment. The study will be conducted in accordance with the Declaration of Helsinki and will obtain ethical approval from the relevant institutional review board.

The study aims to evaluate the effectiveness of proprioceptive neuromuscular facilitation (PNF) in improving ankle dorsiflexion range in professional paddle tennis players. The study is a randomized controlled trial with two arms: PNF group and Eccentric exercises and electrical stimulation (EEES) group. The study measures vertical jump and ankle dorsiflexion range using weight bearing lunge test and drop jump test. The study is conducted over a period of 1 month. The study is conducted over a period of 1 month.

The INDEPT study is a 12-week multicentre randomized parallel-group open controlled trial, with a follow up assessment at 6- and 12-months after baseline data collection, with two parallel groups with an allocation ratio of 1:1. The main objective of the trial is to assess the effectiveness of dietary counselling promoting MedDiet, as an adjuvant treatment of MDD, to decrease depressive symptoms in adults diagnosed with MDD and having elevated inflammation biomarkers (CRP, IL-6). The study will use a convenience sample from patients diagnosed with MDD attending to outpatient consultations in one for the participating clinics. Participants allocated to the intervention group will attend six nutrition consultations, performed by a register nutritionist in weeks 1, 2, 4, 6, 8 and 10. The intervention will be personalized to each participant and will promote adherence to the Mediterranean Diet, ad libitum, without calories or macronutrients restriction or recommendation for weight change. The study will use a Beck Depression Inventory-II scale to measure changes in symptoms of MDD and inflammation biomarkers (IL-6 and/or CRP) to assess the association between adherence to MedDiet and changes in inflammatory biomarkers and the association between changes in inflammatory biomarkers with symptoms of MDD. The study will be conducted in accordance with Consolidated Standards of Reporting Trials (CONSORT) guidelines. The primary analysis will include all randomized participants, following an intention-to-treat (ITT) approach. The success measure will be a decrease in category in the severity of depressive symptoms. The proportion of participants with a decrease in depression severity symptoms category according to the BDI-II (main outcome) will be compared between control and intervention groups using generalized linear mixed models. Secondary analyses, including the analysis of the main outcome measure (BDI-II) as a continuous variable, will be conducted using (Generalized) Linear Mixed Models, as appropriate. All analyses will be performed using R and R Studio version 3.5.3 and R Studio version 1.3.618 (or another updated version in the moment of analysis), assuming a significance level of 5 percent

The study aims to support refugee parenting and improve family mental health in Tijuana, Mexico. The study uses a participatory research model to prioritize parenting skills and adapt a learning curriculum. The study is a randomized controlled trial with two arms: an experimental arm that receives the adapted learning curriculum and a control arm that receives a handout about parenting techniques. The study measures parenting knowledge, child behavior and parental efficacy, observed parent-child interactions, parental stress, and qualitative feedback. The study will be conducted in two large shelters in Tijuana and will recruit 120 participating parents, divided into 8 groups of 15. The study will be conducted over 8 months, with data collection at pre-intervention, post-intervention, and 2-month post-intervention follow-up. The study will be conducted in Spanish.

The study aims to understand and identify priorities for improving the healthcare experiences of people with incurable head and neck cancer (HNC) and their families. The study will use a qualitative approach, including longitudinal interviews with patients and family carers and on-line focus groups with healthcare professionals. The study will be conducted in three HNC centres in the Northwest, Northeast and Yorkshire. The study will be conducted over 20 months, with the first phase of the study (months 1-18) focusing on generating a thematic framework for co-design workshops and the second phase of the study (months 19-20) focusing on generating potential solutions and identifying priority areas for intervention development. The study will be conducted in accordance with the Declaration of Helsinki and will obtain ethical approval from the relevant ethics committees.

The study aims to investigate the clinical application of indocyanine green fluorescence imaging to assist in identifying nerve roots in endoscopic spinal surgery. The study will be a randomized, parallel assignment, open-label study. The study will include three arms: no intervention (control group), 0.5mg/kg ICG group, and 1mg/kg ICG group. The primary outcome measure will be the fluorescence imaging rate of nerve roots, and the secondary outcome measures will include the fluorescence signal ratio of nerve root to back fluorescence, time taken to find the nerve root endoscopically, ICG-related adverse reactions, visual analogue pain scale (VAS), Oswestry disability index (ODI), surgical complications, and length of surgery. The study will be conducted in patients with lumbar disc herniation who undergo endoscopy spinal surgery for nerve root decompression. The study will be conducted in patients who have no clear contraindications to surgery, have the ability to understand and act, have informed consent, and can participate in all study follow-up voluntarily and sign a written informed consent form. The study will be conducted in patients who are aged between 20 and 60 years and are of both sexes. The study will be conducted in patients who are not allergic to iodine or shellfish, do not have thyroid related diseases, do not have ankylosing spondylitis, lumbar instability or bony spinal stenosis, do not have diabetes, vascular related diseases, or abnormal liver and kidney function, do not have difficulty in tolerating anaesthesia, are not pregnant or lactating, and are able to communicate or do not follow directions. The study will be conducted in patients who are considered suitable to participate in this study by the investigators. The study will be conducted in patients who are able to understand the study protocol and are willing to participate in the study. The study will be conducted in patients who are able to provide informed consent and are willing to participate in the study.
