The study aims to evaluate the effectiveness of a home-based parenting support program for parents with intellectual and developmental disabilities who are at risk of neglect. The program, Parenting Young Children (PYC), is a 3-6 month structured coaching sessions program that focuses on parent-child interaction and child care skills and safety. The study is a non-randomized, parallel assignment study with two arms: experimental and active comparator. The experimental arm receives PYC while the active comparator arm receives treatment as usual (TAU) from the social services. The primary outcome measures are change in Canadian Occupational Performance Measure, performance sub-scale and change in Canadian Occupational Performance Measure, satisfaction sub-scale. Secondary outcome measures include change in Parental Sense of Competence Scale and Strengths and Difficulties Questionnaire. The study is designed to measure the effectiveness of PYC in improving parenting skills and competence in parents with intellectual and developmental disabilities.

=========

The study is an observational study for patients undergoing surgery for male stress urinary incontinence using medical devices such as AUS or sling. The study will collect information on patient characteristics, including age, weight, length, previous urological surgeries and other surgeries in the pelvic area, radiotherapeutic treatment of the prostate, and other co-morbidities. The surgical procedure for treatment of male stress urinary incontinence is according to standard practice. The study will measure the success rate (cure plus improvement) of the treatment, the time being continent, the time being revision-free, patient-reported quality of life, and post-operative general and specific adverse events. The study will follow the patients for 5 years after surgery.

The study aims to investigate the biological mechanisms behind resynchronization therapy in heart failure. The study will collect blood samples, heart tissue, and clinical data from heart failure patients eligible for CRT and a control group of heart failure patients on medical therapy. Patients will be assessed before CRT implantation or early after initiation of medical treatment, at 3 months, 6 months, and 12 months. A subset of the patients in the CRT group will also be subjected to a heart biopsy before CRT implantation and at 3 months. At each time point, all patients will be assessed with echocardiography, ECG, and blood sampling. The blood samples will be analyzed regarding proteins and exosomal miRNA. The heart tissue will be frozen and analyzed regarding proteins, RNA, and contractility. Endothelial function will also be evaluated at inclusion, 3, and 12 months using EndoPAT. Red blood cells (RBCs) will be collected to determine whether they may affect endothelial cell function. The study is an observational study where we follow patients and save blood samples and biopsies for analysis as described above. The primary outcome measure is biomarkers, and the secondary outcome measure is endothelial function. The study aims to separate CRT responders from non-responders.

=========

The study aims to provide evidence of medication strategy in heart failure patients, especially for patients who are intolerable for GDMT. The study will compare the efficacy and safety of GDMT in heart failure patients who were tolerable to GDMT and heart failure patients who were intolerable to GDMT. The primary outcome measure is all-cause mortality or worsening heart failure in 180 days. Secondary outcome measures include change in symptoms and signs of heart failure, change in N-terminal pro-B type natriuretic peptide, change in left ventricular ejection fraction, change in left ventricular end-diastolic diameter, change in left ventricular end-systolic diameter, change in left ventricular fractional shortening, change in blood pressure, change in blood potassium, and terms related to the study. The study will be conducted in heart failure patients who were hospitalized and diagnosed with acute heart failure with typical symptoms and signs, such as dyspnea, shortness of breath and edema. The study will be conducted in two arms: heart failure patients who were tolerable to GDMT and heart failure patients who were intolerable to GDMT. The heart failure patients who were tolerable to GDMT will receive GDMT containing ACEI/ARB/ARNI, β blocker, SGLT2i and MRA. The heart failure patients who were intolerable to GDMT will receive GDMT containing ACEI/ARB/ARNI and β blocker. The study will be conducted for 180 days.

This study aims to improve PRO adherence in patients with cancer by applying behavioral economic strategies. The study will use a three-arm design, with patients randomly assigned to either usual practice, encounter-based PRO monitoring with patient reminders and triage nurse alerts, or remote PRO monitoring with patient reminders and triage nurse alerts. The primary outcome will be PRO adherence, measured as the proportion of expected PRO questionnaires completed per patient over a 3-month period. Secondary outcomes will include the percentage of patients with at least one note documenting PROs during the study period, the percentage of patients with at least one note documenting PROs per month, time to alert response, percentage of patients who trigger an alert for triage nurses, acute care utilization, treatment delays/modifications, and duration of therapy. The study will be conducted at participating Implementation Lab sites.

============

The ProgESC Study is a cross-sectional prospective study that aims to better understand the prognostic awareness of patients referred to the Enhanced Supportive Care (ESC) service at University College London Hospital. The study will assess patients' prognostic understanding, psychological distress, quality of life, trust in medical professionals, and perceived quality of care. The primary endpoint is the level of patients' prognostic awareness, which will be assessed through the Prognosis and Treatment Perception Questionnaire. The study will include 100 patients and will take approximately 20 minutes to complete. The findings of this study will inform the future development of strategies to improve care and communication with patients with advanced cancer.

The study is a pragmatic, randomized controlled clinical trial with parallel group assignment. The study will be performed in the Emergency Department at Vanderbilt University Hospital. The study will enroll patients who are located in the Emergency Department at Vanderbilt University Hospital ≤ 12 hours from patient presentation to the Emergency Department at Vanderbilt University Hospital, are aged ≥ 18 years, have ordered blood cultures, have ordered intravenous vancomycin, and meet other inclusion criteria. The study will compare the time to last dose of intravenous vancomycin between patients who receive direct-from-blood testing using the T2Bacteria® Panel and patients who receive usual care. The study will also measure the time to last dose of systemic anti-pseudomonal beta-lactam antibiotic. The study will be conducted over a period of 14 days from randomization. The study will be conducted as a pragmatic, randomized controlled clinical trial with parallel group assignment. The study will be conducted in the Emergency Department at Vanderbilt University Hospital. The study will enroll patients who are located in the Emergency Department at Vanderbilt University Hospital ≤ 12 hours from patient presentation to the Emergency Department at Vanderbilt University Hospital, are aged ≥ 18 years, have ordered blood cultures, have ordered intravenous vancomycin, and meet other inclusion criteria. The study will compare the time to last dose of intravenous vancomycin between patients who receive direct-from-blood testing using the T2Bacteria® Panel and patients who receive usual care. The study will also measure the time to last dose of systemic anti-pseudomonal beta-lactam antibiotic. The study will be conducted over a period of 14 days from randomization. The study will be conducted as a pragmatic, randomized controlled clinical trial with parallel group assignment. The study will be conducted in the Emergency Department at Vanderbilt University Hospital. The study will enroll patients who are located in the Emergency Department at Vanderbilt University Hospital ≤ 12 hours from patient presentation to the Emergency Department at Vanderbilt University Hospital, are aged ≥ 18 years, have ordered blood cultures, have ordered intravenous vancomycin, and meet other inclusion criteria

=========

This is a randomized-controlled trial that aims to evaluate the effect of temperature-elevating armbaths (Hauffe-Schwenniger-Baths) on arterial hypertension. 50 participants will be randomized to either an intervention group or waitlist (treatment as usual). All participants will be monitored with three 24-hours ambulatory blood pressure measurements at the beginning of the trial after randomization, at 8 weeks and at 6 months. The intervention group will be advised to perform the armbaths on 5 of 7 days per week for 8 weeks total. Each participant will get a detailed instruction how to perform the armbath and will be handed a diary to document their performance. After 6 months, each participant of the control group will be offered to be instructed on performing the armbaths as well. Within the active period of 8 weeks, participants of both groups will be called regularly to ask about their health and whether they have questions regarding the trial. The primary outcome measure is blood pressure, and secondary outcome measures include health-related quality of life, sleep quality, heart rate, adverse events, and medication changes.

The study aims to investigate the effects of acupuncture on perceived stress and health in military service members and veterans. The study will use a randomized controlled trial design with two arms: experimental and active comparator. The experimental arm will receive Manual Standardized Stress Acupuncture (MSSA) and Mindfulness-Based Stress Reduction (MBSR), while the active comparator arm will receive only MBSR. The study will measure the primary outcome of perceived stress using the Perceived Stress Scale (PSS) at baseline, two weeks post interventions, and four weeks post interventions. Secondary outcome measures will include the Insomnia Severity Index (ISI) and the Short Form (SF) Health Survey. Journal entries will also be collected to assess the perceived benefits of treatment. The study will be conducted online via Microsoft Teams.

The study aims to determine the prevalence of persistent COVID-19 in a cohort of patients in Punta Arenas. The study will use a cross-sectional design and will include participants aged 18 years and older who have had at least one positive SARS-CoV-2 RT-qPCR test between July 2022 and July 2023. The study will measure the prevalence of persistent COVID-19 in the cohort over a period of 13 months. The study will also collect data on sociodemographic factors, psychological profiles, standard laboratory parameters, inflammatory biomarkers, immunological repertoire associated with persistent COVID-19, function of the musculoskeletal system, and diagnosis of prevalent COVID-19. The study will use a combination of self-reported survey data, laboratory tests, and imaging studies to collect data. The study will be conducted in accordance with the Declaration of Helsinki and will obtain informed consent from all participants. The study will be conducted by the SEREMI of Health in Punta Arenas.

============

This is a multicenter randomized controlled trial comparing intrathecal catheter placement versus resiting epidural catheter after dural puncture in obstetric patients. The study aims to evaluate the incidence and intensity of post-dural puncture headache (PDPH) at 24 and 48 hours, as well as the quality of analgesia during labor, adverse events, chronic pain at 1 and 3 months, readmission to hospital, and patient's satisfaction. The study will be conducted in 10 centers in Italy and will include 100 obstetric patients with confirmed diagnosis of UDP during labor. Participants will be randomly assigned to either the active comparator group (resiting epidural catheter or intrathecal catheter placement) or the control group (standard care). The study will be conducted in accordance with the Declaration of Helsinki and will be registered in the Italian Registry of Clinical Trials (ISRCTN).

The study is a randomized, parallel assignment study with two arms: experimental and active comparator. The experimental arm uses a sectional matrix system and the active comparator arm uses a circumferential matrix system. The study measures the tightness of proximal contact immediately after the procedure using dental floss. The inclusion criteria include a tooth with compound class 2 cavities, good general health, minimum age of 18 years, fully erupted occluding premolar and molar teeth, and exclusion criteria include a tooth with complex class 2 cavities, severe periodontal disease, diastema between posterior teeth, third molars, and tooth mobility greater than 1 mm. The study is designed to compare the effectiveness of the two matrix systems in achieving a strong contact point in Class II restorations with composite resin in the posterior dental sector.

The study is a randomized controlled trial evaluating the effectiveness of a pay for performance (PFP) program for high-utilizers of mental health services in Santa Clara County, CA. The program includes assertive case management, crisis intervention, substance use counseling, mental health treatment, peer support, skill-building, and care coordination. The study measures the total cost of 24-hour psychiatric services and specific components of these services over 12, 24, and 36 months. The study compares the costs and utilization of services under the PFP program to usual care (UC). The study includes participants with a history of extensive utilization of 24-hour psychiatric services in Santa Clara County, CA and a likelihood of continuing to use them in the future. The study excludes individuals with certain diagnoses, ages, and residency status. The study measures the total cost of 24-hour psychiatric services (12 months), total cost of 24-hour psychiatric services (24 months), and total cost of 24-hour psychiatric services (36 months). The study also measures the total cost of specific components of these services, including emergency psychiatric services, Barbara Arons Pavilion (BAP) Acute Inpatient Psychiatric Care, Contract Hospital, Institutes of Mental Disease (IMD), State Hospital, Crisis Residential, Transitional Residential, Super Board and Care, and Residential Care Facility. The study also measures the proportion of patients who had any days of incarceration during the 12, 24, and 36 months post-enrollment.

===============

The study aims to determine the clinical efficacy and cost-effectiveness of Culturally adapted Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (CaCBT) and Culturally adapted Family Intervention (CulFI) compared to TAU in reducing overall symptoms of psychosis in individuals with FEP in Pakistan. The study will include 390 participants with FEP from psychiatric units of hospitals in ten centres (i.e. Karachi, Lahore, Rawalpindi, Hyderabad, Qambar Shahdakot, Shaheed Benazirabad, Sukkur, Peshawar, Quetta and Multan). Consented participants meeting eligibility criteria will be randomised in a 1:1:1 allocation to CaCBT + TAU, CulFI + TAU or TAU alone. Participants in CaCBT intervention group will receive 12-weekly one-to-one sessions. Participants in CulFI group will receive 10-weekly one-to-one sessions. Each CaCBT and CulFI session will last for approximately 1 hour. Sessions will be delivered by trained psychologists who will receive regular weekly supervision to maintain fidelity. Assessments will be carried out at baseline, months 3, 6, and 12 by trained, blinded assessors. Process evaluation will help to build the implementation knowledge base for proposed interventions across study settings. We will conduct economic evaluations (i.e., the cost-effectiveness and cost-utility analyses) of the CaCBT and CulFI interventions, as add-on to TAU.

The study is a phase 1/2 multi-center study evaluating the safety and efficacy of IMPT-314, a CD19/20 bispecific chimeric antigen receptor (CAR) T cell therapy in participants with relapsed or refractory aggressive B-cell non-Hodgkin lymphoma. The study includes two dose levels and one phase II dose level. The primary outcome measures are the incidence of DLTs and other treatment-emergent adverse events, investigator-assessed complete response rate, and proportion of enrolled participants who receive the target dose. The secondary outcome measures include the overall response rate, duration of response, duration of complete response, median progression-free survival, median overall survival, Cmax from time 0 to Day 28, area under the curve from time 0 to Day 28, and persistence of IMPT-314. The study is designed as a non-randomized intervention model with a single masking. The study is currently ongoing.

=========

The study aims to investigate the effects of Metabolic Syndrome and its components on cognitive performance and physical activity level in middle-age individuals. The study will include 100 participants, 50 in the MetS group and 50 in the control group. The MetS group will be assessed for waist circumference, blood pressure, triglyceride, HDL-C, fasting plasma level, and Metabolic Syndrome Severity Score. The control group will be assessed for the same parameters. The study will also assess cognitive performance using the MoCA and Mini Mental State Examination, and physical activity level using the Stroop Test TBAG Form, International Physical Activity Questionnaire Short-Form, and pedometer. The study will be conducted over a period of 6 months.

===============

The study aims to test the effectiveness of two brief digital interventions to increase COVID-19 vaccination among adults with anxiety or depressive symptoms. The interventions are attitudinal inoculation, CBT-informed intervention, and conventional public health messaging. The study will recruit undervaccinated participants with and without symptoms of anxiety or depression from the CHASING COVID Cohort, a large and geographically diverse US cohort. The study will examine the outcome of COVID-19 vaccination at 4 weeks post-intervention, conducting intent-to-treat comparisons between arms. The primary outcome measure is self-reported receipt of a COVID vaccine dose in the 4 weeks post-intervention. The study will also measure vaccine hesitancy at baseline, immediately post-intervention, 4 weeks post-intervention, and at 6 months post-intervention.

The study is a randomized controlled trial that examines the effects of binaural beat music on sleep quality, heart rate variability, and depression in older people with poor sleep quality in a long-term care institution. The study includes 100 participants aged 65 years and older who have a PSQI score> 7 and stay in the institution for 1 month and more. The intervention group receives 20 minutes of binaural beat music thrice a week for two weeks, while the control group receives 20 minutes of music without BBM. The primary outcome measures are the Pittsburgh Sleep Quality Index (PSQI), heart rate variability (HRV), and Geriatric Depression Scale (GDS). The study will be conducted for 14 days.

The study aims to develop an understanding of the barriers and facilitators of a high level of fidelity that is sustainable for use by patients and health care providers. The study will use a mixed methods approach, including semi-structured interviews, cross sectional patient surveys and clinical data collection. The study will recruit patients referred to the Head and Neck Cancer Personalised Follow Up clinic who have oncological treatment for a Head and Neck cancer, are disease free, at least 2 years post treatment completion and have no risk factors of disease recurrence. The study will also recruit oncologists, surgeons, allied health practitioners, nurses, and support staff who provide care for patients with Head and Neck Cancer. The study will measure the acceptability of the Personalised Follow Up Pathway to patients and service providers, the safety of the Personalised Follow Up Pathway, patient experience within the Personalised Follow Up Pathway, service provider experience within the Personalised Follow Up Pathway and the sustainability of the Personalised Follow Up Pathway. The study will be conducted over 12 months.

The study is a randomized clinical trial comparing intrathecal bupivacaine-dexmedetomidine to intrathecal bupivacaine-neostigmine in elective caesarean sections. The study aims to support the care of patients. The study is double-masked and has three arms. The first arm receives 10 mg (2ml) hyperbaric bupivacaine and 0.1 ml (10 μg) dexmedetomidine and 0.1 ml normal saline. The second arm receives 10 mg (2ml) hyperbaric bupivacaine and 0.1 ml (50 μg) neostigmine and 0.1 ml normal saline. The third arm receives 10 mg (2ml) hyperbaric bupivacaine and 0.2 ml normal saline as a control. The primary outcome measure is the time started from the end of intrathecal injection till achievement of a bilateral sensory block at T10. The study is designed to support the care of patients. This is a randomized clinical trial evaluating the performance of an air-polishing device in preventing white spot lesions and gingivitis among patients undergoing multi-bracketed fixed orthodontic treatment. The null hypothesis tested is that there is no difference between the air-polishing device and the conventional ultrasonic device in preventing white spot lesions and gingivitis during orthodontic treatment. Clinical examination and clinical samples will be taken before, during and after orthodontic treatment. It is a single center study of 3 years duration involving samples of 60 patients attending the Division of Orthodontics for treatment. Half of the participants will be randomly assigned for treatment with the air-polishing device in every orthodontic appointment, meaning once per month, the other half will be treated with a standard ultrasonic scaler every six months. The study duration for each participant will be approximately 2 years. The investigators will then analyze the prevalence of white spot lesions using the Quantitative light-induced fluorescence (QLF) method. Gingivitis will be evaluated throughout the study by using standard clinical parameters; the antimicrobial efficacy against several known periodontal pathogens and the host-response (inflammatory markers in GCF) will be measured by the qPCR assay and the multiplex immunoassay, respectively. Clinical evaluation and collection of samples for microbial and host response analysis will be performed every 6 months. Incidence of bracket debonding will be calculated and compared.

The Atrial Fibrillation Driver Study is a pilot project that aims to obtain tissue samples from patients undergoing cardiac or thoracic surgery and analyze them histologically and molecularly. The study will recruit up to 10 patients undergoing cardiothoracic surgery at University Hospital Southampton NHS Foundation Trust. The tissue samples will be obtained as part of routine clinical care and will be analyzed using immunohistochemistry, in situ hybridisation, electron microscopy, collagen cross-linking, genome sequencing, miRNA and RNA sequencing, culture, RT-PCR, flow cytometry, and immunocytochemistry. The primary outcome measures will be the histological and molecular analysis of the tissue samples. The study will measure the degree of fibrosis in the tissue samples and the molecular markers associated with AF. The study will be conducted over a period of 1 year.

=========

The study aims to compare the effects of integrated and isolated resisted exercise on strength, power and endurance in gym beginners. The study will use a randomized controlled trial design with two groups. The experimental group will receive either integrated or isolated resisted exercise, while the control group will receive no intervention. The study will measure endurance, power, and strength using standardized tests. The study will be conducted over an 8-week period, with participants performing exercises twice a week. The study will be conducted in a gym setting and will be open to healthy volunteers aged 18-30 years old. The study aims to compare the effects of play-based therapy and functional communication training in speech-language delayed children. The study will include children aged 2-6 years with speech language delay from hearing loss. The study will be randomized, with two arms: Group A will receive play-based therapy, while Group B will receive functional communication training. Both groups will undergo assessments using the Portage Guide to Early Education and the Speech Questionnaire at baseline and after three months. The primary outcome measure will be the change in functional language ability from baseline at three months. The study will measure the effectiveness of play-based therapy and functional communication training in improving speech language development in children with speech language delay from hearing loss.

=================

The study aims to assess the barriers and facilitators of integrating Horyzons, an evidence-based digital intervention, in outpatient mental health clinics in North Carolina that provide care to individuals with schizophrenia spectrum and other unspecified psychotic disorders. The study will recruit 20 clinicians and/or peer specialists from the FEP clinics and 50 individuals with FEP to participate in the study. The study will use a mixed-methods approach, including surveys, interviews, and platform usage data, to assess the barriers and facilitators of implementing and integrating Horyzons in clinical practice. The study will also assess client engagement with Horyzons and attrition as part of clinical care and assess the change in clients' psychological measures across the 12-month intervention. The study will be conducted over a 24-month period, with data collection occurring up to 12 months after the intervention.

The study aims to investigate the inflammatory and anti-inflammatory gene expressions in liver transplant patients before and after the operation. The study will measure the expression levels of inflammatory and anti-inflammatory cytokine genes and other relevant genes in peripheral blood samples obtained from liver transplant patients before, 1 month and 6 months after the operation. The study will also measure the classical liver markers and biochemical parameters. The study will investigate the predictive value of these parameters for rejection and infection after liver transplantation. The study will be conducted in two groups: control group (healthy volunteers without acute or chronic diseases) and transplantation group (liver transplant patients). The study will be conducted in accordance with the Declaration of Helsinki and will be approved by the Ethics Committee. The study is a randomized, parallel assignment, open-label study. The primary objective is to compare the efficacy of furosemide-induced diuresis with matched dehydration using the RenalGuard device to standard diuretic therapy in patients with acute heart failure and overt fluid overload. The study will measure daily serum creatinine levels and daily weight decrease during study treatment for assessment of acute kidney injury occurrence and daily weight decrease, respectively. The study will be conducted in two arms: a control group receiving furosemide infusion and an experimental group receiving furosemide infusion with matched dehydration using the RenalGuard device. The study will be conducted in patients with acute decompensated heart failure, estimated weight gain due to peripheral fluid overload >4 kg, admission BNP values >400 pg/ml if in sinus rhythm and >600 pg/ml if in atrial fibrillation, and no contraindications to placement of a Foley catheter or known hypersensitivity to furosemide. The study is a pilot study that aims to determine the feasibility, acceptability, and effectiveness of a self-guided mindfulness-based intervention in pediatric patients with idiopathic chest pain. The study will recruit 20 participants aged 12-18 years who have recurrent chest pain diagnosed as idiopathic or musculoskeletal by a pediatric cardiologist. Participants will be randomly assigned to either the standard of care control group or the mindfulness-based intervention group. The primary outcome measures include participant recruitment rate, participant retention rate, mindfulness-based intervention program adherence, mindfulness-based intervention program evaluation, survey response rate, pain coping strategies, perceived stress, patient quality of life, chest pain episode frequency, and chest pain episode intensity. The study will be conducted over a 44-day period, with data collection occurring at baseline, 14 days, and 44 days.

The study is a four-arm, double-blind, non-inferiority trial to evaluate the safety and immunogenicity of concomitant administration of the Novavax vaccine and a 20-valent pneumococcal conjugate vaccine (PCV20) in adults aged 60 years or older. The study will enroll 1,200 participants, who will be randomly assigned to one of four arms: NVX arm, PCV20 arm, combination arm, or placebo arm. The primary outcome measure will be immunogenicity, assessed by antibody levels on day 28. The study will also evaluate the safety of the vaccines and the non-inferiority of the combination vaccine compared to the individual vaccines. The study will be conducted in the United States and Canada.

The study is designed to evaluate the safety and immunogenicity of concomitant administration of the Novavax vaccine and a 20-valent pneumococcal conjugate vaccine (PCV20) in adults aged 60 years or older. The study will enroll 1,200 participants, who will be randomly assigned to one of four arms: NVX arm, PCV20 arm, combination arm, or placebo arm. The primary outcome measure will be immunogenicity, assessed by antibody levels on day 28. The study will also evaluate the safety of the vaccines and the non-inferiority of the combination vaccine compared to the individual vaccines. The study will be conducted in the United States and Canada.

=================

This is a phase I-II study of the combination of anti-PD-L1 antibody durvalumab and TLR-3 agonist rintatolimod in patients with metastatic pancreatic cancer. The primary objective of the study is to determine the safety of the combination therapy. The secondary objective is to determine the clinical benefit rate of the combination therapy. The study will be conducted in a single center, and will be open-label. The study will be divided into two phases. In phase I, the safety of the combination therapy will be determined in a limited number of patients. In phase II, the clinical benefit rate of the combination therapy will be determined in a larger number of patients. The study will be conducted in accordance with the Declaration of Helsinki and will be approved by the local ethics committee.

===============

The study aims to analyze the potential effects of supplementation with the flavonoid diosmin on delayed-onset muscle soreness (DOMS) in women athletes from a five-a-side soccer team in Brazil. The study will use an intense dynamic exercise protocol and will be conducted through a randomized, double-blinded, and placebo-controlled clinical trial. The study will consist of two experimental groups, one control group that will receive placebo supplementation and one intervention group that will receive diosmin supplementation. The study will evaluate whether treatment with diosmin reduces muscle pain, systemic (serum) levels of total creatine phosphokinase (CFQ), and oxidative stress (lipid peroxidation and antioxidant capacity) induced by the intense dynamic exercise protocol. Additionally, the study will evaluate whether treatment with diosmin is capable of improving the reduction in muscular performance and impairment of balance induced by the intense dynamic exercise protocol. The study will be conducted on approximately 40 female athletes from the Londrina Esporte Clube women's five-a-side soccer team in Brazil. The study is approved by the Research Ethics Committee (CEP) for Human Beings/Brazil Platform.

===============

The Netherlands CP register is an innovative register for data collection which was developed between 2016 and 2020 in a unique collaboration between children with CP, their parents, researchers and health care professionals. The overall aim of the register is to provide personalized, value-based care for children with CP. The study aims to determine the short- (3 months), medium- (1 year) and long-term (2 years) effect of ITB in children with CP on personal treatment goals, and to identify predictive factors for treatment success. The study will be conducted in Amsterdam UMC and the MUMC using the Netherlands CP register to collect data over a period of 4,5 years. The primary outcome measure is goal attainment scaling (GAS) in which achievement of individual goals can be quantified. Secondary outcome measures include: patient characteristics, treatment history, range of motion, spasticity, dystonia, scoliosis, selectivity, functional strength, gait analysis, questionnaires on activities and participation, treatment characteristics ITB including dosage, complications. The study will use a linear mixed-model analysis to determine the development over time for the primary and secondary outcome measures, using time as a categorical variable. All analyses will be adjusted for possible covariates. Effect size (ES) Cohen's d will be calculated for all outcome measures. Univariable linear regression analysis for each potential variable influencing outcome will be conducted. Factors showing a p-value of ≤0.20 are then selected for input in a final model in which a multiple regression analysis using backward stepwise selection will be performed to identify the predicting factors. A p-value < 0.05 is considered statistically significant. Correction for multiple testing will be done by Holm correction of p-values.

===============

The study is a randomized controlled trial (RCT) that aims to investigate the effect of vitamin D supplementation on gestational diabetes mellitus (GDM) development among high risk pregnant women with low vitamin D levels. The study will recruit pregnant women at 7-11 weeks of gestation with low vitamin D levels and randomly assign them to receive either vitamin D3 supplementation or placebo for 4-6 weeks. The primary outcome will be the incidence of GDM based on the International Association of Diabetes and Pregnancy Study Groups Criteria after 75 g OGTT. The study will contribute to the understanding of the relationship between vitamin D and GDM risk through a well-designed RCT with integrated approaches. The findings may inform clinical practice and public health recommendations for vitamin D supplementation during pregnancy.

=================
The PERFORMANCE III study is a prospective, multicenter, single-arm, open label study to evaluate the safety and effectiveness of the Neuroguard IEP Direct System for the treatment of carotid artery stenosis in subjects at elevated risk for adverse events following carotid endarterectomy (CEA). The Neuroguard IEP Direct System is a 3-in-1 carotid stent delivery system consisting of an angioplasty balloon, an integrated embolic protection device and a nitinol self-expanding stent loaded over the balloon and constrained by an outer sheath. Eligible patients greater than or equal to 20 years of age and less than or equal to 80 years of age, are those who have been diagnosed with either de-novo atherosclerotic or post CEA restenotic lesion(s) in the internal carotid arteries (ICA) or at the carotid bifurcation with greater than or equal to 50% stenosis if symptomatic or greater than or equal to 70% stenosis if asymptomatic. Symptomatic subjects are defined as having stroke or transient ischemic attack (TIA) in the ipsilateral hemisphere supplied by the target vessel carotid lesion or ipsilateral transient monocular blindness (amaurosis fugax) within 180 days prior to the index procedure. Subjects will be followed for 30 days post index procedure with additional follow up for subjects having a stroke or cranial nerve injury.

=================

This is a pilot study that aims to test the feasibility and safety of a novel Nordic Walking (NW) activity program for community-dwelling older adults who are at risk of falling or experience fear of falling (FOF). The study will be conducted in two stages. Stage One will involve a two-arm, parallel, single-blind, randomized controlled pilot trial. Forty older adults at risk of falling will be recruited and randomly assigned to either a 10-week NW intervention group or a control group. The intervention group will receive supervised NW training sessions and will be coached to practice independently. The control group will receive regular phone calls to discuss healthy lifestyle habits. Outcome measures will include feasibility and safety data, as well as adverse events. Effectiveness outcomes will be assessed using measures such as the Timed Up and Go (TUG) test, Stay Independent Falls Risk Assessment Tool, Falls Efficacy Scale-International (FES-I), Activities-Specific Balance Confidence Scale, and the Four-Square Step Test (FSST). The study aims to recruit 40 participants (20 per group) to ensure study robustness and account for potential dropouts. Stage Two will involve qualitative interviews with all participants in the intervention group to gather feedback on the acceptability, perceived value, barriers, and facilitators of participating. The data will be analyzed using interpretive description to identify themes and categories.

The study aims to test the feasibility of an online intervention for SGM youth in the US. The intervention is designed to provide information and support for SGM youth, and to help them identify and connect with affirming caregivers. The study will recruit 100 SGM youth aged 13-25 years old from the US. Participants will be randomly assigned to one of three intervention arms: 1) Intersectionality and Identity, 2) Educational Tools, or 3) Finding Affirming Care. The study will use a mixed-methods design, including both quantitative and qualitative data collection methods. The primary outcome measure will be feasibility, including the proportion of IP components completed, the proportion of days IP is used, and the average length of time IP is used. Secondary outcome measures will include usability, acceptability of the intervention principle, help-seeking intention from counselor or therapist, perceived need for treatment, social support, anxiety, depression, mental health stigma, antidepressant outcome expectations, barriers to adolescents seeking help, depression and anxiety literacy, expectation of rejection due to SGM status, confidentiality concerns, receipt of any mental health treatment in the past 4 weeks, 12-item short form survey from the RAND Medical Outcomes Study, social isolation, internalized homophobia, and internalized transphobia.

The study is a randomized controlled trial (RCT) with a parallel assignment model. The primary purpose of the study is to support the clinical practice of fiber colonoscopy and analgesia. The study will be conducted on 100 patients who meet the inclusion criteria. The patients will be randomly assigned to either the controlled analgesia/sedation (PCAS) group or the intravenous combined anesthesia group. The PCAS group will receive a mixture of propofol and remifentanil, while the intravenous combined anesthesia group will receive fentanyl, midazolam, and propofol. The primary outcome measure will be the auditory evoked potential (AEPI), which will be recorded at 5 time points before anesthesia, at the beginning of the examination, during endoscopy to the splenic curvature, ileocecal region, and at the end of the examination. The secondary outcome measures will be the time from surgery to OAA/S score of 5 and Aldrete score of 9. The study will be conducted in accordance with the Declaration of Helsinki and will be approved by the Ethics Committee of the hospital.

=================

The study is a prospective, observational, confirmatory, single-center study in predicting the chronicization of radiation-induced acute intestinal injury based on the expression level of immune factors. The study will enroll 200 patients diagnosed with locally advanced rectal cancer who undergo NCRT and TME and develop RAII during NCRT or within 1 month. The primary outcome is the AUC of chronicization of RAII predicted by the prediction model. The secondary outcomes are accuracy, precision, specificity, and sensitivity of this prediction model in predicting chronicization of RAII. The study will follow up the occurrence and progression of radiation-induced intestinal injury within 1 year after TME. Expression levels of immune factors will be detected in pathological tissue after TME and applied to the prediction model to predict the chronicization of RAII.

The study aims to evaluate the safety and performance of the SEPIOLA System in patients with atrial fibrillation. The study is a single group assignment, open label study. The primary outcome measure is the safety of the device and investigational procedure related serious adverse events (SAE) occurring 7 days, 45 days and 6 months post procedure. The secondary outcome measure is the device success, which is the confirmation of functional LAA closure at 45 days post procedure. The study is designed for patients with a calculated CHA2DS2-VASc score of 2 or greater, who are non-eligible or have an appropriate rationale to seek a non-pharmacologic alternative to chronic oral anticoagulants. The study excludes patients who require anticoagulation for a condition other than AF, have a prosthetic valve in any position, atrial septal defect closure or have an ASD/PFO device, presence of intracardiac thrombus, any cardiac surgery in the past LVEF < 35%, intracardiac thrombus moderate or severe mitral valve stenosis. The study is designed for patients aged 18 years and above, and both sexes are eligible. The study is not accepting healthy volunteers. The study is a single center study. The study is designed for patients with atrial fibrillation who are suitable for vascular/cardiac intervention procedure suitable LAA anatomical measurements for study device.

The study aims to investigate the effectiveness of motivational interviewing (MI) in improving therapeutic alliance and treatment adherence in patients with acute psychosis. The study will be conducted as a randomized, parallel-group, double-blind study. Participants will be male and female patients from inpatient units of the Psychiatric University Hospital of Zurich with an ICD-10 diagnosis of psychosis (F2.x) and fluent in German and able to understand the instructions. The study will include two arms: an experimental group that will receive four sessions of MI and a control group that will receive four sessions of supportive conversations. The primary outcome measures will be change from baseline in therapeutic alliance on the Scale to Assess Therapeutic Relationship (STAR) and change from baseline in treatment adherence on the Brief Adherence Rating Scale (BARS). Secondary outcome measures will include change from baseline in symptom severity measured with the Positive and Negative Syndrome Scale (PANSS) and change from baseline in motivation for psychotherapy and self-efficacy on the Questionnaire to measure the motivation for psychotherapy and the General Self-Efficacy Scale, respectively. The study will be conducted in the acute phase of the illness and will be designed to test and evaluate psychotherapeutic interventions in the setting of an acute care unit.

=================

The study aims to evaluate the sensitivity and specificity of BileCAD, a new method for detecting chromosomal instability (CIN) in bile samples, for diagnosing biliary tract carcinoma (BTC). The study will recruit 100 BTC patients and 100 non-cancer participants. The extracted DNA from bile samples will be analyzed by BileCAD to determine the level of CIN. The primary outcome measures will be the sensitivity and specificity of bile sample analysis by BileCAD. The secondary outcome measures will be the consistency of BileCAD microbial analysis results with clinical microbial culture results and the sensitivity of BileCAD to different types and sites of malignant tumors. The study will be conducted over a period of 12 months.

The aim of this study was to evaluate the success of lumbar plexus block applied in lower extremity orthopedic surgeries using Near Infrared Spectroscopy (NIRS), which is used to measure tissue oxygenation. The study was designed as a single group assignment with open label masking. The primary outcome measure was the regional oxygen saturation (rSO2) measured by the NIRS device at 40 minutes. Secondary outcome measures included sensory block level, blood pressure values and fingertip SO2 measured by pulse oximetry. The study included patients with femoral neck fracture, femoral shaft fracture, and hip replacement surgery who will undergo lumbar plexus block. Exclusion criteria included BMI>40 kg/m2, infection in the block area, peripheral neuropathy, hemoglobinopathy, peripheral vascular disease, allergy to local anesthetics and patients with contraindications for lumbar plexus block.

The study aims to evaluate the use of a digital platform for supporting the clinical effectiveness and integration of task-shared care for schizophrenia in primary care in India. The study will build on important preliminary work led by project collaborators to support its aims to evaluate whether a novel digital platform can enhance the clinical effectiveness and integration of an evidence-based psychosocial rehabilitation intervention for patients with schizophrenia in primary care settings in India. The study will use a randomized controlled trial design with two arms: an experimental arm that will receive COPSI plus mindLAMP and a comparator arm that will receive COPSI alone. The primary outcome measure will be the Indian Disability Evaluation and Assessment Scale (IDEAS) and secondary outcome measures will include the Positive and Negative Syndrome Scale (PANSS), Generalized Anxiety Disorder Assessment-7 (GAD-7), Patient Health Questionnaire-9 (PHQ-9), Clinical Global Impression-Schizophrenia (CGI-SCH) Scale, and Brief Assessment of Cognition in Schizophrenia (BACS). The study will be conducted in India and will recruit 100 participants with a primary diagnosis of schizophrenia per IDC-10 diagnostic criteria for research and an illness duration of greater than 12 months and overall moderate level of severity on the CGI-SCH scale At least one risk factor for early mortality (e.g. hypertension, diabetes, dyslipidemia, etc) Willingness to stay in the study area during the trial period Ability to operate a smartphone. The study will be conducted over a period of 12 months.

===============

The study aims to investigate the characteristics of cytokine response in patients with Temporomandibular Disorders (TMD) treated with occlusal splint therapy. The study will include 60 participants diagnosed with myalgia, arthralgia, headache attributed to TMP and/or painful disk displacement (with and without reduction) according to axis I diagnostic criteria for temporomandibular disorders (DK/TMP). Participants will be treated with a stabilizing occlusal splint made of hard acrylate resin, about 1.5 mm thick in the posterior teeth area with an incisal plateau for canine guidance. The study will measure changes in cytokine levels in circulating blood and gingival crevicular fluid (GCF) after stabilization occlusal splint therapy, as well as changes in pain intensity, pain-related disability, oral health-related quality of life, perceived stress levels, jaw function limitation, depressed mood, anxious feelings and behavior, physical symptoms, and the presence of parafunctional behaviors. The study will use custom ProcartaPlex Multiplex assays for multicomplex quantitative analysis of inflammatory mediators. The study will be conducted in a single center and will be a prospective, interventional study.

12-week study of 3 levels of digital training (Level 1 - Digital tutorial only [T]; Level 2 - Tutorial & digital training materials for self-study [TM]; Level 3 - Tutorial, digital materials, feedback and coaching [TMC]) to establish feasibility, acceptability, and examine the effects of training on CRAFT knowledge, fidelity, and treatment entry and retention.

This is a prospective multi-center observational study that aims to describe the pattern of regional myocardial distribution of 3,3-diphosphono-1,2-propanedicarboxylic acid (DPD) SPECT uptake among patients with ATTRwt and ATTRm. The study will investigate the clinical, biochemical and echocardiographic, including left ventricle longitudinal strain profile in ATTRwt and ATTRm. Moreover, the presence and extent of DPD cardiac uptake among asymptomatic ATTRm variants carriers will be evaluated. The study will include consecutive patients who have Grade 1-3 cardiac DPD retention in scintigraphy and first-degree relatives of patients with ATTRm. The study will use 99mTc-DPD scintigraphy, planar scintigraphy, SPECT and speckle-tracking echocardiography to review and interpret the data. The collected data will be analyzed statistically to verify research hypotheses. The study will obtain approval from the local Bioethical Committee before carrying out the study. All procedures performed are going to be in accordance with the ethical standards of the 1964 Helsinki declaration and its later amendments, or comparable ethical standards.

The study aims to evaluate the effectiveness of treadmill perturbation training in preventing falls after total knee arthroplasty. Participants will be randomly assigned to either the training group or the education control group. The training group will undergo 21 disturbances of larger magnitude on a treadmill, while the education control group will receive written fall prevention materials. The primary outcome measure is the post-training trunk angle and angular velocity at recovery step completion. The secondary outcome measure is the fall rate during the first year after surgery.

=================

A phase 2, open-label, single-arm study of cadonilimab plus nab-paclitaxel in patients with persistent, recurrent or metastatic cervical cancer who have previously failed treatment with PD-1, PD-L1 or CTLA4 inhibitors. The primary objective is to evaluate the clinical activity (as assessed by objective response rate [ORR]) of cadonilimab and nab-paclitaxel combination. Secondary objectives include duration of response (DoR), disease control rate (DCR), time to response (TTR), progression-free survival (PFS), overall survival (OS), incidence of adverse events and health-related quality of life (HRQoL) assessed by EORTC QLQ-C30.

This is a single center, prospective, (1:1) randomized, unblinded, controlled study carried out in Germany to assess the visual performance of the trifocal Hanita Lenses Intensity SL IOL in comparison to the trifocal Alcon PanOptix IOL in bilaterally implanted patients. The study will examine the binocular distance-corrected visual acuity achieved with the study lens for the distance, intermediate and near ranges and compare it with the parameters achieved with the control lens. The study will be conducted in accordance with EN ISO 14155:2020 Clinical Investigation of Medical Devices for Human Subjects, EN ISO 11979-7:2018 Clinical investigations of intraocular lenses for the correction of aphakia, EU MDR 2017/745, MEDDEV 2.7.1 rev. 4 Clinical Evaluation: A Guide for Manufacturers and Notified Bodies, MPDG:2020: Medical Device Law Implementation Act, as well as applicable local regulations and the Declaration of Helsinki.

The study is a retrospective, observational, single-centre, cohort database analysis of the haemodynamic effects of low-dose spinal anaesthesia for hip fracture surgery. The study aims to determine whether lower doses of spinal anaesthesia are linked with a lower rate of low blood pressure during surgery. The study will compare crude vital signs data from the Brighton Hip Fracture Database to published national data from the ASAP 1 study. The study will determine whether prevalence (and/or depth+duration of hypotension) are correlated with outcomes (survival, length of inpatient stay) after hip fracture repair. The study will include adult patients (over 18 years) who have sustained a unilateral hip fracture and received surgery (hemiarthroplasty, dynamic hip screw, cortical screws, proximal femoral nail) under low dose spinal anaesthesia (1.3 mls 0.5% hyperbaric bupivacaine) after fascia iliaca block + sedation, administered by the Chief Investigator (CI) between 3rd March, 2017 and 1st January, 2020 at the Princess Royal Hospital, Hayward's Heath (E Sussex). The study will measure the cohort mean (SD) mean non-invasive blood pressure (MAP) taken at 2 minute intervals peri-operatively for each patient during the 2 hour duration (approximately) of anaesthesia and surgery for each patient. The study will also measure the cohort prevalence of hypotension, variably defined as: Fall in systolic blood pressure (SBP) from baseline > 20%; Fall in systolic blood pressure (SBP) from baseline > 30%; Fall in mean arterial pressure (MAP) from baseline > 20%; Fall in mean arterial pressure (MAP) from baseline > 30%; Lowest SBP < 90 millimetres of mercury (mmHg); Lowest SBP < 100 mmHg Lowest MAP < 70 mmHg; Lowest MAP < 55 mmHg. COVID-19 Transmission and Morbidity in Malawi is a study that aims to investigate the hypothesis that malaria and intestinal parasitic diseases may result in enhanced or tolerogenic innate immune responses that decrease the risk of symptomatic COVID-19. The study will enroll up to 200 symptomatic individuals (index cases) and their household contacts (anticipated 700) and up to 600 vaccinees. The study will assess the innate immune phenotypes that differentiate uninfected Malawians from Western controls and whether those responses are protecting Malawians from infection and/or progression of disease. The study will follow the participants for up to 1.5 years to assess the acquisition and longevity of antibody responses and memory B cells.

The experimental group will receive hot and cold application to the bladder, while the control group will receive routine clinical functioning. The primary outcome measure is the prevention of postoperative urinary retention by applying hot and cold to the bladder. The study will be conducted in the first 6 hours of the postoperative period. The study aims to evaluate the sensitivity and specificity of the deep-learning integrated model established with relevant clinical factors and radiomic features based on the high concentration (370 mgI/ml) Iopromide-enhanced pancreatic CT obtained within 14 days after the first onset of symptoms for quantitative prediction of (the first) recurrence of acute pancreatitis in 12 months follow-up period. The study is a prospective, multicenter study. The study will enroll 694 consecutive eligible patients with first episode of acute pancreatitis that recommended for iopromide 370 mgI/ml enhanced pancreatic CT scan within 14 days after onset of symptoms. The study will follow up the subjects for 12 months and divide them into recurrent group and non-recurrent group according to the first recurrence status. The study will measure the sensitivity and specificity of the model established with relevant clinical factors and radiomic features to quantitative predict the first recurrence of acute pancreatitis in 12 months follow-up period. The study will also measure the sensitivity and specificity of the deep-learning integrated model established with relevant clinical factors and radiomic features to quantitative predict overall recurrence of acute pancreatitis in 3 and 6 months follow-up period. The study will also measure the sensitivity and specificity of the model determined by radiomics features extracted from images with high quality scores (2-3 points). The study will also measure the sensitivity and specificity of the radiomics features in predicting (the first) recurrence of different types and severities of acute pancreatitis at 3, 6 and 12 months.

The study aims to compare the change in hematocrit in blood patients between the patients allocated to CPAP group and the control group over 12 months. The study will be conducted in a randomized, parallel assignment, open label design. The study will include 100 patients with polycythemia and moderate or severe sleep apnea. The intervention will consist of CPAP treatment plus diet and conventional pharmacological treatment. The primary outcome measure will be the change from baseline of hematocrit. Secondary outcome measures will include the change from baseline of hemoglobin, change from baseline in the health-related quality of life assessed by the Euroqol-5, relationship between hypoxic burden and hemoglobin and hematocrit, and change from baseline in sleepiness assessed by the Epworth scale. The study will be conducted over 12 months.

=============

The study aims to compare the vaginal axis in patients undergoing apical prolapse surgery, whether they have undergone hysterectomy or not. The investigation is designed to test the null hypothesis by means of a comparative analysis of preoperative and postoperative Magnetic Resonance Imaging images capturing the vaginal axis. This examination will be conducted on patients slated to receive lateral mesh suspension, pectopexy, and sacrospinous ligament fixation procedures for the correction of apical prolapse. The study will measure the vaginal axis, vaginal distances, prolapse symptoms, urinary symptoms, postoperative de novo dyspareunia, sexual functions, and quality of life measures. The study will be conducted on 100 patients, 50 in each arm. The study will be conducted over a period of 4 months.

=============

The study aims to evaluate the effectiveness of a simulation teaching method in electronic fetal monitoring management for midwifery students. The study is a randomized controlled trial with a parallel assignment intervention model. The experimental group receives simulation training in electronic fetal monitor management, while the control group receives theory training. The primary outcome measures are information evaluation form, student satisfaction and self-confidence scale in learning, and self-efficacy scale in monitoring and management of electronic fetal monitoring. The secondary outcome measures are simulation design scale. The study is designed to measure the effectiveness of the simulation teaching method in improving the knowledge, satisfaction, and self-efficacy of midwifery students in electronic fetal monitoring management.

The study aims to investigate the outcome and predictors of mortality of patients on prolonged mechanical ventilation in critically ill patients. The study will be conducted in Dessie Comprehensive Specialized Hospital from August 2023 to January 2024. A retrospective cohort study will be conducted. Data will be checked, coded, entered, and analyzed using SPSS version 22 software. Descriptive statistics will be used to summarize data, tables, and figures for display results. Bivariate and multivariate analyses will be used to see the effect of the independent variable on the outcome variable. Variables that are significant on bivariate analysis at a p-value less than 0.2 will be taken to multivariate analysis. In multivariate analysis, a p-value of less than 0.05 will be used as a cut-off point for the presence of association. The strength of the association will be measured by 95% confidence interval and odd ratio. The primary outcome measure is the clinical outcome of critically ill patients undergoing prolonged mechanical ventilation. The Tailoring Bleeding Reduction Approaches in Patients Undergoing PCI trial is a randomized, prospective study comparing two strategies for reducing bleeding complications in patients undergoing PCI: DAPT de-escalation and potent P2Y12 inhibitor monotherapy. The study aims to assess the pharmacodynamic effects of these two strategies on thrombus formation, as measured by the Total Thrombus formation Analysis System (T-TAS). Eligible participants must have been on maintenance treatment with DAPT for at least 30 days and must not have a history of stent thrombosis or severe hepatic impairment. The study will measure the area under the curve (AUC) determined by T-TAS at 30 days post-intervention. The primary outcome measure is the comparison of the AUC between the two strategies.

The study aims to investigate the age-dependent effects of egg intake on HDL and immune profiles. The study is a randomized crossover trial with three arms: egg whites, egg yolks, and whole eggs. Participants are 18-30 years old or 60-70 years old and have a BMI < 30 kg/m2. The study measures the change in serum concentration of large HDL particles between diet periods. The study is designed to investigate the effects of egg intake on immune profiles, but the results are not reported in the document.

=========

The study aims to evaluate the effectiveness of a patient-driven augmented reality-based rehabilitation system, MyoTrain AR, in improving upper limb amputee outcomes. The study will recruit 20 participants with trans-radial unilateral limb loss who are candidates for a 2+ degree-of-freedom (DoF) myoelectric pattern recognition prosthesis. Participants will be randomly assigned to either the experimental group, which will undergo functional task training using the MyoTrain AR system, or the active comparator group, which will receive motor imagery exercises. The primary outcome measures will be the mean completion time and relative grasp duration of the GaMA Cup Transfer Task on Day 35. Secondary outcome measures will include the Assessment of Capacity for Myoelectric Controls (ACMC) and the completion rate and wrist activation of the GaMA Cup Transfer Task.

The study is a prospective, double-blinded, randomized controlled trial. The study aims to evaluate the efficacy of Gastric electric pacemaker as a treatment of postoperative ileus following extensive surgery. The study includes 100 patients who are planned for elective cytoreductive surgery with or without heated intraperitoneal chemotherapy due to either colorectal or appendiceal cancer or with peritoneal metastases or due to pseudomyxoma peritonei. The study is designed to measure the time from surgery till first stool, whole gut and regional transit times, length of hospital stay, medical and surgical complications, need for surgical or radiological interventions, re-hospitalization within 30 days, time till initiation of postoperative systemic adjuvant chemotherapy, if indicated, and 90-day mortality. The study is conducted in accordance with the Declaration of Helsinki and has been approved by the Ethics Committee of the University Hospital of Cologne.

The study is a randomized controlled trial that aims to evaluate the effect of aromatherapy and music therapy on pain, anxiety, and vital parameters in patients with cancer. The study includes four groups: music group, aromatherapy group, music and aromatherapy group, and control group. The music group listens to specially composed music with headphones for 20 minutes for three consecutive days, while the aromatherapy group uses 5% lavender oil with a diffuser for 15-20 minutes. The study measures pain, anxiety, and vital parameters using the Visual Analog Scale, Facial Anxiety Scale, Distress Thermometer, and Edmonton Symptom Diagnostic Scale. The study is conducted in a palliative care service and includes inpatients.

The Somatosensation Device Trial is a non-randomized crossover study that tests the effectiveness of the Somatosensation Device in enhancing feedback in lower extremities for individuals with amputation or neuropathy. The study measures the Functional Gait Assessment, 10 Meter Walk Test, Mini-BESTest, Activities Specific Balance Confidence Scale, and Vestibular Disorders Activities of Daily Living Scale. Participants will perform all outcome measures without wearing the somatosensation device at baseline and while wearing the device during the intervention. The study is open to individuals aged 18-65 years with a below-knee amputation or neuropathy in their lower limbs, able to wear the somatosensation device and test equipment, and able to follow simple directions. Exclusion criteria include history of severe back or knee pain in the last 3 months, inability to walk for 3 minutes with or without an assistive device, poor skin integrity, and severe vertigo or balance disorders.

This is a decentralized clinical trial that uses technology and virtual meetings to communicate with study participants and collect study data. The study seeks to enroll until 36 participants in the MoW arm have completed the study, and until 72 participants have completed the QoL arm. Participants will complete a one day enrollment meeting and an approximately 14 day Baseline Phase. After the Baseline Phase participants will be randomized within their assigned group (MoW or QoL) at a 2:1 ratio to an active arm or sham arm to begin the Treatment Phase of the study. Participants will be sent a study device to use when they have a vertigo episode. Participants that enroll in the study are expected to participate up to 49 days with virtual meetings at the approximate intervals: MoW Group: Day 21, Day 24, Day 31, and Day 42 QoL Group : Day 16, Day, 24, Day 36, and Day 49 Participants will be required to complete the DHI (Dizziness Handicap Inventory), VSS (Vertigo Symptom Scale), Global Impression of Symptoms, and Global Impression of Change questionnaires. The study is a randomized controlled trial that aims to evaluate the effectiveness of the multistrain probiotic OMNi-BiOTiC® Active in preventing upper respiratory tract infections (URTIs) in older people. The study will recruit 100 participants aged 65 years or older who are able to eat independently and adhere to all procedures of the clinical study. Participants will be randomly assigned to either the experimental group, which will receive the multistrain probiotic OMNi-BiOTiC® Active, or the placebo group, which will receive a rice starch, maltodextrin, plant protein, potassium chloride, magnesium sulphate, manganese sulphate placebo. The study will last for 12 weeks, and the primary outcome measure will be the incidence of URTIs in both arms. Secondary outcome measures will include the duration of URTIs and changes in the concentration of leukocytes, neutrophils segm., lymphocytes, monocytes, eosinophils, basophils in serum, as well as changes in the concentration of immunoglobulin A (IgA) in serum. The study will be conducted in accordance with the Declaration of Helsinki and will be approved by the Ethics Committee of the University of Zagreb School of Medicine.

This is a phase 3 clinical trial that compares the efficacy and safety of disitamab vedotin in combination with pembrolizumab versus standard of care chemotherapy in patients with previously untreated locally advanced or metastatic urothelial carcinoma that expresses HER2. The study is open-label and randomized, with participants being randomly assigned to either the disitamab vedotin arm or the standard of care arm. The primary outcome measures are progression-free survival (PFS) and overall survival (OS), while secondary outcome measures include objective response rate (ORR), duration of response (DOR), control rate (DCR), and adverse events. The study is expected to run for approximately 3 years, with participants being followed for up to 5 years.

This is a double-blinded randomized controlled trial (RCT) to study the effect of lactoferrin versus placebo in improving clinical outcomes in ICU patients. The study will be conducted in Mansoura University Hospital, Egypt. The study will include 650 patients (325 in each study group) who will be randomly assigned to either lactoferrin or placebo. The intervention will be given for 28 days. The primary outcome will be 28-day mortality rate. Secondary outcomes will include incidence of hypersensitivity reactions, need for invasive mechanical ventilation, oxygen support duration, and duration of ICU stay. The study will be conducted in accordance with the Declaration of Helsinki and will be approved by the Institutional Review Board (IRB) of Mansoura University.

=========

A 10-week randomized double-blinded crossover trial of BiOkuris® chitin-glucan based formulation versus placebo in patients with Crohn's disease in remission and having Irritable Bowel Syndrome-like symptoms. The study will recruit 50 patients aged from 18 years to 75 years, who are long-standing steroid-free clinical remission Crohn's disease according to clinical and biochemical assessments, clinically remission, absence of inflammatory markers at V1, presence of IBS-like symptoms according to Rome IV criteria, Likert scale ≥ 3 for abdominal pain at V0, patient with correct and complete reporting of the study questionnaires and scores during the run-in period (≥ 75% completion), to continue all medication used in the last month before inclusion at the same dosage, anti-spasmodic, hypomotility agents, probiotics, prebiotics, bile-acid chelators, and anti-depressants are authorized if consumed for longer than 1 month before inclusion and maintained at a stable dosage for the entire study duration, agreeing to maintain their lifestyle behaviours during the participation in the study, patient has read, understood, and signed the informed consent form (ICF), patient capable of communicating with the investigator, replying to the questionnaires, and understanding the requirements and constraints of the study protocol, possessing a digital device (i.e., smartphone or tablet), patient willing to adhere to the study visit schedule and able to understand and comply with protocol requirements and product administration, male or female patient of childbearing potential who agrees to use acceptable methods of birth control (oral, transdermal, systemic contraception, intrauterine device, condom) for the duration of the study, patient can read and write in French. The primary outcome measure is subject's global assessment (SGA) and the secondary outcome measures are individual symptoms, stool consistency and dyschesia, stool number, IBS-related quality of life, anxiety and depression, serum CRp & fecal calprotectine, and adverse events. The study will consist of a 2 to 3-week run-in period, then patients will take either placebo or B

=========

The study aims to develop a novel biomarker for response and prognosis of HBV-related HCC patients undergoing RT. The investigators will use previously collected serum samples and surgical/biopsied tissues from HBV-related HCC patients undergoing radiotherapy. The consistency of junctional clones by Capture NGS needs to be tested between both pre- and post-RT serums, and serial changes in copy numbers of vh-DNA by ddPCR are quantified in the representative cases. The same junction clones from pre-post-RT serums and surgical tissues will be confirmed and the copy number changes of vh-DNA be correlated with RT response and disease-control status. The investigators plan to identify HBV integrations by Capture NGS and quantify the specific vh-DNA by ddPCR as personalized biomarkers from the same-patient serum samples. The investigators will further correlate clinical response and recurrence/metastasis with serial changes of vh-DNA copy numbers. The investigators have been prospectively collecting plasma samples from HBV-related HCC patients before/after RT, at 1, 4, 7 months, and at recurrence/metastasis. The investigators plan to confirm the viable role of pre-/post-RT changes of plasma vh-DNA copies of the same junction clone in post-RT response and prognosis. Moreover, The investigators will explore the recurrent/metastatic tumors arising from the original or a de novo one by identifying their clonality with HBV integration patterns. The true value of this novel HBV chimera vh-DNA will be revealed. The results will also support the consolidative use of personalized vh-DNA for earlier evaluating treatment response after RT, for post-RT disease monitoring, and for differentiating clonality at recurrence to design future clinical trial on combinational treatment.

The study aims to test the effectiveness of an online individual intervention program in improving the meaning in life and psychological health of women with breast cancer. The program is based on the Meaning-Making Model and principles of meaning therapy. The study uses a randomized controlled design with a waitlist control group. The primary outcome measures include the Meaning in Life Questionnaire, Posttraumatic Growth Inventory-X, Stress Appraisal Measure, Global Meaning Violations Scale, Impact of Event Scale-Revised, Acceptance and Action Scale-II, and Hospital Anxiety and Depression Scale. The study has been approved by the Institutional Ethics Committee of Dokuz Eylül University. Participants were recruited through social media platforms, oncology associations, and healthcare professionals. The sample size was determined using the power analysis method, and 44 women diagnosed with breast cancer were randomly assigned to either the intervention group or the waitlist control group. The intervention group received eight individual sessions of the Meaning-Centered Coping Program over a period of one week. The study found that the intervention group showed significant improvements in meaning in life, posttraumatic growth, stress appraisal, global meaning violations, intrusion and avoidance, psychological flexibility, and psychological distress compared to the waitlist control group. The study suggests that online individual intervention programs can be an effective tool in improving the psychological health and meaning in life of women with breast cancer.

=============

The study aims to investigate the nutritional intake, nutritional status, and physical activity level in people who have undergone a major dysvascular lower limb amputation (LLA) and their association with clinical outcomes. The study will be conducted in four time points: during hospital admission 2 to 10 days post-LLA, at 5 weeks post-LLA, at 6 months post-LLA, and at 9 months post-LLA. The study will measure nutritional intake, diet quality, nutritional status, muscle mass, muscle strength, body mass index, physical activity level, and quality of life. The primary outcome measures will be nutritional intake, diet quality, nutritional status, muscle mass, muscle strength, body mass index, and physical activity level. The secondary outcome measures will be mortality, wound healing, quality of life, K-level, and 6-minute walk test. The study will use a cross-sectional design with no intervention. Eligible participants will be 18 years or older who have undergone a major dysvascular LLA. The study will exclude participants with severe malabsorption disease or requiring re-amputation.

This study aims to assess the feasibility of conducting a remote clinical trial in patients with type 2 diabetes and albuminuria. The study will evaluate the feasibility of remote urine collection, blood pressure, and body weight measurements, as well as the adherence to treatment. The study will also assess the individual response to empagliflozin and the potential additive effects of finerenone on albuminuria, blood pressure, body weight, eGFR, and fasting plasma glucose. The study will be conducted in a decentralized manner, with participants collecting their own urine samples and measuring their own blood pressure and body weight at home. The study will be conducted in accordance with the Declaration of Helsinki and will be approved by the Ethics Committee of Centre Hospitalier Valida.

### Study Design

**Design Type:** Randomized Controlled Trial (RCT)

**Study Duration:** 6 months

**Study Start Date:** 01-JAN-2023

**Study End Date:** 31-DEC-2023

### Study Objectives

Primary Objective:

To assess the feasibility of conducting a remote clinical trial in patients with type 2 diabetes and albuminuria.

Secondary Objectives:

1. To evaluate the feasibility of remote urine collection, blood pressure, and body weight measurements.
2. To assess the adherence to treatment.
3. To assess the individual response to empagliflozin.
4. To evaluate the potential additive effects of finerenone on albuminuria, blood pressure, body weight, eGFR, and fasting plasma glucose.

### Study Population

**Inclusion Criteria:**

1. Diagnosis of type 2 diabetes.
2. Albuminuria (UACR ≥30 mg/g or UACR ≥40 mg/g and eGFR ≥60 mL/min/1.73m2).
3. Stable on an SGLT2 inhibitor or an MRA for at least 3 months prior to study entry.
4. Able to understand and comply with the study protocol.
5. Able to provide informed consent.

**Exclusion Criteria:**
