The study aims to examine the implementation strategy, in terms of feasibility and the possible benefits, of a free online Zoom t'ai chi and qigong gentle movement and meditation program to reduce back pain and improve quality of life among those with chronic back pain. The primary objective of this study is to examine whether a safe and moderate online t'ai chi and qigong exercise program, offered without cost to individuals with chronic back pain, improves pain levels, sleep, and quality of life; The secondary objective is to explore whether improvements in pain levels are different among smokers and those with unhealthy BMI than among others. The study will be a prospective, randomized controlled trial with two groups: a t'ai chi and qigong exercise (treatment) group and a waitlist control group. The treatment group started the t'ai chi and qigong classes in September 2022; the waitlist control group was offered instruction beginning in January 2023. The study will use previously validated, self-administered survey instruments to assess the primary outcome of low back pain, as well as associated outcomes of sleep and quality of life, including the Oswestry Disability Index, the Visual Analog Scale for Back and Leg Pain, the SF-36, Short Form Health Survey questionnaire, and the 19-Item Pittsburgh Sleep Quality Index. A maximum of 300 people with chronic low back pain will be selected to participate in the program on a first-come basis. The study will include a minimum of 200 total recruited participants, which, accounting for possible attrition, will result in a minimum of 50 participants in each study group, enough to statistically analyze the primary outcome of pain alleviation (see Sample Size and Power below). At the completion of the intervention/study, 25 qualitative interviews will be conducted to assess the barriers and facilitators related to implementing the online T'ai Chi and Qigong intervention.

The EMBOL-AF is a multicenter, international, observational study designed as a retrospective registry that will investigate the characteristics of systemic arterial embolic events after treatment of atrial fibrillation by catheter ablation. The study will gather all clinically relevant aspects and data of all cases of arterial embolism that have occurred over the last 5 years in the centers that will participate in the registry. Based on these reported cases, the incidence, management and outcomes of embolic events (particularly stroke and TIA) will be studied. The primary objectives are to study the acute clinical profile, symptoms, signs and results of image techniques of stroke/TIA associated to AFAbl (or technically akin procedures such as left atrial macroreentry mapping and ablation), the acute therapeutic management of these events and the sequelae and clinical consequences at 3 months of follow-up. The secondary objectives are to study whether the risk of stroke/TIA is more frequently associated to any AFAbl technique, whether the severity of stroke/TIA is associated to any specific AFAbl technique and whether other measures associated with AFAbl procedures have any impact on the incidence and severity of stroke/TIA. The study will be conducted in accordance with the ethical standards as laid down in the 1964 Declaration of Helsinki and its later amendments.

=============

This is a randomized controlled clinical trial that aims to evaluate the effectiveness of electrical stimulation in accelerating the en-masse retraction of upper anterior teeth. The study will include 60 participants with class II malocclusion, division 1, who will be randomly assigned to either the experimental group (electrical stimulation) or the active comparator group (traditional retraction). The primary outcome measures will be changes in the perception of pain, discomfort, burning, and swelling, while the secondary outcome measures will include changes in chewing ability, speech ability, analgesic consumption, patients' satisfaction, ease of the procedure, the possibility of repeating the procedure, and recommendation of the procedure to a friend. The study will be conducted over a period of five months, with assessments at the 1st, 3rd, and 7th day of the first, second, and third months from the beginning of the en-masse retraction of upper anterior teeth.

===============

This is a single-site, non-randomized prospective observational study of men with prostate cancer. The primary objective is to evaluate whether baseline plasma Amyloid-beta 42/40 (Aβ42/40) ratio is associated with cognitive decline in men upon starting ADT. The secondary objective is to evaluate whether ADT is associated with a decline in plasma Aβ42/40 ratio. The study will also evaluate whether intensified ADT (iADT) receipt is associated with greater cognitive decline compared to ADT. The study will recruit 100 participants with prostate cancer who are starting ADT and 100 participants in remission from prostate cancer who have never received ADT. Participants will undergo cognitive assessments and blood-based assays for Aβ42/40 ratio at baseline and at 12 months. The study will measure the proportion of participants with cognitive decline, mean cognitive decline, and proportion of participants with cognitive impairment after ADT. The study will also measure change in mean plasma Aβ42/40 ratio, mean cognition score, and mean study partner-reported cognition score.

===============

The HI-DOCC trial is a multicenter, parallel-arm, double-blind, randomized controlled trial comparing high-dose (1000 mg QID) cephalexin to standard-dose (500 mg QID) cephalexin to treat adult patients with non-purulent cellulitis. The primary outcome is outpatient oral antibiotic treatment failure, defined as a change in antibiotic (change in class of oral antibiotic or step up to IV therapy) within 7 days due to worsening infection. Secondary outcomes include clinical cure, clinical response, unplanned visits to a healthcare provider, unplanned hospitalization, adverse events, antibiotic intolerance, antibiotic allergy, medication adherence, and health-related quality of life. The study will be conducted at 8 Canadian EDs and will require a total sample size of 446 patients (223 per group). If high-dose cephalexin is found to be superior to standard-dose cephalexin, this will change practice, with the potential to reduce unnecessary IV antibiotic use, hospitalization, and costs.

=============

This study aims to determine the Turkish validity and reliability of the Health Literacy Scale for Acute Complications of Type 1 Diabetes for Children (8-12 Years) and to provide a diabetes health literacy box game to 8-12 school age children diagnosed with Type 1 diabetes. The study will be conducted in two stages, with the first stage involving a general screening methodological method to determine the current situation, and the second stage involving a randomized controlled study to evaluate the effect of educational games on acute complications of diabetes and health literacy in children. The study will use the Health Literacy Scale for Acute Complications of Type 1 Diabetes for Children (8-12 Years) to measure the health literacy of children with type 1 diabetes aged 8-12 years. The study will use a randomized controlled design, with the experimental group receiving the diabetes health literacy board game and the control group receiving no intervention. The study will measure the validity and reliability of the Health Literacy Scale for Acute Complications of Type 1 Diabetes for Children (8-12 Years) in Turkish and evaluate the effect of the diabetes health literacy board game on acute complications of diabetes and health literacy in children. The study will be conducted over a 6-month period, with data collection forms filled out at baseline, 4 weeks, and 12 weeks after randomization. The study will use the Social Learning Theory to explain the effect of the diabetes health literacy board game on acute complications of diabetes and health literacy in children. The study will use the Board Game as an intervention model. The study will use the Health Literacy Scale for Acute Complications of Type 1 Diabetes for Children (8-12 Years) as the primary outcome measure. This is a randomized controlled clinical trial comparing the biofilm accumulation on zirconia versus titanium implants. The study will be conducted in the Master of Oral Surgery and Implantology of the Faculty of Dentistry of the Complutense University of Madrid (Spain). The selection of subjects will be based on a previous oral and radiological examination and a clinical questionnaire. For implant placement, a linear incision of the edentulous ridge and an intrasulcular incision of the adjacent teeth will be made, and a full-thickness flap will be raised. Once the implant is in place, simple stitches with supramid monofilament 4/0 suture will be placed until the wound is closed. The final screw-retained metal-ceramic crown will be loaded with a transepithelial abutment made of titanium for titanium implants or zirconia for zirconia implants. The study will be conducted for 12 months, and the primary outcome measure will be the total amount of biofilm on implants placed prior to crown placement, at 6 months and 1 year after final crown placement. The study will be conducted in accordance with the principles established by the Declaration of Helsinki and will be conducted under the approval of the Clinical Trials Committee of the Hospital Clínico San Carlos of Madrid.

The study will be conducted in a randomized controlled trial design. The study will have two arms: a control group with no interference before dental anesthesia and extraction and an active comparator group with two interventions: rosemary and lemongrass oil. The primary outcome measures will be measuring pulse rate, oxygen saturation, blood pressure, and pain level using the Wong-Baker Scale. The study aims to investigate the effect of crossword puzzles on nursing students' learning concepts related to vital signs. The study will be conducted with first-year nursing students of Bilecik Şeyh Edebali University Nursing Department. The students will be randomly assigned to either the experimental group or the control group. The experimental group will apply puzzles for two weeks, while the control group will be educated only during the normal course. The primary outcome measure will be students' knowledge test successes. The study will be conducted for five weeks.

This is a randomized split-face trial comparing the efficacy of Potassium-titanyl Phosphate (KTP) laser combined with Ivermectin 1% cream to KTP laser alone for the treatment of facial rosacea. The study includes 40 participants with Fitzpatrick skin type I-IV and mild to moderate erythematous rosacea or papulopustular rosacea with permanent erythema. Participants are randomly assigned to receive KTP laser and ivermectin 1% cream on one side of the face and KTP laser alone on the other side. The primary outcome measure is the efficacy of laser and cream vs laser alone in reducing erythema as assessed by the Normalized Erythema Index (NEI). Secondary outcome measures include the efficacy of laser and cream vs laser alone in reducing erythema as assessed by the Skin Redness Index (SRI) and Clinical Erythema Assessment (CEA), as well as the efficacy of laser and cream vs laser alone in the clinical improvement of skin lesions as assessed by the 6-point Physician Global Assessment (PGA) and patient's satisfaction related to the improvement of skin lesions as assessed by a 9-point anchored visual analogue scale (VAS). The study is expected to last 16 weeks, with assessments at 4, 8, 12, and 16 weeks.

The study is a retrospective review of a large cohort of FDG PET data in patients with neurodegenerative diseases and head trauma. The study aims to identify the regions of altered brain function specific for each clinical condition. The study measures the brain areas of hypo or hyper regional metabolism in patients with neurodegenerative disease. The study is designed to characterize the different pathologies examined starting from the study of regional metabolism in individual subjects up to the study of the functional activity of the different brain circuits. The study is conducted over a period of 4 years.

This is a prospective, longitudinal cohort study in people with Cystic Fibrosis (pwCF) that involves the repeated serial sampling of participants. The study will be conducted at participating CF centers over a 3-year period. Study participants will include pediatric and adult pwCF. For the UK section of the study, UK investigators in the European Cystic Fibrosis Society-Clinical Trials Network (ECFS-CTN) will be invited to participate. Participating investigators can enroll all eligible pwCF over a 12-month period. Participants are then followed up for 24 months. Participants will donate blood samples at their routine clinic visits. Blood samples will be collected at Day 0 (baseline), at Months 6, 12, 18, and 24 (to coincide with routine clinical reviews). Additional blood samples will be taken opportunistically every time the participant visits the clinic for blood draws. Serum from blood samples will be shipped to a central laboratory (Queen's University Belfast) for standardized measurement of SARS-CoV-2 antibodies. Alongside the blood samples, the investigators will also collect clinical data from the patient's health records and will input this data into the case report form (CRF). Clinical data will be collected in conjunction with routine care visits, according to local clinical practice. Investigators will collect data elements from information routinely recorded in the patient's medical records. Data will be collected at baseline, months 6, 12, 18, and 24 as per the study schedule, and at additional blood sampling time points as previously explained above. Data collection will include routine data available from CF clinic follow-ups including background demographic information, CF medical history, medications, exacerbation information, sputum microbiology, and clinical and lung function parameters. Information on SARS-CoV-2 infection history and vaccine receipt will also be collected. The maximum follow-up duration of participation in the study for each patient will be 24 months. This study duration (24-month follow-up) is justified as it provides sufficient time to observe changes in antibody prevalence over the course of the COVID-19 pandemic as well as sufficient time to determine long-term clinical outcomes for pwCF who are S

The study aims to evaluate the use and reproducibility of duplex ultrasound to provide indices of left common iliac vein diameter in patients presenting with unexplained left leg swelling. The study will be conducted in two groups: symptomatic and asymptomatic. The primary outcome measure will be the left common iliac vein diameter measurement in mm, while the secondary outcome measure will be the inter- and intra-operator variation of the diameter measurement of the left common iliac vein. The study will be conducted over a period of 6 months.

The Health-Related Quality of Life of the Patients With Symptomatic Convergence Insufficiency

The Health-Related Quality of Life of the Patients With Symptomatic Convergence Insufficiency is a study that aims to evaluate the health-related quality of life of patients with symptomatic convergence insufficiency. The study is a randomized controlled trial that compares the health-related quality of life of patients who received visual training with those who did not receive visual training. The study is designed to measure the changes in EuroQol five dimensions questionnaire(EQ-5D-5L) score and shortForm 6D(SF-6D) questionnaire score between baseline and 3 months. The study is conducted in patients aged 8-15 years old with monocular best corrected visual acuity at distance and near was more than 0.8, near exophoria 4Δ greater than distance exophoria, NPC ≥ 6cm, PFV ≤15△BO, stereogram ≤500 '', Score of CISS questionnaire ≥16 or COVD questionnaire≥20, and other diseases except myopia. The study is conducted in two arms: a training group and a not training group. The training group receives visual training in hospital, while the not training group does not receive visual training. The study is conducted in patients with symptomatic convergence insufficiency.

The study aims to compare the detection rate of SLNs using ICG dye vs blue dye for sentinel lymph node mapping in patients with early-stage SCC of the vulva. The study will use a mixed-effects logistic regression model to account for the clustering effect and assess the significance of dye type using the Wald test or likelihood ratio test. The study will also report the sensitivity, specificity, and negative predictive value of ICG dye vs standard blue dye. The study will be conducted at Tufts Medical Center.

The study will be conducted in a single-center, randomized, controlled, and blinded study design. The study will enroll 100 patients with early-stage SCC of the vulva who are planned for surgery at Tufts Medical Center. The patients will be randomly assigned to either the ICG dye group or the blue dye group. The study will be conducted in two phases. In phase 1, the study will assess the feasibility of the study design and the safety of the study. In phase 2, the study will assess the primary outcome measure, which is the detection rate of SLNs using ICG dye vs blue dye for sentinel lymph node mapping. The study will also assess the secondary outcome measures, which are the sensitivity, specificity, and negative predictive value of ICG dye vs standard blue dye.

The study will use a mixed-effects logistic regression model to account for the clustering effect and assess the significance of dye type using the Wald test or likelihood ratio test. The study will also use a 2x2 contingency table for sensitivity, specificity, and negative predictive value. The study will be conducted in a single-center, randomized, controlled, and blinded study design. The study will enroll 100 patients with early-stage SCC of the vulva who are planned for surgery at Tufts Medical Center. This is a crossover, experimental, randomized, double-blind trial composed of apparently healthy participants. The objective is to compare the effects of different NMES protocols applied to the triceps surae muscle for evoked torque, muscle fatigue, sensory discomfort, and peripheral oxygen extraction. The effects of the types of neuromuscular electrical stimulation (NMES) protocols on the aforementioned outcomes will be evaluated in the same participant by randomizing the sequences of interventions for each visit in the laboratory. The study is considered double-blind, as individuals will not know the sequence of the protocols applied. The evaluator will also not know which protocol will be used at the time of the intervention. It will consist of a total of 5 sessions with seven days between them. In the first session, anthropometry, the maximum intensity level for each electrical stimulation protocol as well as the protocol sequence for each individual will be evaluated. From the second to the fifth session, the following will be considered: voluntary and evoked maximum joint torque of the triceps surae muscle, muscle fatigue through the evaluation of the H-reflex, M-wave, fatigue index, torque-time-integral and recruitment curve, peripheral oxygen extraction, electromyographic signals through RMS (root mean square) and median frequency, and level of sensory discomfort with the Visual Analog Scale (VAS). From the second to the fifth session will be composed by the following evaluation sequence: warm-up with six submaximal contractions with 6 seconds of duration and 10 seconds of rest between them; then the assessment of muscle fatigue; then two maximal isometric contractions, then two maximal evoked contractions; fatigue protocol at 20% of the maximum isometric contraction (this fatigue protocol will use the NMES sequence randomized in the first session; after the fatigue protocol, two maximum evoked contractions will be performed again; then two maximal isometric contractions and at the end, the muscle fatigue evaluation will be performed again. The NMES protocols will be CR10% (Russian Current at 2500 Hz, modulated in 50 Hz bursts, 200 µs and 10% duty cycle - 2 ms burst

The study aims to investigate the metabolic effects of four-week lactate-ketone ester supplementation in obese individuals. The study is a randomized, double-masked, crossover design with two arms: LaKe arm and Placebo arm. The primary outcome measure is insulin sensitivity expressed as an M-value, which is determined using a hyperinsulinemic-euglycemic clamp. Secondary outcome measures include differences in lipolysis rate, body weight and composition, gastric emptying rate, cardiac output, left ventricular ejection fraction, tricuspid annular plane systolic excursion, global longitudinal strain, mitral inflow velocities, mitral plane velocities in the lateral mitral annulus, global work index, changes in blood concentrations of 3-OHB, lactate, free fatty acids, glucose, insulin, growth/differentiation factor 15 (GDF-15), gastric inhibitory polypeptide (GIP), ghrelin, glucagon, liver-expressed antimicrobial peptide 2 (LEAP-2), C-peptide, triglycerides, cholesterol, brain-derived neurotrophic factor (BDNF), N-lactoyl-phenylalanine (Lac-Phe), Fibrosis-4 (FIB-4), erythrocyte volume fraction (EVF), Erythropoietin (EPO), inflammation markers, mood, assessed by Major Depression Inventory score (MDI), Anxiety Symptom Scale questionnaire (ASS), and supplement tolerability. The study is expected to run for approximately 12 weeks.

This is a 6-week study to explore the impact of FitnessGenes' platform, with a follow-up after 3 months. NHS staff from multiple NHS trusts will be recruited to partake in the study. Participants will undertake a DNA test provided by FitnessGenes, free of charge. This test will require participants to provide a saliva sample via a spit test. This sample will then be analysed at an ISO-accredited laboratory and results provided back to the participant within 2-3 weeks. Test result data is stored in an encrypted format and saliva samples are anonymized using unique barcodes printed on the collection tubes, which do not contain any Personal Information. User identity data (email, name, address, contact info etc.) is kept in a separate database to user personal data (demographic, biometric, lifestyle, genetic etc.). Once their genetic data is added to a participant's FitnessGenes account, they will be asked to spend a week exploring this upgraded information. A feedback questionnaire will be completed, 3 weeks after they have received their results, to assess participant's experiences of the platform and their results. At this stage, some semi-structured interviews may be conducted, to those who consent to this, to gain further insight. A 3-month follow up, after the baseline measures were taken, will be completed to assess whether the platform has had any long-lasting impacts on participants' health and wellbeing. This follow up will be completed via a short online questionnaire. The primary aim of the study is to assess changes in subjects' well-being, as evaluated by the 5-item World Health Organisation Well-being Index (WHO-5). The investigators will adopt a repeated measures analysis, collecting raw WHO-5 scores from the same subjects at three discrete time points: baseline (i.e. before genetic analysis), 3 weeks after receiving genetic results and at 3 months after baseline. The investigators will also assess the internal consistency of the WHO-5 by performing a Cronbach's alpha test at the three time points. To assess changes in well-being, raw WHO-5 scores (ranging from 0 to 25) will be multiplied by 4 and transformed into final scores of 0 - 100 for each subject. Psoas Tenotomy Under Ultrasound
================================

This study aims to evaluate the success rate of a new ultrasound-guided ilio-psoas tendon tenotomy technique and compare it to standard practice on pain experienced by the patient. The study will be conducted on patients with ilio-psoas conflict after total hip replacement. The procedure will be performed under ultrasound guidance using an ultrasound machine, a 3 mm Acufex hook blade and a specific kit usually used for guided vertebroplasty. The primary outcome measure will be the disappearance of the ilio-psoas conflict after surgery, evaluated at the first control consultation 3 weeks post-operative. Secondary outcome measures will include pain experienced by the patient, evaluated using a numerical scale from 0 to 10 before surgery, 3 hours after surgery, the day after surgery, then 3 weeks, 6 weeks, 3 months and 6 months after surgery. The non-inferiority limit is set at 1.5 on the pain EVA scale. Other secondary outcome measures will include the Oxford Hip Score, the Harris Hip Score, the Postel and Merle Aubigne score, the technical difficulty of surgical procedure, the operative time, the installation time, the total blood loss, the length of hospital stay, the scarring after surgery, the impact of the patient's quality of life, patient satisfaction with the results of the operation, the subjective value of the hip, the forgotten hip sensation, the forgotten hip score, early and late surgical complications related to surgery, and the rate of patient requiring a stay in a rehabilitation center.

The study aims to compare the pain scores and morphine consumption between patients who receive a thoracic paravertebral block with 20 ml, 25 ml, and 30 ml of 0.25% bupivacaine. The study will be conducted in patients who are planned to have a thoracic paravertebral block and are scheduled for elective thoracotomy surgery. The study will be conducted in a randomized, double-blind, parallel assignment design. The primary outcome measure will be pain scores assessed using the visual analog scale at different time points after surgery. The secondary outcome measure will be morphine consumption for 24 hours after surgery. The study will be conducted in patients who are 18 to 80 years old, have an American Society of Anesthesiologists (ASA) physical status I-II-III, and a BMI of 18 to 40 kg/m2. The study will exclude patients who refuse the procedure, have emergency surgery, or have a history of chronic opioid or analgesic use.

The study aims to investigate the effects of vibration therapy on the mobility and postural control of patients with multiple sclerosis, as well as reduce fatigue. The study is an interventional type, with the experimental group receiving additional vibration treatment. The study will use a battery of neuropsychological assessments, including the Expanded Disability Status Scale (EDSS), Fatigue Severity Scale (FSS), Modified Fatigue Impact Scale (MFIS), Fatigue Scale for Motor and Cognitive Functions (FSMC), Borg Scale, Medical Research Council Scale (MRC), 6 minutes walking test, Multiple Sclerosis Quality of Life-54 (MSQOL-54) scale, Beck Depression Inventory-II, Coping Orientation to Problems Experienced (COPE). The sample size is 20 eligible subjects recruited and treated with traditional rehabilitation approach plus vibrational therapy, and 20 patients who have undergone a traditional rehabilitation treatment without the application of vibrations and who will represent the control group. The results will be compared to those obtained from the control group using a descriptive analysis of the two groups for clinical and socio-demographic variables. An intra-group analysis will be carried out to compare both clinical and instrumental scores between T0 and T1 in each group using either T-Student or Wilcoxon for paired data, and a Pearson correlation or Spearman rank correlation to evaluate the relationship between clinical scales and instrumental data. The inter-group analysis will be applied to compare both clinical and instrumental scores between the groups at T0 and T1 using either a parametric test (T-Student for unpaired data) or a non-parametric test (U-Mann Whitney). The study will be conducted in accordance with good clinical practice guidelines and current regulations. The principal investigator will conduct the study in accordance with good clinical practice guidelines and current regulations. All study participants will sign informed consent in accordance with current regulations. The study investigator will inform the subject that participation in the protocol is voluntary and that refusal will not in any way affect the relationship with the researcher. Before enrollment in the study, each subject will receive a clear explanation of the nature and purpose of the study from the investigator. A clear information sheet outlining all salient aspects will also be provided

The study aims to compare the diagnostic efficacy of transbronchial cryobiopsy (TBCB) versus traditional transbronchial lung biopsy (TBLB) for diagnosing lung transplantation rejection. The study will be conducted in a randomized, parallel assignment, open label design. The primary outcome measure is the diagnostic yield of TBCB for diagnosing lung transplantation rejection, compared with that of TBLB. The secondary outcome measures include the incidence of complications, the area size of the biopsy sample, the number of alveoli in the biopsy sample, the number of blood vessels in the biopsy sample, the percentage of the area of lung parenchyma without artifacts in the biopsy sample, and the number of attempts to get five samples. The study will be conducted in patients with unexplained pulmonary function decline, acute/chronic clinical lung injury or new pulmonary infiltrates or patients requiring monitoring of rejection after lung transplantation. The study will be conducted in patients aged between 18-65 years old. The study will be conducted in patients who undertake routine preoperative examinations for lung cryobiopsy, including routine blood test, coagulation function, electrocardiogram, and chest CT, and the patients have no contraindications to cryobiopsy. The study will be conducted in patients who are eligible for inclusion and who agree to participate in the study. The study aims to improve outcome prediction at the time of sFGR diagnosis by testing several predictors. The investigators hypothesize that additional ultrasound parameters could be of benefit in making the current classification system more accurate and less variable. The study will evaluate the impact of a sFGR pregnancy on parental mental health and parent-to-infant(s) attachment, which has not been carried out this extensively before. The study will be conducted in a longitudinal follow-up until 2 years after birth. The primary outcome measure is a composite outcome consisting of fetal single or double demise, including selective fetal reduction and/or an iatrogenic elective birth < 32 weeks of gestational age because of fetal distress. Secondary outcome measures include an explanatory analysis of ultrasound parameters over the course of sFGR pregnancy, prenatal and postnatal attachment, post-traumatic stress, and PARCA-R evaluation. The study will be conducted in a monochorionic diamniotic twin pregnancy complicated by sFGR (diagnosed before 28 weeks of gestational age). The study will be conducted in a multicenter study design.

The study aims to evaluate the effectiveness of a 12-week integrated care pathway for patients with alcohol use disorder (AUD) and cannabis use disorder (CUD) using the Addictions Neuroclinical Assessment (ANCA). The study will use a non-randomized, single group assignment design with behavioral interventions, including CBT and motivational enhancement therapy. The primary outcome measures will include changes in binge drinking days, cannabis use frequency, average drinks per day, amount of cannabis used per week, self-reported alcohol craving, and self-reported cannabis craving during treatment. Secondary outcome measures will include retention in treatment, depressive symptoms, anxiety symptoms, and quality of life. The study will be conducted in a single center and will enroll 100 participants (50 in the AUD group and 50 in the CUD group). Participants will be assessed at baseline, 12 weeks, and 24 weeks. The study will be conducted in accordance with the Declaration of Helsinki and will obtain ethical approval from the institutional review board.

The study aims to investigate the short-term impact of positive, neutral, and negative expectation speech on pain intensity in patients with chronic low back pain. The study will be a randomized controlled trial with a blinded assessor. Participants will be randomly assigned to one of three groups: positive expectation, neutral expectation, or negative expectation. After watching a short video delivering the assigned message, participants will receive one session of spinal manipulative therapy. Pain intensity, global perceived effect of improvement, and expectations related to treatment will be assessed immediately post-treatment. The study will also investigate the perceptions of patients regarding the videos. The main hypothesis of this study is that the group submitted to the positive expectation speech will have a higher hypoalgesic effect, greater perception of improvement, and higher expectations regarding spinal manipulative therapy than the other groups immediately post-treatment.

The study aims to determine the prevalence or occurrence of upper gastrointestinal diseases in patients younger than 50 years old who underwent gastroscopy and colonoscopy simultaneously. The study will include individuals with normal colonoscopy examination and those with colorectal polyps diagnosed by colonoscopy. The primary outcome measure will be the prevalence or occurrence of upper gastrointestinal diseases, including Helicobacter pylori, atrophic gastritis/intestinal metaplasia, reflux esophagitis, Barrett's esophagus, peptic ulcer, gastric polyps, low-grade intraepithelial neoplasia (LGIN), and high-grade intraepithelial neoplasia (HGIN). The study will be conducted as a retrospective cross-sectional study.

This is a randomized clinical trial comparing the outcome of screw tent pole technique to conventional gold standard technique of block bone grafts in atrophied anterior maxilla. The study aims to assess the amount of bone gain and bone quality in both techniques after 6 months of healing. The study design is parallel groups, with 1:1 allocation ratio. The primary objective is to assess the amount of bone gain, and the secondary objective is to assess bone quality. The study will be conducted in two arms: the experimental arm, which will receive the screw tent pole technique, and the active comparator arm, which will receive the autogenous bone block technique. The study will measure the primary outcome of bone gain and the secondary outcome of bone quality evaluation. The study will be conducted in a unicentered, parallel groups, 2 arms, Allocation ratio 1:1, Equivalent trial design.

The study aims to evaluate the correlation between changes in IFN-γ response in the first antigen tube (TB1) and the newly added antigen tube (TB2) and the reference standard of treatment response (culture conversion) in smear-positive and smear-negative/culture-positive pulmonary TB cases. The study will be conducted in two arms: a control group (healthy subject) and a subject with pulmonary tuberculosis (PTB). The study will measure the degree of correlation between changes in IFN-γ response in the first antigen tube (TB1) and the newly added antigen tube (TB2) and the reference standard of treatment response (culture conversion) in smear-positive and smear-negative/culture-positive pulmonary TB cases at four time points: at time of diagnosis (t0), 30+ 4 days after anti-TB treatment initiation (t1), 2 months after anti-TB treatment initiation (t2), and at the end of the anti-TB therapy (6 to 9 months) (t3). The study will use a diagnostic test called Interferon gamma release assay (IGRA) as the intervention/treatment. The study will be conducted in a randomized controlled trial design.

The study aims to evaluate the accuracy of brain response to mechanical and radiofrequency stimuli in humans. The study will be conducted in two experimental settings. In the first setting, the precision of the brain response to RF and mechanical sharp stimuli will be evaluated in terms of latency and amplitude. In the second setting, the relationship of these parameters with psychophysical results (questionnaires) and heat thresholds will be explored to investigate the relationship between these variables. The study will be conducted in an automated manner, which will reduce the uncertainty derived from human subjectivity. The study aims to characterize the biomechanical coupling of the brain to the skull in human volunteers with and without a history of traumatic brain injury (TBI) using magnetic resonance elastography (MRE). The study will recruit 25 mild TBI patients with a history of acute TME (TME+), 25 TME-patients (mild TBI patients without TME) and 25 healthy controls. The primary outcome measure will be the global differences in the amplitudes and temporal delays of translation and rotation between brain and skull. The secondary outcome measure will be the local measures of skull-brain coupling using octahedral shear strain, with a focus at the cortical surface. The study will use MRE to estimate the global differences in the amplitudes and temporal delays of translation and rotation between brain and skull. The study will also measure the local measures of skull-brain coupling using octahedral shear strain, with a focus at the cortical surface. The study will recruit 25 mild TBI patients with a history of acute TME (TME+), 25 TME-patients (mild TBI patients without TME) and 25 healthy controls. The study will use MRE to estimate the global differences in the amplitudes and temporal delays of translation and rotation between brain and skull. The study will also measure the local measures of skull-brain coupling using octahedral shear strain, with a focus at the cortical surface.

The Effect of Pharmacist-Initiated Home Blood Pressure Monitoring on Blood Pressure Control in Women

Study Overview:

The study aims to determine the impact of home blood pressure monitoring when used in addition to pharmacist care, compared to usual care, in women with blood pressure elevated above their target level. The study will be conducted as a randomized controlled trial with a study length of 24 weeks, with a final follow-up at 52 weeks. The study will be conducted in community pharmacies throughout Ontario, Canada.

The study will recruit a 50:50 ratio of pharmacies from urban and rural communities. Participants will be identified through various methods, including during their usual workflow in providing patient care, during a hypertension screening day at the pharmacy, searching patient pharmacy profiles, and through referral from another healthcare provider.

The study will involve two groups: an intervention group and a control group. The intervention group will receive a home blood pressure monitor and will measure their blood pressure at home every four weeks for five four-week periods, as per the Hypertension Canada 7-day BP protocol. The control group will not receive a home blood pressure monitor and will have their blood pressure taken at the pharmacy at baseline, week 12, and week 24.

The primary study will be complete at the end of the 24-week intervention period. After 52 weeks, a final follow-up will be conducted to assess ongoing use of the home blood pressure monitor and any further interactions with the prescribing clinician.

The study will be conducted in accordance with the Declaration of Helsinki and will obtain ethical approval from the University Health Network Research Ethics Board.

The study is a multicenter randomized controlled trial that aims to investigate the effect of moderate alcohol consumption on heart function in patients with a recent myocardial infarction. The study includes 220 patients who are randomly assigned to either moderate alcohol consumption (1 standard unit a day for 12 months) or abstinence (no alcohol beverages for 12 months). The primary outcome measure is the change in left ventricular ejection fraction between the baseline visit and 12-month visit. The study is designed to be a prevention trial.

===============

The study aims to evaluate the efficacy and safety of lactulose for bowel preparation in patients with inflammatory bowel disease (IBD). The study is a randomized, parallel assignment, single-masked study. The primary outcome measure is the effective preparation rate, which is evaluated using the Boston Bowel Preparation Scale (BBPS) >= 6 with a partial score >= 2 in each colon segment. The secondary outcome measures include the incidence of adverse events and the taste score evaluated by patients. The study also evaluates the effects of bowel preparation drugs on liver function and serum electrolyte. The study is designed to include patients with confirmed IBD or suspected IBD for at least 3 months, aged between 16-75 years and requiring a colonoscopy. Patients are excluded if they have clinical active UC and CD, known or suspected gastrointestinal obstruction, bowel perforation, toxic colitis or megacolon, recent or active gastrointestinal bleeding, congestive heart failure, severe renal failure, severe dehydration or electrolyte disturbances, pregnancy, allergies to PEG or Lactulose, diabetes, lactose or galactose intolerance, or refuse to participate in the study. The study will include two arms: experimental and active comparator. In the experimental arm, patients will take lactulose for bowel preparation, while in the active comparator arm, patients will take 3L-polyethylene glycol for bowel preparation. The study will be conducted in accordance with the Declaration of Helsinki and will be approved by the Ethics Committee of Centre Hospitalier Valida.

The study aims to understand the sleep status and quality of life of older adults at risk of metabolic syndrome in the community and the potential contributing factors, and to explore the effect of aromatherapy on improving the sleep quality and quality of life of the older adults at risk of metabolic syndrome in the community. The study is a longitudinal study with a prospective randomized control design. A total of 64 elderly people were recruited from 2 community bases in the East District of Hsinchu City. The two bases were determined as the experimental group or the control group by simple randomization. The experimental group received aromatherapy, an intervention using lavender essential oil compound, while the control group received a placebo, sweet almond oil. The research tools include: Basic Demographic Information,  The Chinese version of the Pittsburgh Sleep Quality Index, CPSQI , The World Health Organization Quality of Life Questionnaire -Taiwan Version and The World Health Organization Quality of Life Questionnaire -old. The primary outcome measures are the quality of sleep and quality of life of elderly people at risk of metabolic syndrome in community bases participating in aromatherapy, measured 1 month after intervention. The study is expected to find that older adults in the experimental group (use aromatherapy) had better sleep and quality of life than those who use placebo.

The study is a 6-months prospective randomized controlled clinical trial. The study aims to compare the clinical course and aesthetic results of soft tissue augmentation with a free connective tissue graft and with a collagen matrix in patients with soft tissue atrophy in the distal part of the lower jaw. The study will be conducted in accordance with the Declaration of Helsinki and will be approved by the Ethics Committee of the E.V. Borisovsky Institute of Dentistry of the Russian Academy of Medical Sciences.

The study will include 30 patients with soft tissue atrophy in the distal part of the lower jaw. The patients will be randomly divided into two groups: the first group will undergo soft tissue augmentation with a free connective tissue graft, and the second group will undergo soft tissue augmentation with a collagen matrix. The study will be conducted in accordance with the Declaration of Helsinki and will be approved by the Ethics Committee of the E.V. Borisovsky Institute of Dentistry of the Russian Academy of Medical Sciences.

The primary outcome measure will be the amount of soft tissue thickness gain in the study area on the 90th day compared to the 0th day (initial value). The secondary outcome measures will be the amount of soft tissue thickness gain on the 180th day compared to the 0th day (initial value), the severity of pain syndrome, the assessment of collateral edema, the consumption of analgesics, and the quality of life.

The study will be conducted in accordance with the Declaration of Helsinki and will be approved by the Ethics Committee of the E.V. Borisovsky Institute of Dentistry of the Russian Academy of Medical Sciences.

The study aims to evaluate the effectiveness of intraoral injection of trigger points by botox in the treatment of myofascial pain in the masseter muscle. The study is a randomized, parallel assignment, single-masked study. The study will include 20 participants aged between 18 and 60 years, with a definite diagnosis of myofascial pain and a referral for the presence of one or more trigger points in the unilateral or bilateral masseter muscle. The study will compare the effectiveness of intraoral injection of trigger points by botox with transcutaneous injection of trigger points by botox in the treatment of myofascial pain in the masseter muscle. The primary outcome measure will be pain score measured on a 10-point visual analogue scale (VAS) at 6 weeks post injection. The secondary outcome measure will be OHIP-14 scale at 6 weeks post injection.

The OptimizeD study is a randomized controlled trial that aims to determine whether different patients respond differentially to brief psychological treatment or a widely used generic SSRI and, if so, whether one can optimize outcomes in a cost-effective fashion for primary care patients with moderate to severe depression. The study has two specific aims and two exploratory aims: Specific Aim 1 (Clinical and Functional Outcomes): To evaluate the effectiveness of optimization via generating a precision treatment rule (PTR) on patients with moderate to severe depression randomized to either psychotherapy based on behavioral activation called the Healthy Activity Program (HAP) or antidepressant medication (fluoxetine). The study will use machine learning to develop the PTR, using a wide range of clinical, socio-economic, and neuro-cognitive characteristics measured at baseline as predictors. The investigators hypothesize that patients randomized by chance to their optimal intervention will be more likely to remit and recover than patients who are not. Specific Aim 2 (Cost-effectiveness Outcomes): To assess the costs of optimal vs. non-optimal treatments and to conduct a cost-effectiveness analysis by comparing relative costs and effectiveness between those who were randomly allocated to their optimal treatment with those who were randomly allocated to a non-optimal treatment, based on the PTR developed in Aim 1. The investigators hypothesize that optimizing will be more cost-effective than not. Exploratory Aim 1 (Mediators): To explore whether one can use the PTR to make our tests of mediation more precise. Patients who respond differentially to different treatments adhere to different causal mechanisms, and inclusion of the PTR in interaction terms with the purported mediators should facilitate the detection of moderated mediation among patients who show specificity of response. The investigators will also consider whether treatment-related factors (e.g., adherence, quality) act as mediators of the effects of each treatment on remission and recovery. This exploratory aim will offer insights into mechanisms of action for each treatment. Exploratory Aim 2 (Genetic Predictors): To explore whether polygenic risk scores and other biomarkers can enhance the prediction of both general and differential response to either treatment.

The ILLUMINA-1 study is a prospective, observational study of 40 mechanically ventilated patients with ARDS. The study aims to investigate the immune cell-microbiome interactions in ARDS and their relation to disease severity and progression. The study will be conducted in two arms: one arm for patients with none-to-mild ARDS and one arm for patients with moderate-to-severe ARDS. The study will be conducted in two phases: a discovery phase and a validation phase. The discovery phase will be conducted in the first 72 hours after intubation, and the validation phase will be conducted 7-10 days after intubation. The study will be conducted in accordance with the Declaration of Helsinki and will be approved by the Ethics Committee of Hvidovre Hospital. This is a cross-sectional study that aims to compare the pulmonary ventilation function between patients with primary and recurrent incisional hernia. The study includes patients diagnosed with abdominal incisional hernia who have complete CT imagings of the abdomen and pulmonary function tests data. The primary outcome measure is recurrence after surgery repair. The study uses the fixed threshold method to grade pulmonary ventilation dysfunction, with FEV1 as a percentage of the expected value. The maximum length of the abdominal wall defect is measured using multi-slice helical CT 3D reconstruction technology. The study is conducted at a single center and includes 100 patients. The study aims to determine the frequency and mapping of unstable coronary plaques highlighted by 18F-Na PET in patients at intermediate and high risk, as well as their evolution under treatment. The study will use a non-invasive coronary imaging test to evaluate the impact of secondary prevention treatment on these patients initially diagnosed as rapidly progressive and/or unstable. The study will also compare the study cohort symptoms evolution to the symptoms evolution of an historical local cohort with comparable symptomatology which motivated the implementation of a secondary prevention type treatment. The study will also compare the rate of occurrence of cardiovascular events of interest between the study cohort and the historical cohort. The study will use a single group assignment and will be open label. The primary outcome measure will be the unstable coronary plaque evolution description through calcium score variation, while the secondary outcome measures will be the effectiveness of primary cardiovascular prevention strategy initiation by the care team, comparison of study cohort symptoms evolution to the symptoms evolution of an historical local cohort with comparable symptomatology which motivated the implementation of a secondary prevention type treatment, and compare the rate of occurrence of cardiovascular events of interest between the study cohort and the historical cohort. The study will be conducted over a period of 24 months.

The WHITE MATTER Hyperintensity Shape and Glymphatics study is a cross-sectional study that will be conducted at the Leiden University Medical Center (LUMC). The study aims to investigate the association of a more complex WMH shape with abnormalities in small vessel morphology. The study will include 3T and 7T MRI scans, as well as neuropsychological assessments. The data will be analyzed by performing association analysis. The study population will be patients of the memory/geriatric clinic that are over 65 years of age. The main study parameter/endpoint will be the association between a more complex WMH shape and structural and functional markers of cerebral SVD. Other study parameters will include the association between SVD markers/cognition and novel glymphatics markers. The nature and extent of the burden and risks associated with participation, benefit and group relatedness will be discussed.

The study is a single center, case-control, diagnostic study that aims to evaluate the clinical auxiliary value of an intelligent endoscopic diagnosis system developed and verified based on deep learning for the diagnosis of esophagogastric junctional adenocarcinoma. The study includes three arms: training set, test set, and verification set. The primary outcome measures are sensitivity, specificity, negative predictive value, positive predictive value, and accuracy. The study will compare the established AI model with the diagnostic results of endoscopists to evaluate the clinical auxiliary value of the model for endoscopists. The study will be conducted for 36 months.

The study is a phase III clinical trial that evaluates the efficacy and safety of FRSW107, a recombinant human coagulation factor VIIa fusion protein, in pediatric patients with severe hemophilia A. The study includes children under 12 years old who weigh more than 10 kg and have clinically confirmed severe hemophilia A. Participants must have previously received EVI treatment and meet certain criteria, including normal prothrombin time or international normalized ratio, at least 6 months of treatment, and detailed records of bleeding events before screening. The study will measure the annual bleeding rate and the frequency and severity of all adverse events during the 1-year treatment period. The study will also assess the immunogenicity of FRSW107 and its effect on FVIII activity.

The study aims to assess differences in feasibility and acceptability of music therapy played live and listening to a recording thereof at the palliative care ward of the University Hospital Zurich. The study will investigate multiple simultaneous biomarkers of autonomic response to music therapy and a recording thereof, such as heart rate, heart rate variability, electrodermal activity and distal body temperature. To investigate subjective quality of life and psychological outcomes, the investigators will administer highly validated and widely used questionnaires, namely the European Organisation for Research and Treatment of Cancer Quality of Life Questionnaire 15 Palliative Care, the Edmonton Symptom Assessment System and the Hospital Anxiety and Depression Scale. The study will use a commercially available tracker, the wristband 287-2 by Corsano, to investigate multiple simultaneous biomarkers of autonomic response to music therapy and a recording thereof, such as heart rate, heart rate variability, electrodermal activity and distal body temperature. The study will use a prospective repeated measures design with a crossover assignment. The study will be conducted at the palliative care ward of the University Hospital Zurich. The study aims to investigate the effect of reusing operative supplies on cataract surgery and climate change. The study will be conducted in two arms, where in one arm, the surgeon will change the gown and glove between each case with hand sterilization with alcohol before and after wearing the next glove. In the other arm, the surgeon will change only the glove and use alcohol for hand sterilization before and after wearing the next glove. The study will measure the rate of postoperative complications, specifically the occurrence of infection, six months after the surgery. The study will also investigate the environmental impact of reusing operative supplies in cataract surgery.

A new neuroregulatory technology is being developed for the treatment of anorexia nervosa (AN) based on the pathological neural network of the anterior cingulate cortex (ACC). The study is a randomized controlled trial that will investigate the efficacy and safety of dTMS targeting ACC in the treatment of adult AN. The study will use a multicenter design and will enroll 80 patients with AN, who will be randomly assigned to either the dTMS treatment group or the pseudo-stimulation group. The dTMS treatment group will receive 5 dTMS sessions per week for 6 weeks, while the pseudo-stimulation group will receive 5 sham dTMS sessions per week for 6 weeks. The primary outcome measure will be body mass index (BMI) at baseline, week 2, 4, and 6 (during treatment), and week 4, 12, and 24 (after completion of treatment). Secondary outcome measures will include eating disorder examination questionnaire (EDE-Q6.0), eating disorder inventory (EDI-II), Beck depression inventory (BDI), Beck anxiety inventory (BAI), and self-assessed compulsive questionnaire for eating disorders (SR-YBC-EDS). The study will explore factors predictive of dTMS efficacy in AN patients of the dTMS treatment group, divided into two groups according to whether dTMS was effective or not at the end of treatment (week 6) (effective is defined as BMI increasing by ≥1.2 kg/m2 at the end of treatment). The study will provide theoretical and practical basis for the pioneering ACC-targeted dTMS treatment in China, helping to establish a new type of intervention program for AN, with expected results of innovation.

The SeDeN-p3 Study is a mixed-methods study that aims to measure parental acceptability of expanded newborn screening using genetic testing in France. The study will be conducted in four populations: Population 1Q (parents or co-parents of a newborn child), Population 2 (parents or co-parents whose youngest child is 1 week to 3 years old), Population 3 (parents or co-parents whose child had a suspicious newborn screening result that was confirmed at the diagnosis phase), and Population 4 (parents or co-parents whose child was diagnosed later based on clinical signs for diseases not included in the list of diseases screening in French newborn screening, but included in the list of diseases screened in newborn screening in other countries). The study will use a mixed-methods design, including both quantitative and qualitative data, to measure parental acceptability of expanded newborn screening using genetic testing. The primary outcome measure will be a mixed matrix of parental acceptability dimensions of expanded newborn screening, and secondary outcome measures will include parental acceptability scores for expanded newborn screening, typology of parental acceptability scores for expanded newborn screening, measure of importance given to different modalities of information about newborn screening, parent opinion on newborn screening for Spinal Muscular Atrophy, Duchenne muscular dystrophy, BRCA-related breast and ovarian cancer predisposition syndrome and congenital long QT, and parent's views on the use of genetic testing in expanded newborn screening. The study is a randomized trial that compares the effectiveness of remote Tai Chi and Qigong rehabilitation to usual care for individuals with low back pain. The study is designed to measure changes in the Oswestry Disability Index, visual analogue scale for low back pain, and other secondary outcome measures at 3 months after intervention. Participants must be 18 years and older, have experienced low back pain for the last 6 weeks or longer, understand written and spoken English, and be willing to complete the initial survey and 3 additional ones emailed baseline and January 2023. The study is open to all sexes and does not accept healthy volunteers. The intervention is a 12-week, twice-per-week t'ai chi and qigong gentle movement and meditation program adapted from the WaQi program, a curriculum developed by Master Yang Yang, PhD. The study is measuring the change in the Oswestry Disability Index, visual analogue scale for low back pain, and other secondary outcome measures at 3 months after intervention.

===============

This is an observational study of people living with HIV who have received CD19-directed CAR T cell therapy for B-cell lymphoid malignancies. The study aims to capture clinical information on participants who carry a diagnosis of HIV disease and received CAR19 therapy outside of a clinical trial between August 30, 2017 and August 31, 2021. The primary outcome measure is the rate of toxicities related to CAR19 therapy, which will be reported by Common Terminology for Adverse Events (CTCAE) criteria, as well as American Society for Transplantation and Cellular Therapy (ASTCT) criteria (for cytokine release syndrome). Secondary outcome measures include change in CD4 count, absolute lymphocyte count, HIV viral load, overall response, complete remission, and terms related to the study.

===============

The PEAR-MET study is a UK-based observational study that aims to discover novel predictive biomarkers with the potential to guide treatment decision making and prolong PFS and OS in patients with advanced TNBC. Patients will undergo a mandatory, study-specific core needle biopsy or fine needle aspiration of the breast tumour or metastasis before commencing their next line of therapy. The research sample will be run on Pear Bio's test whilst the patient receives therapy as per their physician's choice. Treatment response data will be collected at multiple timepoints to conduct analyses on the study's secondary and tertiary objectives. Fresh tissue resections that arrive at Pear Bio's lab will undergo processing, cell culture and various drug dosing and omics assays (depending on extracted cell numbers). Tumour samples will be processed using a cell isolation kit to retrieve a viable single-cell suspension. A minimum of 100,000 cells (10,000 viable cells per chip) will be used for staining with live and dead cell-tracking dyes. In parallel, blood vials will be processed for PBMCs and further effector cell extraction (flow cytometry, Dynabeads, etc). The remaining cells will be used for sequencing (DNA/RNA), fixed for immunofluorescence characterisation of biomarkers/receptor status or used for further omics assays (if cell numbers allow). This may include tumour mutational burden and microsatellite instability testing. The stained cells will be cultured in a biomimetic hydrogel within Pear Bio's organ-on-a-chip to provide a physiological 3D environment for drug dosing experiments. Using a microfluidic device, samples in each chip will be exposed to approved therapies (either as monotherapy or combination therapies, as outlined below) over multiple days. In parallel, PBMCs will be extracted from whole blood, characterised and sorted via flow cytometry and fluorescence-activated cell sorting (FACS) or magnetic beads selection. Cells of interest (e.g. CD8+ T cells) will be used for culture in Pear Bio's chips jointly with cells isolated from the matched tumour sample.

This study is a health economic analysis that includes quality of life. It aims to investigate how the health economy is affected when surgery is delayed for patients with inflammatory bowel disease. The study includes two groups: those waiting for surgery and those who have already been operated. The primary outcome measure is the effect of delayed surgery on health economy including quality of life. The secondary outcome measures include socioeconomic differences in delayed surgery and the effect of waiting for surgery on the result. The study will be conducted in 2023/2024 and will last for 2 years.

The study aims to better understand the non-immunological functions of myeloid-derived suppressor cells (MDSC) in non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC). The study will assess the non-immunological pro-tumor functions of MDSC isolated from lung cancer patients through in vitro studies. The study will collect tumor samples from patients with lung carcinoma surgically treated by surgery only. The primary outcome measure will be a comparative analysis of the modifications of phenotype and functions of lung cancer cell lines when exposed to MDSC extracted from patient tumor tissue. The study will be conducted at Centre Hospitalier Valida.

The study aims to investigate the effect of substituting unsweetened sparkling water for sugar sweetened beverages on sweetness perception in adolescents. The study will be conducted as a prospective, before and after, cohort study. Participants will be male and female adolescents aged 10-21 years who are overweight or obese, high consumers of SSB, have a family history of diabetes or prediabetes, and are at risk for developing type 2 diabetes. Participants will be randomly assigned to either the intervention group or a control group. The intervention group will receive unsweetened sparkling water to substitute for SSB, while the control group will continue to consume SSB. The study will measure changes in 2-hour glucose concentration, dietary consumption of SSB and sparkling water, insulin sensitivity, glycemic variability, flavor perception of beverage sweetness, blood pressure, blood triglycerides, and waist circumference. The study will be conducted over a 12-week period.

=============

The study is a randomized, monocentric, double-blinded, prospective study that evaluates the early wound healing after the utilization of NOVOSYN® Quick versus MONOSYN® Quick suture material in resective periodontal surgery. The study includes 100 participants who undergo resective periodontal surgery and are randomly assigned to either the NOVOSYN® Quick or MONOSYN® Quick group. The primary outcome measure is the early wound healing score (EHS), which is evaluated in 3 parameters: clinical signs of re-epithelization, clinical signs of haemostasis, and clinical signs of inflammation. The study also evaluates secondary outcome measures such as the incidence of wound dehiscence, dentinal hypersensitivity, oral candidiasis, angular cheilitis, swelling, bleeding, infection, systemic complications, pain assessment, patient satisfaction, bacterial contamination of the thread, and assessment of the handling of the suture material. The study is conducted in a single center and is expected to be completed in 10 ± 5 days postoperatively.

=================

This is a small sample, unicentric, randomized, controlled clinical study of Coenzyme I for Injection in the treatment of Sudden Sensorineural Hearing Loss. The study recruited patients with sudden sensorineural hearing loss and collected basic demographic data. The patients were randomly divided into the experimental group and the control group. The experimental group received conventional treatment + Coenzyme I for injection, while the control group received conventional treatment for 14 days. Baseline data were collected before treatment, and post-treatment data were collected on 3d, 7d, 14d, 1m and 3m of treatment. The primary outcome measures were Pure Tone Average (PTA), Speech Recognition Rate, Tinnitus Handicap Inventory (THI), Tinnitus Visual Analogue Scale (VAS), and Severity of ear fullness. The secondary outcome measures were Pure Tone Average (PTA) at different sound intensity levels, Speech Recognition Rate at different sound intensity levels, and Tinnitus Handicap Inventory (THI) at different sound intensity levels. The study was designed to measure the effect of Coenzyme I for injection on the treatment of Sudden Sensorineural Hearing Loss.

===============

The study aims to demonstrate the transferability of genetic newborn screening for cystinosis to other laboratories and to lay the scientific basis for screening for primary hyperoxaluria. The study will investigate whether the inclusion of these diseases into general newborn screening should be recommended. By observing the identified infants in comparison to patients symptomatically diagnosed outside of the pilot project, it will be determined whether and to what extent early diagnosis and therapy lead to a more favorable prognosis. The study will be conducted in Germany and will involve 11 certified laboratories for newborn screening. The study population will include newborns whose parents wish to participate in the pilot project and have provided written informed consent. The study will use molecular genetic screening to detect cystinosis and primary hyperoxaluria. The study will measure the number of newborns with confirmed diagnosis of cystinosis, number of newborns with heterozygous mutations, and patients with PH1 and PH3. The study will be conducted for 12 months.

===============

This is a randomized controlled trial that compares the rate of surgical site infection (SSI) in patients who underwent intra-abdominal surgery with negative pressure drainage versus those without negative pressure drainage. The study is double-blinded and the investigators randomize the patients into two groups by an unassociated personnel who opens an enclosed envelope after the surgical procedure is completed and before the beginning of closing the skin layer. The drainage catheter is placed in the surgical wound for 5 days and/or removed if fluid content is less than 20 ml per day. The primary outcome measure is the rate of SSI, which is measured at post-operative day 3, day 5, day 7, and the day that the patient is discharged from the hospital. The secondary outcome measures include length of hospital stay and score of quality of life. The study is designed to prevent SSI in clean-contaminated and contaminated surgical wounds.

===============

A randomized, open-label, parallel-group study is planned to compare the immune modulation effects of palbociclib, ribociclib, and abemaciclib with letrozole in neoadjuvant treatment for ER+/HER2- early breast cancer. The study will collect tumor tissue, blood, and stool samples prospectively before treatment, at 2 weeks after treatment, and after 12 weeks of treatment at the time of surgery. Immune modulation effects will be compared between 3 treatment groups from breast tumor RNAseq analysis. The study aims to determine the expression of immune-related signature change after different CDK4/6 inhibitor treatments by RNAseq. The study will also assess adverse events according to CTCAE 4.03.

The study aims to develop a dementia care intervention for PLWD and their caregivers, Dementia Care Quality at Home, and test the feasibility of implementing the intervention in two HBPC practices to ultimately improve outcomes of PLWD and their caregivers. The investigators will evaluate the feasibility, acceptability, and fidelity in implementing HBPC Dementia Care Quality at Home in two practices for persons living with dementia and their caregivers through an open pilot. The primary outcome measures include feasibility for the caregiver to engage with and complete baseline assessments, feasibility for the caregiver to access educational materials and community resources, feasibility for the practice of identifying potential patients/caregivers, feasibility for the practice of assessing eligible patient/caregiver dyads, and feasibility for the practice to use patient and caregiver assessments.

=================

This is a randomized clinical trial comparing the effects of resistance training and flexibility training on self-efficacy, symptoms, and maternal quality of life in postpartum depression. The study will recruit 36 postpartum females aged 20 to 40, 6 weeks to 8 months postpartum, who are primiparous or multiparous and have no psychiatric diagnoses other than depression. Participants will be randomly assigned to either the resistance training group or the flexibility training group. Both groups will receive training twice per week for 8 weeks, with a total of 16 sessions. The primary outcome measures will be exercise self-efficacy, symptoms of depression using the Center for Epidemiologic Studies Depression Scale, and maternal quality of life using the Maternal Postpartum Quality of Life questionnaire. Data will be collected at baseline and at 8 weeks post-intervention. The study aims to determine the effectiveness of resistance training and flexibility training in improving self-efficacy, reducing symptoms of depression, and improving maternal quality of life in postpartum depression.

The study aims to compare the surface hardness and wear resistance of prefabricated and CAD/CAM milled artificial teeth. The study is a cross-over clinical study, where participants will receive a complete denture with prefabricated artificial teeth for 3 months, followed by a complete denture with CAD/CAM milled artificial teeth for 3 months. The study will measure the wear resistance and surface hardness of the denture teeth using 2D, 3D wear measurements and Vickers's test. The study will be conducted in participants who are completely edentulous with angle class I maxillomandibular relations and have no systemic disease that affect the bone and soft tissue health. The study will be conducted in participants aged between 55 and 65 years old. The study will be conducted in both genders and will accept healthy volunteers.

This is a phase 2, randomized, open-label, multi-center study of trastuzumab deruxtecan (T-DXd) versus standard neoadjuvant treatment (TCHP or PCHP) in patients with HER2-positive breast cancer. The study aims to determine the efficacy and safety of T-DXd versus standard neoadjuvant treatment in patients with HER2-positive breast cancer. The study will enroll 250 patients with HER2-positive breast cancer who are eligible for neoadjuvant treatment. Patients will be randomly assigned to receive either T-DXd or standard neoadjuvant treatment. The primary endpoint of the study is the pathologic complete response (pCR) rate at the molecularly HER2-enriched population, defined as ypT0/Tis, ypN0, as determined at the surgical specimen by a pathologist blinded to treatment assignment (intention-to-treat analysis). Secondary endpoints include the pCR rate in the initially randomized patients, event-free survival, biomarkers of response/resistance to administered neoadjuvant therapy using genomics, transcriptomics and proteomics in both tumor tissue and blood/plasma, pathologic complete response in ER-positive and luminal patients, pathologic complete response in ER-negative and luminal, basal-like, and normal-like patients, objective response rate at three cycles, overall survival, distant relapse-free survival, objective response rate at six cycles, residual cancer burden, breast conserving surgery, de-escalation of breast surgery, sentinel lymph node dissection, de-escalation of axillary surgery, rates of adverse events, change from baseline in global health status/quality of life score on the European Organization for Research and Treatment of Cancer Quality of Life Questionnaire Core 30 (EORTC QLQ-C30) in all participants, change from baseline in physical functioning score on the EORTC QLQ-C30 in all participants, change from baseline in emotional functioning score on the EORTC QLQ-C30 in all participants, and axillary surgery. The study will be conducted in accordance with the Declaration of

The study aims to compare the effects of intraoperative use of intravenous anesthetics propofol and inhaled anesthetics sevoflurane on the prognosis of patients undergoing surgery for primary brain, liver, lung, and ovarian cancer tumors and the investigation of its mechanism of action. The study is a randomized, parallel assignment, triple-masked study. The primary outcome measures are 6-month, 1-year, and 3-year overall survival and the presence of disease progression. The secondary outcome measures are postoperative complications, Karnofsky performance status score, and length of hospital stays. The study is designed to measure the effects of different anesthetics on the prognosis of primary tumors and its mechanism of action.

The study "Take Care!" aims to disseminate physical activity-related health competence (PAHCO) in vocational education of nursing care. The study is a cluster-randomized controlled trial (cRCT) with 16 schools. The experimental arms include cooperative planning for promoting PAHCO, expert-based intervention for promoting PAHCO delivered by external physical activity specialists, and expert-based intervention for promoting PAHCO delivered by teachers. The control arm includes regular education and health promotion. The primary outcome measures include physical activity-related health competence, psychological movement quality, and quality physical activity. The secondary outcome measures include general health status, work ability, musculoskeletal complaints, and physical job stress in nursing. The study will measure the outcomes at short-term and medium-term follow-up.

The study aims to evaluate the effects of Diosmin/Hespiridin combination on the clinical outcomes in patients with Polycystic Ovary Syndrome. The study is a randomized, double-masked, placebo-controlled trial. The study includes three arms: active comparator (Metformin + Combined oral contraceptive), experimental (Diosmin/Hesperidin + Combined oral contraceptive), and active comparator (Diosmin/Hesperidin + Metformin + Combined oral contraceptive). The study measures the improvement of inflammation, glycemic index, PCOS status levels, and patient's quality of life. The study is conducted over a period of 4 months.
