The study is a phase 1/2 study of idasanutlin and selinexor in children with recurrent or progressive atypical teratoid/rhabdoid tumors (AT/RT) or malignant rhabdoid tumors (MRT). The study is designed to determine the maximum tolerated dose (MTD) and recommended phase 2 dose (RP2D) of combination treatment with oral idasanutlin and selinexor in children with recurrent or progressive AT/RT or MRT in the dose finding/safety phase. The study will also evaluate the safety and efficacy of combination treatment in the expansion phase. The study will be conducted in two phases. In the dose finding/safety phase, patients will receive idasanutlin and selinexor at different dose levels and will be closely monitored for adverse events. The MTD will be determined based on the safety and tolerability of the treatment. In the expansion phase, patients will receive the MTD of combination treatment and will be closely monitored for adverse events and response to treatment. The study will be conducted in accordance with the Declaration of Helsinki and Good Clinical Practice guidelines.

The study is a randomized, parallel assignment, open label study. The study aims to compare the effectiveness of radial shortening and capitate shortening in the treatment of ulna minus variance Kienbock's disease. The study includes 2 arms: radial shortening and capitate shortening. The study measures the primary outcome using the modified Mayo wrist score. The study includes 25 participants, aged 18-65 years, with stages II and III ulna minus variance Kienbock's disease. The study is conducted over a 1-year period.

Prehabilitation in Pancreatic Cancer Patients Undergoing Surgery: A Randomized Controlled Trial

Pancreatic cancer is a highly aggressive and lethal disease with a poor prognosis. The combination of surgical resection and neoadjuvant chemotherapy is the most effective treatment for pancreatic cancer. However, the surgery is associated with a high risk of postoperative complications and poor recovery. Prehabilitation is a multidisciplinary intervention that aims to improve the functional capacity of patients before surgery, thus reducing the risk of postoperative complications and improving the recovery.

This study aims to evaluate the effectiveness of a 4-week preoperative intervention in improving the functional capacity of patients undergoing pancreatic cancer surgery. The intervention includes exercise training, nutritional therapy, and anxiety reduction techniques. The study will be conducted as a randomized controlled trial with 226 patients. The primary outcome measure is the Comprehensive Complication Index (CCI) at 90 days after surgery. Secondary outcome measures include functional capacity, time to patient functional recovery, length of stay, and bioimpedance analysis-derived body composition.

The study will be conducted in accordance with the Declaration of Helsinki and will be approved by the Institutional Review Board. Patients will be informed about the study and will provide written informed consent.

The study will be conducted in a single center. Patients will be recruited from the surgical unit of the hospital. Eligible patients will be randomly assigned to either the intervention group (multimodal prehabilitation) or the control group (usual care). The intervention will be conducted for 4 weeks before surgery. The study will be conducted for 90 days after surgery.

The study will be conducted in accordance with the CONSORT guidelines. The study protocol will be registered in the ClinicalTrials.gov registry (NCT03901172).

The study will be conducted in accordance with the CONSORT guidelines. The study protocol will be registered in the ClinicalTrials.gov registry (NCT03901172).

The study will be conducted in accordance with the CONSORT guidelines. The study protocol will be registered in the ClinicalTrials.gov registry (NCT03901172).

The study aims to evaluate the effectiveness of dual task exercise training in improving balance, mobility, physical performance, and quality of life in children with cerebral palsy. The study will be conducted as a randomized controlled trial with two arms: experimental and active comparator. The experimental group will receive conventional rehabilitation and dual task exercise training, while the active comparator group will receive conventional rehabilitation only. The study will measure the Pediatric Balance Scale, Timed Up and Go Test, One Leg Standing Test, 3-Meter Backward Walk Test, 6-Meter Walk Test, and the Generic Children's Health-Related Quality of Life Questionnaire. The study will be conducted over 12 weeks, with assessments conducted before and after the interventions.

The study is a pilot study to investigate the zoonotic transmission of influenza viruses in Belgium. The study will be conducted in four groups: Avian Influenza Outbreak Farms, Poultry Farm Sentinel Network, Wild bird/life Rehabilitation Centre Sentinel Network, and Pig Industry Veterinarian Sentinel Network. Participants will be invited to take part in the study if they are a worker or volunteer of one of the targeted groups at one of the selected sites and accepting to take part in the study to have regular contacts with animals within job/activity framework being committed to take the regular samples. The study will be conducted for a period of 2 weeks for Avian Influenza Outbreak Farms, 2 weeks for Poultry Farm Sentinel Network, Wild bird/life Rehabilitation Centre Sentinel Network, and Pig Industry Veterinarian Sentinel Network. The study will measure the number of sentinel participants positive for a non-seasonal influenza virus and the number of outbreak participants positive for a non-seasonal influenza virus. The study will also measure the number of outbreak participants with seroconversion against a non-seasonal influenza virus. The study will use RT-qPCR test to detect and characterize non-influenza viruses and inhibition of haemagglutination or seroneutralisation assay to detect seroconversion against a non-seasonal influenza virus.

The study is a longitudinal, within-person design with two parallel conditions. In one condition, youth receive a 6-week canine therapy intervention. The other condition consists of treatment as usual. The subject population are youth that are in a full-time residential treatment facility in Lawrence Hall. The Recovery & Care Canine-Assisted Therapy intervention is a 1.25 hour structured curriculum that will occur weekly across a period of 6 weeks. The program will be delivered by the Canine Therapy Corps (CTCorps). Youth will work with CTC-affiliate staff, including trained dog-handler teams, a canine behavior expert, and a clinical supervisor to engage in a series of structured activities progress throughout the intervention. The primary outcome measures are Emotional Stroop, Flanker Task, Rosenberg Self-Esteem Scale, and Change in Negative Affect. Secondary outcome measures include Attendance and Attrition, Change in Positive Affect, Significant Event Report, and Change in Attitudes towards Pets. The study is designed to evaluate the impact of a canine-assisted therapy program in youth residing in a residential treatment center.

=============

This study is a randomized controlled prospective study that aims to investigate the effect of myofascial release in addition to foot core exercises on lower extremity performance in young adults with asymptomatic flexible pes planus. The study will be conducted with two randomized groups of young adults with flexible pes planus, one group will be applied an exercise program including only foot core exercises, while the other group will be applied self myofascial release with foam rollers, which is a myofascial release method, in addition to foot core exercises. Both the experimental and control groups will receive a program consisting of 7 different foot core exercises, each of which will be progressed gradually for 6 weeks, 3 sets of 10 repetitions per day. A brochure for the exercises will be prepared and given to the participants to do at home. In order to follow up the exercise of the participants, the individuals will be called weekly during this period and exercise follow-up will be performed. The experimental group will also be planned to perform 60 seconds of myofascial release on each tissue on the thoracolumbar fascia, iliotibial band, hamstring, gastro-soleus, peroneals and plantar fascia 2 days a week for 6 weeks with foam roller, which is a self-myofascial release method. At the end of six weeks, the initial evaluations will be performed again on all individuals and the measurement results will be analyzed.

The study aims to investigate whether training of the arms can reduce pain when inserting a peripheral venous catheter and how it is experienced that there can be challenges with vein status for patients in cytostatic treatment. The study is a randomized, parallel assignment study with an 8-week daily arm training program as the intervention. The primary outcome measures are pain level as measured by the Numeric Rating Scale at baseline, after five weeks of training/control, and after eight weeks of training/control. Secondary outcome measures include vein status as assessed via ultrasound at baseline, after five weeks of training/control, and after eight weeks of training/control. The study is designed to measure the effectiveness of arm training in reducing pain and improving vein status in patients undergoing cytostatic treatment.

The study aims to determine whether decidual leukocyte subpopulations and their associated activation markers are different between women having miscarriage of either a trisomy 16 conceptus (47XY+16 or 47XX+16) compared with a chromosomally normal male conceptus (46XY) and compared with gestationally age-matched decidual tissues. The study will use ultrasound-guided manual vacuum aspiration (USG-MVA) as a treatment option for managing with miscarriage or termination of pregnancy (TOP) in first trimester loss. The study will measure the histopathologic diagnosis of chorionic villi and immunohistochemistry staining of maternal decidua. The study will be conducted in accordance with the Declaration of Helsinki and will be approved by the Institutional Review Board of The Chinese University of Hong Kong.

The SUSPECT Italian Prospective Study is a single-arm, prospective study designed to evaluate the performance characteristics and technical outcomes of single-use duodenoscopes in patients with gastrointestinal tract disease undergoing clinically indicated ERCP or other duodenoscope-based procedures. The study will enroll 100 patients who meet the inclusion criteria and will follow them for 24 months. The primary outcome measures will be technical performance and procedural performance. The study will assess technical performance by evaluating the device's ability to perform specific tasks, such as biopsy acquisition and stent placement, and procedural performance by assessing the device's ability to complete the procedure safely and effectively. The study will also evaluate the device's durability, ease of use, and cost-effectiveness. The study will be conducted in accordance with the Declaration of Helsinki and will obtain ethical approval from the local ethics committee.

===============

The Hybrid Pulmonary Rehabilitation Study is a feasibility study that aims to assess the feasibility of a technology-enabled hybrid pulmonary rehabilitation programme for patients with chronic respiratory disease. The study will use the UKCA/CE Class I-approved and DTAC-certified Active+me REMOTE App (Aseptika Ltd www.activ8rlives.com) to deliver a hybrid PR programme that may be used to support a move to a remotely delivered service. The study will recruit patients with chronic respiratory disease who are referred to the Harefield Pulmonary Rehabilitation Programme and will compare outcomes for patients recruited to a Hybrid PR Intervention with a propensity-matched Control Group that has previously received Standard PR. Additional data will be collected from the Hybrid PR group (via Active+me REMOTE / Trial Surveys) to provide supporting evidence relating to uptake, adherence, clinical outcomes (not routinely recorded in standard practice), and usability/acceptability of the Hybrid PR programme. The study will generate evidence to support larger trial to compare effectiveness of a Hybrid PR vs Standard PR delivery model on patient uptake, adherence and outcomes, and service capacity. The aim of the larger trial is to provide definitive evidence to inform clinical guidelines for PR delivery.

===============

An observational study will be conducted to describe the baseline demographics and clinical characteristics of patients who received EVUSHELD as pre-exposure prophylaxis against SARS-CoV-2 infection/COVID-19 in Japan. The study will use secondary data from a database and will include patients who have a record of administration of EVUSHELD in the database. The index date will be defined as the date of first EVUSHELD administration in the database (Day 0) and the patients will be followed up to 6 months after the index date (Day 1 to 180). The primary outcome measure will be the demographics and clinical characteristics of patients received Evusheld as PrEP, while the secondary outcome measures will be the event rate and time to event for medically attended COVID-19, COVID-19 hospitalization, in-hospital mortality due to COVID-19, and all cause mortality up to 180 days after the date of first administration of Evusheld. The study will be conducted in Japan and will be an observational, cohort study.

============

This is a phase 4, multicenter, randomized, double-blind study of risankizumab for the treatment of adult subjects with moderate to severe genital psoriasis or moderate to severe scalp psoriasis. The study will assess the safety and efficacy of risankizumab in these patient populations. The study will enroll 200 participants, who will be randomly assigned to either the experimental group (risankizumab) or the control group (placebo for risankizumab). The study will have two arms: Study G and Study S. Study G will assess the efficacy of risankizumab in the treatment of moderate to severe genital psoriasis, while Study S will assess the efficacy of risankizumab in the treatment of moderate to severe scalp psoriasis. The study will have a 52-week treatment period, followed by an 8-week follow-up period. The primary outcome measures for the study will include the percentage of participants with achievement of static Physician Global Assessment of Genitalia (sPGA-G) of 0 or 1 in Study G and the percentage of participants with achievement of Scalp Investigator Global Assessment (IGA) of 0 or 1 in Study S. Secondary outcome measures will include the percentage of participants with achievement of Dermatology Life Quality Index (DLQI) of 0 or 1, the percentage of participants with achievement of Clinically Meaningful (>= 4-point) Improvement from Baseline on the Genital Psoriasis Itch Numerical Rating Scale (NRS) [Among Participants with a Baseline Score >= 4], and the percentage of participants with achievement of Genital Psoriasis Sexual Frequency Questionnaire (GenPs-SFQ) Item 2 score of 0 or 1 among Participants with a Baseline score >= 2. The study will also assess the safety and efficacy of risankizumab in the treatment of moderate to severe scalp psoriasis, as measured by the percentage of participants with achievement of Psoriasis Scalp Severity Index (PSSI 90) and the percentage of participants with achievement of PSSI 75. The study will be conducted in accordance with the Declaration of Helsink

The study is a descriptive cross-sectional study of patients with a diagnosis of thumb CMC arthritis. The study will collect demographic data, and dichotomous data indicating whether a patient has the variation or does not have the variation, and if the variation is present in one hand or both hands. The study will take place at the Bone and Joint Center at 1365 Washington Avenue, Albany New York, and satellite offices in Guilderland, Clifton Park, Malta, Saratoga, Schenectady and Catskill. Data will be collected for up to two years. There are no risks to patients enrolled in the study, as the test involves asking the patient to simply bend the tip of their thumb. Documentation of the variation is not usually noted in the chart. Therefore, the physicians involved in the study will be asked to include the findings of the variation in their documentation. The patients will be informed during clinical examination if they have a LCV. There is no compensation to participants for enrolling in the study.

=============

This is a phase 3, multicenter, 12-week, double-blind, placebo-controlled study to evaluate the safety and efficacy of atogepant for the preventive treatment of episodic migraine in pediatric subjects 6-17 years of age. The study includes two PK substudies and a double-blind treatment period. The primary outcome measure is change from baseline in mean monthly migraine days. Secondary outcome measures include change from baseline in mean monthly headache days, change from baseline in mean monthly acute medication use days, percentage of participants who achieve at least a 50% reduction in average of monthly migraine days, change from baseline in the Pediatric Quality of Life Inventory (PedsQL) total score, and change from baseline in the Pediatric Migraine Disability Assessment (PedMIDAS) total score. Eligibility criteria include a weight of 20 kg to 135 kg, a history of episodic migraine with or without aura consistent with a diagnosis according to the International Classification of Headache Disorders (ICHD) -3 (2018), and 4 to 14 migraine days and < 15 headache days in the 28-day baseline period per eDiary. The study is being conducted at multiple sites in the United States.

===============

The study aims to examine the effects of a 2-week home-based training program with a 4-week follow-up on touchscreen sliding motions delivered on a tablet in patients with Parkinson's disease. The study will be conducted in a randomized controlled trial (RCT) with 36 participants, who will be randomized (strata: age, H&Y stage) in the experimental or control group. The primary outcome measure will be the average slide duration (in ms) after two weeks of training, while the secondary outcome measures will include performance accuracy (in %), retention effects on average slide duration (in ms) after four weeks follow-up, and consolidation effects of two weeks of training. The study will use an extensive screening session, including motor and non-motor screening, to assess the association with training responsiveness. The study will also explore whether compliance to training has an impact on learning effects within the training group by using a correlation analysis between compliance rates and training-related changes in performance.

===============

The study is a non-randomized quasi-experimental study that investigates the effect of intensified tactile contact between a mother and newborn on the emotional transformation of women after physiological delivery. The study was conducted in a local childbirth school and the participants were selected from the local population of pregnant women who volunteered to provide experimental intervention to their children after birth. The intervention was applied in the form of Shantali massage and lasted until the end of the 12th week after birth. The study used four standardized, self-reported psychological questionnaires to measure the level of emotions in the designated 'negative' domain (depression, anxiety, negative affects) and the level of emotions in the designated 'positive' domain (satisfaction, sense of effectiveness, positive affects). The study found that the direction of the mother's emotional transformation was different after the intensification of tactile contact with the newborn in comparison to the control group. The study also found that the intervention was effective in reducing the level of depression, anxiety, negative affects, and increasing the level of satisfaction and effectiveness in the experimental group.

=================

This is a phase 2, open-label, randomized, parallel-group, multi-centre study of the efficacy and safety of paclitaxel + bevacizumab + atezolizumab versus paclitaxel + bevacizumab in patients with NSCLC who have progressed after treatment with immunotherapy and a doublet of platinum-based chemotherapy, given concomitantly or sequentially. The study will enroll 100 patients. The primary objective is to assess the progression-free survival at 6 months determined by independent reviewer. Secondary objectives include progression-free survival, objective response rate, overall survival, time until definitive health-related quality of life score deterioration, and incidence, nature, and severity of adverse events. The study will be conducted in accordance with the Declaration of Helsinki and Good Clinical Practice guidelines.

===============

The study aims to evaluate the role of osteopathic manipulative treatment (OMT) in the management of persistent post-COVID-19 symptoms. The study is a pilot prospective cohort study that includes patients with at least one symptom of post-COVID-19 that has persisted for at least 4 weeks after diagnosis. The study provides OMT at the discretion of the treating physician and based on the patient's response to previous treatments. The primary outcome measures include patient recruitment rate and data completion rate, while the secondary outcome measures include neurocognitive and psychological symptoms, physical symptoms, global health, and return to work. The study will be conducted over an average of 1 year, with data collected 3 days after every other OMT session for up to 4 months after enrollment and 2 months after the participant's final OMT session. The study will use the Rivermead Post Concussion Symptoms Questionnaire, the Long COVID-Household Pulse Survey, the PROMIS SF v1.2 Global Health scale, and a 4-point scale to assess return to work. The study will be conducted in French and will be conducted in a single center in Quebec, Canada.

=================

The study is a pilot study that compares the use of ICG microangiography and conventional angiography in severe frostbite patients. The study is designed to assess the concordance or discordance of the two imaging modalities in demonstrating ischemic tissue present in severe frostbite. The study will use the Hennepin Frostbite Score to assess the imaging results. The study will also assess the safety of ICG when delivered in close association with contrast dye used in conventional angiography. The study will be conducted over an average of 2 years.

=============

The study is a randomized, open-label, controlled study that compares the impact of a multidisciplinary approach in the Perioperative Geriatrics Unit (GPOU) on the functional status of patients aged 70 and over who are operated on for colorectal cancer. The study includes two arms: a control group that receives classical management in the digestive surgery department and a GPOU group that receives treatment in the Peri-Operative Geriatrics Unit to optimize specific geriatric care. The primary outcome measure is the change in functional status after colorectal cancer surgery between groups, measured using the Instrumental Activities of Daily Living (IADL) score at baseline and month 3. Secondary outcome measures include changes in functional status, basic functional status, patient motor ability, patient satisfaction with care, length of hospital stay, medical complications during hospitalization, surgical complications, destination of patients on discharge from hospital, change in patient weight, patient quality of life, change in the patient's place of abode, and overall survival. The study is designed to measure the impact of a multidisciplinary approach in the Perioperative Geriatrics Unit on the functional status of patients aged 70 and over who are operated on for colorectal cancer.
64Cu-DOTA Pembrolizumab for Imaging Metastatic Solid Tumors in Patients Receiving Stereotactic Body Radiation

============

A Follow-up Study to Describe the Safety of Study Participants Who Received RSVPreF3 Maternal Vaccination (Any Dose) or Controls From Previous RSV MAT Studies During Any Pregnancy Conceived Post Vaccination/Control

The study is a phase 3b, non-randomized, open label, multi-country, cohort study to describe the safety of study participants who received RSVPreF3 maternal vaccination (any dose) or controls from previous RSV MAT studies (RSV MAT-001, RSV MAT-004, RSV MAT-010, RSV MAT-011, RSV MAT-009, RSV MAT-012 and RSV MAT-039) during any pregnancy conceived post vaccination/control. The study includes both retrospective and prospective cohorts of adult/adolescent participants from any of the prior RSV MAT studies who have either received RSV MAT vaccine or control (placebo, Tdap or influenza vaccine). The primary outcome measures are the percentage of maternal participants reporting pregnancy outcomes from Day 1 up to Day 42 post-delivery of the first pregnancy conceived within 2 years post-vaccination, the percentage of maternal participants reporting pregnancy related adverse events of special interest (AESIs) from Day 1 up to Day 42 post-delivery of the first pregnancy conceived within 2 years post-vaccination, and the percentage of infant participants reporting infant AESIs from birth up to Day 42 post-birth of the first pregnancy conceived within 2 years post-vaccination. Secondary outcome measures include the percentage of maternal participants reporting selected pregnancy outcomes and pregnancy related AESIs stratified by selected risk factors of those outcomes, and the percentage of infant participants reporting infant AESIs stratified by selected risk factors of those events. The study is designed as a non-randomized, parallel assignment study with an open label design. The study will be conducted in multiple countries and will enroll both retrospective and prospective cohorts of adult/adolescent participants from any of the prior RSV MAT studies who have either received RSV MAT vaccine or control (placebo, Tdap or influenza vaccine).

===============

This is a cross-sectional pilot study of 19F MRI in healthy children and children with mild cystic fibrosis lung disease. The study aims to evaluate the feasibility of using 19F MRI in these populations and to assess the primary and secondary outcome measures. The study will recruit 6-17 year old participants who are non-smokers and non-vapers, have a diagnosis of cystic fibrosis, and have stable lung function. Participants will breathe a biologically inert contrast gas, perfluoropropane, during the MRI procedures, and the 19F-tuned MRI will be used to image the lungs and chest. The primary outcome measures will include the participation rate, completion rate, and parental and child acceptability scores. The secondary outcome measures will include MRI defined ventilation defect parameters and fraction of lung volume with slow gas washout time in healthy participants and participants with cystic fibrosis.

=================

This is a randomized clinical trial comparing open and closed chain exercises in athletes with patellofemoral pain syndrome. The study will be conducted in Pakistan sports board Lahore, Model town Sports Club Lahore and Sheikh Zaid Hospital, Lahore. The sample size will be taken to evaluate the effects of open chain exercise and closed chain exercise among athletes with an age group of 18 - 40 years. Participants will be randomly assigned to 2 groups. Group A will include participants who will receive open kinetic chain exercises 3sets of 10 repetitions for each exercise along with the general training. Group B will include the participants who will receive closed kinetic chain exercises 3sets of 10 repetitions for each exercise along with general training. The subjects will be assessed for pain, function and balance at baseline and after 6weeks of treatment. The primary outcome measures will be Numerical Pain Rating Scale (NPRS), Lower Extremity Functional Scale (LEFS) and Y Balance test.

===============

The study aims to investigate the effects of the MIND diet on oxidative stress, inflammation, and neurodegenerative risk biomarkers in American football players. The study will include 30 athletes, 15 in each group, with 95% confidence (1-α), 95% test power (1-β) and f=0.6 effect size; with 80% confidence (1-α), 80% test power (1-β) and f=0.6 effect size, a total of 20 athletes, 10 in each group, should be included. The study will be conducted over a period of 9 weeks, and the participants will be randomly assigned to either the MIND diet group or the control group. The MIND diet group will receive nutritional advice and will be asked to include the food groups in the MIND diet in their diet in accordance with their consumption frequency. The control group will maintain their usual eating habits. The primary outcome measures will include tau protein, NfL (Neurofilament light polypeptide), S100B protein, BDNF (Brain Derived Neurotrophic Factor), telomere, zonulin, NOX2 (NADPH oxidase), 8-OHdG (8- hydroxy-2-deoxyguanosine), F2-isoprostanes (F2-isoPs), hs-CRP (High-sensitivity C-reactive protein), IL-6 (Interleukin 6), and TNF-α (Tumor necrosis factor alpha). The secondary outcome measures will include sleep quality score and quality of life score.

The study is a Phase 1a, randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled, single site, single ascending dose study of the safety, tolerability, and pharmacokinetics of CSX-1004 injection in healthy adults. The study is designed to assess the safety, tolerability, and pharmacokinetics of CSX-1004 in healthy adults. The study will enroll 24 healthy adults, aged 18 to 50 years, inclusive, with a minimum weight of 50.0 kg and maximum weight of 100.0 kg, BMI within the range of 18.0 to 32.0 kg/m2, inclusive. The study will be conducted over a period of 5 months. The primary outcome measures will include treatment-emergent adverse events (AEs), serious AEs, and AEs leading to discontinuation. Secondary outcome measures will include Cmax, AUCinf, AUClast, Tmax, and t1/2. The study will be conducted in accordance with the Declaration of Helsinki and Good Clinical Practice guidelines.

* Joint Aspiration in Dysfunctional Hip, Knee or Shoulder Prostheses (Chronic Infection or Implant Failure) JAD-Pro
* Joint Prosthesis; Complications
* Other: joint puncture
* Primary Outcome Measures: Analysis of the bacteriological concordance between JFA and perioperative samples

19F MRI is a non-invasive imaging technique that can detect and quantify airway dysfunction in cystic fibrosis. The study aims to evaluate the effectiveness of 19F MRI in detecting and quantifying airway dysfunction in cystic fibrosis. The study will use a combination product of 19F MRI and inhaled perfluoropropane. The study will measure the change in ventilation defect parameter (VDP) over 14 days and 365 days, as well as the change in FLVlongtau2 over 14 days and 365 days. The study will also measure the change in VDP occurring with a protocol-defined CF pulmonary exacerbation. Secondary outcome measures will include the change in MRI severity score over 365 days and the correlation of MRI severity score with VDP and FLVlongtau2 at baseline.

32 healthy Chinese subjects will be randomly assigned to TR group and RT group in a 1:1 ratio. Subjects in the TR group will take the test preparation (T) 200 mg/ pill × 1 pill on day 1 (D1) and the reference preparation (R) 200 mg/ pill × 1 pill on day 8 (D8). The sequence of medication in RT group is reversed from TR group. Wash for at least 7 days between doses. The trial drug STI-1558 should be taken with approximately 240 ml of water after fasting overnight for at least 10h. Except for drinking water, water should be prohibited for at least 1h before and after administration, and fasting should be at least 4h after administration. Test drugs (T and R) must be swallowed whole and not chewed, crushed or separated. In order to ensure the subject's compliance with the medication procedure, the staff should check the subject's mouth after taking the medication. Screening was performed within 28 days prior to initial dosing, and all eligible subjects were admitted to the clinical research center 1 day prior to Cycle 1 dosing (D-1) and discharged on day 10 of the study (D10) after completing Cycle 2 PK blood collection, corresponding safety examination, and evaluation. On the 14th day of the study (± 1 day), the clinical research center was returned for follow-up to further evaluate the safety and tolerability of the subjects.

============

The study is a randomized controlled trial that aims to evaluate the effectiveness of detachment of the breathing circuit on the rate of double-lumen endotracheal tube malposition after the change of position in patients undergoing thoracic surgery. The study includes 100 patients who are randomly assigned to either the experimental group or the control group. The experimental group receives disengagement of the breathing circuit when the patient's position is changed from the supine position to the lateral decubitus position, while the control group receives maintenance of the normal connection of the breathing line. The primary outcome measure is the malposition rate of a double-lumen endobronchial tube, which is measured immediately after a change in body position. Secondary outcome measures include the effects of lung collapse, blood oxygen saturation, and PACU length of stay. The study is conducted in accordance with the Declaration of Helsinki and is approved by the Ethics Committee of Centre Hospitalier Valida.

The study aims to evaluate the effectiveness of personalized comprehensive diabetes support among families of children with newly diagnosed type 1 diabetes. The study is a randomized, parallel assignment, open-label study. The intervention is personalized comprehensive diabetes support for 6 months following type 1 diabetes diagnosis. The primary outcome measures are Diabetes Distress Scale and Problem Areas in Diabetes (PAID) scores at 24 months. The study includes families of children 16 years of age or younger with a new diagnosis and a stable living situation. The study excludes families of children older than 16 years and those from non-English speaking families.

=================

The relevance of telemedicine monitoring in the management of depression after a hospitalization in medicine or surgery is being investigated. The study is a randomized, multicenter clinical trial with two arms. The primary objective is to assess the efficacy of telemedicine monitoring in the management of depression after a hospitalization in medicine or surgery. The secondary objective is to evaluate the feasibility and satisfaction of telemedicine tools by patients included in the experimental group. The study will be conducted over a period of 3 years, with a follow-up of 36 months. The study will include 120 patients, aged 18 years and over, who have been hospitalized in medicine or surgery and have been diagnosed with a major depressive disorder. The study will be conducted in two arms: one arm will receive usual care, and the other arm will receive telemedicine monitoring in addition to usual care. The primary endpoint will be the clinical efficacy of telemedicine monitoring in the management of depression after a hospitalization in medicine or surgery, assessed by the percentage of patients in remission from depression at 6 months after inclusion. The study will also evaluate the feasibility and satisfaction of telemedicine tools by patients included in the experimental group, as well as the clinical variables associated with dropout of the care program. The study will be conducted in accordance with the Declaration of Helsinki and will be approved by the Ethics Committee of the Centre Hospitalier Valida.

=============

This study aims to develop an AI algorithm that can differentiate between benign and malignant soft tissue masses using quantitative MRI. The study will recruit patients who are already having a scan for sarcoma and will ask them to consent to extra MR images being acquired. The extra images will add a maximum of 10 minutes to the patients' standard MRI scan, meaning patients will not need to make an extra trip or undergo any extra procedures. A small subset of patients will be asked if they would be willing to come for a second scan so that the researchers can see how reliable the measurements are, but this will be entirely optional. The study will measure the diagnostic accuracy of the AI algorithms using ROC analysis of accuracy, sensitivity and specificity of the algorithm for distinguishing between benign and malignant soft tissue lesions. The study will also measure the classification accuracy of the AI algorithms using ROC analysis of accuracy, sensitivity and specificity of the algorithm for classifying malignant lesions into their pathological grade. The study will use MRI, Diffusion weighted imaging, Radiomics, Deep Learning, Machine Learning, and Quantitative MRI.

* Study design: Split-mouth randomized controlled trial
* Study duration: 24 months
* Study population: 20 systematically healthy patients having thin gingival phenotypes
* Study interventions: Microneedling alone and microneedling along with hyaluronic acid
* Study outcomes: Gingival thickness, keratinized tissue width, and periodontal indices
* Study location: Department of Periodontics and Oral Implantology, Post Graduate Institute of Dental Sciences, Rohtak

The study is a multicenter randomized controlled trial (RCT) that aims to evaluate the effects of preoperative immunonutrition on patients undergoing elective colorectal surgery for neoplasm. The study will compare the outcomes of patients receiving a dietary supplement (Oral Impact Nestle) with those of patients receiving a placebo. The primary outcome measure is surgical site infection (SSI), while secondary outcome measures include anastomotic leakage, length of stay, inflammatory infiltration in the subcutaneous adipose tissue (SAT) and visceral adipose tissue (VAT), and grade of fibrosis in the SAT and VAT. The study will be conducted in accordance with the Declaration of Helsinki and will be registered in the ClinicalTrials.gov registry.

===============

The study aims to investigate the impact and possible additional benefits of adding an oculomotor treatment to a cervical protocol in patients with migraine. The study will be a randomized, parallel assignment intervention model with a control group receiving a cervical treatment and an experimental group receiving an additional oculomotor treatment. The primary outcome measure will be changes in the impact of headache using the Headache Impact Test (HIT-6) Questionnaire. Secondary outcome measures will include changes in pain using the Visual Analog Scale (VAS), changes in disability using the Migraine Disability Assessment (MIDAS) Questionnaire, changes in depression using the Patient Health Questionnaire (PHQ-9) Questionnaire, changes in anxiety using the Generalized Anxiety Disorder (GAD-7) Questionnaire, changes in sleep quality using the Pittsburgh Sleep Quality Index (PSQI) Questionnaire, changes in kinesiophobia using the Tampa Scale of Kinesiophobia (TSK-11) Questionnaire, changes in catastrophizing using the Pain Catastrophizing Scale (PCS) Questionnaire, changes in central sensitization using the Central Sensitization Inventory (CSI) Questionnaire, changes in neck disability using the Neck Disability Index (NDI) Questionnaire, changes in head repositioning using the Head Repositioning test, changes in the strength of the deep cervical flexors using the Grimmer Test, changes in ocular movement using the Smooth tracking test, changes in ocular movement with variation of the head using the Smooth Pursuit Neck Torsion test, changes in range of movement using the Cervical Range of Motion Instrument, and changes in quality of life using the Short-Form 12 Health Survey (SF-12). The study will be conducted over a period of 6 weeks, with participants receiving treatment once a week. The study will be conducted in a single center in Spain.

The CRATOS study is a single-arm, open-label, interventional study evaluating the safety and efficacy of the Cratos™ Branch Stent Graft System in the treatment of descending aorta lesions, including aortic dissection type B, intramural hematoma, and penetrating aortic ulcer. The study is designed to assess the 30-day all-cause mortality rate in patients who receive the Cratos™ Stent Graft TEVAR procedure. Eligibility criteria include the presence of thoracic aortic pathology, appropriate proximal aortic landing zone, appropriate left subclavian artery landing zone, appropriate distal aortic landing zone, and appropriate exclusion criteria. The study is conducted as a single-group assignment with no masking. The primary outcome measure is 30-day all-cause mortality.

The DETECT-IP trial is a randomized controlled trial that aims to reduce the incidence of acute renal failure and/or hyperkalemia adverse drug events in older hospitalized patients by incorporating specific rules into a computerized support system and dedicated procedures. The study will be conducted in 10 hospitals in France and will recruit 1,000 patients over a period of 18 months. The intervention group will receive clinical decision support, while the control group will not. The primary outcome measure will be the number of adverse drug events such as acute renal failure and/or hyperkalemia in older hospitalized patients. Secondary outcome measures will include the presence of an adverse event related to the intervention provided, therapeutic adaptations implemented in case of acute renal failure or hyperkalemia upon hospital admission, relevance of CDSS alerts, number of pharmaceutical interventions accepted, changes in ADEs prevention/management work process induced by the introduction of alerts, and cost-effectiveness of the pharmaceutical intervention. The study will be conducted over a period of 20 days, and the results will be analyzed using intention-to-treat principles.

=========

The study aims to investigate the differences in the proportions and abundance of bacterial taxa and the function of the bacterial profile between the mesentery, ileal tissue and blood of Crohn's Disease (CD) patients with and without early post-surgical disease recurrence. The study will also investigate the association analysis of genetic variants related to innate immunity and the bacterial microbiome profile of CD patients. The study will include CD patients requiring surgical treatment (ileocecal resection) and a control group of patients requiring an ileocecal resection for a cause other than CD. The primary outcome measures will be the differences in the proportions and abundance of bacterial taxa and the function of the bacterial profile between the mesentery, ileal tissue and blood of CD patients with and without early post-surgical disease recurrence. The secondary outcome measures will be the association analysis of genetic variants related to innate immunity and the bacterial microbiome profile of CD patients. The study will be conducted at Centre Hospitalier Valida.

The study is a randomized, parallel assignment, open-label study of the effect of injection site on the relative bioavailability of a single dose of LY3437943 in healthy participants with a high body mass index. The study is designed to measure the pharmacokinetics of LY3437943, including the area under the plasma concentration versus time curve from zero to infinity (AUC[0-∞]) and maximum concentration (Cmax). The study will be conducted in two parts. In Part A, participants will receive a single dose of LY3437943 administered subcutaneously (SC) in either thigh, upper arm, or abdomen. In Part B, participants will receive a single dose of LY3437943 administered intravenously (IV). The study will be conducted in healthy participants with a high body mass index between 27.0 and 45.0 kg/m². The study will be conducted in accordance with the Declaration of Helsinki and Good Clinical Practice guidelines.

=================

A Research Registry on Aggressive PitNETs is a study that aims to characterize the aggressiveness of pituitary tumors by transcriptome analysis. The study is designed for patients with a diagnosis of pituitary tumor whose file has been presented to the national HYPOcare RCP. The study measures the molecular and transcriptomic signature of aggressiveness of pituitary tumors predictive of prognosis over a time frame of 3 years. The study does not have any exclusion criteria and is open to all ages and sexes.

The OPTI study is a randomized, phase 2 pilot study that aims to investigate the feasibility of a lower starting dose of oral anticancer drugs in older adults with cancer. The study will recruit 30 patients aged 65 years or older, who are starting treatment with one of the following anti-cancer drugs: pazopanib, olaparib, lenvatinib, sunitinib, or palbociclib. The study will compare the standard-of-care (control group) with a lower starting dose of the anti-cancer drug (intervention group). The primary endpoint is the feasibility of investigating whether a lower starting dose with a step-up approach leads to a better overall treatment utility compared to standard dosing. Secondary endpoints include progression-free survival, overall survival, quality of life, safety, hospital care use, and pharmacokinetic parameters. The study will be conducted over a period of 12 weeks, with blood samples for PK analysis collected every 2 weeks, and a baseline blood sample collected for pharmacogenomic analysis.

The study is a prospective, multicenter, randomized controlled study (PRECAM-R) to evaluate the efficacy and safety of neoadjuvant chemoradiotherapy followed by Envafolimab Plus CAPEOX for MSS-type advanced middle-low rectal cancer. The study will enroll 108 patients with MSS-type advanced middle-low rectal cancer who are willing to receive neoadjuvant therapy. The patients will be randomly assigned to receive neoadjuvant chemoradiotherapy followed by Envafolimab Plus CAPEOX or neoadjuvant chemoradiotherapy alone. The primary objective of the study is to evaluate the pathologic complete response (pCR) rate following short-course radiation then Envafolimab Plus CAPEOX. The secondary objectives are to evaluate the tumor regression grade, overall survival (OS), progression-free survival (PFS), treatment-related adverse events (TRAEs), surgical complications, and quality of life (QoL) of the patients in two neoadjuvant settings of short-course radiation followed with or without Envafolimab Plus CAPEOX. The study will be conducted in accordance with the Declaration of Helsinki and will be approved by the Institutional Review Board of each participating center.

A two-stage study to evaluate the safety, efficacy, pharmacokinetics, pharmacodynamics, and immunogenicity of levilimab in patients with active rheumatoid arthritis resistant to methotrexate monotherapy. The study will be conducted in two stages. Stage 1 will be an open-label, single-center, non-randomized cohort study of the safety and tolerability of single intravenous or subcutaneous levilimab injections administered to healthy subjects at ascending doses. Stage 2 will be a randomized, comparative, double-blind, controlled clinical study to assess efficacy, safety, pharmacokinetics, pharmacodynamics, and immunogenicity of levilimab when administered at repeated intravenous or subcutaneous doses in subjects with active rheumatoid arthritis resistant to methotrexate monotherapy. The primary endpoint of the study is the safety profile of levilimab following its single subcutaneous or intravenous administration at ascending doses in healthy subjects. The secondary endpoint is the proportion of subjects who achieved low activity of rheumatoid arthritis (DAS28-ESR <3.2) at Week 24 of the study in each treatment group. The study will be conducted in accordance with the Declaration of Helsinki and Good Clinical Practice guidelines.

===============

The study is a randomized, double-blind, cross-over clinical trial to evaluate the efficacy of white kidney bean on oral glucose tolerance test. The study includes 30 healthy adults aged 25-45 years, with a male to female ratio of more than 40% and BMI 24. The intervention is a dietary supplement, and the primary outcome measure is the change of blood glucose level in mmol/L based on OGTT (Oral Glucose Tolerance Test) after intervention. The study is designed to measure the change of blood glucose level in mmol/L based on OGTT (Oral Glucose Tolerance Test) after intervention: chewing Wonderlab Product - White Kidney Bean Pressed Candy, followed by Placebo Product at the interval of washout duration of 72 hours; and chewing Placebo Product, followed by Wonderlab Product - White Kidney Bean Pressed Candy at the interval of washout duration of 72 hours. The study is conducted in two phases, each phase is 1 day.

The IMPLEMENTATION of Evidence Based Facility and Community Interventions to Reduce the Treatment Gap for depression is a randomized controlled trial. The study aims to evaluate the effectiveness of community intervention strategies delivered by community volunteers in addition to the facility model of the Healthy Activity Program (HAP) in reducing the treatment gap for depression. The study will be conducted in village clusters in India. The primary outcome measures will be contact coverage and effectiveness coverage, measured using the Patient Health Questionnaire 9 items (PHQ-9) score. Secondary outcome measures will include sustained effectiveness, remission, response to treatment, client service receipt inventory, WHO Disability Assessment Schedule (WHODAS 2.0), survey form for collecting costs of receiving HAP intervention to patients, inventory form for collecting system-level economic costs of delivering interventions, depression awareness, perceived social support, Multidimensional Scale of Perceived Social Support (MSPSS), and treatment completion. The study will be conducted over a period of 12 months.

The study aims to investigate the acute and chronic effects of low-intensity blood flow restriction training in normoxia and hypoxia conditions on muscle strength, thickness, catecholamine, and inflammatory responses in physically active adults. The study will use a randomized, parallel assignment, single-masked design with four arms: active comparator (low-intensity normoxia and high-intensity normoxia), experimental (low-intensity normoxia with blood flow restriction and low-intensity hypoxia), and control (low-intensity normoxia and low-intensity hypoxia). The study will measure primary outcomes such as force output, one-repetition maximum, maximum number of repetitions, countermovement jump height, countermovement jump power output, catecholamine response, muscle stiffness, and muscle thickness. Secondary outcomes will include perception of pain, perception of effort, blood pressure, and inflammatory responses. The study will be conducted over a period of 6 weeks, with participants performing resistance training twice a week.

* Mosunetuzumab is a new, bispecific, T-cell engaging antibody that has shown very high response rates and long response duration in B-cell lymphoma patients with multiple relapses or lack of response to standard salvage regimens.
* The main hypothesis of this trial is that mosunetuzumab is better than standard 2nd line salvage regimens in terms of progression free survival 2 years after the initiation of 2nd line treatment in POD24 patients.
* The study will investigate the efficacy of subcutaneous (SC) mosunetuzumab monotherapy in follicular lymphoma (FL) with POD24.
* The secondary objectives are to investigate safety of mosunetuzumab in patients with a current POD24 event prognostic significance of 18F-FDG-PET-CT response to mosunetuzumab rate of transformation to higher grade lymphoma following mosunetuzumab patients´ self-reported quality of life during and after mosunetuzumab resource usage related to mosunetuzumab Interventions: Mosunetuzumab is administered SC as described below. Patients are followed for at least 2,5 years and a maximum of 5 years in the trial. Study-specific sampling of peripheral blood for exploratory research amounts to 330-380 mL (depending on the number of treatment cycles) collected over 3 years. Study-specific tumor samples for future research will be collected by fine needle aspiration before the start of treatment and after the third treatment cycle. Ethical considerations: Previous studies have shown that mosunetuzumab is highly effective and well tolerated in heavily treated B-cell lymphoma patients. The safety profile is favourable compared to standard immunochemotherapy. Mosunetuzumab can be safely administered to older patients with co-morbidities, and there is no upper age limit for participation in the trial. The potential beneficial effect of mosunetuzumab in a population of follicular lymphoma patients with POD24 outweighs the risk for rare and undiscovered serious adverse events. The total volume of blood samples is considered acceptable for patients in clinical trials. The extra

===============

The ASCERTAIN study is a 2-arm, multicentre, phase IV, randomised, open-label study that aims to evaluate the implementation and utility of a primary care model in patients with Atherosclerotic Cardiovascular Disease (ASCVD) or ASCVD-risk equivalents and elevated LDL-C. The study will include male and female participants ≥18 years of age with a history of ASCVD or ASCVD-risk equivalents who have elevated LDL-C (≥1.8 mmol/L). A total of approximately 600 participants will be included in the study and will be randomised in a 1:1 ratio at approximately 20 sites across Australia. The study will utilise Electronic Health Records (EHR) and only clinics using Medical Director (MD) Clinical software will be able to participate in the study. The primary clinical question of interest is: What is the effectiveness of a new model of care implementation strategy compared to usual care in patients who have not reached their LDL-target? In the usual care arm, GPs will be educated on the European Society of Cardiology (ESC) guidelines and Guideline Directed Management therapy (GDMT) and will receive monthly short message service (SMS) messages with regards to cardiovascular health and appointment reminders (low touch engagement nudges) and telephone-based support calls from a study nurse trained in motivational interviewing. In the new model of care arm, GPs will be educated on the ESC guidelines and GDMT and will receive monthly SMS messages with regards to cardiovascular health and appointment reminders (low touch engagement nudges) and telephone-based support calls from a study nurse trained in motivational interviewing. Participants will receive a link to the questionnaire via text message or email. The analysis will be performed at the end of the study, after the data for all participants are available.

This is a randomized, controlled, single-blinded study conducted in urology operating theatre, Al-Azhar university hospital. Forty eight patients of both sex and aged from 21-65 years in period between February 2022 to January 2023 scheduled for elective open renal surgeries under general anesthesia were enrolled in this study. The patients were classified to one of three groups: Erector spinae block (ESPB), Thoracic para-vertebral block (TPVB), or control group. The primary outcome measure was total morphine requirements 24 hours postoperatively.

The study aims to describe and evaluate musculoskeletal health of adult haematological cancer survivors and its impact to survivors. The study will use mixed quantitative and qualitative methodology. The study will be conducted in 5-10 years post cancer treatment, 11-20 years post cancer treatment, 21-30 years post cancer treatment, and 30 years + post cancer treatment. The study will be conducted in male and female participants aged 18-70 years at diagnosis of haematological cancers: lymphoma or leukaemia. The study will be conducted in cancer survivors as recorded in the local database of lymphoma and haematopoietic stem cell transplant database. The study will be conducted in English. The study will be conducted in a mixed methods study design. The study will be conducted in a cross-sectional study design. The study will be conducted in a descriptive study design. A Phase 2 Basket Study of Disitamab Vedotin in Adult Subjects With Previously Treated, Locally-Advanced Unresectable or Metastatic Solid Tumors That Express HER2

The study is a Phase 2 basket study of disitamab vedotin in adult subjects with previously treated, locally-advanced unresectable or metastatic solid tumors that express HER2. The study has four cohorts: HNSCC, NSCLC, Ovarian Cancer, and Endometrial Cancer. The intervention is disitamab vedotin monotherapy given into the vein (IV, intravenous) every 2 weeks. The primary outcome measure is the confirmed objective response rate (ORR) per response evaluation in solid tumors version 1.1 (RECIST v1.1) by investigator assessment, measured approximately 3 years after the start of study treatment. Secondary outcome measures include the number of participants with adverse events (AEs), number of participants with laboratories abnormalities, number of participants with dose alterations due to AEs, confirmed disease control rate (DCR) per RECIST v1.1 by investigator assessment, duration of response (DOR) per RECIST v1.1 by investigator assessment, duration of progression-free survival (PFS) per RECIST v1.1 by investigator assessment, overall survival (OS), pharmacokinetic (PK) parameters, and incidence of antidrug antibodies (ADAs). The study is designed as a single group assignment with no masking. The study is open to adult subjects with HNSCC, NSCLC, Ovarian Cancer, and Endometrial Cancer who have previously treated, locally-advanced unresectable or metastatic stage disease and have progressed after treatment with a platinum-based therapy or, within 6 months of platinum-based adjuvant, neoadjuvant, or concomitant chemoradiotherapy for early or locally-advanced stage disease. The study is not open to healthy volunteers. The study is designed to measure the efficacy and safety of disitamab vedotin monotherapy in adult subjects with previously treated, locally-advanced unresectable or metastatic solid tumors that express HER2.

=========

The study aims to assess and address ICU survivor driving safety through in-vehicle driving assessment and monitoring. The investigators propose to enroll a cohort of older ICU survivors with risk factors for ICU-acquired cognitive impairment to complete neurocognitive measures and participate in driving data collection via in-vehicle sensors over a 6-month post-hospital discharge period. The study will evaluate the relationship between neurocognitive assessments and driving behavior and safety in older ICU survivors, and conduct stakeholder advisory panels on the priorities and data presentation needs of driving assessments for older ICU survivors. The study is designed in response to the NIA Strategic Plan (Goal C-1-9 Safety of Older Drivers) to contribute to a critical gap in health promotion to develop an evidence-based, in-vehicle driving assessment system to provide actionable driving safety data and rehabilitation strategies tailored to ICU survivors, the participants' care partners and clinicians.

The ACT for Healthy Living study is a randomized controlled trial that evaluates the efficacy of a brief ACT workshop for weight loss in women with obesity. The study includes 70 women who will be randomly assigned to either the intervention group (n = 35) or the waitlist control group (n = 35). The intervention group will receive a 4-hour ACT workshop, while the waitlist control group will not receive the intervention until all members of the intervention group have received the workshop. The primary outcome measures include change from baseline in psychological flexibility, distress tolerance, valued living, weight self-stigma, body image, emotional eating, physical activity, and diet quality at Week 1 and 1 month. Secondary outcome measures include change in body weight at Week 1 and 1 month. The study is designed to measure the effectiveness of the ACT workshop in improving these outcomes.

===============

This is a one-arm prospective observational clinical study that aims to evaluate the value of MRD detection in monitoring postoperative recurrence of high-risk GIST, investigate the effect of drug holiday treatment mode based on MRD detection on disease recurrence and patient survival, and to explore whether it can delay the occurrence of drug-resistant mutations. The study will assist some high-risk GIST patients who have been treated with imatinib for 3 years after surgery and have achieved disease control to adopt the treatment mode of drug holiday based MRD detection. The primary outcome measure is progression-free survival after patients first enter the drug holiday, and the secondary outcome measures include overall survival, drug re-use rate, drug retreatment response rate, genetic mutation profiling of ctDNA-MRD, and comparison of MRD versus imaging examination. The study will be conducted in accordance with the Declaration of Helsinki and will be approved by the Ethics Committee of Centre Hospitalier Valida.

=============

This is a randomized control trial comparing the effects of Dohsa hou exercises on functional mobility in children with Down syndrome. The study will use the Test of trunk impairment scale and Time Up and Go Test to assess functional mobility. Participants will be divided into two groups using simple random sampling techniques and will receive either standard treatment protocol or Dohsa hou exercises. The study will run for 6 weeks, with assessments conducted at the end of the study period. The primary outcome measures will be the Trunk impairment scale and Time Up and Go Test.

The SPLASH study is a 2-arm, group randomized controlled trial (RCT) with n=400 3rd-5th grade students from low-income schools receiving either the multilevel Rising New York Road Runners (RNYRR) program (n=4) or delayed-intervention control (n=4). The overarching hypothesis is that the RNYRR program will have positive effects on elementary schoolchildren's physical literacy (PL) and, in turn, physical activity (PA). Aims include testing the multilevel RNYRR program using a 2-arm, group randomized controlled trial (RCT) with n=400 3rd-5th grade students from low-income schools receiving either the multilevel RNYRR program (n=4) or delayed-intervention control (n=4). Aim 3: To evaluate the impact of the RNYRR program on children's physical literacy (PL) and physical activity (PA) (total daily volume and moderate-to-vigorous PA (MVPA)) over one school year. Hypothesis: Children who attend schools with the RNYRR programming will increase PL and PA (total daily volume and MVPA) relative to children in control schools. Aim 3a: To examine whether RNYRR program effects on children's PL and PA differ by sex or weight status. Aim 3b: To test whether changes in PL and PL subdomains (e.g. ability, confidence, motivation) mediate changes in daily total PA volume or MVPA.

A Phase III, Randomised, Double-blind, Parallel-group, 76-week, Efficacy and Safety Study of BI 456906 Administered Subcutaneously Compared With Placebo in Patients With Obesity Disease in Japanese

The study is a Phase III, randomized, double-blind, parallel-group, 76-week, efficacy and safety study of BI 456906 administered subcutaneously compared with placebo in patients with obesity disease in Japanese. The study aims to evaluate the efficacy and safety of BI 456906 in reducing body weight and improving metabolic parameters in patients with obesity disease in Japanese. The study will enroll 200 patients who meet the inclusion criteria and will be randomly assigned to either the experimental group (BI 456906) or the placebo group. The experimental group will receive BI 456906 administered subcutaneously once weekly for 76 weeks, while the placebo group will receive placebo administered subcutaneously once weekly for 76 weeks. The primary outcome measure will be the percentage change in body weight from baseline to Week 76. Secondary outcome measures will include the achievement of body weight reduction ≥5%, ≥10%, ≥15%, and ≥20% from baseline to Week 76, as well as the achievement of body weight reduction ≥5%, ≥10%, ≥15%, and ≥20% from baseline to Week 76. The study will also assess the safety and tolerability of BI 456906.

The study aims to compare the results with values considered risky for aspiration by evaluating the pre- and postoperative gastric volume with ultrasound in children who undergo tonsillectomy and/or adenoidectomy. The study will include ASA 1,2,3 patients under the age of 18 who will undergo tonsillectomy and/or adenoidectomy in the operating rooms of Istanbul University, Istanbul Medical Faculty, Department of Otorhinolaryngology, after the approval of the ethics committee. All the patients will be given oral midazolam at a dose of 0.3 mg/kg as standard in the preoperative preparation room. After standard monitoring (ECG, NIBP, SpO2) is performed in the operating room, gastric volume will be evaluated by ultrasound in the right lateral position before the operation. After induction of general anesthesia (sevoflurane + 02 + NO2 inhalation, 1 mcg/kg fentanyl, 0.5 mg/kg rocuronium) patients will be intubated. After intubation, gastric volume will be re-evaluated by ultrasound in the right lateral position. anesthesia will be maintained with a mixture of sevoflurane + 40%/60% O2/NO2 for a MAC of 1.0. At the end of the surgery, before the patient is extubated, the gastric volume will be evaluated by ultrasound in the right lateral position. Afterwards, the patients will be extubated and taken to the postoperative recovery room. Nausea and vomiting of patients during awakening and for the next 24 hours will be recorded. Patients' age, gender, height, weight, duration of surgery will also be recorded in the follow-up form.

The study aims to explore the impact of pituitrin on the prognosis of patients with pulmonary hypertension after cardiac surgery. The study is a randomized controlled study, with 100 patients in the pituitrin group and 100 patients in the normal saline group. The patients are randomly assigned to either the pituitrin group or the normal saline group. The pituitrin group receives pituitrin, while the normal saline group receives normal saline. The primary outcome measure is a composite endpoint of mortality or severe postoperative complications. The secondary outcome measures include incidence of postoperative infection, septic shock, duration of mechanical ventilation, postoperative pulmonary complications, time to achieve hemodynamic stability, use of dobutamine or other vasoactive drugs, incidence of digital ischemia, acute mesenteric ischemia, gastrointestinal complications, incidence of acute myocardial infarction, new onset tachyarrhythmia, water poisoning, vasodilative shock, incidence of pulmonary embolism, low cardiac output syndrome, acute respiratory distress syndrome, delirium, need for renal replacement therapy (RRT), need for hemodialysis, incidence of readmission to ICU, length of ICU stay, length of stay, levels of serum antidiuretic hormone in patients, levels of copeptin in patients, secondary endotracheal intubation. The study is expected to provide reference for the clinical application of pituitrin in patients with pulmonary hypertension after cardiac surgery.

=============

This is a feasibility and safety study of home initiation of noninvasive positive pressure ventilation (NiPPV) in children with medical complexity. The study compares home NiPPV initiation to usual care of initiating NiPPV in a one-night in-hospital polysomnogram (PSG). The study aims to evaluate the feasibility and safety of an innovative model of care for NiPPV initiation in the home environment utilizing remote telemonitoring compared to usual care which is in-hospital PSG laboratory-based initiation. The study will recruit 20 participants aged 5-17 years old who are newly prescribed NiPPV and tolerated awake NiPPV trial. The study will measure the recruitment and retention rate, proportion of eligible patients randomized, proportion of patients that crossover based on safety criteria, mean minutes of nightly NiPPV usage, proxy-reported Psychological Scale (percentage rank), proxy-reported Psychological Scale (T-value), self-reported Psychological Scale (percentage rank), self-reported Psychological Scale (T-value), caregiver reported Sense of Mastery, patient and family study experience, preference of intervention and barriers, difference in expiratory positive airway pressure based on home NiPPV titration and PSG titration in the intervention arm, and difference in inspiratory positive airway pressure based on home NiPPV titration and PSG titration in the intervention arm. The study will be conducted over a 12-week period.

The study will be a single-blind randomized clinical trial carried out in the department of Invasive Physiotherapy of a private Physiotherapy Clinic in Toledo. The study will be conducted on healthy female volleyball practitioners who have latent MTPs in gastrocnemius and are familiar with performing CMJ tests. The study will be conducted in two groups: intervention group and control group. The intervention group will receive dry needling on the latent trigger points diagnosed on the selection phase. The control group will not receive any intervention. The primary outcome measure will be the counter movement jump. The study will be conducted for 15 minutes. The aim of the present study was to investigate the clinical features of refractory GI HSP and the clinical outcome of mycophenolate mofetil in these patients. The study was a single group assignment, open label, and designed to treat refractory gastrointestinal Henoch-Schönlein purpura patients with mycophenolate mofetil. The primary outcome measure was the incidence of abdominal pain, hematemesis, and bloody stools, assessed by checklist for 6 months. The secondary outcome measure was the count of red blood cells in stool, tested every week for 6 months. The study included patients aged 3 to 18 years old who met the diagnostic criteria for HSP and involved the digestive tract, were refractory to intravenous corticosteroid 2 mg/kg/d for 3 days without efficacy or relapsed during the attenuation of corticosteroid, and had parents or guardians who agreed to treatment and signed a written informed consent form. The study excluded patients who were allergic to MMF, had severe diseases, other digestive system diseases, had previously used MMF clinical trials, or were in other situations the researcher thought inappropriate to participate in the study.

===============

The study is a staged, open-label, Phase II/III safety, feasibility, and efficacy investigational device trial for Electroencephalogram (EEG) Enhanced Transcranial Magnetic Stimulation (eTMS) for Chronic Trauma and Stressor-Related Disorders (TSRD). The study aims to assess the safety, feasibility, and preliminary efficacy of eTMS as an adjunct to standard of care and integrative treatment for TSRD. The study will enroll 30 participants in the initial cohort, and an additional 270 participants in Stage 2. The primary outcome measures are the number of participants with device-related serious adverse events and the rate of participants completing 80% of scheduled visits. The secondary outcome measure is the mean change in Veterans RAND 36-item health survey (VR-36) mental component scores. The study will be conducted over 6 weeks, with 30 sessions of daily eTMS as an adjunct to standard of care and integrative treatment for TSRD.

A retrospective study of radiotherapy combined with EGFR-TKI for stage III EGFR mutant lung cancer. The primary study metric is progression-free survival (PFS). Eligibility criteria include patients diagnosed with lung cancer by pathology, genetic testing for EGFR mutation type, compliance with the international eighth edition of lung cancer TNM stage IIIA-IIIC, treatment modality of radiotherapy + targeted therapy, Eastern Cooperative Oncology Group (ECOG) physical status score ≤ 2, and no surgery or chemotherapy. The study is an open-label, multiinstitutional, single-arm retrospective study of three-dimensional conformal radiotherapy (3DCRT) or intensity-modulated conformal radiotherapy (IMRT) at a prescribed dose of 54-66 Gy/27-33 f. The combined TKI includes gefitinib, erlotinib, erlotinib, oseltinib, and ametinib. The specific uses are: gefitinib 250 mg orally once daily; erlotinib 125 mg orally three times daily; erlotinib 150 mg orally once daily; oseltinib 80 mg orally once daily; ametinib 110 mg orally once daily. TKI is taken until disease progression or intolerability. The primary outcome measure is progression-free survival (PFS) for 2 years.

The study aims to identify the microorganisms responsible for acute head and neck infections. The study will be conducted over a period of 4 years and will involve DNA analysis of ribosomal ribonucleic acid (rRNA) genes and biochemical testing. The study will also collect patient characteristics such as age, sex, site of infection, length of hospital stay, antibiotic treatment, and diabetic diagnosis. The primary outcome measure will be the identification of Streptococci species, while the secondary outcome measures will include patient characteristics and clinical outcomes. The study will be conducted at Northampton General Hospital.

===============

The study was conducted in the period of 07/21/2021-30/10/2021. The study included 48 women aged 29-49 years old who have complained of stress urinary incontinence for at least 4 weeks, who gave birth and signed the consent form. The study aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of functional magnetic stimulation and pelvic floor muscle training on pelvic floor muscle function, urinary incontinence symptoms and quality of life in women with stress urinary incontinence. Participants were randomly divided into two groups: the I group (n=24), in which participants underwent functional magnetic stimulation and the II group (n=24) in which subjects received pelvic floor muscle training program. Participants were evaluated before the intervention and repeated after 6 weeks. Subjects responded to a general questionnaire before the intervention, before and after the intervention, the International Consultation on Incontinence Questionnaire-Short Form (ICIQ-SF) and Incontinence Impact Questionnaire-Short Form (IIQ-7) were used to assess the symptoms of urinary incontinence and their impact on quality of life. Pelvic floor muscle strength and endurance were assessed with a Pelvexiser perineometer. Statistical analysis was performed by IBM SPSS Statistics 26.0 and Microsoft Excel software 365.

=============

The study aims to optimize the selection and treatment outcomes of biologic therapies for psoriatic arthritis (PsA) and seronegative rheumatoid arthritis (RA) patients. The study will use ultrasonographic and tissue biomarkers to phenotype synovial immune and stromal cells in PsA and RA patients. The study will have six arms, each with a different patient group and intervention/treatment. The primary outcome measure will be minimal disease activity status achievement, recorded for all study cohorts. The study will also measure PsA development and remission maintenance in specific patient groups. The study will use terms such as synovial tissue.

=================

The study aims to investigate the use of artificial tears to prevent nasolacrimal duct obstruction (NLDO) in patients who are treated with radioactive iodine for thyroid cancer. The study is a randomized, parallel assignment, open-label study. Participants will receive artificial tears to be administered in the 4 days immediately following radioactive iodine therapy. The primary outcome measure is the incidence of NLDO as determined by tear duct irrigation by an ophthalmologist. The study will measure the rate of NLDO in each experimental group over a 2-year period.

* Study Title: A Decentralized Phase II Randomized Controlled Trial of Atorvastatin in Resected High-Risk Melanoma
* Study Type: Phase II
* Study Design: Randomized, Parallel Assignment, Double-blind, Placebo-controlled
* Study Duration: 5 years
* Study Status: Active
* Study Start Date: 2019-01-01
* Study End Date: 2024-01-01
* Study Sponsor: National Cancer Institute
* Study Coordinating Center: Oregon Health & Science University (OHSU)
* Study Principal Investigator: Dr. David J. Hicks
* Study Contact Information: [david.hicks@ohsu.edu](mailto:david.hicks@ohsu.edu)


Summary of Study Objectives
=================

* Primary Objective: I. To compare recurrence-free survival (RFS) of patients with high-risk melanoma treated with atorvastatin to placebo.
* Secondary Objectives: I. To compare distant metastasis-free survival (DMFS) between treatment arms. II. To compare overall survival (OS) between treatment arms. III. To assess the clinical utility of gene expression profiling in melanoma.
* Exploratory Objective: I. To assess the clinical utility of gene expression profiling in melanoma.

Summary of Study Outline
=================

* Patients are randomized to 1 of 2 arms.
* ARM I: Patients receive placebo orally (PO) once per day in the absence of disease progression or unacceptable toxicity for up to 5 years and undergo computed tomography (CT) and/or magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) throughout the study.
* ARM II: Patients receive atorvastatin PO once per day in the absence of disease progression or unacceptable toxicity for up to 5 years and CT and/or MRI throughout the study.
* After completion of study treatment, patients are followed for 5 years.

Summary of Study Conditions
=================
