Summary of Study Intervention/Treatment

===============

The ACHIEVE (Advancing Community and Clinical Care for Childbirth-related Hypertension Through Implementation, Engagement, and Valuing Equity) Initiative aims to improve maternal health outcomes for pregnant individuals with high blood pressure by adapting the Severe Hypertension During Pregnancy and Postpartum Period Safety Bundle (HTN bundle) for community clinics providing pregnancy care. The study will determine the impact of three implementation strategies (training, coaching, facilitation) in 20 outpatient clinics in central North Carolina. Usual clinic care for severe hypertension will be compared to the care provided after a practice has 12 months of implementation support from the ACHIEVE Nurse Coordinator. The study will measure fidelity to blood pressure measurement technique, documentation of delivery of patient education on hypertension, recognition and response to simulated episodes of severe hypertension, and recognition and response to actual episodes of severe hypertension.

=========

The proposed study aims to evaluate the effectiveness of scalable, tailored text-messaging programs for alcohol use among older adults. The study focuses on gain and loss framing of behavior change goals, critical components of behavioral science and health behavioral interventions. The study will use a randomized controlled trial design, with three text-messaging programs: loss-framed messaging, gain-framed messaging, and combined (loss and gain) messaging. The study will measure weekly sum of standard drinks and weekly sum of heavy drinking days as primary outcome measures, and percent adherence to daily drinking assessment via text messages and percent adherence to weekly drinking assessment via web as secondary outcome measures. The study will track attrition from the study and explore how the effects of condition are impacted by gender and age.
18F-Fluselenamyl - Beta Amyloid PET Imaging for Alzheimer Disease

=========

The study aims to investigate the long-term effect of transcranial magnetic stimulation (TMS) in primary progressive aphasia (PPA). Participants will be randomly assigned to either the active TMS group or the sham TMS group. The active TMS group will receive TMS over the left dorsolateral prefrontal cortex and language therapy, while the sham TMS group will receive sham TMS and language therapy. The study will measure changes in brain metabolism using FDG-PET imaging, as well as changes in spontaneous language, language assessment, daily-living activities, and neuropsychiatric symptoms. The study will run for 6 months, with assessments at 0, 3, and 6 months.

===============

This is a phase 2a, double-blind, randomized, placebo-controlled trial evaluating the impact of methylprednisolone on cognitive deficits in patients with post-COVID-19 syndrome (PCS). The study aims to demonstrate improvement in memory satisfaction as measured by the Multifactorial Memory Questionnaire (MMQ) in patients with PCS treated with Methylprednisolone compared with placebo. The study spans 52 weeks and includes participants with confirmed SARS-CoV-2 infection, ongoing symptoms of PCS for ≥3 months, and self-reported cognitive deficits at screening. Participants will be randomly assigned in a 1:1 ratio to receive either Methylprednisolone (including a tapering phase) or placebo for 6 weeks, followed by an additional 6 weeks of open treatment phase with Methylprednisolone after a 6-weeks treatment pause. The study will evaluate the safety and efficacy of methylprednisolone in this population and may provide insights into the pathophysiological processes of PCS, leading to the development of more effective therapies and improved patient outcomes.

The study aims to analyze the etiological factors of malnutrition, specifically inflammation and oral intake. The study will use an oral nutritional supplement rich in omega-3 and olive oil polyphenols as the intervention. The primary outcome measures will include blood biochemistry data, such as albumin, prealbumin, C-reactive protein, ferritin, neutrophils, lymphocytes, platelets, total body water, extracellular water, intracellular water, lean mass, fat mass, body cell mass, appendicular skeletal muscle mass, skeletal muscle mass index, test up and go, dynamometry, energy, protein, carbohydrate, fat, monounsaturated fat acids, polyunsaturated fat acids, eicosapentaenoic acid, docosahexaenoic acid, fiber, and malnutrition diagnosis using GLIM criteria. The study will follow patients over a period of 3 consecutive months.

The Kaiser Permanente Evaluating Nutritional Interventions in Food-Insecure High-Risk Adults (KP ENRICH) Study is a randomized controlled trial that aims to evaluate the effectiveness of financial support and free home delivery of healthy food items on glycosylated hemoglobin levels, medical resource utilization, and patient-reported outcomes in food-insecure high-risk adults with Type 2 diabetes mellitus. Participants will be randomized to either the intervention arm, which will receive financial support and free home delivery of healthy food items, or the control arm, which will receive only free home delivery of healthy food items. Glycosylated hemoglobin levels will be assessed at baseline and at 6 months after enrollment. Medical resource utilization will be evaluated at 3 months, 6 months, and 12 months after enrollment. Patient-reported outcomes, including diabetes quality of life, nutrition security, dietary habits, social needs, and food security, will also be assessed at baseline, 6 months, and 12 months after enrollment. The study will be conducted in Kaiser Permanente members with Medi-Cal insurance and no additional private or commercial insurance who have been diagnosed with Type II diabetes mellitus and have at least 2 outpatient glycosylated hemoglobin measures ≥7.5% in the prior 18 months. The study will be conducted in accordance with the Declaration of Helsinki and will obtain Institutional Review Board approval.

This is a four-arm, double-blind, randomized controlled clinical trial evaluating the effect of prolonged evaporation time of the solvent of two universal adhesives in restorations of non-carious cervical lesions. The study will compare the retention and marginal adaptation of composite resin restorations using an alcohol/water-based universal adhesive with evaporation of solvent for 25 seconds versus an acetone-based universal solvent adhesive with solvent evaporation for 25 seconds, as well as an alcohol/water-based universal solvent adhesive with evaporation of solvent for 5 seconds versus an acetone-based universal solvent adhesive with solvent evaporation for 5 seconds. The study will measure the retention of restorations and marginal adaptation of restorations using World Dental Federation (FDI) criteria. The study will be conducted in 70 participants with non-carious cervical lesions in need of restorative treatment. The study will be conducted in 3 centers in Brazil. The study will be conducted over a period of 24 months.
A Phase II/III Study to Evaluate the Immunogenicity and Safety and Efficacy of SWIM816 Vaccines for SARS-CoV-2

=========

The Esbjerg Cohort is a cross-sectional study conducted in the municipality of Esbjerg, Denmark. The study aims to investigate the relationship between ergonomic exposure and physical capacity in relation to work ability and musculoskeletal pain in workers aged 55 to 70 years old. The study population consists of 336 citizens divided into 12 groups based on gender, age, and occupational group. The study will measure work ability using the Work Ability Index, height, weight, body mass index, waist-to-hip ratio, blood pressure, pressure pain threshold, warm and cold detection threshold, heat and cold pain threshold, temporal summation, conditioned pain modulation, physical activity, musculoskeletal pain, and additional questions about ergonomics and pain. The study will also measure strength and endurance in the legs using the 30-seconds sit to stand test, balance using a one-leg balance test, functional strength, balance, and agility using the stair climb test, maximal aerobic capacity using the Astrand 6-minute cycle test, isokinetic muscle strength in the shoulder and knee, isometric muscle strength in the shoulder and knee, and handgrip strength. The study will provide knowledge about the consequences of high physical workload on the musculoskeletal system in the oldest group of workers, which is necessary for better treatment and counseling to the oldest group of workers and for improved guidelines on how to optimize the balance between the physical work demands and the capacity of the workers.

This is a phase I safety and feasibility study of cellular immunotherapy for extensive stage small cell neuroendocrine prostate cancer using autologous T cells lentivirally transduced to express L1CAM-specific chimeric antigen receptor.

The study is an uncontrolled before and after study that assesses the safety and efficacy of a new technique Whipple over the splenic artery (WOTSA) as a treatment for pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma (PDAC) which traditionally requires total pancreatectomy (TP). The study group comprised 40 consecutive patients who underwent WOTSA for PDAC. Their clinicopathological characteristics and survival were compared with those of a historical control group comprising 30 consecutive patients who underwent TP between 2010 and 2016. The primary outcome measure was the clinicopathological characteristics of the remnant pancreas before and 1 week after the operation. The secondary outcome measure was the postoperative chemotherapy and follow-up of the patients. The study found that WOTSA was safe and effective in treating PDAC and that it can replace TP in many cases.

=========

The study aims to investigate the effect of breastfeeding education given to fathers via Whatsapp messaging application in the postpartum period on breastfeeding. The study will be conducted as an experimental design with four groups of Solomon. The randomization of the participants will be made using a computer program and the participants will be assigned to the experimental and control groups in this way. The primary outcome measures will be the Breastfeeding Support Scale and The Partner Breastfeeding Influence Scale. The study will measure the breastfeeding support of fathers and the effect of fathers on breastfeeding. The study will be conducted in the postpartum clinic of the hospital and will be open to eligible mothers and fathers who are willing to participate. The study will be conducted over a period of 39 days and the scales will be re-administered on the 42nd postpartum day and at the 12th week postpartum.

=========

The study aims to evaluate the prevalence of PIK3CA mutations among patients with advanced breast cancer and the time from first diagnosis to first PIK3CA evaluation. The study will also assess the type of biopsy, tissue sample, source of tissue sample, analytical method used for PIK3CA evaluation, age at advanced breast cancer diagnosis, stage when patients were diagnosed with BC, number of patients with known metastatic sites, performance as assessed by Karnofsky Performace Scale, performance as assessed by the Eastern Cooperative Oncology Group (ECOG) Performance Status Scale, height, weight, body mass index (BMI), number of patients per stage of cancer, number of patients per line of treatment, time from advanced diagnosis to initiation of lines of treatment, number of patients per systemic therapy, number of patients per treatment sequence, number of patients per supportive treatment, and number of tests for patients with CDK4/6 inhibitor treatment. The study will be conducted as a non-interventional study and will include patients with newly diagnosed advanced breast cancer between 01 January 2015, and 30 June 2020 who were evaluated for a PIK3CA mutation and identified PIK3CA gene status. The study will be conducted in French and will be conducted in France.

The study aims to investigate the effects of melatonin on sleep spindles in children with autism spectrum disorder (ASD). The study is a single group assignment, open-label study. Participants are male and female subjects with ASD aged 12-18 years who are English speaking and able to understand and respond to questionnaires in English. Exclusion criteria include pregnancy or breastfeeding, substance abuse or dependence within the past six months, chronic medical conditions that affect sleep, unstable chronic medical conditions, head injury resulting in prolonged loss of consciousness or other neurological sequelae, IQ <70, other neurological disorder, including seizure disorder, diagnosed sleep disorder, known genetic causes of ASD, and currently taking melatonin or those who have had an adverse reaction to melatonin in the past. The study measures changes in sleep spindle density and sleep quality over five nights of sleep over two weeks. The intervention is 5mg melatonin gummy 30 min before bedtime for two consecutive nights.

The DETERMINED study is a phase 1/2 umbrella basket trial that aims to evaluate the efficacy and safety of existing and novel targeted therapies in rare cancers with actionable genomic alterations. The study will use a novel evaluation platform that combines molecular profiling with a network of clinical sites to identify and evaluate promising therapies in a rapid and efficient manner. The study will be conducted in two phases. In phase 1, the study will identify promising therapies in rare cancers with actionable genomic alterations using a molecular profiling platform. In phase 2, the study will evaluate the efficacy and safety of these therapies in a basket design, where patients with rare cancers with actionable genomic alterations will be treated with the identified therapies. The study will be conducted in two phases. In phase 1, the study will identify promising therapies in rare cancers with actionable genomic alterations using a molecular profiling platform. This is an etiological study of persistent velopharyngeal insufficiency in children with operated velopalatine cleft by analysis of velopharyngeal motor skills in static and dynamic MRI. The study includes children aged 7 to 12 years with isolated cleft lip isolated velopalatal cleft without a diagnosis of syndromic cleft or Pierre Robin sequence who are French speaking and have French as their native language. The study is conducted at the Amiens University Hospital and includes children who have undergone cheiloplasty or intravelar veloplasty at the Amiens University Hospital and whose follow-up is done at the Amiens University Hospital. The study is a non-randomized intervention model with double masking. The primary outcome measure is the ratio between the diameter of the pharynx at rest and during phonation, closure distance between the velar knee and the posterior pharyngeal wall, and distance between the velar knee and the posterior pharyngeal wall. The study is conducted using real-time MRI and an elastic strap is fixed to the forehead to limit movement during the scan. The study is designed to investigate the etiology of persistent velopharyngeal insufficiency in children with operated velopalatine cleft.

=============

The study aims to evaluate the feasibility and efficacy of a home-based, remotely supported exercise intervention program in improving cognition and mobility among older adults with MS who have cognitive and walking impairment. The study adopts an innovative intervention approach via telerehabilitation and is convenient and accessible for older adults with MS. The study will use a randomized controlled trial design with two arms: an aerobic and resistance exercise program (GEMS program) and a flexibility and stretching program (FLEX-MS program). The primary outcome measures will include changes in cognitive function, physical function, lower-extremity function, functional mobility, walking endurance, and walking speed from baseline to post-intervention and follow-up. Secondary outcome measures will include changes in time spent in moderate-to-vigorous physical activity, daily step count, exercise behavior, central blood pressure, augmentation index, and carotid-to-femoral pulse wave velocity from baseline to post-intervention and follow-up. The study will recruit 100 participants aged 50 years or older with a diagnosis of MS who are relapse-free for the past 30 days, have internet and e-mail access, and are able to travel to the laboratory (for testing only). Participants will be randomly assigned to either the experimental group (aerobic and resistance exercise program) or the active comparator group (flexibility and stretching program). The study will be conducted over a 32-week period, with assessments conducted at baseline, post-intervention (16 weeks), and follow-up (32 weeks). If successful, the study will provide foundations for implementing larger, high-quality RCTs using remotely-delivered exercise intervention for managing the consequences of aging and MS and ultimately contributing to successful aging with MS.

=============

This is a pilot study aimed at measuring the clinical and biological effects of using the oXiris hemofiltration hemofiltration membrane in critically ill patients with vasoplegic shock. The study will involve the collection of additional blood tubes at specific time points to analyze the clearance of vasoactive metabolites, including angiotensins and endothelial permeability markers. The primary outcome measure is a 50% reduction in vasoinotropic score within 24 hours of initiation on oXiris. Secondary outcome measures include the evolution of the vaso-inotropic score and the clearance of endothelial permeability markers. The study will also assess markers of sepsis-induced immunosuppression and mortality at 90 days. The study will be conducted in accordance with the Declaration of Helsinki and will be approved by the Ethics Committee of the Centre Hospitalier Valida.

============

The study is a randomized controlled trial that compares the efficacy of central urinary bladder dissection versus lateral urinary bladder dissection during total laparoscopic hysterectomy in cases with previous cesarean section. The study aims to determine the rate of urinary bladder injury during dissection and compare the operative time, amount of blood loss, and late urological complications between the two groups. The study will be conducted in a tertiary care hospital in India and will recruit 100 patients who are undergoing total laparoscopic hysterectomy for benign conditions with a previous cesarean section scar. The patients will be randomly assigned to either the central group or the lateral group, and the procedure will be performed using a Wolf laparoscopy tower. The primary outcome measure will be the rate of urinary bladder injury during dissection, and the secondary outcome measures will be the operative time, amount of blood loss, and late urological complications. The study will be conducted over a period of 2 years and will be monitored by an independent data monitoring committee.
6-month observational study of the association of the asthma microbiome and disease characteristics, severity and treatment response.

=============

This is a randomized controlled trial comparing the effects of split-body and full-body resistance training on strength and functional performance in amateur cricket players. The study will recruit 28 male cricketers aged 20 to 30 years with no history of systemic disease. Participants will be randomly assigned to either the split-body resistance training group or the full-body resistance training group. Both groups will undergo 6 weeks of training, with the split-body group performing exercises targeting specific muscle groups and the full-body group performing exercises targeting multiple muscle groups. The primary outcome measures will be the bench press test, leg press test, and 30-second sit-to-stand test. Data will be analyzed using SPSS version 25.

===============

The study aims to investigate the effect of training on breastfeeding given to fathers on breastfeeding, parent-baby bonding and breastfeeding self-efficacy level. The study is a randomized controlled trial with three groups: experimental group 1, experimental group 2, and control group. The experimental groups received breastfeeding training, while the control group did not receive any intervention. The primary outcome measures are breastfeeding self-efficacy scale-short form, mother to infant bonding scale, father breastfeeding self-efficacy scale short form, paternal-infant attachment questionnaire, and baby evaluation form. The study will be conducted for 3 months, and the data will be collected at the 1st week, 1st month, and 3rd month. The study will be double-masked.

=========

This is a randomized, double-blind controlled trial to investigate the effects of Amway Bundle Combination of Products on Osteoarthritis & Sarcopenia. The study includes 4 arms: Active Comparator: Bundle Group 1 with Nutrilite Lifestyle, Active Comparator: Bundle Group 2 without Nutrilite Lifestyle, Placebo Comparator: Control Group 1, and Placebo Comparator: Control Group 2 with Nutrilite Lifestyle. The primary outcome measure is the change of Short Physical Performance Battery (SPPB) score from baseline to day 180. Secondary outcome measures include changes in WOMAC Questionnaire Scores, Visual Analogue Scale/Score (VAS), Chalder Fatigue Scale (CFS), Improvement of Fat and Muscle Portions measured by Inbody S10, Change of Hand & Grip Strength measured by Jamar Smart Hand Dynamometer, and Change of bone density measured by DXA Bone Densitometer. The study is designed to support the care of patients with Osteoarthritis & Sarcopenia.

The study aims to improve alcohol and substance use (ASU) care, outcomes, and equity during the reproductive years. The study will use a mixed-methods, sequential explanatory design to evaluate the implementation of a brief intervention for ASU in family planning clinics. The study will use a Type 1 Hybrid Effectiveness-Implementation Trial design to evaluate the effectiveness of the intervention and the implementation process. The study will recruit 10 family planning clinics in the Northeast region of the United States. The study will use a randomized controlled trial design to compare the implementation of the intervention in the intervention arm versus usual care in the control arm. The study will use a mixed-methods design to collect both quantitative and qualitative data. The study will collect data on ASU screening, referral, and treatment outcomes, as well as implementation process data. This is a summary of the clinical trial titled "Gut Microbiome and Blood Lipids After Habitual Consumption of Herbal Green Tea" (NCT04111558).

The study aims to investigate the effect of adding strengthening exercise for hip rotators and ankle muscles to knee exercises on pain, function, strength of muscles, and knee proprioception in patients with knee osteoarthritis. The study will be conducted as a randomized controlled trial with two groups: control and experimental. The control group will receive knee exercises in the form of stretching for hamstring and calf, while the experimental group will receive strengthening exercise for hip rotators and ankle muscles in addition to knee exercises. The study will measure pain level, functional level, knee proprioception, hip internal and external rotator strength, ankle dorsi flexors, planter flexor, invertor and evertor strength, and quadriceps strength at baseline and after 4 weeks. The study will be conducted for 4 weeks, with 12 sessions in total.

===============

A Clinical Study to Evaluate the Safety and Effectiveness of Novabel Bioabsorbable Steroid-releasing Stent for the Chronic Sinusitis is a randomized, double-masked, parallel assignment study. The study aims to evaluate the non-reintervention rate, Lund-Kennedy score, Lund-Mackay score, VAS score, sinus panty rate, and implantation successful rate of the experimental device (Novabel bioabsorbable steroid-releasing stent) and the active comparator device (marketed bioabsorbable steroid-releasing stent) in patients with chronic sinusitis who are scheduled to undergo primary or revision bilateral ESS. The study will be conducted over a 360-day follow-up period, with primary outcome measures assessed at 30 days, and secondary outcome measures assessed at 30 days, 90 days, 180 days, and 1 year. Eligibility criteria include a diagnosis of chronic sinusitis based on Chinese guidelines for diagnosis and treatment of chronic rhinosinusitis (2018), evidence of bilateral sinus based on computed tomographic (CT) scan (Lund-Mackay [L-M] score of <=3 on each side), and the ability to understand the purpose of the study and provide informed consent. Exclusion criteria include a history of allergy or intolerance to corticosteroids or mometasone furoate, a known allergic reaction or contraindication to the device material and its degradation products, and a known history of immune deficiency or concurrent condition requiring active chemotherapy and/or immunotherapy management for the disease. The study will be conducted in China.

=========

The study aims to evaluate the impact of providing cancer care closer to home for patients with multiple myeloma. The study will compare the experience of patients who elect to transfer their care to a satellite site with those who maintain care at their usual site. The study will measure the proportion of eligible participants who successfully transfer to the provider at a satellite location, types of candidacy that providers use for transfer of care to satellite sites, treatment burden of participants, satisfaction of with participant-provider interactions, financial toxicity of participants, and participant rationales for opting to transfer to a satellite site or maintain care at their usual site. The study will be conducted as a non-randomized, parallel assignment study with an estimated completion time of 6 months.

This is a prospective, randomized controlled, interventional therapy utilizing virtual reality goggles as a method of distraction. The study will compare the use of virtual reality headsets to nitrous oxide for purposes of anxiolysis and analgesia during dental treatment on pediatric patients. The study will measure the rate of effectiveness of virtual reality goggles to reduce pain and the rate of effectiveness of virtual reality distraction to nitrous oxide. The study will be conducted over a period of 12 months.

The study aims to identify patients with recurrent colorectal lesions risk and design an optimal intervals of surveillance colonoscopies, especially in the high-risk group of patients, using mutation and clinical-pathologic phenotype. The study will involve 200 patients with colorectal polyp larger than 10mm removed by colonoscopy therapeutic method (EPE, EMR, ESD) and signed informed consent with the study and with colonoscopy. The primary outcome measure is the development and clinical utility of a new method to identify patients with risk of recurrent colorectal lesions and personalization of their surveillance based on mutation burden and clinical-pathological phenotype. The study will measure the mutation profile and mutation burden of colorectal lesions in 200 patients based on examination of all their index and synchronous lesions found during index colonoscopy using an established PCR/DCE-based heteroduplex method. The study will also evaluate the clinical and histopathological parameters and mutational profiling of all metachronous lesions found during five-year surveillance period. The study will compare the mutation profile of lesions from the index period with the mutation profile of metachronous lesions. The study will also analyze the similarity of the mutation profile of lesions found in the same / close areas of the colorectum.

The SAM Project: Science Against Malnutrition Project is a study that aims to characterize malnutrition through the identification of specific biomarkers of the condition. The study will collect clinical, anamnestic and lifestyle data, as well as faecal, blood and saliva samples from patients affected by malnutrition due to deficiency or excess and sex- and age- matched healthy controls not affected by any pathology and/or malnutrition due to deficiency or excess. The study will use untargeted microRNA expression profile in blood and saliva samples, plasmatic extracellular vesicles, metagenomic analysis of fecal and salivary samples, and metabolomicanalysis of fecal samples to characterize malnutrition. The study will run for 36 months.

===============

The study aims to evaluate exercise and physical activity every 3 months in a cohort of people with Parkinson's disease from two clinics in the Chicagoland area. The study will evaluate differences in 12-month physical activity trajectories between groups enrolled during each of three conditions: (1A) standard care (condition 1, year 1), (1B) written exercise guidance (condition 2, year 2), and (1C) Consultative PT (condition 3, year 3). Participants will be tracked using a remote therapeutic monitoring platform (Datos) and commercial grade activity trackers. Research-grade actigraphy and patient reported outcome measures will be monitored every 3 months for the first year. The study will recruit consecutive patients meeting the eligibility criteria based on contacting consecutive patients who meet the inclusion criteria based on scheduling and EMR screening prior to their visit with their neurologists. The study will use a combination of data available in the EMR for existing patients and a quick screening questionnaire that can be done in person or over the phone to screen for eligibility. After identifying that the participant is interested and satisfies the inclusion criteria for the study, they will be sent an e-consent. Once consent is obtained, they will work with the study team to set a time for the baseline assessment period which will include ensuring the participant has their own -wrist-worn activity tracker and is able to get commercial grade activity tracker from the research team. At baseline and every 3-months throughout the 12-month (baseline, 3-months, 6-months, 9-months, 12-months) study, participants will complete online survey assessments including demographic questionnaires, habits and perceptions of physical activity and exercise, and healthcare and exercise resource utilization. Participants will, also, wear a research-grade physical activity monitor on a belt clip around their waist for 7-consecutive days at baseline, 3-, 6-, 9-, 12-months. In addition to research-grade physical activity monitoring, participants will be asked to a personal commercially available activity tracker daily which will be synced to the Datos Health app. The study aims to evaluate differences in 12-month physical activity trajectories between groups enrolled

===============

The study aims to use multi-channel time-resolved functional near infrared spectroscopy (tr-fNIRS) to detect and prevent ischemic brain injury during perioperative surgery. The study will use a full head coverage tr-fNIRS device to monitor the entire brain, as opposed to only select regions, in the perioperative setting. The study will measure cerebral oxygenation (ScO2) between brain regions and cerebral autoregulation index during surgery. The study will assess the association between cerebral desaturation events in multiple brain regions to clinical outcomes such as stroke and delirium. The study will be observational in nature and no intervention will be applied based on the results of the tr-fNIRS device.

=========

The study "Mechanical Insufflation-Exsufflation (Cough Assist) in Critically Ill Adults" is a randomized clinical feasibility trial. The study aims to determine the feasibility of using mechanical insufflation-exsufflation (MI-E) in critically ill adults who are invasively ventilated. The study will be conducted in two phases. In phase 1, the study will determine the feasibility of the intervention and the safety of the intervention. In phase 2, the study will determine the efficacy of the intervention. The study will be conducted in two arms: an experimental arm and a control arm. In the experimental arm, patients will receive MI-E sessions twice a day for a maximum of 7 days. In the control arm, patients will receive standard airway care. The primary outcome measure of the study is the proportion of complete sessions of MI-E every calendar day. The secondary outcome measures of the study include the incidence of pneumothorax, endotracheal tube obstruction, severe hypoxemia, severe hypotension, severe hypertension, acceptability of the intervention, appropriateness of the intervention, feasibility of the intervention, amount of time needed for MI-E, frequency of endotracheal suctioning, frequency of manual hyperinflation, incidence of ventilator-associated pneumonia, duration of invasive ventilation, mortality at day 28, ventilator-free days at day 28, ICU mortality, hospital mortality, use of supplemental oxygen on ICU delivery after detubation, length of stay in ICU, and length of stay in hospital. The study will be conducted in two centers in France. The study will be conducted in two phases, with phase 1 lasting 6 months and phase 2 lasting 12 months. The Enavogliflozin Outcome Trial in Functional Tricuspid Regurgitation (EVENT) is a multicenter, randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled study to assess the effects of enavogliflozin on outcomes in patients with functional tricuspid regurgitation (TR) and heart failure with preserved left ventricular ejection fraction (HF). The study will test the hypothesis that, compared with placebo, therapy with the SGLT2 inhibitor enavogliflozin for 18 months would improve clinical and echocardiographic outcomes in HF patients with functional TR and preserved LVEF. The study will enroll 1000 patients with functional TR and preserved LVEF, who will be randomly assigned to receive either enavogliflozin or placebo for 18 months. The primary outcome measure will be a composite of cardiovascular death, hospitalization for HF, or worsening of TR that occurs during follow-up. Secondary outcome measures will include all-cause death, cardiovascular clinical event, renal event, change of TR, and change of RV strain. The study will be conducted in accordance with the Declaration of Helsinki and Good Clinical Practice guidelines.

The study aims to determine the critical time window for rehabilitation after incomplete spinal cord injury. Participants will be randomized into one of four intervention groups based on when additional walking training is given following injury. The study will measure walking speed using the 10 meter walk test and distance traveled during a 6 minute walk test at a self selected pace. Additionally, the study will assess the physical assistance and assistive devices needed to walk 10 meters using the Walking Index for spinal cord injury and daily step counts from a waist worn activity tracker. The study will take place over a 1-year period.

===============

The study aims to investigate the effect of education given according to the health promotion model on premenstrual symptoms, emotional eating behavior, and perceived stress. The study will be conducted as a pretest-posttest randomized controlled study. The study population will consist of women aged 18-30 years who experience premenstrual symptoms and meet the inclusion criteria. The study will use the Philips 66 technique to train the experimental group, while the control group will not receive any training. The primary outcome measures will include the Premenstrual Syndrome Scale, Eating Habits During the Premenstrual Period Form, Healthy Lifestyle Behaviors Scale, Emotional Eating Scale, Perceived Stress Scale, and Visual Vissual Pain Scale. The secondary outcome measures will include Feedback of the training using the Health Promotion Model and Philips 66 technique, Eating Habits During the Premenstrual Period Form, Premenstrual Syndrome Scale, Healthy Lifestyle Behaviors Scale, Emotional Eating Scale, Perceived Stress Scale, and Visual Vissual Pain Scale. The study will be conducted over a period of 1 year, with data collection taking place at the beginning and end of the study period. The study will be conducted in accordance with the Declaration of Helsinki and will obtain ethical approval from the relevant institutional review board.

=================
The AMP SCZ Observational Study: PREDICT-DPACC is a non-interventional study examining clinical trajectories and predictors of outcomes in the CHR population. The study is based out of Brigham and Women's Hospital (BWH) and Mass General Brigham (MGB) and works with two Clinical High Risk (CHR) research networks (ProNET and PRESCIENT) to capture data from the research networks in a uniform manner, build flexible infrastructure to accommodate multiple data types, develop and refine pipelines that provide rapid data processing (in close to real-time) and quality assurance (QA) and quality control (QC), provide data coordination, management, and monitoring of data, develop powerful and robust stratification tools to identify & validate biomarkers and predict individual outcome trajectories, and assist in archiving data and making it publicly available in the NIMH Data Archive (NDA). The study examines clinical, cognitive, neurophysiology, neuroimaging, genetics and fluid biomarkers, speech and facial expression (audio/video recordings are optional), and outcome assessments. Digital assessments such as daily ecological momentary assessment (daily digital diary entries) and passive sensing measurements (actigraphy and geolocation) are optional. The study is designed to capture data from the CHR cohort and healthy controls (HCs) at baseline and 2 months post-baseline, with additional assessments completed at other time points. CHR subjects will be assessed longitudinally for 2 years. Participants who develop first-episode psychosis ('converted' cases) during their study participation will continue to be assessed as scheduled. The primary outcome measure is conversion to psychosis as defined by psychosis threshold criteria on the PSYCHS. Secondary outcome measures include remission and non-conversion/non-remission. The study is designed to capture data from the CHR cohort and HCs, and the data will be analyzed to identify predictors of outcomes in the CHR population. The study is designed to capture data from the CHR cohort and HCs, and the data will be analyzed to identify predictors of outcomes in the CHR population.

=================
The PROSPER study is a pilot randomised controlled trial (RCT) that aims to evaluate the feasibility and acceptability of implementing the Problem Management Plus (PM+) intervention in Dutch prisons. The study entails a single-blind pilot RCT (Study Phase 2) and a qualitative study to evaluate the process following the pilot RCT (Study Phase 3). The study population for Study Phase 2 includes Dutch-speaking adults (18 years old or above; N=60) who are imprisoned in a Dutch prison and have a remaining sentence length of at least 15 weeks and who report an elevated level of psychological distress (K10 >15). The intervention is a brief, evidence-based psychological intervention program based on cognitive behavioural therapy (CBT) techniques that are empirically supported and formally recommended by the WHO (Dua et al., 2011; Tol et al., 2013). The primary outcome measures include PM+ fidelity, perceptions about PM+ from stakeholders, indicators of intervention delivery, retention rate PM+ sessions, and recruitment and consent rates. The secondary outcome measures include preliminary indications of pre to post-effects on symptoms of depression and anxiety, self-identified problems, quality of life, trauma, and suicidal vulnerability. The study is designed as a parallel-group, two-arm trial with a 1:1 allocation ratio. Participants will be stratified by gender. The study will be conducted in Dutch prisons.

The study aims to determine the best safe dose of xevinapant when given in combination with radiation and chemotherapy. The study will be conducted in 4 escalation cohorts, each with a different dose of xevinapant. The primary outcome measure is the determination of the best safe dose of xevinapant when given in combination with radiation and chemotherapy. Secondary outcome measures include progression-free survival, number of side effects seen when xevinapant is given in combination with radiation and chemotherapy, overall survival, locoregional failure, distant failure, and response rate. This is a phase II, randomized, open-label, multi-center study of olaparib and alpelisib in patients with metastatic HER2-negative breast cancer who are PARP inhibitor naive. The study will assess the efficacy and safety of olaparib and alpelisib in this patient population.

This is a multi-center, two-arm, assessor-blinded, randomized controlled superiority study of schema therapy versus treatment as usual for patients with treatment resistant depression. The study will recruit 100 patients from the Danish secondary psychiatric sector. The primary outcome will be the change in depression symptoms on the Hamilton-6 Rating Scale for Depression at 12 months after baseline measurements. Secondary outcomes will include changes in depression symptoms at 6 months and 24 months after baseline, as well as changes in subjective functional impairment, psychological well-being, personal recovery after mental illness, reactions to anger, repetitive negative thinking, anxiety symptoms, health-related quality of life, negative expectancies for change in depression symptoms, schema modes, early maladaptive schemas, response to treatment, and remission from depression. The study will be conducted in accordance with the Declaration of Helsinki and will be approved by the Danish Data Protection Agency.

The study is a prospective, multicenter, randomized, controlled, open-label, phase III, stepped wedge cluster randomized trial. The study aims to evaluate the effectiveness of a paramedical protocol for ventilation in acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS). The study includes patients aged 18 years and above who are intubated with artificial ventilation and have ARDS evolving for less than 72 hours. The intervention involves respirator settings being adjusted by nurses according to a pre-established care protocol that complies with international recommendations. The primary endpoint is a combination of mortality and the number of days without mechanical ventilation at D28. Secondary endpoints include measures of tidal volume ventilation, plateau pressure, positive end-expiratory pressure (PEEP), FiO2, oxygenation, number of days without mechanical ventilation, number of days without catecholamine, number of days without continuous sedation, duration of mechanical ventilation, occurrence of mechanically ventilated pneumothorax, duration of Acute respiratory distress syndrome, duration of weaning from mechanical ventilation, number of participants with rescue therapy, rate of re-intubation, rate of use of non-invasive ventilation and curative high-flow oxygen therapy, tracheostomy rate, length of stay in intensive care and in hospital, and number of deaths in ICU and hospital. The study will be conducted over a period of up to 26 months.

The study aims to test a culturally tailored engagement and retention intervention for Haitian immigrants living with HIV (HILWH) called Haitian immigrant iENGAGE (H-iENGAGE). The study is a sequential mixed-methods formative pilot research that examines engagement and retention in care, and viral suppression (VS) for HILWH and adapts a promising intervention that will result in viral suppression between baseline and a 6 month follow-up assessment. The study will be conducted as a prospective, quasi-experimental single arm with a sample of newly diagnosed or nonvirally suppressed HIWLH adults drawn from 2 Federally Qualified Health Centers (FQHC) sites in Miami. The study will measure care of engagement index score and viral suppression. The study will be conducted over a period of 6 months.

===============

A randomized, non-blinded, single-center pivotal clinical investigation was conducted to evaluate the effectiveness and safety of the Endoclean device for root canal debridement up to 12-month follow-up. The study included 109 subjects, randomly assigned to one of three arms: Passive Ultrasonic Irrigation (PUI), Endoclean (EC), or Conventional. The primary objective was to test the effectiveness of the Endoclean device for root canal debridement up to 12-month follow-up. The secondary objective was to test the extended effectiveness and safety of the Endoclean device up to a 24-month follow-up. The study found that the Endoclean device was effective in root canal debridement up to 12-month follow-up and had a good safety profile.

=========

FRACT-AI is a study that evaluates the impact of artificial intelligence (AI) on the diagnostic accuracy of frontline clinicians in the detection of fractures on plain X-rays. The study includes 18 readers from various clinical specialties and levels of experience who will review 500 X-rays each in two sessions, with and without AI assistance. The primary outcome measures include the sensitivity, specificity, and area under the ROC curve (AU ROC) of the Gleamer Boneview algorithm, as well as the performance of readers with and without AI assistance in terms of sensitivity, specificity, and AU ROC. Additionally, the study measures the mean time taken to review a X-ray with and without AI assistance. The study aims to determine whether AI assistance improves the diagnostic accuracy and speed of fracture detection on X-rays.

=============

The study aims to examine the fine motor skills, hand grip strength, and hand and forearm anthropometric characteristics of children with Specific Learning Disorder (SLD) compared to those of healthy children and to investigate their relationships with each other. The study will use the Bruininks-Oseretsky Test of Motor Proficiency-2 (BOT-2), Purdue Pegboard Test, Hand Dynamometer, and Pinch Gauge to measure fine motor skills, hand grip strength, and finger strength. The study will also use the Participation and Environment Measurement Child & Youth (PEM-CY) and the Pediatric Quality of Life Inventory (PEDS-QL) to measure participation and environment factors in the home, at school, and within community settings and quality of life, respectively. The study will include children with SLD aged 6-12 years old and healthy children of the same age. The study will be conducted in a cross-sectional design. The primary outcome measure will be the Bruininks-Oseretsky Test of Motor Proficiency-2 (BOT-2) scores. The secondary outcome measures will be the Purdue Pegboard Test scores, Hand Dynamometer scores, Pinch Gauge scores, Participation and Environment Measurement Child & Youth (PEM-CY) scores, and the Pediatric Quality of Life Inventory (PEDS-QL) scores. The study will be conducted in a cross-sectional design. The primary outcome measure will be the Bruininks-Oseretsky Test of Motor Proficiency-2 (BOT-2) scores. The secondary outcome measures will be the Purdue Pegboard Test scores, Hand Dynamometer scores, Pinch Gauge scores, Participation and Environment Measurement Child & Youth (PEM-CY) scores, and the Pediatric Quality of Life Inventory (PEDS-QL) scores.

=========

The IM-ZBULLE Study is a multicenter, prospective, randomized, double-blind, controlled, study in 2 parallel groups. The experimental group will be offered an intramuscular injection using the Z-track and Airlock techniques, while the control group will have an usual injection. An intermediate analysis of futility and efficacy is planned once 50% of the planned sample has completed the study. The object of the research is the intramuscular injection procedure - Product injected: haloperidol decanoate (Haldol Decanoas®). The study will measure pain reduction, drug leakage reduction, impact of the injection, improving participants satisfaction, improving the therapeutic alliance, and identifying the obstacles and levers to changing practices.

=================

The current standard approach to the management of extremity STS is a combination of radiotherapy and limb preserving surgery. The study aims to define the feasibility, toxicity, efficacy, and potential improvement in access to care associated with preoperative 5-day HFRT. The study will utilize a 30Gy/5fx preoperative regimen as it has an estimated EQD2 of 50 Gy (based on a α/β ratio=4) and therefore would be expected to closely parallel the biologic effect of CFRT. The study will compare serum levels of SFRP2 before and after preoperative 5-day HFRT to define levels of expression in patients with STS and assess the effect of radiotherapy on SFRP2 expression. The study will also evaluate the association of the change in serum SFRP2 levels with extent of tumor fibrosis/hyalinization, a histologic predictor of oncologic outcome, to determine the potential of SFRP2 as a predictive biomarker for favorable pathologic response.

===============

The study is a randomized controlled trial that compares the efficacy of pericapsular nerve group block (PENG block) combined with lateral femoral cutaneous nerve block (LFCN block) to patient-controlled analgesia (PCA) for postoperative analgesia after hip replacement surgery. The study includes 100 patients with American Society of Anesthesiologists (ASA) physical status I-III who undergo hip replacement surgery. The patients are randomly assigned to either the PENG block and LFCN block group or the PCA group. The primary outcome measure is the average visual analogue scale (VAS) score at rest and on movement of both groups. The study also measures the rate of side effects such as vomiting/nausea, itchy, urinary retention, and respiratory failure postoperative of both groups. The study is designed as a parallel assignment intervention model with a single masking design. The study is conducted over a period of 72 hours from the initiation of catheterization or PCA insertion.

The study aims to compare the mean vertical displacement (in millimeters) measured on the anterior wall of the vagina, cervix, and posterior wall of the vagina between rest and maximum pushing force during dynamic MRI in patients with pelvic endometriosis and patients without pelvic endometriosis. The study also aims to measure the variation in mean vertical displacement on the wall of each pelvic organ at the push effort between the initial dynamic MRI of patients with endometriosis and post-therapeutic dynamic MRI data. The study will use a comparative study design, with patients with pelvic endometriosis and patients without pelvic endometriosis as the two arms. The study will measure the primary outcome measure of the mean vertical displacement (in millimeters) measured on the anterior wall of the vagina between rest and maximum pushing force during dynamic MRI at baseline. The study will also measure the secondary outcome measures of the mean vertical displacement (in millimeters) measured on the cervix and posterior wall of the vagina between rest and maximum thrust effort during dynamic MRI at baseline, the measurement of variation in mean vertical displacement (in millimeters) on the wall of each pelvic organ at the push effort between the initial dynamic MRI of patients with endometriosis and post-therapeutic dynamic MRI data, and the statistical association between the symptoms of patients with endometriosis and the mean vertical displacement (in millimeters) on the wall of each pelvic organ at the push effort during dynamic MRI at baseline. The study will use a dynamic MRI sequence as the intervention/treatment. The study will be conducted in a single center and will recruit 20 patients with pelvic endometriosis and 20 patients without pelvic endometriosis. The study will be conducted over a period of 1 year. The study will be conducted in accordance with the Declaration of Helsinki and will obtain ethical approval from the Institutional Review Board. The study will be registered with the ClinicalTrials.gov registry.

The study aims to provide up-to-date epidemiological evidence on the uptake of the influenza vaccines and influenza-related healthcare resource use in children in England. The primary objective is to evaluate the uptake of influenza vaccines in children aged ≥2 and <18 years in England between 2012 and 2020 for LAIV, QIV, and influenza vaccinations where the product is not specified. Secondary objectives include describing usage patterns of LAIV in England between 2012 and 2020, describing HCRU associated with laboratory confirmed influenza and/or influenza-like-illness (ILI) in England between 2012 and 2020 and assessing the relative impact of LAIV on HCRU use of LAIV vs no vaccination, describing demographics and clinical characteristics of individuals vaccinated with LAIV or not vaccinated against flu by any vaccine in each flu season between 2012 and 2020, and estimating a DAG aligned model for LAIV uptake in England based on demographic and clinical factors for each flu season and across multiple seasons between 2012 and 2022. The study will include all research eligible aged between ≥2 and <18 years in the study period, with 6 months of history in CPRD before their first influenza vaccination. It will use the Clinical Practice Research Datalink data (vaccinations, diagnoses, characteristics) linked to Hospital Episode Statistics (HCRU). Logistic regression analyses will be used to test for factors associated with vaccine uptake, and outcomes between vaccinated and unvaccinated children. The study will provide up-to-date epidemiological evidence on the uptake of LAIV and its impact on HCRU related to ILI in children in England. This may be used by the NHS for planning and evaluation of the childhood influenza vaccination program.

===============

This is a pilot pre-post interventional trial with no controls, with 10-20 South Asian children in primary schools (Grades 1-2, age 6-9) being recruited. The intervention comprises three 1.5-hour sessions of Tang poem reciting and one session for participant performances. The feasibility outcomes will be reported descriptively and narratively, including the recruitment rate, duration, and retention rate. The primary outcome measures are the number of successful recited poems reported by independent observers and change in happiness reported subjectively by students. The secondary outcome measures are change in acculturation, ability in speaking Chinese, and attitude in Chinese learning.

The study aims to test the effectiveness of a digital platform in improving clinical outcomes for adolescent patients at high risk for suicide. The platform integrates mobile sensing data and HIPAA-compliant client communication tools into practitioners' management of these young people. The study will use a pragmatic randomized controlled trial (RCT) design, with 200 adolescent patients aged 13-18 years old randomized to either the Vira group or treatment as usual control group. Participants will include current patients receiving treatment in the intensive outpatient program, and all treatment decisions will be overseen by practitioners within the program. The primary outcome measure will be the Columbia Suicide Severity Rating Scale (C-SSRS) at 6 months, while secondary outcome measures will include the Scale for Suicidal Ideation (SSI), Screen for Anxiety Related Emotional Disorders (SCARED), Risky Behavior Questionnaire for Adolescents (RBQ-A), Pittsburgh Sleep Quality Index (PSQI), Mood and Feelings Questionnaire (MFQ), and Anticipatory & Consummatory Interpersonal Pleasure Scale (ACIPS) at 3 and 6 months.

=========

The study aims to investigate the impact of sex and age on non-visual light input that affects sleep and circadian rhythms. Participants will be randomized to one of eight different light stimuli within the pupillometer testing. The study will measure pupil size, melatonin levels for circadian timing assessment, and melatonin levels for hormone response. The study will be conducted in healthy volunteers aged 18-85 years old.

=========

The study is a randomized controlled trial (RCT) with parallel groups, where eligible individuals are block randomized on each clinical site to one of two groups (ratio 1:1): Treatment (IPSA directly) or Control (continued routine services; offered IPSA approximately six months later). The study is carried out by the Center of Neurodevelopmental Disorders at Karolinska Institutet (KIND), Karolinska Institutet, Sweden, in collaboration with an ADHD Center run by the publicly-funded Habilitation & Health, Stockholm Health Care Services, Region Stockholm, Sweden. The study has been approved by the Regional Ethics Committee of Stockholm, Sweden (dnr. 2017/2435-31/5, 2019-06362, and 2023-03871-02). The primary outcome measure is parental self-efficacy, and the secondary outcome measures are parental stress, levels of household disorganization or frequency and perception of disruptive behavior problems in the participant's target child. The study aims to evaluate the efficacy of IPSA, as well as the feasibility of the program. The investigators will explore the potentially moderating or mediating effects of baseline variables and levels of active participation on efficacy outcomes. The study will be conducted in two phases: a pre-intervention phase and a post-intervention phase. In the pre-intervention phase, participants will complete baseline assessments, including pre-intervention questionnaires. In the post-intervention phase, participants will receive IPSA or continued routine services, and their outcomes will be assessed at three time points: immediately after the intervention (post IPSA; T2), and approximately 1.5-3 months after program completion, in connection with an IPSA booster session (follow-up; T3). The study will be conducted in accordance with the Declaration of Helsinki and Good Clinical Practice guidelines.

The Substance Use and Health Risk Intervention (SUHRI) for Justice-involved Youth is a 1-arm design study that examines preliminary efficacy of the adapted intervention. The study is designed to measure the proximal outcomes of problem recognition, decision making, intention to reduce personal risk, service initiation, and the distal outcomes of substance use and sexual/STI risk. The study is conducted with youth aged 14 to 18 who are disposed to community supervision and meet eligibility requirements. The intervention is a technology-based application that addresses the interrelated topics of substance use and risky sex practices, within the context of personal relationships. The study is conducted at a private space within a juvenile justice office or mutually agreed upon location of participant's choosing.

* Study Title: Open-label, Single-center, Single-arm Futility Trial Evaluating Daily Remote Ischemic Conditioning for Reducing Progression of Disability in Patients With Primary Progressive Multiple Sclerosis (PPMS)
* Study Type: Phase II open-label, single-center, single-arm futility trial
* Study Design: Simon-2-stage MiniMax design for futility studies
* Study Duration: 12 months
* Study Objective: To demonstrate non-futility of RIC for reducing progression of disability, as measured with the timed 25-foot walk (T25FW), in people with PPMS
* Study Population: People with Primary Progressive Multiple Sclerosis (PPMS)
* Study Intervention: Remote Ischemic Conditioning (RIC)
* Study Outcomes: Timed 25-foot walk, Nine Hole Peg Test, MRI measure of remyelination, SDMT

===============

The study aims to evaluate whether prothrombin time at diagnosis is a predictor of response to standard medical treatment in severe alcoholic hepatitis. The study includes patients admitted with a clinical diagnosis of severe alcoholic hepatitis eligible to corticosteroid treatment. Prothrombin time at diagnosis was registered to evaluate whether it correlated with Lille score at day 7 and therefore response to standard medical treatment. The primary outcome measure is response to steroid treatment assessed with Lille score at day 7. Secondary outcome measures include death, early liver transplantation, and occurrence of opportunistic infections following steroid treatment. The study is designed as a diagnostic test study.

===============

The randomized control trial will be conducted through convenient sampling. There will be two group the experimental group will receive functional task training. according to GMFS, Pediatric balance scale and goniometer to assess the gross motor function, ROM and balance in cerebral palsy, while control group will receive functional therapy program (bobath technique) to improve gross motor function, ROM and balance in cerebral palsy. The duration of the treatment will be 8 weeks. Gross motor function, pediatric balance scale, and goniometer will be used as outcome measure. Data will be analyzed on spss version 29, normality of the data will be checked and test will be applied according to the normality of the data either in will be parametric test or nonparametric based on the normality.

=================

This retrospective observational study was conducted on tetralogy of Fallot (ToF) primary repair in National Cardiovascular Center Harapan Kita between January 2020 until December 2022. The study aimed to evaluate the prognostic value of neutrophil-lymphocyte ratio (NLR), absolute lymphocyte count (ALC), and thrombocyte-lymphocyte ratio (TLR) in predicting the outcomes of ToF primary repair. The primary outcome measures were the number of patients requiring redo surgery, mortality, and complications. The secondary outcome measures were hospital length of stay and postoperative length of stay. The study included 100 patients who underwent ToF primary repair and had a complete blood cell count with differential count available preoperatively. The results showed that NLR, ALC, and TLR were significantly associated with the number of patients requiring redo surgery, mortality, and complications. The study concluded that NLR, ALC, and TLR could be useful predictors of the outcomes of ToF primary repair.

Patient-Applied Pretreatment Analgesia for Intrauterine Device Placement is a Pilot Randomized Double Blind Clinical Trial study that assesses the effectiveness of patient-applied aqueous lidocaine via tampon as a pre-treatment prior to intra-uterine device placement. Subjects will apply the lidocaine or a saline placebo to the end of a standard tampon with a plastic applicator and then place the tampon 1 hour prior to the procedure. The tampon will be removed as the subject prepares for the procedure. The procedure team will measure the procedure time as well as the subject and provider impressions of the procedure. This data will be evaluated to compare the lidocaine to the control group. The study is designed as a randomized, double-blind, parallel assignment study. The primary outcome measures are procedure time, patient-reported pain level, patient-reported satisfaction with procedure, and patient-reported interest in subsequent procedure. The secondary outcome measures are provider-reported procedural difficulty. The study is measuring the effectiveness of patient-applied aqueous lidocaine via tampon as a pre-treatment prior to intra-uterine device placement.

* Study Title: General Population Universal Capillary Screening for Chronic Autoimmune, Metabolic and Cardiovascular Diseases (UNISCREEN): Feasibility and Acceptability Pilot Study.
* Study Type: Feasibility and Acceptability Pilot Study
* Study Design: Single Group Assignment
* Study Intervention: capillary sampling
* Study Duration: through study completion, an average of 1 year
* Study Population: Population from Cantalupo, locality of the Municipality of Cerro Maggiore (MI)
* Study Outcomes: feasibility and acceptability, blood glucose and lipids level, IAA, GADA65, ZnT8, IA2 autoantibodies, anti-transglutaminase autoantibodies, systolic and diastolic blood pressure, HbA1c
* Study Status: Not Specified

=============

SMaRT Mom is an intervention study that aims to treat breastfeeding mothers' smartphone addiction. The study will measure changes in infant temperament, maternal self-efficacy, breastfeeding as a rewarding experience, maternal attention towards the infant, frontal asymmetry, event related response during the smartphone cue-reactivity task, heart rate variability, skin conductance level, and cardiograph impedance before and after the intervention week. The study will use a randomized, parallel assignment design with two arms: experimental (intervention) and control (no intervention). The intervention will consist of the SMaRT Mom intervention plan, which will be administered for one week during which mothers will be instructed not to use their smartphone while breastfeeding. The study will be conducted in two lab sessions, with the first session taking place before the intervention week and the second session taking place after the intervention week. The study will be conducted in healthy breastfeeding mothers aged 20-40 years old with smartphone addiction scores of 31 and above on the Smartphone Addiction Scale. The study will be conducted in accordance with the Declaration of Helsinki and will obtain ethical approval from the Centre Hospitalier Valida.

=================

This is a summary of the study titled "Low Level Laser Therapy for Plantar Fasciitis: A Single-Blind Randomized Control Trial". The study aims to evaluate the effectiveness of low-level laser therapy (LLLT) in treating plantar fasciitis (PF) in active-duty military personnel. The study will use a randomized controlled trial design, with participants being randomly assigned to either the active treatment group (LLLT) or the control group (usual care). The active treatment group will receive LLLT to the affected area for 3 weeks, while the control group will receive usual care. The study will measure the effectiveness of LLLT using various outcome measures, including the Foot and Ankle Ability Measure (FAAM), the Defense and Veterans Pain Rating Scale (DVPRS), and plantar fascia thickness measurements using ultrasound. The study will be conducted in accordance with the Declaration of Helsinki and will obtain ethical approval from the Institutional Review Board.

This is a single-center, open, randomized, single-dose, completely repeated crossover bioequivalence study to evaluate the effects of the test/reference preparation, Entacapone,Levodopa and Carbidopa Tablets (II) in the postprandial state in healthy adult subjects.

The study will be conducted in 36 healthy subjects who will be randomly assigned to two groups: Group A: Test (T)-Reference (R) and Group B: Reference (R)-Test (T). The washout period between doses will be at least 2 days. After fasting for at least 10 hours.

The primary outcome measures will be Peak Plasma Concentration (Cmax), Area under the plasma concentration versus time curve (AUC0-t), and Area under the plasma concentration versus time curve (AUC0-∞).

The study will be conducted in accordance with the Declaration of Helsinki and Good Clinical Practice guidelines.

The study will be conducted in a single center in China.

The study will be conducted from March 2019 to March 2020.

The study will be conducted by Qilu Pharmaceutical Co.

The study will be conducted in healthy adult subjects aged 18 years or older.

The study will be conducted in healthy adult subjects who weigh no less than 50.0 kg and female subjects who weigh no less than 45.0 kg, with a body mass index in the range of 19.0 to 28.0 kg/m2.

The study will be conducted in healthy adult subjects who have no history of serious medical conditions such as cardiac, hepatic, renal, gastrointestinal, neurological, endocrine, respiratory, and psychiatric abnormalities, which are deemed inappropriate for the participant by the study physician.

The study will be conducted in healthy adult subjects who have no abnormalities judged by the clinician to be clinically significant, including physical examination, vital signs examination, electrocardiogram, or clinical laboratory tests.

The study will be conducted in healthy adult subjects who have no previous or existing postural hypotension or morning dizziness.

This study aims to fine-scale map brain anatomy and function in healthy participants and patients with tremor, psychosis, and epilepsy using simultaneous electroencephalography (EEG) and 7 Tesla magnetic resonance imaging (MRI). The study will include healthy participants, essential tremor patients, psychosis patients, and epilepsy patients. The interventions for the study will include MRI and combined EEG-fMRI. The primary outcome measures for the study will include contrast-to-noise ratio between thalamic nuclei in 7T structural MRI, Pearson correlation between thalamocortical brain regions in 7T functional MRI, and microstate duration in EEG acquired concurrently with 7T functional MRI. The secondary outcome measure for the study will be neuroimaging datasets published in fully anonymized form in suitable public data repositories.

The study aims to investigate the effect of weight loss on hepcidin levels and iron status in subjects with obesity. The study will consist of two phases: Phase 1, which will be cross-sectional, and Phase 2, which will involve a randomized controlled clinical trial. Phase 1 will involve a cross-sectional study to compare hepcidin levels, iron status, and inflammatory markers in people living with and without obesity. Phase 2 will involve a randomized controlled clinical trial to assess the impact of weight loss on hepcidin levels, iron status, and inflammatory markers in individuals living with obesity. Participants will be recruited from those identified in the first phase who exhibit iron deficiency (serum iron < 50 mcg/dL). Participants will be randomly assigned to one of two dietary intervention groups, both of which will undergo a 60-day follow-up period with a calorie-restricted diet, reducing caloric intake by less than 25% of the resting energy expenditure determined by indirect calorimetry. The intervention groups will be as follows: Calorie-restricted diet with macronutrient distribution: 1.5 g/kg of ideal body weight in protein (including red meat), 50% carbohydrates, and 25-30% fats. Calorie-restricted diet with macronutrient distribution: 1.5 g/kg of ideal body weight in protein (excluding red meat), 50% carbohydrates, and 25-30% fats. Additionally, all participants will receive ferrous sulfate 200mg every 48 hours for three months to correct iron-deficiency anemia. During the initial and final visits, participants will undergo a 24-hour dietary recall, complete a physical activity questionnaire, and fill out a quality-of-life questionnaire. Anthropometric measurements and body composition analysis will be conducted. Blood samples will be collected to determine various biochemical parameters in the blood, including lipid profile (total cholesterol, LDL cholesterol, HDL cholesterol, triglycerides), liver function tests, glucose, insulin, creatinine, urea,

===============

The NIEM-O Study is a single center prospective cohort intervention study with historical controls. Eligible women will be prospectively included in the cohort receiving standard treatment: CTG monitoring intermittent up to three times a day. From these eligible women, a random sample (464) of the prospective cohort (511) will be offered to receive a new monitoring method: 24/7 eCTG monitoring with NFMS. The primary outcome measure is a composite outcome consisting of incidence of perinatal mortality and/or incidence of a major neonatal morbidity. Secondary outcome measures include incidence of maternal mortality, incidence of other neonatal morbidity, patient satisfaction, caregiver satisfaction, duration of pregnancy, switch of monitoring method from eCTG to CTG monitoring, duration of admission to the Obstetric High Care, timing of obstetric interventions (caesarean section), number of obstetric interventions (caesarean section), admission to the NICU (neonatal intensive care unit), and duration of admission to the NICU. The study aims to include 1911 pregnant women ≥18 years old with a singleton pregnancy between 23+0 and 32+0 weeks of gestation requiring hospitalization on the OHC for maternal or fetal surveillance (including 1400 historical controls). The collected NFMS and demographic data will be used to develop and verify a mathematical model for the prediction of time until (preterm) birth, which may be used in clinical practice to reduce unnecessary OHC admissions and facilitate a better timing of interventions. Furthermore, data collected in this study (NFMS, accelerometric, annotated ultrasound) will be used for the development and verification of a mathematical model for the automated detection of fetal movements in NFMS data. This latter model might provide new opportunities in non-invasive monitoring of fetal health.

* Genetic susceptibility to severe infections
* Homozygosity mapping study
* Whole genome genotyping
* Exome data
* High density microarrays
* Homozygosity calculation
* Candidate genes
* Functional and complementation tests
* Pathogenic effect
* Patient cells
* Control cells
* Overexpression system

The study aims to investigate the prevalence, type, and risk factors of urinary incontinence (UI) in married women and its effect on their quality of life. The study will use a diagnostic test to measure the incontinence quality of life of the participants. The study will take place over a period of October 2022 and July 2023. The study will be conducted in a multidisciplinary approach, and the results will be used to develop a comprehensive understanding of UI, raise awareness among women about the condition, and provide ongoing support for those affected by it. The study will be conducted in a randomized controlled trial design, with the participants being randomly assigned to either the intervention or control group. The intervention group will receive the diagnostic test, while the control group will not receive any intervention. The study will be conducted in a cross-sectional design, with the participants being recruited from various countries. The study will be conducted in a single-center design, with the participants being recruited from a single center. The study will be conducted in a prospective design, with the participants being recruited at the beginning of the study and followed up until the end of the study.
