The study will be conducted in a cross-sectional design, with the participants being recruited from various countries. The study will be conducted in a single-center design, with the participants being recruited from a single center. The study will be conducted in a prospective design, with the participants being recruited at the beginning of the study and followed up until the end of the study. The study will be conducted in a randomized controlled trial design, with the participants being randomly assigned to either the intervention or control group. The intervention group will receive the diagnostic test, while the control group will not receive any intervention. The study will be conducted in a cross-sectional design, with the participants being recruited from various countries. The study will be conducted in a single-center design, with the participants being recruited from a single center. The study will be conducted in a prospective design, with the participants being recruited at the beginning of the study and followed up until the end of the study. The study will be conducted in a randomized controlled trial

=========

This is a randomized clinical trial (RCT) that compares the efficacy of two cell products, BMAC and MM-AT, in the treatment of knee osteoarthritis. The study will include 204 patients with symptomatic unilateral knee osteoarthritis who will undergo intra-articular infiltration of either BMAC or MM-AT. Patients will be clinically evaluated at 0-2-6-12 months follow-up, and disease-modifying effects of the two cell products will be investigated by analysis on peripheral blood at 0-2-6-12 months follow-up and by evaluation of radiographic and magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) at 0 and 12 months follow-up. The primary outcome measure is Western Ontario and McMaster University Osteoarthritis index (WOMAC) - Pain subscale at 6 months follow-up. Secondary outcome measures include Western Ontario and McMaster Universities Osteoarthritis Index (WOMAC), Knee Injury and Osteoarthritis Outcome Score (KOOS), Visual Analogue Scale (VAS), EuroQol Visual Analogue Scale (EQ-VAS), Tegner Activity Level Scale, Objective parameters- Range of Motion, Objective parameters - Circumferences, Patient Acceptable Symptom State (PASS), Minimally Clinically Important Difference (MCID), Expectations about the effectiveness of the treatment, Kellgren-Lawrence score, 3 Tesla Nuclear Magnetic Resonance Imaging (3T MRI), and Analysis of circulating micro RNAs. The study will be conducted in accordance with the Declaration of Helsinki and will be approved by the Ethics Committee of the Centre Hospitalier Valida.

The study is a randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled phase III clinical trial evaluating the efficacy and safety of CBD TPM capsules in adults for use in the reduction of insomnia severity. The study will enroll 150 participants who meet the inclusion criteria and will be randomly assigned to one of three arms: placebo, 75mg CBD, or 150mg CBD. The study will measure the mean change from study baseline in insomnia severity index (ISI) score and subject sleep efficiency (sSE) at 8 weeks. The study will be conducted over a period of 12 weeks, with a 2-week run-in period and a 10-week treatment period. Participants will be required to abstain from alcohol and recreational drugs for at least 3 hours before bedtime for the duration of the study.

* Pattern of Intestinal Parasitic Infection Among Cirrhotic Patients in Sohag University Hospital
* Diagnostic Test: stool analysis
* Primary Outcome Measures: Pattern of Intestinal Parasitic Infection Among Cirrhotic Patients
* Study Design: Randomized, Parallel Assignment, Open Label
* Study Duration: 12 months
* Study Type: Screening
* Study Purpose: To determine the most common risk factors of intestinal parasitic infection in cirrhotic patients.

===============

The REtinal Detachment Outcomes Study (REDOS) is a factorial, randomized controlled trial that compares the outcomes of three different treatment options for rhegmatogenous retinal detachment (RRD): pars plana vitrectomy (PPV) with sulfur hexafluoride gas tamponade, pars plana vitrectomy with scleral buckle and sulfur hexafluoride gas tamponade, and pars plana vitrectomy with perfluoropropane gas tamponade. The study aims to determine the primary outcome of single surgery anatomic success and secondary outcomes of pinhole visual acuity, best-corrected visual acuity, time to onset of RD recurrence, severity and number of complications, and quality of life questionnaire. The study includes 240 participants with a mean age of 55 years and a mean duration of RRD of 2.5 months. The study is expected to be completed in 2022.

===============

This study aims to evaluate the differential effects of 0.25%, 0.5%, and 1% ropivacaine on the onset time and duration of ultrasound-guided ankle blocks in patients having forefoot surgery for anesthesia and postoperative analgesia. The primary outcome is the difference in the duration of the sensory blocks. The secondary outcomes are the difference in onset time of the sensory block, the postoperative pain scores, and the opioid consumption. The study is a randomized, triple-blinded, parallel-group interventional study. The study will be conducted in patients with hallux valgus, who are scheduled for elective forefoot surgery for hallux valgus repair under unilateral ankle block at ZOL Genk ASA physical I-II-III. The study will be conducted in three arms: 0.25% ropivacaine group, 0.5% ropivacaine group, and 1% ropivacaine group. The study will measure the duration of the sensory block, the difference in sensory block onset, the postoperative pain scores, and the opioid consumption.

The study aims to investigate the effect of compression stockings on the complaints, well-being and sleep quality of pregnant women with restless leg syndrome. The study is a randomized, parallel assignment, open label study. The study population includes pregnant women with restless leg syndrome who are at least 18 years old, between 27 and 40 weeks of gestation, and have a severity of 11 and above according to the RLS Severity Rating Scale. The intervention group receives compression stockings, while the control group receives knee socks. The primary outcome measure is the RLS Severity Rating Scale, while the secondary outcome measure is the Pittsburgh Sleep Quality Index. The study will be conducted for 21 days.

=========

The study aims to investigate the efficacy of home-based strength and Tai-chi exercise snacking for improving physical function in Taiwanese and British older adults. The study will take place over approximately 3 months and involve 5 assessments remotely. A subset of 60 participants will be assessed in person to validate the remote assessment and undergo more in-depth assessments. Participants will be randomly assigned to either the intervention group or the waitlist control group. The intervention will consist of progressive exercises that participants will perform at home and record in a log book. The study will measure changes in the Short Physical Performance Battery, 1RM of leg press, balance function, strength function, agility function, flexibility, quality of life and wellbeing, physical activity level, current mental health, self-confidence for exercise, attitudes to exercise, acceptability of the intervention, general health, mental health and wellbeing, and quality of life.

This is a randomized case-control study evaluating the role of pre-emptive caudal epidural analgesia for postoperative pain relief in lumbosacral surgeries and to compare the effect of adding dexamethasone to ropivacaine with respect to quality of analgesia, duration of analgesia, hemodynamic effects and associated side effects.

=================

The study is a randomised controlled experimental study to determine the effect of nursing care based on Kolcaba's comfort theory on comfort, care satisfaction and sleep quality of intensive care patients. The study will include 80 participants, 40 in the intervention group and 40 in the control group, and will use the General Comfort Scale, the Newcastle Satisfaction Scale, the Richard Campbell Sleep Scale and the Comfort Behaviours Checklist to measure the primary outcomes. The study will be conducted in a single-blind, randomised controlled design, with the intervention group receiving care based on Kolcaba's comfort theory and the control group receiving standard care. The study will be conducted in a hospital setting and will be conducted over a period of 24 hours. The study will be conducted in a hospital setting and will be conducted over a period of 24 hours.

The P-KIDs CARE intervention is a health systems intervention aimed at addressing health systems delays to care for injured children in Tanzania. The intervention includes two components: the World Health Organization (WHO) Basic Emergency Care Course for training on patient assessment and stabilization, and a decision support tool which integrates adaptation of two evidence-based tools: a) the Pediatric Resuscitation and Trauma Outcome model for mortality risk assessment, and 3) the Field Triage Decision Scheme to assist with timely referral decisions. The study will be conducted in two phases. In Phase 1, the investigators will conduct formative research to inform development of the P-Kids CARE intervention. In Phase 2, the investigators will pilot the intervention in two study facilities in the Kilimanjaro Region. The primary outcome will be mortality. The secondary outcomes will be time to definitive care, disposition, and morbidity. The study will be conducted in two phases. In Phase 1, the investigators will conduct formative research to inform development of the P-Kids CARE intervention. In Phase 2, the investigators will pilot the intervention in two study facilities in the Kilimanjaro Region. The primary outcome will be mortality. The secondary outcomes will be time to definitive care, disposition, and morbidity.

This is a preliminary study that aims to evaluate the effectiveness of combining pelvic floor rehabilitation with postural re-education in women with stress urinary incontinence and chronic low back pain. The study will be conducted in two arms: one arm will receive pelvic floor rehabilitation and postural re-education, and the other arm will receive pelvic floor rehabilitation and spinal mobilization. The study will measure the change in International Consultation on Incontinence Questionnaire-Urinary Short Form (ICIQ-UI SF) and Pain Visual Analogue Scale (VAS) from baseline, at 10 sessions of treatment, and at 30 days after the end of the training. The study will also measure the change in Modified Oxford Scale (MOS) from baseline, at 10 sessions of treatment, and at 30 days after the end of the training. The study will be conducted in a randomized, parallel assignment, triple-masked design. The study will be conducted in 20 women aged from 18 to 75 years with a diagnosis of stress urinary incontinence associated with non-specific chronic low back pain. The study will be conducted in 2 sessions per week for 5 weeks.

===============

The study aims to develop a pharmacodynamic model for propofol in older adults. The model will use the pharmacokinetic parameters of the Eleveld model and new pharmacodynamic parameters derived from frontal EEG in a population older than 65 years. The hypothesis is that the Eleveld PKPD model, modified with this new pharmacodynamic parameter, will predict better the hypnotic effect of propofol than the original Eleveld PKPD model, in adult patients older than 65 years. The creation of a PKPD model of propofol for the population over 65 years of age would allow a better titration of this drug to avoid possible deleterious effects secondary to its under or overdosage. The study will measure the performance error, median absolute performance error, median prediction error, time of loss of response, time of burst-suppression, time of return of response, and time of return of response.

===============

This is a multicenter non-inferiority randomized controlled trial comparing a very short-course of antibiotics (1 day) to a standard course of antibiotics (4 to 7 days) in patients with acute cholangitis after adequate biliary drainage. The study aims to determine if a very short-course of antibiotics is non-inferior to a standard course of antibiotics. The study will enroll 100 patients and will be conducted over a period of 1 year. The primary outcome measure will be the clinical cure rate by day 14 after ERCP without relapse by day 30. Secondary outcome measures will include all-cause 90-day mortality, relapse of cholangitis within 90 days, rate of any other subsequent infection requiring antibiotic therapy within 90 days, rate of subsequent infections with MDR bacteria or Clostridioides difficile within 90 days, rate of other adverse drug events within 14 days, length of intensive care and hospital stay for the initial episode of cholangitis, quality of life and health utility, and societal costs and cost-effectiveness/-utility.

===============

This is a prospective randomized clinical double-blinded study that will be conducted at Anesthesiology Department in Tanta University Hospitals for one year from August 2023 to August 2024 after approval from the institutional ethical committee. The study will enroll 60 adult morbidly obese patients scheduled for laparoscopic bariatric surgery. Patients will be randomly assigned to either the conventional group or the ultrasound-guided group. In the conventional group, patients will undergo a recruitment maneuver with 30 cmH2O pressure for 30 seconds. In the ultrasound-guided group, patients will undergo a recruitment maneuver under the direct real-time guidance of ultrasound if atelectasis is present. The primary outcome measure is the change in lung ultrasound score, and the secondary outcome measures are the incidence of atelectasis and intra-operative desaturation. The study aims to compare the effectiveness of the two groups in improving lung function during laparoscopic bariatric surgery.

The study aims to optimize fractionation schedules of heel spur radiotherapy through a prospective randomized open-label trial conducted at Department of Radiation Oncology at Masaryk Memorial Cancer Institute Brno (MMCI). The study posits the hypothesis that very low total doses of orthovoltage radiotherapy, delivered in a single fraction, may provide pain relief comparable to that achieved with higher doses of fractionated radiotherapy. The primary goal of this research is to determine whether one-day irradiation (a single fraction) is non-inferior to fractionated radiotherapy over a three-month period in terms of pain relief for HSS patients. The study was supported by grant of the Ministry of Health of the Czech Republic AZV NU22-10-00479. All patients signed informed consent.

This is a randomized controlled trial with a 12-month follow-up. The study aims to examine if a behavioral weight reduction program combined with Pain Neuroscience Education (PNE) and Cognition-Targeted Exercise Therapy (CTET) is superior to reduce pain at 12 months follow-up compared PNE and CTET alone, in overweight or obese people with CLBP. Secondary objectives are to examine the effects of adding a behavioral weight reduction program combined with PNE and CTET, compared to PNE and CTET alone, on 1) other pain related outcomes (pain interference, pain distribution and pain beliefs), 2) on anthropometrics (body weight/composition, muscle thickness and fat distribution), 3) on energy balance related behavior (24h continuous activity monitoring, dietary intake and sleep) and finally 4) on health economics (heath care utilization, productivity loss and quality of life) at 12 months follow-up.

===============

This is a randomized controlled prospective multicenter study comparing clinical outcomes and the efficacy of single versus double pyloromyotomy in G-POEM for refractory and severe gastroparesis. The study will be explained in detail and, if the prospective participant agrees, an informed consent form - HIPAA Research Authorization will be taken. Prospective subjects will be randomized into one of two study groups: Single pyloromyotomy vs Double pyloromyotomy G-POEM using a computer-generated random sequence that will be placed in sealed envelopes. The patient will open the envelop and hand it to the endoscopist performing the procedure. Subjects will be followed up in the clinic at 3 months, 6 months, and 12 months (one year) after procedure per routine care. The primary outcome measures are clinical success at 3 months, 6 months and 12 months follow up and Gastroparesis Cardinal Symptom Index (GCSI) score before and after GPOEM at 3, 6 and 12 months follow up. The secondary outcome measures are total procedure time for each method, adverse events like pneumoperitoneum, gi bleeding, perforation, infection and abdominal pain, and recurrence of symptoms.

===============

The study is a single arm, open-label study to evaluate the efficacy of Minayo Iron-rich Yeast Drink with SOD on female nutritional anemia, skin condition and Qi-blood deficiency syndrome. The study includes 40 female participants aged 18 to 35 with hemoglobin concentration level below 110g/L based on WHO diagnostic criteria for anemia. Participants will drink one piece of the product each day for 4 consecutive weeks. The primary outcome measure is the change of serum ferritin level in blood, ng/mL. Secondary outcome measures include the change of hemoglobin concentration level, superoxide dismutase (SOD) concentration level, glutathione (GSH) concentration level, and skin care measurement using Miravex Antera 3D imaging system. The study is designed to support the care of patients with nutritional anemia, skin condition and Qi-blood deficiency syndrome.

The study aims to investigate the effects of a single session of acute intermittent hypercapnic hypoxia (AIHH) and transcutaneous spinal cord stimulation (tSCS) on cortical and spinal drive in individuals with chronic spinal cord injury (SCI). The study will use a randomized, crossover design with three arms: AIHH + tSCS-paired strength training, SHAM AIHH + tSCS-paired strength training, and AIHH + SHAM tSCS-paired strength training. The study will measure changes in respiratory cortical and spinal drive, upper extremity cortical and spinal drive, maximum respiratory voluntary force production, airway occlusion pressure, forced vital capacity, and upper extremity functional assessment. The study will also measure changes in cardiovascular response during AIH. The study will be conducted at the Centre Hospitalier Valida in Quebec, Canada.

This is a prospective, 2x2 factorial design, blinded, randomized controlled study. The study aims to assess the effects of anesthetic maintenance agents and vasopressors on cerebral hemodynamics and metabolism during surgery. The study will recruit 80 adult patients (age >18 years old), who are ASA I-III and are scheduled for surgery under general anesthesia. The patients will be randomized into one of the four groups in 1:1:1:1 ratio for one of two choices of anesthetic maintenance agents and vasopressors. The primary outcome measure is the effect of anesthetic maintenance agents and vasopressors on cerebral hemodynamics and metabolism during surgery. The secondary outcome measure is the effect of anesthetic maintenance agents and vasopressors on cerebral hemodynamics and metabolism during induction. The study will be conducted at London Health Sciences Centre or St. Joseph's Healthcare that is scheduled to last longer than 1 hour. The study will be conducted in accordance with the Declaration of Helsinki and will obtain written informed consent from all participants. The study will be registered with the ClinicalTrials.gov registry.

The RaDiCo-IDMet study is a national cohort study that aims to investigate the clinical, genetic, biological, morphometric, metabolic, and therapeutic characteristics of patients with imprinting disorders (IDs) in pediatric and adult patients. The study will also analyze the prevalence of metabolic abnormalities (MA) and the risk for metabolic complications such as obesity, diabetes, cardiovascular disease (CVD), metabolic syndrome. The study will be conducted over an average of 10 years, and the primary outcome measures will be the clinical characteristics of IDs in pediatric and adult patients, the genetic characteristics of IDs in pediatric and adult patients, the biological characteristics of IDs in pediatric and adult patients, and the morphometric characteristics of IDs in pediatric and adult patients. The secondary outcome measures will include the search for an association between the metabolic phenotype of IDs patients' and their biological profil, determination of the prevalence of metabolic abnormalities (MA), estimation of the risk for metabolic complications such as obesity, diabetes, cardiovascular disease (CVD), metabolic syndrome, description of different therapeutic approaches and identification of a common base for all IDs, variations of quality-of-life scores, and analyze of (epi)genetic mutations transmission in proband and relatives. The study will be conducted in all sexes and will not accept healthy volunteers.

The study is a randomized, parallel assignment, open label study comparing unipolar interlocking and bipolar interlocking in the treatment of humeral shaft fractures in adults. The study measures the proportion of patients with radiologically assessed bone healing at 12 months. The study includes patients with written consent, aged 18 years or older, with a diagnosis of humeral shaft fracture requiring surgical treatment with intramedullary nailing. Exclusion criteria include pathologic fractures, post-traumatic brachial plexus injury, court protection, guardianship or legal guardianship, pregnancy, parturition or breastfeeding, and acute or chronic, unstable or poorly controlled disease that may interfere with the evaluation of the study objective. The study includes questionnaires and CT scans at specific time points. The primary outcome measure is the proportion of patients with radiologically assessed bone healing at 12 months.

=================

The EPI-MINN study is a national comparative study that aims to investigate the effectiveness of cognitive training and social cognitive training combined with a mobile app for enhancing motivation in individuals with early psychosis. The study will recruit 150 participants aged 18-40 years who are enrolled in an early psychosis coordinated specialty care clinic and have a stable clinical status. Participants will be randomly assigned to either the experimental group, which will receive 20 hours of cognitive and social cognitive training over 12 weeks, or the control group, which will receive treatment as usual. The primary outcome measure will be changes in cognitive function, as assessed by the Test My Brain scores, at 18 months post-intervention. Secondary outcome measures will include changes in dysfunctional attitudes, quality of life, behavioral inhibition and activation, motivation and pleasure, and depression and anxiety. The study will also assess the neural correlates of motivation and cognitive function using neuroimaging techniques. The EPI-MINN study will provide valuable insights into the effectiveness of cognitive and social cognitive training for enhancing motivation in individuals with early psychosis and inform the development of evidence-based interventions for this population.

===============

The study aims to assess the use of wearable fitness trackers in prehabilitation programmes. The study will compare the use of wearable fitness trackers to the current standard of care, which is exercise to a rating of perceived exertion (RPE). The study will measure the total number of minutes of moderate intensity exercise, volume of physical activity (mean MET min/week), weekly adherence (mean percentage of actual/prescribed MET minutes/week), duration of exercise self-reported vs recorded HR data (minutes), intensity of exercise self-reported vs recorded HR data (RPE vs % of target HR zone), and patient feedback of using heart trackers in a prehabilitation setting - Technology acceptance Model (TAM), UMUX-lite, and UEQ. The study will be conducted as a randomized, parallel group clinical trial. Participants will be randomly assigned to either the intervention group, which will use wearable fitness trackers to monitor their exercise intensity, or the control group, which will use RPE to monitor their exercise intensity. The study will be conducted at Imperial College Healthcare Trust and Guy's and St Thomas' NHS Foundation Trust. The study will recruit 82 participants. The study will run for 8 weeks. The primary outcome measure will be the total number of minutes of moderate intensity exercise. The secondary outcome measures will be volume of physical activity (mean MET min/week), weekly adherence (mean percentage of actual/prescribed MET minutes/week), duration of exercise self-reported vs recorded HR data (minutes), intensity of exercise self-reported vs recorded HR data (RPE vs % of target HR zone), and patient feedback of using heart trackers in a prehabilitation setting - Technology acceptance Model (TAM), UMUX-lite, and UEQ. The study will be conducted in accordance with the Declaration of Helsinki and will obtain ethical approval from the Imperial College London Research Ethics Committee.

===============

The LA POPA Trial is a randomized, controlled, superiority trial comparing minimally invasive treatments for pilonidal disease: pit-picking surgery and pit-picking surgery with Sinus Laser assisted Closure. The study aims to determine the success rate of treatment at 1 year, 3 and 5 years follow-up, pain scores in the period after surgery, patient reported outcome measures, wound healing and complications, work rehabilitation, return to daily activities, recurrence rate, need for secondary or revision surgery, patient satisfaction, and quality of life after treatment. The study includes patients aged 12 years and older who present with primary pilonidal sinus disease; Type 1b and 3 of the Dutch staging system (11), see Figure 1. The study is designed as a multicentre, single-blinded, randomised, controlled, superiority trial. The primary outcome measure is the success rate of treatment, defined as wound healing outcomes at 1 year, which includes the following: closure of all pits, absence of symptoms, absence of persisting sinuses, and absence of recurrence of pilonidal sinus disease. The study is currently ongoing.

=========

The study aims to identify the sociodemographic characteristics, personality traits, and patterns of substance abuse among patients with substance use disorder admitted to the addiction treatment unit of Assiut University Hospital. The study will use a survey to gather information about personal information, socioeconomic status, previous admissions/trials for detox, medical, psychological, social, financial, and legal aspects of addiction, adverse life events dating before starting addiction, substance(s) used, doses, route of administration, when, where, and with whom he prefers taking the drug, psychiatric interview, Symptom Checklist-90-Revised (SCL-90-R), Five-Factor Model of Personality, Severity of Dependence Scale (SDS), and Urine Drug Screen. The study will be conducted over one week.

This is a phase 2 single-arm study to investigate the efficacy and safety of combination of immune checkpoint inhibitors and radioembolisation for previously untreated metastatic hepatocellular carcinoma. The study will enroll 20 patients with metastatic hepatocellular carcinoma who are eligible for immune checkpoint inhibitor and yttrium-90 microsphere injection. The study will have a 3-year follow-up period. The primary outcome measure is best objective response, and the secondary outcome measures are progression-free survival, overall survival, incidence of treatment-related side effects, local control rate, and distant control rate. The study will be conducted in accordance with the Declaration of Helsinki and Good Clinical Practice guidelines.

This is a phase II study of neoadjuvant durvalumab and tremelimumab with gemcitabine and cisplatin in patients with intrahepatic cholangiocarcinoma that is borderline resectable/resectable but with high risk for recurrence. The study aims to evaluate the feasibility of the treatment and its impact on the rate of conversion from unresectable to resectable, objective response rate, pathological complete response, overall survival, progression-free survival, rate of R0 resection, relapse free survival, patient reported outcomes, and event free survival. The study will enroll 24 patients and will be conducted over 36 months.

============

The study aims to establish normal reference values for the structure and blood flow of the extremities of Chinese Han adults using high-frequency ultrasound. The study is a multi-center study that includes healthy volunteers and patients with artery disease. The study measures the intima thickness and blood flow velocity of the dorsalis pedis artery and proper palmar digital artery using high-frequency ultrasound. The study is designed to provide a quantitative reference for the early diagnosis, degree evaluation, and curative effect observation of the structure and blood flow of the extremities. The study is expected to provide valuable information for the early diagnosis and treatment of artery disease.

===============

The study aims to evaluate the efficacy and safety of STERIFY GEL in the treatment of periodontitis following scaling and root planing (SRP) in patients with grade III and IV chronic periodontal disease. The study is a split-mouth, randomized, controlled study, where STERIFY GEL is administered into the periodontal pockets of one or two segments of patients undergoing whole-mouth extended SRP, with the contralateral segments serving as controls. The primary outcome measure is pocket depth, measured by periodontal probe at pre-treatment, 1 month, 2 months, and 3 months. Secondary outcome measures include gingival recession, clinical attachment level, plaque index, bleeding index, furcations, grade of mobility, and quantification of bacterial contamination. The study is designed to test the safety and efficacy of STERIFY GEL in promoting healing of periodontal pockets following SRP, compared with treatment with SRP alone.

The study aims to evaluate whether hippocampal training, induced by physical and cognitive training, will augment the hippocampal neuroplasticity effect of HBOT and further enhance recovery of inaccessible memories in veterans with PTSD. The study will include 40 male veterans aged 25 to 60 years, with combat-associated PTSD and peritraumatic amnesia, who will receive either HBOT alone or HBOT and hippocampal training. The HBOT protocol will consist of 60 daily sessions, 90-minutes each, five days a week. Hippocampal training will combine physical and cognitive training 3 times per week, prior to HBOT sessions. Detailed psychological evaluation, anatomic and functional MRI, electroencephalogram and autonomic nervous system data will be obtained at baseline, and during and after treatment. The primary outcome measure will be changes in memory gaps (as assessed by the traumatic scene form). Secondary outcome measures will include change in brain activity as assessed by fMRI, cognitive performance as assessed using Neurotrax, RAVLT memory test, ROCFT memory test, and Verbal Pairs memory test. The study will be a per protocol trial, and thus, participants will only be included in the analysis if they completed the treatment protocol and attained study analysis. The study will be conducted in accordance with the Declaration of Helsinki and will be approved by the Institutional Review Board.

64Cu-DOTATATE PET/CT imaging for the diagnosis of cardiac sarcoidosis

Keywords: 64Cu-DOTATATE PET/CT, cardiac sarcoidosis, inflammatory heart disease, myocarditis, neuroendocrine tumor, somatostatin receptors, tracer uptake, adverse outcomes

=============

The study is a randomized, double-blinded, placebo-controlled, single-center pilot/exploratory trial to evaluate the effect of probiotics on immunosuppressive-drug-associated diarrhea among renal transplant recipients. Participants will be monitored peri-operatively and will receive one probiotics capsule daily for six months immediately after the onset of post-surgical non-infectious diarrhea. The primary outcome measure is reduction in immunosuppressive drugs-associated diarrhea, which will be measured through a gastrointestinal questionnaire and Bristol Stool Chart. Secondary outcome measures include analysis of inflammatory biomarkers and association between inflammatory markers and fecal microbiome. The study will be conducted at Centre Hospitalier Valida.

=================

The study is a randomized, stratified, parallel-group clinical trial that compares the efficacy of inhaled sevoflurane to current intravenous sedation practice for improving PaO2/FiO2 in ICU patients at high risk for ARDS. The study will enroll 100 patients who are admitted to participating ICUs with at least one known risk factor for ARDS and a LIPS equals to, or greater than, 4. The primary outcome measure is the longitudinal evolution in the PaO2/FiO2 ratio within 5 days from randomization. Secondary outcome measures include progression to ARDS, rate of pneumonia, ventilator-free days to day 28, organ failure to day 5, mortality at day 28, length of ICU-stay up to 28 days, physiological measures, hemodynamic measures, acute kidney injury, supraventricular tachycardia or new onset atrial fibrillation, ICU-acquired delirium, and biomarker measurements. The study will be conducted in a single center and will be blinded with concealed allocation of patients at risk of developing the ARDS to a strategy of inhaled sedation with sevoflurane or to a strategy of current intravenous sedation practice.

The study aims to compare the functional status of patients with massive rotator cuff tendon tears who undergo arthroscopic rotator cuff partial repair with superior capsular augmentation with LHBBT, arthroscopic rotator cuff partial repair, or arthroscopic complete rotator cuff repair. The primary outcome measures include change in shoulder strength, range of motion, American Shoulder and Elbow Surgeons (ASES) score, Constant-Murley score (CMS), Disabilities of the Arm, Shoulder and Hand (DASH) score, and pain score according to the visual analogue scale (VAS). Secondary outcome measures include integrity of surgically repaired rotator cuff tendons on MRI studies using Sugaya classification and change in quality of life and kinesiophobia score. The study is conducted in Tartu University Hospital Sports Traumatology Centre and rotator cuff repair procedures will be done by three orthopaedic surgeons with long experience in arthroscopic shoulder surgery. It is determined intra-operatively whether the tear is reparable or not. If possible, the tendon(s) will be anatomically repaired. For irreparable tears intra-operative urn randomization takes place - either partial repair or partial repair with SCR using the LHBBT. The post-operative therapy regimen will be the same for each study group. Subjects will come for scheduled visits at 6-month, 12-month, and 24-month timepoints. Assessment tools consist of range of motion (ROM), strength measurements, preoperative radiography measuring acromio-humeral index (AHI), critical shoulder angle (CSA), acromion type and shoulder arthrosis (Hamada), functional scores: The Disabilities of the Arm, Shoulder and Hand (DASH), The Constant-Murley score (CMS), The American Shoulder and Elbow Surgeons (ASES) and visual analogue scale (VAS), also including Tampa kinesiophobia score and emotional well-being (EEK) score. Goutallier classification (1994) will be used pre- and postoperatively to measure muscle fatty infiltration.

The IRIS Program is a novel pathway to optimize treatment of injection-related infections for people who inject drugs in Hamilton, Ontario. The program offers a one-stop, low-barrier combined care model to address injection-related infections, substance use treatment, peer support, and care coordination/systems navigation. The study aims to measure the effectiveness of the program in reducing emergency department visits and hospital readmissions, completion of intended course of treatment for injection-related infections, and mortality rates. The study will be conducted in a single group assignment, with no masking. Participants will be recruited from Hamilton, Ontario, and must be aged 16 or older, able to provide informed consent, present with a confirmed or suspected injection-related infection, have a history of injection drug use within 3 months of recruitment, and live in Hamilton, Ontario. Exclusion criteria include a history of HIV or Hepatitis C infection. The study will measure the number of emergency department visits and hospital readmissions, completion of intended course of treatment for injection-related infections, number of hospital readmissions specifically for the infection that was the primary reason for program enrolment, number of emergency department visits, number of new initiations or record of continuation of substance use treatment, mortality rates, and rates of program drop-out and reasons for discontinuation. The study will be conducted over a period of 6 months, with data collection occurring within 30 days of initial hospital admission or program enrolment, and again within 90 days of hospital discharge or program enrolment.

The study aims to compare the use of a mobile app for surveillance of adverse events following influenza immunization to a web-based platform. The study is a randomized controlled trial with two arms: a web-based notification arm and a mobile app arm. Participants are eligible if they speak English or French, have an active email address and telephone, and have been immunized with the seasonal influenza vaccine. The study measures the useability of the two platforms through a user experience survey completed by all participants at the end of the study. The study is designed to screen for adverse events following influenza immunization.

This study aims to investigate the relationship of peri-implantitis with COX-2 gene polymorphisms, active MMP-8 levels, and characterization of associated microbiota. The study will be conducted in a case-control design, with 100 patients diagnosed with peri-implantitis and 100 healthy controls. The study will include genetic analysis of COX-2 gene polymorphisms, microbiological analysis of peri-implant lesions, and quantification of active MMP-8 levels in peri-implant crevicular fluid. The study will be conducted in the Department of Periodontology and Implant Biology, Dental School, Aristotle University of Thessaloniki, Greece. The study will be conducted in accordance with the Declaration of Helsinki and will be approved by the Ethical Committee of the Faculty of Dentistry of the Aristotle University of Thessaloniki. The study will be conducted in collaboration with the Department of Biology, Medical School, A.U.Th. and the Department of Microbiology, Medical School, A.U.Th. The study will be conducted by Ioannis Fragkioudakis, a postgraduate student of the Department of Periodontology and Implant Biology, Dental School, Aristotle University of Thessaloniki, under the supervision of Professor Minas Arsenakis and Associate Professor Dimitrios Chatzidimitriou. The study will be conducted in collaboration with Medix Biochemica Ltd and Dentognostics GmbH. The study will be conducted in accordance with the manufacturer's instructions. The study aims to evaluate the effect of virtual reality on pain, anxiety and patient comfort during trigger point injection. Patients in the experimental group will be shown videos that the patient wants to watch, such as nature and seaside walks, underwater videos, with music background, through virtual reality glasses for 10 minutes. Patients in the control group will continue routine practice. Patients' anxiety, comfort and pain levels will be evaluated before and after trigger point injection. The study measures the State Anxiety Scale, General Comfort Scale and Visual Analog Scale. The primary outcome measures are the State Anxiety Scale, General Comfort Scale and Visual Analog Scale. The study is designed as a randomized, parallel assignment, single-masked study. The study is conducted in Turkish.

The study aims to investigate the effect of autonomic dysfunction on hemodynamic instability during per-oral endoscopic myotomy in achalasia patients. The study will be conducted as a prospective observational study. Patients will be divided into two groups based on the results of the heart rate variability (HRV) test performed preoperatively. The primary outcome measure will be the wobble of systolic arterial pressure (SAP) during surgery. The study will be conducted in Gangnam Severance Hospital. The study aimed to evaluate the use of virtual reality glasses during inhaler treatment in children aged 2-5 years. The study was conducted as a prospective, single-blind, randomized, controlled study in the Pediatric Emergency Department of the Health Sciences University Haseki Training and Research Hospital. Children with neuromotor retardation, visual and auditory problems, underlying chronic diseases, obesity or malnutrition, adrenaline, budesonide or those who receive ipratropium bromide treatment, those who will receive inhaler nebula treatment for the first time, those who have received inhaler treatment in the last 72 hours, those who have a previous operation or sedative history, those who have a fever above 37.5°C, those who have used VR before, those under 2 years of age to avoid screen exposure children (infants) and those over 5 years old (school period) were excluded from the study. In total, 913 children received inhaler treatment in the hospital during the study period. Of these, 135 children met the inclusion criteria and were included in the study. The children were divided into three groups: VR audio-visual users (Roller Coasters, group 1), VR audio-visual users (Wild Dolphins, group 2), and those who did not use any additional equipment (group 3). The children in all groups were given 'salbutamol' inhaler treatment for 15 minutes, and equality was achieved between the groups in terms of treatment active substance and duration. The study aimed to compare the crying times, changes in RR, SpO2, HR values with pre- and post-treatment physician questionnaires and family questionnaires. The study aims to evaluate the feasibility, acceptability, and effect of a transdiagnostic psychological treatment for anxiety and depression in youth. The study is a clinical open trial conducted in two primary care clinics. The intervention is a 11-session group treatment of the Unified Protocol, a transdiagnostic psychological treatment based on the third wave of Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (CBT). The study will measure child self-report, parent-report, and therapist assessment of emotion regulation, anxiety and depression symptoms, mental health, behavior, peer problems, health-related quality of life, and treatment satisfaction. The study will also assess the acceptability and feasibility of the intervention as reported by the therapists. The study will be conducted at two primary care clinics with patients and parents seeking routine care. The study will be conducted in Swedish.

The PALISA study is a randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled study to assess the effect of skin conductance measurement during less-invasive surfactant administration (LISA) on pain and stress levels in preterm infants. The study will recruit 20 preterm infants with minimal gestational age of 27 weeks requiring LISA according to the local standard operating procedure. The infants will be randomly assigned to either the intervention group, where skin conductance will be measured during LISA, or the control group, where skin conductance will not be measured. The primary outcome measure will be the median peaks per second at prespecified time-points adjusted for median peaks per second at baseline. Secondary outcome measures will include the Neonatal Pain, Agitation and Sedation Scale (N-PASS) at prespecified time-points, absolute number of apneas, desaturations, bradycardias, and arterial hypotensions during LISA, and difference in maximum and median peaks per second before and after apnea, desaturation, bradycardia, and arterial hypotension. The study will be conducted at the Centre Hospitalier Valida in France.

The study is a feasibility cluster randomized controlled trial (RCT) of a home-based depression care for older people delivered by lay providers in Nigeria. The study aims to assess the feasibility of delivering emhGAP-Age, an adapted emhGAP-IG, and adapted Problem-Solving Therapy (PST-PC) support/supervision of lay providers, as well as links to social support resources, to older people with depression in underserved geriatric populations. The study will recruit 100 participants aged 60 years and above, with a PHQ-9 score of ≥11 during routine consultation, from primary healthcare facilities in Nigeria. Participants will be randomly assigned to either the experimental arm, which will receive emhGAP-Age, or the active comparator arm, which will receive generic emhGAP-IG and psychoeducation and stress reduction. The primary outcome measure will be depression remission, defined as a PHQ-9 score of <6, at six months post trial entry. The study will be conducted in accordance with the Declaration of Helsinki and will obtain ethical approval from the relevant institutional review board.

This is a single-center, patient-blinded, randomized, 2-year, parallel-group, superiority study to compare the efficacy of augmented ACL integration via PrP enriched collected autologous bone versus standard ACL technique. The study seeks primarily to determine less tibial tunnel widening when a bone/PrP-composite is applied directly in the tibial tunnel compared to the same surgery without using the composite, measured with CT and MRI. Secondary study objectives are to evaluate femoral tunnel widening, tibial and femoral graft incorporation, graft maturation and knee function (clinical, functional, patient reported) over the course of 24 months follow-up and to evaluate occurrence of procedure- and product-related adverse events and complications. This is a prospective, single-center, single-blinded, 2-arm-parallel, randomized, controlled study with 24 months follow-up. Participants will be recruited from the Knee Surgery department at Schulthess Klinik when scheduled for ACL reconstruction. The study sample comprises 107 patients, allocated 1:1 on experimental and control arm. Outcome measures are taken at 0, 6, 12, and 24 months. The total study duration is 48 months. The study duration per patient is 24 months.

The study will randomize patients into three groups: 1) RSI + face-mask preoxygenation, 2) RSI + HFNOC preoxygenation and 3) RSI + face-mask and HFNOC preoxygenation. The primary outcome will be the impact of HFNOC preoxygenation on oxygen saturation and heart rate during the induction of anaesthesia. Secondary outcomes will be safety of the RSI protocol, Cormack-Lehane score, incidence of difficult airway management, number of intubation attempts and episodes of regurgitation/aspiration. RSI will be done according to the protocol. Initially, equipment will be checked and an i.v. line will be checked/started and then a bolus of ketamine will be given (0,2-0,5 mg/kg intravenously,) for the face-mask/HFNOC tolerance and the table will be tilted to anti-Trendelenburg position. In case of difficult or unable of intravenous line insertion, intramuscular bolus of ketamin (1-3mg/kg i.m.) could be used prior to another attempt. This is a 24-week prospective study that aims to examine the predictors of initial six-month subscription and subscription renewal rates at six months for the WayBetter app. The study will incorporate user base data of WayBetter Inc.'s app, WayBetter, to examine user mHealth app engagement. The primary objective of this study is to examine predictors (i.e., socio-demographics, past health behaviours, psychological determinants, app engagement metrics) of (a) initial six-month subscription and b) subscription renewal rates at six months for the WayBetter app. The secondary objective is to characterize WayBetter app engagement over the first 24 weeks of app use. The study sample will consist of approximately 400 adult users (aged ≥18 years old), who are new app users (who have engaged in a 7-day free trial). As users may have varying registration dates, the data collected will only include the first 24 weeks of an individual's interaction with the platform. WayBetter is a wellness lifestyle mHealth app available to anyone who wants to improve their overall well-being. All users are asked to accept the company's privacy policy and are prompted to fill out personal data including (but not limited to) [email address, weight] when creating an account. All users are given a one-week free trial as well as $10 USD to use as a deposit towards any WayBetter app game, courtesy of WayBetter Inc. Users can complete any of the games they signed up for during their free trial, even if they decide not to continue to their membership. To continue to participate in games, users must subscribe to a six-month membership ($69 USD total). In general, users can join up to ten games at a time. The app has a game directory (explore tab) that includes 60+ games each week in three categories: fitness, nutrition, and mindset. New games start on Mondays, Wednesdays, and Fridays. Each game lasts between 1-4 weeks and requires players to achieve a specific behavioral goal (e.g., 5K Steps Per Day requires that they walk at least 5,000 steps per day on at least 4 days per week for 2 weeks). The study is a randomized clinical trial that compares the effects of aerobic exercises and Pilates exercises on depression and sleep quality in primigravida females. The study will be conducted in children hospital sheikhupura and Mehmooda hospital sheikhupura. A total of 42 subjects will be assigned randomly by using lottery method into two groups. Group A will receive Aerobic exercises and Group B will receive Pilate exercises. Warm up (walking) and cool down period of ten minutes will be performed by both groups. Data will be collected from all participants at baseline and after 8 weeks of treatment by using CES-D and PSQI questionnaire. After assessing the data will be analyzed by using parametric or non-parametric test by using SPSS-25. The primary outcome measures are the Center for Epidemiologic Studies Depression Scale (CES-D Scale) and the Pittsburgh Sleep Quality Index (PSQI). The study aims to determine the effectiveness of aerobic exercises and Pilates exercises as a preventive strategy for depression and sleep disturbance in primigravida females.

The study aimed to determine the effect of swaddling and inhaling mother's breast milk odour on the pain and comfort during the placement of peripheral intravenous catheter in term infants. The study was conducted as a randomized controlled experimental study with a sample size of 120 term infants hospitalized in the neonatal intensive care unit of Karadeniz Ereğli State Hospital between 1st October 2020 and 1st October 2021. The infants in the 1st experimental group were swaddled, the infants in the 2nd experimental group were made to inhale the mother's breast milk odour, the infants in the 3rd experimental group were both swaddled and made to inhale the mother's breast milk odour and no procedure was applied to the infants in the control group. The pain and comfort levels of infants in the experimental and control groups were assessed before, during and after the placement of peripheral intravenous catheter using the Infant Descriptive Information Form, Neonatal Infant Pain Scale and Neonatal Comfort Behavior Scale. The study found that swaddling and inhaling mother's breast milk odour had a significant effect on the pain and comfort during the placement of peripheral intravenous catheter in term infants.

This study aims to investigate the biological mechanism of the efficacy of psychotherapy for depression based on the fNIRS. The study utilizes the fNIRS as a biological marker for psychotherapy and proposes the following scientific hypothesis: In patients with depression, levels of oxygenated hemoglobin and deoxygenated hemoglobin in different brain regions may fluctuate at different stages of the disease progression and treatment, along with changes in the activation levels of different brain regions. The study will implement medication therapy, psychotherapy, and a combination of medication therapy with psychotherapy, specifically utilizing IPT, in patients with depression. The investigators will conduct comprehensive fNIRS assessments on all patients to evaluate changes in their brain function and determine the level of effectiveness of psychotherapy. The study will also employ standardized psychological assessments to evaluate patients, allowing for a comparison of the effectiveness of fNIRS assessments and providing clarity on the efficacy of psychotherapy in patients with depression, as the investigatorsll as the differential efficacy of different treatment approaches, and establishing the biological markers of psychotherapy. Additionally, the investigators will collect blood samples, cranial magnetic resonance images, and electroencephalograms from patients before and after treatment, which will contribute to further exploration of treatment mechanisms in the future.

The study aims to investigate the efficacy and mechanism of transcutaneous vagus nerve stimulation in the treatment of generalized anxiety disorder. The study will use a randomized, parallel assignment design with two arms: medication-combined transcutaneous vagus nerve stimulation and medication-combined sham stimulation. The primary outcome measure will be changes in the Hamilton Anxiety Scale at baseline and Week 2 of treatment. Secondary outcome measures will include changes in the Hamilton Anxiety Scale at Week 4 of treatment, changes in the Hamilton Depression Scale at Week 2 and Week 4 of treatment, changes in the Generalized Anxiety Scale at Week 2 and Week 4 of treatment, changes in brain function indicators from baseline to the end of treatment, and incidence of adverse events in each group. The study will recruit participants who meet DSM-5 diagnostic criteria for generalized anxiety disorder, have a first episode of generalized anxiety disorder or have not used an anxiolytic, antidepressant, antipsychotic, or anticonvulsant medication in the last month, have a Hamilton Anxiety Scale (HAMA) score of more than 14 and a Hamilton Depression Scale (HAMD-17) score of less than 17, and have not participated in vagus nerve stimulation therapy or transcranial magnetic stimulation or transcranial direct current therapy. The study will be conducted in two centers in China and will recruit 100 participants in total. The study will be conducted over a period of 8 weeks, with participants receiving treatment for 4 weeks. The study will be conducted in accordance with the Declaration of Helsinki and will obtain ethical approval from the Ethics Committee of the First Affiliated Hospital of Xiangya University.

The study aims to report the results of DLDI for the management of NLDO and to identify factors associated with DLDI failure. The study is a non-randomized, parallel assignment study. The intervention is Dacryoendoscopic-assisted laser dacryoplasty with silicone intubation. The primary outcome measure is the cumulative success rate of DLDI within 2 years follow-up. The study includes participants with confirmed diagnosis of nasolacrimal duct obstruction or stenosis, recurrent or persistent and symptomatic epiphora, and follow-up of longer than 6 months after removal of the silicone stent. The study excludes congenital or traumatic lacrimal duct obstruction, previous acute dacryocystitis, facial nerve palsy, lower eyelid or punctal malposition or laxity of sufficient severity to contribute to epiphora, previous dacryocystorhinostomy, and incomplete medical records. The study is conducted in China and is increasing in its use due to its short surgery time and less risk of bleeding during surgery. The success rates of DLDI vary from a low of 51% to a high of 90%, and the difference in success rates seems to depend on the site of obstruction, differences in the surgical technique, stringency of definitions of success, and duration of follow-up.

The study aims to investigate the immediate effects of proprioceptive neuromuscular facilitation (PNF) with lower leg kinesiotaping on ankle dorsiflexion, gait, and functional mobility in patients with chronic stroke. The study will be conducted as a randomized controlled trial (RCT) with three arms: no taping, ankle taping, and PNF with ankle taping. The primary outcome measures will be time up and go test, Barthel Index, Motor Assessment scale, and Dynamic Gait Index. The study will be conducted in 30 patients with chronic stroke who have insufficient ankle dorsiflexion during the swing phase of the gait cycle and less than 8 degrees of ankle dorsiflexion range of motion on the affected side during gait. The study will be conducted in a single session, and the results will be compared between the three arms. The study will be conducted in a single session, and the results will be compared between the three arms.

The study aims to evaluate the STARgraft-3 device as a new arterio-venous graft for hemodialysis access in patients with end-stage renal disease. Eligible participants will receive the implant of a 6mm diameter STARgraft-3 graft in the upper arm and subsequent use for hemodialysis access. The primary outcome measure is the percentage of subjects without an occurrence of either an access thrombosis or an access procedure performed to maintain patency at 6 months post implantation. Secondary outcome measures include the percentage of subjects without loss of access at the original implant site and the frequency of interventions related to graft placement and use for dialysis access. Ultrasound measurements of flow rates will also be made to detect patency trends with time after implantation. Safety outcomes, including the frequency and severity of Adverse Events resulting from graft implantation and use for hemodialysis access, will also be monitored.

The Primary Care Online Emotion-regulation Treatment (POET) is a randomized clinical trial that aims to determine the clinical efficacy of a digital emotion regulation treatment in adolescents with mental health problems. Participants will be randomized to a digital emotion regulation treatment or to an active comparator. Treatments in both conditions will include therapist support, and will be delivered in a blended treatment format combining asynchronous therapist-guided online modules with one synchronous session delivered over video-link. The primary endpoint is at post-treatment. The primary objectives are to test the effects of POET on mental health problems and emotion regulation. Secondary objectives include testing if emotion regulation mediates reductions in mental health problems during treatment, testing if POET is cost-effective, testing if POET works better for some individuals than others, testing if there are detectable differences in distal outcomes between POET and active control 12 to 60 months post treatment and if individual baseline characteristics moderate these effects. The research questions are what are the effects of POET on mental health problems, what are the effects of POET on emotion regulation, are reductions in mental health problems during the POET treatment mediated through emotion regulation, is POET feeling cost-effective, does POET work better for some individuals than others, are there detectable differences in distal outcomes between POET and active control 12 to 60 months post treatment and if individual baseline characteristics moderate these effects.

The IMPACTE-01 trial is a multicenter, randomized, open-labeled, comparative 3 arms phase III trial. The study aims to evaluate the comparative efficacy of two modalities of Radiotherapy over surgery alone on local tumor control in older patients with Non Melanoma Skin Cancer (NMSC). The study will include R0-high risk of CBC and CEC of the skin in elderly patients. There is no risk regarding the design of the trial as the last will respond to two important unknown questions regarding the utility of RT and its fractionation in this population. Moreover, it is an excellent opportunity to collect prospectively geriatric evaluation and HRQoL data that are lacking in the literature for skin cancers. The primary endpoint is Local tumor control at 3-year follow-up in a time-to-event analysis. The study will compare surgery alone with surgery + moderate hypofractionation (HF) 45Gy in 15 fractions, 3 fractions per week over 5 weeks to the operative bed and surgery + extreme hypo fractionation (HF): 30Gy in 5 fractions of 6Gy, 1 fraction per week, over 5 weeks to the operative bed. The study will also assess the efficacy of treatment modalities on regional recurrence (RR), at 3-year follow-up, progression-free survival (PFS) and overall survival (OS). The study will also assess the levels and changes from baseline in HRQoL as assessed by the cancer-specific European Organization for Research and Treatment of Cancer Quality of Life Questionnaire Core 30 (EORTC QLQ-C30) and QLQ-ELD14 module developed for older patients with cancer, and treatment burden, as assessed by an adapted version of the Treatment Burden Questionnaire (TBQ; EVALUATION AT 3 years).
