The SurvOlderAdults Study is a cohort study that aims to compare the cumulative risk of colorectal cancer (CRC) after age 75 in a cohort of older adults with history of normal colonoscopy (n=101,328) vs. colonoscopy with polypectomy (n=29,548) prior to age 75. The study will also assess the comparative effectiveness of exposure vs. no exposure to surveillance colonoscopy after age 75 for reducing CRC risk using a case-cohort design. The study will obtain multi-level stakeholder perspectives regarding CRC risk and surveillance outcomes to inform future use and VA policy regarding surveillance colonoscopy in older Veterans. The primary outcome will be specific recommendations regarding use of surveillance colonoscopy in older adults, ranked by priority and feasibility, that can guide VA policy around future implementation (or de-implementation) of surveillance among older adults. The study will fill critical evidence gaps and inform guidelines within and outside VA. The study will also serve as a model for leveraging VA data to address an important population health challenge for the VA's large and growing older adult population, and to use these data to engage Veterans, healthcare providers, and policy makers in identifying interventions which can be scaled and sustained to optimize outcomes.

The study aims to assess the effect of early bedside cycling exercises on selected physical and psychological outcomes in patients after heart valve surgery. This study will be carried out on fifty patients diagnosed with valve heart disease and undergoing valve replacement or intervention. They will be recruited from National Heart Institute-Cairo, Egypt. The purpose, nature and the risk of the study will be explained to the patients and each patient will be consented prior to participation in the study. The patients in this study will randomly be assigned and randomly allocated into two equal groups (n=25), the intervention group will be treated daily from being extubated and being relatively stable until discharge from the hospital: Study group (25 patients): will receive bedside cycling in addition to the medical treatment and physiotherapy protocol. Control group (25 patients): will receive only routine physiotherapy treatment protocol and the medical treatment. The bedside cycling will be introduced and conducted in the intervention group in addition to the conventional phase one of cardiac rehabilitation program through preexisting physical therapy staff who present the hospital. Bedside cycling: once the patient is relatively stable by weaning off the ventilator and off the require inotropic support and continued until the discharge from the hospital. Intensity: Rating of Perceived exertion scale (RPE) from 11 to 13 (scale 6-20) post-surgery: resting HR + 20-30 bpm (up to tolerance if non-symptomatic), from low intensity and progressed to medium intensity. Duration: Session duration: Total duration of 20 min, early morning. Intervention duration: 5-15 Resting as the patient wishes and in case signs of exertion. Warming up for 5min: low impact, dynamic movement of large group of muscles through available Active Range of Motion (ROM) or introduce to cycling, HR after warming up 10-11 RPE Cooling down for 5 min or longer: patient observed 30 min after exercise to get to Resting Heart Rate (RHR) Guided by 11-13 RPE, talk test, 20-30 bpm above RHR (Target HR) and sign and symptoms for stopping exercise. According ASCM recommendations for prescription of the exercises in phase one of cardiac rehabilitation

The Sloane Project is a molecular analysis of screen detected non-invasive breast cancer and atypical breast hyperplasias. The study includes DCIS, LCIS, Atypical Ductal Hyperplasia, and Atypical Lobular Hyperplasia. The study is designed to measure the progression of breast disease from diagnosis to the end of 2016. The study is open to female participants only.

===============

Tirzepatide for the Concurrent Treatment of Obesity and Type 1 Diabetes is a randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled study. The study aims to evaluate the efficacy and safety of Tirzepatide in the concurrent treatment of obesity and type 1 diabetes. Participants will be randomly assigned to either the experimental group, which will receive Tirzepatide, or the control group, which will receive insulin treatment. The study will last for 32 weeks, and the primary outcome measure will be the percentage change in body weight. Secondary outcome measures will include changes in HbA1c levels, time in range, total daily insulin dose, insulin carbohydrate ratio, waist and neck circumference, blood pressure, mean glucose, time in hypoglycaemia, time in hyperglycaemia, continuous glucose monitoring metrics, lipid parameters, albumin to creatinine ratio, renal function, NAFLD biomarkers, and FIB-4 index. The study will be conducted in accordance with the Declaration of Helsinki and will obtain ethical approval from the relevant institutional review board.

The study aims to evaluate the efficacy of Losartan in the prevention of Paclitaxel-induced Peripheral Neuropathy in breast cancer patients. The study is a randomized, parallel assignment, single-masked study. The primary outcome measure is the incidence of development of paclitaxel-induced peripheral neuropathy and the grade of neuropathy according to NCI Common Terminology Criteria for Adverse Events. The secondary outcome measures include patient quality of life assessed by Functional Assessment of Cancer Therapy/Gynecologic Oncology Group - Neurotoxicity (FACT/GOG-NTX) and the level of Nerve growth factor (NGF) in Serum. The study is designed to enroll female breast cancer patients who are scheduled to receive paclitaxel 80 mg/m2 and who are not known to have hypersensitivity to Losartan. The study will be conducted over a period of 12 weeks.

This study was designed to investigate the effects of Ginkgo biloba ketone ester tablets on cognitive function in type 2 diabetes patients with mild cognitive impairment. The study was conducted in two groups: experimental and control. The experimental group received Ginkgo biloba ketone ester tablets combined with conventional hypoglycemic treatment, while the control group received conventional hypoglycemic treatment. The study used the Montreal Cognitive Assessment Basic (MoCA-B) to detect cognitive dysfunction and neuropsychological testing to assess cognitive function. The study also collected blood samples to detect C-reactive protein, interleukin-6, oxidative stress, ApoE4 genotype, phosphorylated tau protein, irisin, and β-amyloid protein before and after the experiment. The study also measured changes in ankle brachial pulse wave conduction velocity (baPWV)/and ankle brachial blood pressure index (ABI) of patients before and after the experiment. The primary outcome measure was cognitive function testing using the Alzheimer's Disease Assessment Scale-Cognitive section (0-70), and the secondary outcome measures were memory function assessment, assessment of daily living ability, perform functional evaluation, and attention assessment. The study was conducted for six months, and the results will be analyzed to determine the effectiveness of Ginkgo biloba ketone ester tablets in improving cognitive function in type 2 diabetes patients with mild cognitive impairment.

The study is a randomized, open-label, phase 2 trial to compare the efficacy and safety of CsA+ATG+AVA versus CsA+AVA for the treatment of newly-diagnosed severe aplastic anemia (SAA) in the elderly. The study will enroll 40 patients aged greater than 60 years with newly diagnosed SAA who meet the diagnostic criteria of severe aplastic anemia (SAA). Patients will be randomly assigned to receive either CsA+ATG+AVA or CsA+AVA for 6 months. The primary outcome measure is the overall response rate, which will be assessed at 6 months. Secondary outcome measures include the complete response rate, relapse rate, and adverse event rate, which will be assessed at 6 and 12 months.
89Zr Panitumumab for Assessment of Indeterminate Metastatic Lesions on 18F-FDG-PET/CT in Head and Neck Squamous Cell Carcinoma

=================

A Prospective, Open-label, Multicenter, Randomized Controlled Phase III Study of Prophylactic Central Neck Dissection in Low-risk Papillary Thyroid Cancer is a clinical trial that aims to assess the effect of prophylactic central neck dissection on the excellent response and recurrence-free survival of cN0 low-risk papillary thyroid cancer. The study is designed as a randomized controlled trial with two arms: experimental group (prophylactic central neck dissection) and control group (no central neck dissection). The primary outcome measure is excellent response, which will be assessed at 1 year. Secondary outcome measures include recurrence-free survival, which will be assessed at 1 year and 2 years. The study is open to patients aged 18-70 years old, with a low-risk papillary thyroid cancer diagnosis, cN0 status, and no history of malignancy or other serious medical conditions. The study is not accepting healthy volunteers.

===============

The Net Transition Initiative is a three-arm superiority, single-blinded, cluster-randomized trial that aims to evaluate the efficacy of two next-generation nets for control of malaria in Cote d'Ivoire. The study will be conducted in the department of Tiebissou, Southern Bouake city, central Côte d'Ivoire. The study will compare the incidence of malaria cases between each intervention study arm and the control arm, a cohort of 50 children will be recruited per cluster in 33 clusters for 12 months follow up to be able to detect a 35% relative reduction in malaria cases per child per year (rate ratio 0.65) between the intervention and the reference arms, assuming transmission in the control arm is 1.2 malaria cases per year with a coefficient of variation of 0.29 between clusters. The study will have 80% power to detect a relative 35% lower prevalence (prevalence ratio 0.65 in each intervention arm (VEERALLIN or Interceptor G2) relative to standard LLIN, assuming a prevalence of 50% in the control arm and a coefficient of variation of 0.3. Vector density over 12 months will be followed using Human Landing Collection (HLC) indoor and outdoor with collection in 6 households in every cluster every 2 months. Insecticide resistance intensity will be monitored at baseline and post intervention using adapted CDC bottle assays. The mechanism involved in resistance to pyrethroid and chlorfenapyr will be screened.

===============

The PRECISION Study is a Phase II study of 3 fractions of prostate SBRT with RayPilot system and HypoCath image guidance for men with low or intermediate risk prostate cancer. The study aims to assess the safety of the 3 fraction radiotherapy schedule and to determine the number of patients who will experience acute and late radiation oncology/toxicity grading (RTOG) urinary and bowel toxicity. The study will also assess the quality of life of patients using patient reported outcome measures such as EPIC-26, IPSS, IIEF-5 and Vaizey Score. The study will be conducted in a single arm, non-randomized design with 100 patients recruited in the UK and other global centres. The study will be open in the UK with Edinburgh as the lead Centre. The anonymized data from each Centre will be recorded on a trial specific RedCap database held by the University of Edinburgh for analysis of the trial results. On the day of treatment planning, the patient will be met by the research team and taken to the MRI suite. Patients will have already have been prescribed a rectal suppository by their GP to bring with them. The patient will be directed to the toilet at the MRI scanner and will pass the suppository into their rectum and wait 30 seconds before evacuating it. The aim is to dispel rectal gas not necessarily to move the bowels. Patients will also empty their bladder of urine. The research nurse or radiographer will then place a dummy RayPilot HypoCath (called a ViewCath) or a simple standard Foley urinary catheter if preferred, and fill the bladder with 100-150 mls of water. This volume is recorded and kept as a constant for each day of subsequent treatment. An MRI of the prostate is then performed with standard T1 and T2 anatomical images and functional Dynamic Contrast Enhanced (DCE) and diffusion weighted (DW) sequences that identify the tumour. The MRI scan will last approximately 20minutes. On completion the patient is then taken for the planning CT scan within the Radiotherapy Department. The bladder is drained and then refilled through the catheter to the same volume as the

=============

The study aims to investigate the effectiveness of low-level laser therapy (LLLT) in reducing root resorption of the upper incisors during intrusion movement using mini-implants in adult patients with deep overbite. The study is a randomized controlled clinical trial with two arms: a control group and an experimental group. The control group receives traditional orthodontic treatment, while the experimental group receives LLLT. The primary outcome measures are change in root volume and change in root length, which will be measured using cone-beam computed tomography (CBCT) images before and after the end of intrusion. The study is expected to take place over a period of 4 to 5 months.

=================

The Italian Study on the Right Hemicolectomy: How the Lymphadenctomy is Performed is a multicenter study that aims to investigate the analysis of lymphadenctomy in the course of right hemicolectomy, in relation to the radicality of surgical resection that is performed. The study will enroll 788 patients and will be conducted over a 6-month observational period. The primary outcome measure will be the analysis of lymphadenectomy in the course of right hemicolectomy, in relation to the radicality of surgical resection that is performed. Secondary outcome measures will include the study of vascular anatomical variability. The study will be conducted at high-volume specialist centers that perform this type of intervention in Italy, with a minimum number of 25 interventions per year. The data of the patients involved will be collected independently and anonymously by the individual centers involved, using a common alpha numeric code decided by the coordinating center. The parameters examined will be: Personal data of the patient Stage of neoplasm due to surgery Type of surgery and duration Post-operative course Presence of post-surgical complications and eventual hospital readmission due to these complications Study of the operating piece and lymphadenectomy performed: Tumor free margin Terminal ilium length The different vascular ligatures and levels at which they are performed Integrity of the mesocolon Number of positive nodes per total removed Following the end of the 6 months of observational study period, the data will be processed anonymously at the coordinating centre.

* The study aims to investigate the effects of Cawthorne Cooksey Exercises on balance and quality of life in children with hearing deficits.
* The study will use a randomized controlled design with two arms: Cawthorne Cooksey Exercises and Swiss Ball Exercises.
* The primary outcome measure will be the Pediatric Berg Balance Scale, which will be assessed at 12 weeks.
* Secondary outcome measures will include the Four-step square test.
* Eligibility criteria include children aged 7-12 years with sensorineural hearing deficits, normal vision, and no orthopedic or neurological impairments.
* Participants will be excluded if they are taking medications that affect central nervous system, absent from more than two sessions, non-cooperative, or have orthopedic accidents.

The study aims to explore the experiences of women with GTN following completion of chemotherapy. The study will use a semi-structured telephone interview to gather data from a sample of 20 women who completed single agent or multi agent chemotherapy between 6 weeks and 24 months post treatment. The study will use thematic analysis to generate in depth descriptions of the patients experiences. The findings will enable health care professionals working closely with this unique group of patients to gain some understanding of the patient perspective and improve the patient experience.

=========

The study aims to evaluate the utility of bone grafts in open wedge corrective osteotomy and plate fixation in patients with malunited distal radius fractures. The study is a randomized, parallel assignment study with two arms: one group with bone grafting and one group without bone grafting. The primary outcome measures are complications, quality of life using the EQ-5D-5L questionnaire, and time to complete bone healing. Secondary outcome measures include subjective and objective functional outcomes and cost effectiveness. The study will follow up with participants for at least one year.

This study aims to examine the effectiveness of a brief behavioral teacher training program for teachers of children with behavioral difficulties at school. The program combines individually-tailored stimulus control and contingency management techniques to treat children's behavioral difficulties in two (bi)weekly training sessions of two hours and a third session of one hour in which the training will be evaluated and maintenance training will be provided. The study will use a randomized controlled trial design with two arms: (a) brief teacher training with practice as usual (PAU) or (b) PAU only. The primary outcome measure will be the severity of teacher-rated daily measured target behaviors in specific classroom situations. Secondary outcome measures will include severity of daily the same four daily rated target behaviors in other classroom situations than the specified situation which is used as primary outcome, teacher-reported severity of behavioral difficulties of the child in the classroom, teacher-reported number of child behavioral difficulties in the classroom that the teacher considers troublesome, teacher-reported child impairment at school associated with behavioral difficulties, teacher's sense of self-efficacy, teacher-reported frequency of supportive and non-supportive management strategies, caregiver-reported severity of child behavioral difficulties at home, and quality of the teacher-student relationship. The study will be conducted in the Netherlands.

=============

The study is a feasibility, acceptability, and usability pilot study of a tele-rehabilitation combining immersive virtual reality exercises and therapeutic education for chronic non-specific neck pain. The study will recruit 20 participants who meet the inclusion criteria and will be randomly assigned to the experimental group. The intervention will last for 6 weeks and will consist of 5 virtual reality sessions and 1 teleconsultation session per week. The primary outcome measures will include feasibility (retention rate, adhesion, safety, implementation at home, and online consultations), acceptability (satisfaction), and usability (virtual reality system and online consultations). Secondary outcome measures will include changes in range of motion, neck disability, pain intensity, kinesiophobia, illness perception, and global perceived effect. The study will also investigate the experiences of the intervention during semi-structured interviews.

This is a non-inferiority randomized controlled trial (RCT) that aims to assess if HABIT-ILE at home is not inferior to HABIT-ILE in camp regarding physical abilities, functional activities and participation of the participants. The study also aims to assess if the maintenance of skills during HABIT-ILE camp at 3- and 6-months post-therapy has been proven, and if the transfer of learned skills could be improved with a follow-up at home post therapy. The study will be conducted in 2 arms: HABIT-ILE therapy classic or at home and HABIT-ILE therapy at home with a HABIT-ILE follow-up at home. Participants will be randomly assigned to one of the two arms. The study will be conducted in a single center. The study will be conducted in a single center. The study is a randomized controlled trial that compares digital and speculum exams in women with preterm prelabor rupture of membranes (PPROM). The primary outcome measure is pregnancy latency, and secondary outcome measures include maternal chorioamnionitis, endomyometritis, maternal sepsis, maternal wound infections, maternal intensive care unit (ICU) admission, maternal death, composite neonatal morbidity, length of neonatal intensive care unit (NICU) admission, need for respiratory support, neonatal sepsis at <72 hours of life, neonatal sepsis at >72 hours of life, neonatal intraventricular hemorrhage (IVH), necrotizing enterocolitis (NEC), hypoxic ischemic encephalopathy, neonatal pneumonia, and patient satisfaction with exams. The study is designed as a parallel assignment with single masking and randomized allocation. The study is measuring pregnancy latency, maternal chorioamnionitis, endomyometritis, maternal sepsis, maternal wound infections, maternal ICU admission, maternal death, composite neonatal morbidity, length of NICU admission, need for respiratory support, neonatal sepsis at <72 hours of life, neonatal sepsis at >72 hours of life, neonatal IVH, NEC, hypoxic ischemic encephalopathy, neonatal pneumonia, and patient satisfaction with exams.

===============

The study is a single-center, prospective, single-arm study of sequential adult left lateral lobe liver transplantation (SALT) in the treatment of patients with liver cirrhosis with hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC). The study aims to evaluate the overall survival and disease-free survival of patients with liver cirrhosis with HCC treated with SALT. The study is designed as a two-stage liver resection, with the first stage being a hemihepatectomy combined with left lateral lobe liver transplantation, and the second stage being a residual liver resection performed after the graft grows to a sufficient functional liver volume. The study is open label and does not involve any masking. The primary outcome measure is overall survival, and the secondary outcome measure is disease-free survival. The study is designed to evaluate the feasibility of SALT in the treatment of patients with liver cirrhosis with HCC and to determine the optimal timing for the second stage of liver resection.

The study aims to establish the validity and reliability of a Dexterity Assessment Tool in patients with degenerative cervical myelopathy and healthy volunteers. The study will measure dexterity using the Dexterity Assessment Tool and correlate the results with other validated tools. The study will also assess inter-rater and test-retest reliability. The study will be conducted in two arms: one arm will include patients with cervical myelopathy, and the other arm will include healthy volunteers. The study will measure dexterity at one time point for patients with cervical myelopathy and at two time points for healthy volunteers. The study will be conducted in English-speaking participants between the ages of 35 and 75 years. The study will be conducted in a single center. The study will be conducted in a single center. This is a non-interventional, single center, multi-surgeon, observational study to evaluate the effect of intraocular lens (IOL) centration and tilt on visual performance in patients who have undergone Clareon® Vivity® IOL implantation. The study population will include individuals implanted with Clareon® Vivity® and Vivity® Toric IOLs. IOL implantations reviewed will range from the earliest performed (May 2022) onward, until 100 implanted patients (200 eyes) are reached. Potential subjects will be consented, then retrospective chart review of pre-operative and operative implantation data will occur and postoperative data will be collected (1 or more months post-operation) via examination. The primary outcome measure is monocular best-corrected distance visual acuity (BCDVA) (4 m) (logMAR) and secondary outcome measures include decentration of intraocular lens (IOL) (mm), tilt of intraocular lens (IOL) (°), monocular uncorrected distance visual acuity (UCDVA) (4 m) (logMAR), monocular distance-corrected intermediate visual acuity (DCIVA) (66 cm) (logMAR), monocular uncorrected intermediate visual acuity (UCIVA) (66 cm) (logMAR), manifest refraction/Manifest refraction spherical equivalent (MRSE) (D). The study will be conducted at a single center and will include a multi-surgeon team. The study will be conducted in accordance with the Declaration of Helsinki and will be approved by the Institutional Review Board.

The study aims to investigate the efficacy of US-guided SPSIPB for postoperative analgesia management after mastectomy and axillary lymph node dissection surgery. The primary aim is to compare postoperative pain scores (NRS), and the secondary aim is to evaluate the need for rescue analgesics, block-related complications, dermatome level, and side effects (allergic reaction, nausea, vomiting) associated with opioid use. The study is a randomized, prospective, controlled study. The intervention is SPSIPB, and the control group receives wound infiltration with bupivacaine. The primary outcome measure is pain scores (NRS), and the secondary outcome measures are the need for rescue analgesia, adverse events, and dermatomal analyses. The study will be conducted in female patients undergoing mastectomy and axillary dissection surgery under general anesthesia. The study will be conducted in a single center. The study is an exploratory study that aims to conduct another imaging using contrast-enhanced spectral mammography (CESM) 4-6 hours after the routine iopromide 370 mgI/ml-enhanced ductography, to explore the optimization of the ductography technique and assess the clinical value of this delayed imaging protocol. The study plans to include 100 female patients aged 18-65 years old, who have completed routine iopromide 370 mgI/ml enhanced ductography for initial clinical diagnosis of suspected pathological nipple discharge, under the recommendation of the clinician. The primary outcome measure is the percentage of changes from baseline in imaging diagnosis caused by the results of delayed ductal imaging. Secondary outcome measures include diagnostic accuracy of delayed ductal imaging results for the nature of the lesion, percentage of changes from baseline in imaging diagnosis caused by the results of delayed ductal imaging in patients with dense breasts, percentage of changes from baseline in imaging diagnosis caused by the results of delayed ductal imaging in patients with non-palpable breast mass/no abnormal findings on palpation, and Kappa values for the evaluation of diagnostic imaging results of delayed ductal imaging by different radiologists. The study will be conducted in a single center and will be open label. The study will be conducted in accordance with the Declaration of Helsinki and will be approved by the Ethics Committee of the Center Hospitalier Valida.

=========

A prospective clinical study was conducted to investigate the association between postoperative dyslipidemia and organ rejection in heart transplant patients. The study included patients aged 18 years and above who had undergone heart transplantation and had symptomatic heart failure for at least 6 months prior to screening. The study measured blood lipid levels, left ventricular ejection fraction, and graft/patient survival over a period of 4 years. The study found that postoperative dyslipidemia was associated with an increased risk of graft rejection and reduced graft/patient survival in heart transplant patients.

===============

This is a prospective cohort study of women > 18 years of age with symptoms of stress urinary incontinence, recruited via an online recruitment tool. Participants will be randomized to one of three arms: Pelex Upp (study device) only Pelvic floor physical therapy + Pelex Upp (device under study) Pelvic floor physical therapy only. The study will measure change in stress urinary incontinence symptoms as measured by the ICIQ. The study will be conducted over 4 weeks, with participants completing a pre-treatment urinary incontinence symptom questionnaire (ICIQ) and a post-treatment urinary incontinence symptom questionnaire (ICIQ) at the end of the study. The study will be conducted in an open-label design.

===============

The study aims to improve attendance in Community Wise, a multi-level manualized behavioral intervention to decrease alcohol and substance misuse frequency in a population of self-identified men with histories of substance use disorder (SUD) and incarceration in Essex County, NJ, U.S. The study will conduct a 23 full factorial experiment to identify efficient strategies for improving attendance and, hence, maximize the interventions' effect in reducing ASM. The study will examine the individual and interactive contributions of each intervention delivery strategy on intervention attendance. The intervention delivery strategies include recruiting individuals under supervision, incentivizing intervention attendance, and delivering the intervention in an open group format. The study will also compare intervention satisfaction measures between intervention strategies. The study will expand eligibility criteria to include women and people with SUD living in marginalized communities who have not been previously incarcerated. The study will impact public health as it will improve the potency of an optimized multi-level intervention adaptable to address different health inequities.

===============

This is a randomized clinical trial comparing the efficacy of interpectoral area block + serratus anterior area block (IPSA) and erector spinae block (ES) in minimally invasive cardiac surgery. The study aims to investigate the effectiveness of these two methods in managing postoperative pain and recovery. The primary outcome measure is pain scores (NRS) up to 48 hours, while secondary outcome measures include opioid consumption, recovery criteria, intraoperative changes in NIRS values, and CPOT score until extubation. The study is designed as a parallel assignment with double masking. Eligible participants are ASA I-II patients between the ages of 18-75 with an average bleeding profile who have given written consent to participate in the study and have no local anesthetic allergy or history. The interpectoral and serratus anterior area blocks will be applied immediately after general anesthesia is given to the participants under ultrasound guidance. The study will be conducted at Namık Kemal University anesthesia clinic.
The study aims to evaluate the efficacy of Botox and internal sphincterotomy in pain relief after hemorrh

===============

The study is a phase II single-arm prospective study aimed at exploring the clinical efficacy and safety of fruquintinib as maintenance therapy for advanced colorectal cancer patients who achieve NED after adjuvant chemotherapy. The study will enroll patients who have previously received first-line chemotherapy and have achieved disease control (PR+SD) according to RECIST 1.1, have undergone curative local treatment (surgery, ablation, SBRT) and achieved no evidence of disease (NED), and have completed adjuvant chemotherapy and evaluated as no disease progression. The study will use Fruquintinib as the intervention and will measure the 2-year recurrence and metastasis rate as the primary outcome measure. The study will be conducted for 2 years after NED.

=================

The study aims to assess the efficacy of Methylphenidate (MPH) compared to placebo (PBO) for reducing PTSD and depression symptoms in Veterans with PTSD and neurocognitive complaints. The study will use an aggregated N-of-1 randomized placebo-controlled trial design. N=70 Veterans across two sites will each receive sequential 4-week periods of MPH and PBO, in randomized order and separated by a 1-week washout, for a total of 20 weeks. During this time, they will complete weekly or biweekly assessments. The study will assess the impact of MPH compared to PBO on neurocognitive functioning in this same population, and characterize the baseline predictors of treatment response to MPH in this population, including whether Veterans with a history of mTBI show greater average treatment response to MPH versus PBO. The study will also allow a systematic assessment of risks in this population, including the risk of discontinuation effects or loss of efficacy over time. If the results of this study support the use of MPH to decrease PTSD and neurocognitive symptoms in Veterans, it would provide an important new treatment option for Veterans with PTSD, which could be rapidly integrated into clinical practice.

=========

The study aims to prospectively validate the capacity of CFRflow as a predictor of the presence of angina measured by SAQ7 in patients with INOCA at 3 months. Secondary objectives include identifying hemodynamic factors related to the persistence of angina at 3 and 12 months, identifying clinical factors related to the persistence of angina, establishing the prevalence of patients with coronary microvascular dysfunction within the cohort of INOCA patients, identifying predictors of major cardiovascular events at 12 months, validating the pathological value of MMR and establishing the pathological value of AF measured in ml/min. The study also aims to evaluate the concordance between measures of the coronary microvascular function obtained by continuous thermodilution and bolus thermodilution, as well as their concordance with clinical characteristics. The study is designed as a diagnostic study of microvascular coronary dysfunction using continuous thermodilution flow reserve. The primary outcome measure is the angina status assessed by the Seattle Angina Questionnaire (SAQ) at inclusion. The secondary outcome measures include the accuracy of continuous thermodilution measured CFR flow and minimal microvascular resistance (MMR flow) at inclusion, and the quality of life status in patients at 3 months post-diagnosis measured by the Seattle Angina Questionnaire (SAQ). The study is designed to include patients over 18 years of age with a clinical indication for coronary angiography and in whom the use of microvascular function diagnosis by pressure guide is considered clinically necessary. The study aims to evaluate the concordance between measures of the coronary microvascular function obtained by continuous thermodilution and bolus thermodilution, as well as their concordance with clinical characteristics. The study is designed to include patients over 18 years of age with a clinical indication for coronary angiography and in whom the use of microvascular function diagnosis by pressure guide is considered clinically necessary. The study aims to evaluate the concordance between measures of the coronary microvascular function obtained by continuous thermodilution and bolus thermodilution, as well as their concordance with clinical characteristics.

The study is a phase 2a study of adding ruxolitinib with tacrolimus/methotrexate regimen for GVHD prophylaxis in myeloablative conditioning HCT in pediatric and young adult patients. The study aims to determine the safety and efficacy of the regimen in preventing GVHD and reducing the risk of relapse/progression in pediatric and young adult patients undergoing allogeneic HCT for acute myeloid leukemia, acute lymphoblastic leukemia, or myelodysplastic syndrome. The study will be conducted in two phases. In the phase 1 segment, the safety of the regimen will be evaluated in pediatric and young adult patients with hematologic malignancies who are eligible to undergo allogeneic HCT from a matched donor. In the phase 2 segment, the efficacy of the regimen will be evaluated in pediatric and young adult patients who have undergone a patient safety lead-in. The primary objective of the study is to determine the incidence of adverse events during the phase II segment. The secondary objectives of the study include the incidence of acute GVHD, non-relapse mortality, chronic GVHD, overall survival, progression-free survival, relapse/progression, infection rate, and incidence of secondary malignancies. The study will be conducted in accordance with the Declaration of Helsinki and Good Clinical Practice guidelines.

* Irritable bowel syndrome (IBS) is a chronic gastrointestinal disorder characterized by recurrent abdominal pain, abdominal discomfort, changes in bowel habits, and abdominal bloating.
* The study aims to investigate the effectiveness of a temple stay experience in improving the symptoms of IBS.
* The study will include 20-69 year old patients with diarrhea-predominant IBS who have voluntarily agreed to participate in a temple stay for up to 8 days.
* The primary outcome measure will be the symptom score for IBS using the IBS-SSS scale.
* The secondary outcome measure will be the fecal microbiome composition, diversity, and difference in the proportion of the species of primary interest.
* The study will measure the IBS-SSS score before, during, and 4 weeks after the temple stay experience.
* The study will investigate the effects of a temple stay experience on the microbiome and psychosocial factors in patients with IBS.
* The study will validate the hypothesis that the dietary changes in a temple stay environment will alter the microbiome and reduce the symptoms of IBS, thereby improving the quality of life.

===============

The study aims to assess asthma patients' willingness to change inhalers for environmental reasons as well as prescribers' willingness to prescribe a different inhaler for environmental reasons at the patient's request. The study will also be assessing patient awareness of the climate impact of inhalers and the importance that they attribute to this issue as well as other issues (cost and ease of use). The study will be conducted as a single group assignment with an open label design. The intervention will be a low risk educational intervention. The primary outcome measure will be the proportion of participants who changed their inhaler from Ventolin MDI to Bricanyl Turbuhaler within 30 days of study visit. The secondary outcome measures will include the rate of failure of the intervention, the proportion of patients who filled Bricanyl Rx change, awareness of patients regarding the climate impact of inhalers, patients' willingness to change inhalers for environmental reasons, and providers' willingness to change inhalers for environmental reasons.

The study is a single-center, randomized, single-blinded clinical trial evaluating the efficacy and safety of hybrid argon plasma coagulation plus endoscopic sleeve gastroplasty (HAPC-ESG) for weight loss and improvement in obesity-related co-morbidities compared to ESG alone. The study population includes adult patients who are seeking ESG at True You Weight Loss in Cary, NC with a BMI ≥ 30 and ≤40 kg/m² who have failed to achieve and maintain weight loss with a non-surgical management. The primary outcome is durability assessed by blinded physician(s) with expertise in endoscopic sleeve gastroplasty (ESG) procedures graded according to a priori standardized criteria. The secondary outcomes include %TBWL, %EWL, blood pressure, HbA1c percentage, change in quality of life measured by Questionnaire: Short Form Health Survey (SF-36), change in quality of life measured by Questionnaire: Impact of Weight on Quality of Life-Lite (IWQOL-Lite), change in depression measured by Questionnaire: Patient Health Questionnaire (PHQ-9), change in eating behavior measured by Questionnaire: The Three-Factor Eating Questionnaire (TFEQ-r18), and binary outcomes: ≥25% change in %EWL. The study is a single-center, randomized, single-blinded clinical trial evaluating the efficacy and safety of hybrid argon plasma coagulation plus endoscopic sleeve gastroplasty (HAPC-ESG) for weight loss and improvement in obesity-related co-morbidities compared to ESG alone. The study is a single-center, randomized, single-blinded clinical trial evaluating the efficacy and safety of hybrid argon plasma coagulation plus endoscopic sleeve gastroplasty (HAPC-ESG) for weight loss and improvement in obesity-related co-morbidities compared to ESG alone. The study aims to determine the barriers for women with physical disabilities between the ages of 18-65 to adopt behaviors to diagnose common cancers in women at an early stage, and to increase participation in early diagnosis behaviors in cancers that are common in women (Breast Self Examination (BSE), Clinical Breast Examination (CBE), Self-Examination). Vulva Self Examination (KKVM), Mammography and PapSmear Test) was planned to determine the effectiveness of awareness training based on SIM. The study will be conducted using a randomized controlled experimental design with two arms: Intervention 1 and Intervention 2. Intervention 1 will provide cancer awareness training based on the Health Belief Model, while Intervention 2 will provide standard cancer education. The primary outcome measure will be the Gynecological Cancers Awareness Scale, and the secondary outcome measure will be the Champion's Health Belief Model Scale for Breast Cancer and Screening. The study will be conducted over a period of 12 weeks.

The study aims to assess the feasibility of a coach-led digital platform using an intelligent coaching assistant for an urban community over a 6-month period. The study is conducted with partners from SláinteCare Healthy Communities Kildare, Healthy Ireland, and Empeal (technology provider), with an emphasis on vulnerable populations within the community (perinatal women, lone parents, elderly citizens living alone, citizens with chronic disease, recent migrants and the Irish Traveller community). The primary outcomes are assessing the feasibility of the coach-led digital health platform, implementing an intelligent coaching assistant, and assessing participants' experience of the coach-led digital platform through qualitative interviews and focus groups. Secondary outcomes include identifying the needs of vulnerable groups and examining changes in mental health and lifestyle medicine vital signs. The study will be conducted in Athy, Co. Kildare, with participants recruited and onboarded in month 1. The study will be completed in month 12, with a feasibility study report and dissemination of summary data reports to all stakeholders.

The study will be conducted in accordance with the Declaration of Helsinki and will be approved by the RCSI Ethics Committee. Participants will provide informed consent prior to participation in the study. Data will be collected using surveys and qualitative interviews, and will be stored securely in accordance with GDPR guidelines. The study will be conducted in collaboration with Empeal, the technology provider, and will be conducted in accordance with CONSORT guidelines for conducting feasibility/pilot projects.

The study is a randomized controlled clinical trial that aims to investigate the effect of Progressive Muscle Relaxation and Deep Breathing Exercises training on dyspnea, fatigue, and quality of sleep in patients with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). The study will be conducted on 100 patients who will be randomly assigned to one of three groups: Progressive Muscle Relaxation (PMR) Group, Deep Breathing Exercise (DBE) Group, and Control Group. The PMR exercise, which includes the systematic relaxation of the main muscle groups of the body aimed at physical and psychological relaxation, will be applied twice a day, every weekday, for eight weeks. The DBE training will be given to the patients in this group individually by face-to-face interview. The study will measure the Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease and Asthma Fatigue Scale, Dyspnea-12 Scale, and Pittsburgh Sleep Quality Index. The study will be conducted for two weeks.

=========

The study aims to evaluate the functional diagnostic accuracy of ultrasonic flow ratio (UFR) in assessing de novo coronary artery lesions. The study will use fractional flow reserve (FFR) and intravascular ultrasound (IVUS) as reference standards. The study will include patients with stable angina pectoris, unstable angina pectoris, or after the acute phase of myocardial infarction, aged ≥18 years, with intermediated coronary lesions (diameter stenosis of 30%-80% by visual estimation from coronary angiography). The study will measure the sensitivity and specificity of UFR in predicting functionally significant coronary stenosis at the patient and vessel level, using FFR as the reference standard. The study will also measure the diagnostic accuracy of UFR in predicting functionally significant coronary stenosis at the patient level, using FFR as the reference standard. The study will calculate the AUC of UFR for coronary stenosis with FFR as the gold standard.

The study aims to investigate the effect of Balint group on burnout and self-efficacy of nurse leaders in China. The study is a randomised controlled trial with a sample size of 100 nurse leaders. Participants in the experimental group completed Balint training for a period of three months, while participants in the non-intervention group did not receive any intervention. The primary outcome measures are Maslach Burnout Inventory-Human Services Survey (MBI-HSS) subscale emotional exhaustion (MBI-EE) and General Self-Efficacy Scale (GSES). The study is designed as a single group assignment with a single masking. The study is conducted in China.

This is a randomized controlled trial testing non-pharmacological TCM-based treatments for cognitive impairment in people with long COVID symptoms. The study includes three arms: acupuncture, TCM-based lifestyle management, and a combination of both. The primary outcome measure is global cognitive function, and secondary outcome measures include cardiopulmonary function, fatigue, health-related quality-of-life, psychological distress, neurocognitive functions, and neurobiological outcomes. The study will recruit participants with a diagnosis of SARS-CoV-2 infection at least 3 months prior to recruitment, who have at least mild cognitive impairment or self-reported at least one cognitive symptom persisting for 12 weeks or longer after clinical recovery of SARS-CoV-2 infection. The study will exclude participants with severe cognitive impairment, mood disorder, anxiety disorder, current psychiatric disorders that require taking medication, current medical conditions that could interfere with cognitive functions, epilepsy or any other unstable medical conditions, alcoholism or drug abuse within the past 1 year, bleeding tendency, severe needle phobia, heart pacemaker or other electronic devices implanted in the body, and currently participating in another research studies or clinical trials. The study will recruit participants aged 18 years or older and will last for 8 weeks.

=========

The myCare-102 trial is a survey of physician and molecular tumor board perspectives on the clinical utility and usability of Cellworks Singula™ and Cellworks Ventura™ reports in facilitating patient treatment decisions for pan-cancer patients. The study includes patients with a diagnosis of cancer who have already received first-line therapy and have relapsed or refractory cancer and have exhausted standard of care therapy options. The primary outcome measure is the majority of physicians and molecular tumor boards (MTB) have a positive view of the Cellworks Singula™ and Cellworks Ventura™ reports. The secondary outcome measures include patient demographics, institution demographics, patient disease status, and ECOG score. The study is expected to be completed in approximately 24 months.

===============

The study aims to investigate the effect of Cognitive Stimulation Therapy (CST) on the levels of apathy, loneliness, anxiety and daily living activities in elderly individuals diagnosed with Alzheimer's. The study will be conducted in a single center and experimental research design with pretest posttest control group. The research will be planned to be carried out between January 2023 and June 2023 at the Moral House affiliated to Gaziantep Metropolitan Municipality Disabled and Health Services Department. The study will use the Standardized Mini-Mental Test, Geriatric Anxiety Scale, Apathy Rating Scale, Loneliness Scale and Functional Disability in Dementia Scale to measure the primary outcomes. CST will be applied by a trained researcher in therapy, 2 days a week, in a total of 14 sessions of 45-50 minutes. The study will evaluate the research data in SPSS 25.0 New York package program.

The study is a prospective, parallel, two-arm (1:1), randomised controlled experimental study. The aim of the study is to examine the effect of counselling and follow-up after education on the risks and prevention methods of breast cancer on early diagnosis behaviours and healthy lifestyle behaviours. The population of the study will consist of female administrative staff working at Mersin University. The sample of the study will consist of 160 people with an effect size of 0.23, 80% power maximum 5% type 1 error and drop out rate of 10%. The sample determined by randomisation A total of 160 personnel in the group will be divided into group A (study) and group B (control) formed by the independent researcher in the computer environment. All participants will be given one-hour training on breast cancer, modifiable and non-modifiable risk factors for breast cancer, symptoms of breast cancer, screening programmes and breast self-examination. Group A will be counselled for 6 months after the training and a reminder message will be sent via SMS on Monday every week as Check your modifiable risk factors for breast cancer and their feedback will be received. In group B, no additional application will be made except for the training. The data of the study will be collected before and 6 months after the training by using the Descriptive Characteristics Form, Breast Cancer Early Diagnosis Behaviours Form, Counselling Form and Healthy Lifestyle Behaviours Scale II. The data obtained from the study will be analysed in a computer environment. Number, percentage, mean and standard deviation will be used as descriptive statistics in the evaluation of the data.

The study aimed to determine the effect of simulation-based postpartum hemorrhage management on the application skills, satisfaction, self-confidence and self-efficacy-competences of Health Sciences University Hamidiye Health Sciences Faculty Midwifery Department 3rd year students. The research population consisted of 3rd grade students who took the Risky Birth and Postpartum Period course, studying at the Department of Midwifery, Hamidiye Faculty of Health Sciences, in the spring semester of the 2021-2022 academic year (N:82). Students who volunteered to participate in the study were included in the study. In the study, the entire target population was reached, except for the 4 students who were absent from the Risky Birth and Postpartum Period course (N:78). Computer-assisted randomization will be used in the study, and random assignment was made to the intervention (n:39) and control (n:39) groups by entering the number of cases through the program whose URL address is https://www.randomizer.org. An introductory information form was applied to all groups, and informed consent was obtained from the students before the applications. The students were given information about the introduction of the simulator and the model, the flow chart of the training plan, the content of the training plan, the environment, the locations of the materials. Before the application, all groups were given theoretical information about postpartum hemorrhage management for 2 hours with a power point presentation. Student Satisfaction and Self-Confidence Scale in Learning and Self-Efficacy Scale were applied as a pre-test after the information. Intervention group students were given practical training on postpartum hemorrhage assessment and management in the basic skills laboratory, accompanied by an adult standard patient care model, with a high-reality Gaumard Scientific brand, product code: S550.100 Noella simulator in the simulation laboratory of the Midwifery department. After the application, Student Satisfaction and Self-Confidence in Learning Scale, Self-Efficacy Scale and Early Postpartum Hemorrhage Management Skill Assessment Form were applied to all students as a post-test, and Scale for Evaluation of Simulation-Based Learning to the intervention group. The Clinical Study on the Mangrove Sword Bean Food Bar Effect for Older People is a non-randomized study with a parallel assignment intervention model. The study aims to prevent nutrition disorders in older people affected by the landslide disaster in Cihanjuang Village, Sumedang District, West Java Province, Indonesia. The treatment group consumed 50 g mangrove sword bean food bar each day during 15 days, while the control group consumed 50 g sword bean food bar each day during 15 days. Both groups received balanced nutrition education once at the first week of study. The primary outcome measure is the weight of older people, which will be measured by digital weighing SECA by trained enumerators at the first week and the second week of study. The secondary outcome measure is the balanced nutrition knowledge of older people, which will be measured by the baseline and end-line questionnaires by trained enumerators. The study is designed to measure the effect of mangrove sword bean food bar on the weight of older people and the balanced nutrition knowledge of older people.

=========

The pAIn-sense study aims to develop a novel telemonitoring system for pain patients that combines real patient data from a physical and emotional perspective to characterize the pain nature of patients and provide a tailored continuum-of-care. The system includes robotic wearable sensors for physiological monitoring, a digital platform for psychological assessments, and an AI-based engine to model the pain level of the subject. The study will monitor patients during normal activities while collecting physiological, psychosocial, and pain information. The primary outcome measures include pain level, psychological and clinical factors affecting pain, medication intake, rehabilitation, sleep, activity, and quality of life. Secondary outcome measures include predictors of chronification from the acute phase, responsiveness to medication, and correlation between sleep, activity, and other daily factors with pain. The study will use an observational study design with no intervention. The study will recruit patients with ongoing nociceptive pain after an injury or neuropathic pain (acute or chronic) who are familiar with using electronic devices. The study will exclude patients with language problems, psychological disorders, dementia, or who are unable or unwilling to give informed consent. The study will be conducted over a period of up to one month.

=========

A Phase 2a/b Single Arm Open Label Study to Evaluate the Safety and Efficacy of Intracystic Administration of TARA-002 in Participants Between 6 Months to Less Than 18 Years of Age for the Treatment of Macrocystic and Mixed Cystic Lymphatic Malformations. The study is designed to evaluate the safety and efficacy of TARA-002 in participants with macrocystic or mixed cystic lymphatic malformations of the head/neck/mediastinum. The study will enroll participants between 6 months to less than 18 years of age who have macrocystic or mixed cystic lymphatic malformations of the head/neck/mediastinum according to the ISSVA 2018 criteria. Participants will receive up to 4 intracystic injections spaced approximately 6 weeks apart. The primary outcome measure is the proportion of participants with clinical success after one treatment cycle of TARA-002. Secondary outcome measures include safety, durable response, clinical success by lymphatic malformation type, investigator assessment, and quality of life.

===============

This is a multi-center, randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled clinical study to evaluate the efficacy and safety of Chiglitazar added to glargine in patients with type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM) who still have poor hypoglycemic effect. The study included 128 patients who were randomly assigned 1:1 to the combination of metformin and insulin glargine combined with Chiglitazar sodium tablet 48mg/ day group or the metformin and insulin glargine combined with placebo group. The primary outcome measure was changes in HbA1C from baseline at 18 weeks of treatment. The study found that the addition of Chiglitazar to glargine significantly reduced HbA1C levels compared to the placebo group. The study also found that the addition of Chiglitazar to glargine significantly reduced the daily dose of insulin and triglyceride levels compared to the placebo group. The study concluded that the addition of Chiglitazar to glargine is an effective and safe treatment option for patients with T2DM who still have poor hypoglycemic effect.

=================

The Technical Evaluation of Earswitch Phase A is a study that aims to evaluate the robustness of the Earswitch technology in detecting voluntary eardrum movements in people with assistive needs. The study will recruit both healthy volunteers and people with assistive technology needs. The study will take place in a single session and will include four main parts: PART 1 - Co-design Questionnaires, PART 2 - Earswitch insertion, PART 3 - Ear rumbling test, and PART 4 - Usability testing (optional). The primary outcome measure will be the F-score, Matthews correlation coefficient (MCC), the receiver operating characteristics (ROC) curve, and the Area Under the ROC curve (AUC). The secondary outcome measures will include Q2: How accurately can people with assistive technology needs perform voluntary TT movements, and How comfortable and easy is for people to perform voluntary eardrum movements with the Earswitch. The study will take place over a period of 6 months.

The study aims to prospectively validate an EHR-based PDAC risk model in a real-time clinical setting. The study will deploy the PDAC risk model within the TriNetX federated network database and will follow all individuals for up to 3 years to assess the primary end-point of PDAC development. The study will use the following metrics to test the discriminative performance and calibration of the EHR-based PDAC risk model in predicting incident PDAC, at the end of the 3-year period: AUROC, sensitivity, specificity, PPV/NPV for assessing discrimination Calibration: for assessing the accuracy of estimates, based on the estimated to observed number of events.

The study is a randomized, parallel assignment, single masked study. The study aims to compare the efficacy of autologous adipose tissue graft with hyaline cartilage graft mixed with fiberinglu versus microfracture for the treatment of articular cartilage defects in patients with knee osteoarthritis. The study will include 105 patients, aged 18 to 60 years old, with cartilage defect size range 2-5 cm2, outer bridge classification II & III, single full thickness symptomatic femoral condyles ulcer, varus deformity of the affected knee 50 - 100, and exclusion criteria. The study will have three arms: active comparator group, microfracture group, and placebo comparator group. The active comparator group will receive cartilage regeneration technique with autologous adipose tissue graft with hyaline cartilage graft mixed with fiberinglu. The microfracture group will receive cartilage regeneration technique with autologous adipose tissue graft with hyaline cartilage graft mixed with fiberinglu. The placebo comparator group will receive cartilage regeneration technique with high tibial osteotomy. The primary outcome measure will be clinical assessment of International Knee Documentation Committee (IKDC) scores at one year.

=========

The study aims to investigate the relationship between exercise training and recovery strategies to improve physical performance and health status. Participants will be randomized into three groups: a control group, a lower exercise volume group, and an extended recovery group. The study will measure changes in immune system, cardiometabolic, and endocrine markers, as well as aerobic capacity, body composition, and strength. The primary outcome measures will be changes in immune system, cardiometabolic, and endocrine markers, while the secondary outcome measures will be changes in aerobic capacity, body composition, and strength. The study will run for 8 weeks, and data will be collected at baseline, after 4 weeks, and after 8 weeks of intervention.

This study aims to determine whether phosphodiesterase 4B (PDE4B) can be accurately quantified in the human brain and whether it is reduced in the brain of individuals with major depressive disorder (MDD). The study will use PET imaging with the drug 18F-PF-06445974 to measure PDE4B density (distribution volume VT) in the brains of individuals with MDD compared to healthy volunteers. The study will also assess the relationship between clinical rating scales and PDE4B binding. The study will have two arms, one arm will receive the drug 18F-PF-06445974 and PET scanning, while the other arm will receive the same tests. The study will measure the distribution volume of PDE4B in the brain, the optimal length for PDE4B scans, the whole-brain distribution volume of PDE4B in a retest setting, and the relationship between clinical rating scales and PDE4B binding. The study will have a primary endpoint of measurement of PDE4B density (distribution volume VT) in the brains of individuals with MDD compared to healthy volunteers and secondary endpoints of determining the optimal length for PDE4B scans, measuring whole-brain distribution volume of PDE4B in a retest setting, and assessing the relationship between clinical rating scales and PDE4B binding.

3D Joint Space Evaluation in Knee Osteoarthritis: The Importance of Weight-bearing and Flexion

The study aims to evaluate the effectiveness of a novel at-home surface electromyography (sEMG) biofeedback therapy tool called Biofeedback in Strength and Skill Training (BiSSKit) on swallowing safety and efficiency in patients with Parkinson's disease. The study will compare the use of the BiSSKit program with traditional behavioral swallowing therapy. The primary outcome measures will be the Penetration Aspiration Scale Score (PAS) and Total Pharyngeal Residue. Secondary outcome measures will be the Eating Assessment Tool-10 (EAT-10). The study will be conducted over 12 weeks with weekly clinic visits and at-home therapy.

===============

The GLOBE-HPV study aims to estimate the prevalence and incidence of HPV infection in low socio-economic populations and specific sub-populations in 8 countries. The study will use a harmonized protocol with country-specific adaptations. Two separate approaches will be used to estimate prevalence and incidence respectively in each participating country. Cross-sectional surveys (CSS) will be conducted in both urban and rural areas of selected countries to estimate the point prevalence of HPV infection in sub-Saharan Africa and South Asia. Longitudinal studies (LS) will estimate the incidence of persistent HPV infection in sexually active girls and young women in geographically defined communities and special populations. The study will also collect data on demographics, socioeconomic status, sexual and reproductive history, cervical screening, HPV vaccination, and other potential risk factors. Qualitative sub-studies will be conducted in five selected countries to focus on girls and women of different age strata as well as community members and key informants in the health care system in each study site.

===============

The study aims to assess the efficacy of strategic memory training coupled with non-invasive brain stimulation techniques in healthy aging population and subjective cognitive decline patients. The study is a double-blind randomized controlled trial. Participants will be randomly assigned to the experimental group (strategic memory training plus ACTIVE tDCS) or control group (strategic memory training plus SHAM tDCS). The primary outcome measures are associative learning test scores, list learning test scores, name-face learning test scores, place learning test scores, text learning test scores, grocery learning test scores. The secondary outcome measures are mood and cognitive reserve. The study will be conducted over a period of 3 months, with follow-up visits at T1 (immediately after the intervention program), T2 (1 month after the end of the intervention program), and T3 (3 months after the end of the intervention program).

=================

The FIND-HF study is a model development and validation study that aims to predict the risk of new onset heart failure from population-based nationwide electronic health records. The study will use anonymized patient-level primary care data linked to secondary administrative data from the Clinical Practice Research Datalink (CPRD-GOLD and CPRD-AURUM). The study will use multivariable Cox proportional hazard models with backwards elimination approach to retain predictors of incident heart failure within each prediction window. The primary outcome measure is to develop and validate a for predicting the risk of new onset heart failure. The study will identify and quantify the magnitude of predictors of new onset heart failure. The study will be conducted in an observational cohort using anonymized patient-level primary care data linked to secondary administrative data. The study will be conducted in an observational cohort using anonymized patient-level primary care data linked to secondary administrative data.

=========

The ISHYS study is a randomized study that compares two groups of women who underwent hysterectomy for benign gynaecological disease. The first group resumed sexual intercourse 4 weeks after hysterectomy, while the second group resumed 8 weeks after hysterectomy. The primary endpoint is the FSFI® score, which assesses the impact of the recommended time between hysterectomy and resumption of sexual intercourse on sexual function. The study also measures postoperative complications and follow-up to the recommendation. The study is designed to compare the two groups and determine which recommended time is better for resuming sexual activity after hysterectomy.

=========

The study aims to investigate whether human skeletal muscle possesses an epigenetic memory of testosterone. The study is a randomized, placebo-controlled, double-blind, parallel assignment study. The study includes four arms: placebo comparator, testosterone undecanoate, placebo comparator with resistance exercise training, and testosterone undecanoate with resistance exercise training. The study measures changes in fat-free mass, skeletal muscle size and cross-sectional area, skeletal muscle fibre cross-sectional area, DNA methylation in skeletal muscle and blood, gene expression in skeletal muscle and blood, myonuclei, satellite cells, isometric muscle strength, dynamic muscle strength, and muscle force-velocity profiling. The study is designed to investigate the effects of testosterone on skeletal muscle epigenetic memory in healthy aging men.

A Dengue Sero-prevalence Study in the Metropolitan Area of Buenos Aires

A two-stage stratified design will be used. The primary sampling units will be mostly defined as the census sections of the 2010 National Census of Population, Households and Dwellings. It has 5 strata, constructed through a functional relationship between the income quintiles obtained in the Annual Household Survey (AHS) and the variables that were surveyed in the census. Stratum 1 corresponds to the lowest income population, while stratum 5 corresponds to the highest. The first stage of sampling in this framework will consist of about 100 to 300 primary sampling units, called primary units areas, selected with a probability proportional to size, the measure of size being the total number of dwellings. A sample of 1,487 dwellings is proposed. In each primary unit area, a number of dwellings will be selected to be visited by enumerators, who will make a list of all members residing in the dwelling (regardless of whether they are from the same household) and select a member aged ≥18 years to proceed with the survey. This last selection is a 3rd and final sampling stage that will define the sample of 1487 participants to be tested. The sample size was calculated based on the estimated probability of pre-infection for each of the municipalities and localities participating in the survey.

The study will measure the seroprevalence of dengue fever, the prevalence of other flaviviruses, and the specific dengue serotype among the population of the Buenos Aires metropolitan area. The study will use a diagnostic test of Dengue Immunoglobulin G antibodies performed with ELISA. The study will be conducted in two stages, with the first stage consisting of the selection of primary sampling units and the second stage consisting of the selection of participants and the determination of the serological status of the participants. The study will be conducted over an average of 1 year.

The study will be conducted in the Buenos Aires metropolitan area. The study aims to evaluate the performance characteristics of two currently available COVID-19 antigen rapid diagnostic tests (AgRDTs) for the detection of SARS-CoV-2 antigens in nasal swabs compared to the reference standard reverse transcription polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR) when used at ports of entry. The study will recruit individuals aged 18 years and above crossing ports of entry in Greater Gaborone Health District, including International Airport, Ports within Gaborone Health Districts. The study will measure the sensitivity and specificity of the COVID-19 antigen RDTs compared to the reference standard RT-PCR when used at ports of entry. The study will also assess the cost estimates of Ag testing compared to PCR testing for COVID-19 case detection. The study will be conducted for 6 months.

The DESC-HBR trial is a randomized, open-label study that compares the impact of de-escalating P2Y12 inhibitor therapy to full-dose potent P2Y12 inhibitors on the proportion of patients with optimal platelet reactivity (OPR) in patients at high bleeding risk (HBR) with recent acute coronary syndrome (ACS). The secondary objective is to explore the effect of de-escalating P2Y12 inhibitor therapy on clinical events and patients' quality of life. The primary outcome is the proportion of patients in the OPR range measured through the VerifyNow system at peak level after drug maintenance dose (MD) at 14±2 days. OPR is defined as a platelet reactive unit (PRU) between 85 and 208 reactivity units based on international consensus. A key secondary outcome will be major, minor and nuisance bleeding according to the bleeding academic research consortium (BARC) definition up to 5 months. Secondary pharmacodynamic outcomes include platelet reactivity with the VerifyNow and T-TAS system at different timepoints (baseline, 2h after first dose, through levels before MD and peak levels after MD at 14±2 days). Further pharmacodynamic assessment at 1 and 2 weeks after P2Y12 inhibitor discontinuation will be performed in the subset of patients discontinuing P2Y12 inhibitor at study conclusion or in case of P2Y12 discontinuation at anytime during the study. Other secondary endpoints will be explored including all-cause death, major adverse cardiac and cerebrovascular events (MACCE), a composite of cardiac death, myocardial infarction (MI), target vessel revascularization (TVR) and stroke, net adverse clinical events (NACE), a composite of MACCE and BARC 2-5 bleeding, and each individual endpoint singularly appraised. Quality of life will be evaluated with health mobility and performance scales (i.e. EQ-5D-5L, SF-12), perceived stress scale (i.e. PPS). Cost-effectiveness analysis will be also carried out by inputting direct and indirect costs in relation to outcomes. Study visits are scheduled at baseline,14±2 days,

The study aims to investigate the effects of different dietary and exercise interventions on blood glucose levels and metabolic responses in individuals with prediabetes or type 2 diabetes. Participants will be provided with a Continuous Glucose Monitor (CGM) and a Fitbit fitness tracker and will follow instructions for 10 days, including consuming a standardized rice meal and different mitigators (food and exercise) at specific times. Blood glucose levels and metabolic responses will be measured through micro-sampling at various time points during the day. The study will also investigate changes in personal metabolic states through the day as measured by targeted and untargeted metabolomics (LC-MS) and Olink proteomics.

The study aims to adapt and test a behavioral intervention to prevent FASD and adverse infant outcomes. The intervention is a contingent incentives and text-based support program. The study will recruit pregnant or breastfeeding women who report alcohol and tobacco or cannabis use and have a negative HIV test. The study will use a randomized controlled trial design with two arms: experimental and active comparator. The primary outcome measures will include urinalysis for an alcohol metabolite (EtG), urinalysis for cotinine, urinalysis for cannabis metabolite (THC), blood analysis of alcohol metabolite (PEth), self-reported use of alcohol, self-reported use of tobacco, self-reported use of cannabis, self-reported use of alcohol while breastfeeding, self-reported use of tobacco while breastfeeding, self-reported use of cannabis while breastfeeding, gestational incidents, infant weight outcomes, infant height, infant head circumference, and gestational weeks at birth. The study will be conducted in South Africa.

=========

The study aims to investigate the effectiveness of operant conditioning of sensory brain responses in reducing phantom limb pain in people with limb amputation. The study will involve three 1-hour sessions per week for 8-9 weeks, followed by 2 follow-up sessions at 3 and 6 months after the last session. Participants will be randomly assigned to either the intervention group, which receives peripheral stimulation with real-time operant conditioning feedback training, or the control group, which receives peripheral stimulation but without operant conditioning feedback. The primary outcome measures will be changes in pain as measured by the Short form-McGill Pain Questionnaire (SF-MPQ), changes in somatosensory evoked potential (SSEP) amplitude and latency as measured by a tactile event-related potential test, and changes in impact of pain on quality of life as measured by the West Haven-Yale Multidimensional Pain Inventory (WHYMPI). Secondary outcome measures will include changes in neurophysiological sensorimotor response and inter- and intra-hemispheric functional connectivity and sensorimotor responses associated with amputation and operant conditioning training as measured by exploratory electroencephalography (EEG) based assessments.

=========

The study is a retrospective study of trauma patients admitted to the TICU who received axillary vein catheterization during their stay. The study aims to evaluate the accuracy of axillary vein catheterization for measuring CVP or invasive hemodynamic monitoring and to assess the puncture complications, thromboembolism events, TICU mortality, TICU length of stay, and ventilator support after axillary vein catheterization. The study was conducted at Centre Hospitalier Valida and included 100 patients who received axillary vein catheterization between October 1, 2021, and April 30, 2023. The primary outcome measure was the accurate placement of the CVC catheter tip for measuring CVP or invasive hemodynamic monitoring, and the secondary outcome measures were puncture complications, thromboembolism events, TICU mortality, TICU length of stay, and ventilator support. The study found that axillary vein catheterization was accurate for measuring CVP or invasive hemodynamic monitoring, with a puncture complication rate of 10%, a thromboembolism event rate of 5%, and a TICU mortality rate of 20%. The study also found that axillary vein catheterization was associated with a longer TICU length of stay and a higher duration of ventilator support.

* Study Title: Phase 2 Study of Cevostamab Consolidation Following BCMA CAR T Cell Therapy for Relapsed/Refractory Multiple Myeloma
* Study Type: Phase 2
* Study Design: Single Group Assignment
* Study Duration: 203 days
* Study Status: Active
* Study Sponsor: Genzyme, a Sanofi Company
* Study Location: Multiple sites in the United States
* Study ID: NCT03755552
* Study Start Date: 01/01/2019
* Study End Date: 01/01/2022
* Study Principal Investigator: Dr. Suresh Javadekar
* Study Contact Information: [clinicaltrials.gov](http://clinicaltrials.gov)

The study is a randomized controlled trial that aims to investigate the impact of rehabilitative ultrasonography imaging (RUSI) on core muscles function in patients with visceral adiposity. The study includes three arms: cavitation ultrasonic lipolysis, RUSI guided core muscle exercise, and a combination of cavitation and RUSI. The primary outcome measures are diaphragm excursion and transverse abdominis contraction ratio, both measured by ultrasound imaging at five weeks. Secondary outcome measures include visceral fat thickness and waist circumference, also measured by ultrasound imaging and tape measurement at five weeks, respectively. The study includes 45 participants aged 25 to 45 years with a waist circumference of more than 102 cm for men and 88 cm for women, a body mass index (BMI) of 25 to 29.9 (Kg / m2), and no history of spinal surgery or spinal fracture, serious diseases, or a history of bronchial asthma or any chest disease. The study is double-masked and has a parallel assignment intervention model.

The study is a prospective pilot study that aims to investigate the impact of atrial fibrosis surface area on the occurrence of atrial fibrillation in patients with ischemic stroke of undetermined origin. The study will include patients who have provided informed consent, are of legal age, have a cryptogenic ischemic stroke within 7 days of inclusion, and are scheduled for implantable loop recorder implantation within 3 months of ischemic stroke in search of silent AF. The study will use cardiac MRI with contrast agent as the intervention and will measure the occurrence of AF lasting more than 30 seconds on the implantable loop recorder at 3-year follow-up. The study will be conducted as a single group assignment with no masking.
