The UM CRMC RecuR Score Pilot is a two-arm, parallel-group, prospective, randomized, non-blinded, fallback design, controlled superiority study of the impact of a new transitional care model for patients determined to be at higher risk of 30-day unplanned hospital readmission. The study will be conducted at UM CRMC, an approximately 100-bed community hospital located in Charles County, Maryland. The target patient population is admitted patients (inpatients) at UM CRMC with a high readmission risk (RecuR Score) and/or specific admission diagnoses that are amenable to peri- and post-discharge interventions, where the goal is to reduce the readmission rate of this high-risk population. The study will use a fallback design with two primary endpoints. The first sequential primary endpoint is 30-day post-discharge unplanned hospital readmission in the overall study population. The second sequential primary endpoint is 30-day post-discharge unplanned hospital readmission in the medium-high risk population (RecuR Score 2 & 3). The significance level (0.05) will be divided evenly between the two primary endpoints, for a significance level of 0.025 for the first primary endpoint and a reserved 0.025 significance level for the second primary endpoint. The study will use a stratified randomization method with stratification by RecuR Score. The study will be conducted in accordance with the Declaration of Helsinki and will obtain informed consent from all participants. The study will be conducted in accordance with the Declaration of Helsinki and will obtain informed consent from all participants.

=============

The ANCAR trial is a randomized, monocenter study that aims to evaluate the effects of an acupuncture treatment protocol for nasal congestion in AR compared to azelastine nasal spray (Carelastin®). The study includes 80 participants with diagnosed AR who have nasal congestion and are aged between 18-65 years. The acupuncture treatment protocol consists of 8 treatments over 6 weeks, with 2 treatments per week during the first 2 weeks and 1 treatment per week in the consecutive 4 weeks. The primary outcome measure is the Visual Analog Scale (VAS) score for nasal congestion, and the secondary outcome measures include the Visual Analog Scale (VAS) score for nasal congestion at different visits, Peak Nasal Inspiratory Flow (PNIF) score, Adapted Nasal Obstruction Symptom Evaluation (NOSE) score, and Visual Analog Scale (VAS) score for other nasal and ocular signs and symptoms. The study is expected to start in March 2022 and will be completed in September 2022.

This is a pilot study to assess the feasibility of recruiting patients to a randomised controlled trial of intracoronary cooling and dilution during PCI for STEMI. The study will also assess the safety and feasibility of the intervention. The study will recruit 60 patients with STEMI who are undergoing PCI at Harefield Hospital. Patients will be randomised to either intracoronary cooling and dilution or standard PCI. The primary outcome measure will be the recruitment rate and feasibility of the study. Secondary outcome measures will include safety, invasive haemodynamic assessment, biomarkers, myocardial salvage, and infarct size.

===============

The study is a feasibility pilot clinical trial that aims to improve maternal mental health outcomes by targeting the maternal gut microbiome. The study will recruit 100 pregnant women with a history of anxiety and/or depression and currently stable, and randomize them into one of four study groups. The study will last for 2 years, with six study visits, one every 3 months. The primary outcome is feasibility, measured by recruiting the targeted number of participants within the anticipated timeframe and completing at least 4 of the 6 visits by each participant. The study will measure adherence to supplement intake, dietary protocol, and completion of study visits. The study will also document study obstacles. The study will use dietary modification, fish oil, and probiotics as interventions. The study will be conducted virtually, unless participants need in-person follow-ups. The final visit is expected to occur between 9-12 months after delivery.

This study is a SMART (Smartly Adaptive Randomized Trial) design that evaluates the effectiveness of remotely delivered, culturally tailored weight loss interventions among Latina breast cancer survivors. The study includes a baseline run-in and randomized stage I and stage II studies. The study measures body weight percent change at month 12 and whether EAI effectiveness is moderated by baseline patient characteristics.

The study is a retrospective study of high dose follitropin delta in a mixed protocol with human chorionic gonadotropin in women undergoing IVF/ICSI cycle IVF antagonist protocol. The study aims to evaluate the IVF cycle using the prescribed medication. The primary outcome measure is the number of good quality blastocysts. The study includes two arms: Follitropin delta + hCG and Follitropin delta + HP-hMG. The dosing regimen was determined according to AMH and weight in women undergoing an IVF antagonist cycle. The study is not suitable for women with endometriosis stage III/IV, recurrent miscarriages, hypersensitivity to follitropin delta and/or human chorionic gonadotropin, use of Growth Hormone (GH) during the stimulation cycle, and women undergoing ovarian stimulation for oncologic or elective fertility preservation. The study is suitable for women aged 18 to 42 years with regular menstrual cycles of 24-35 days, presence of both ovaries, and no history of recurrent miscarriages.

=============

The study aims to evaluate the effectiveness of telemedicine in inflammatory bowel disease (IBD). The study will include 60 patients with IBD who will be randomly assigned to either a face-to-face outpatient observation group or an observation group using telemedicine technologies. The telemedicine group will have access to online consultation with a gastroenterologist, educational information about IBD, necessary lifestyle changes, and dietary recommendations. The study will measure the change in quality of life in IBD, clinical remission of Crohn disease and ulcerative colitis, endoscopic and histological remission of IBD, adverse drug reactions, satisfaction with treatment, psychological well-being, and the number of surgical interventions, hospitalizations, and outpatient visits associated with IBD. The study will be conducted over a period of 6 months, with data collection occurring up to 6 months after randomization.

=========

The SAUNA trial is a phase II, randomized, open-label study that evaluates the efficacy and safety of continuing somatostatin analogs (SSAs) versus stopping SSA treatment in patients with locally advanced or metastatic, non-functional, well-differentiated neuroendocrine tumors (GEP-NET) who have progressed on first-line SSA treatment. The study includes two substudies: a targeted therapy substudy and a PRRT substudy. The primary outcome measures are progression-free survival (PFS) and time to deterioration (TTD) in patients continuing or stopping second-line therapy with SSA. Secondary outcome measures include PFS rate, overall survival (OS), response rates, and quality of life (QoL) measurements. The study will also assess the cost-effectiveness of continuing SSA treatment and drug safety.

This study aims to investigate the effectiveness of peer-mediated pivotal response training (PRT) in improving socialization experiences for children with language impairment who are isolated from the classroom social network. The study uses an randomized controlled trial design with 12 classrooms assigned to the treatment condition and 13 to the control condition. Within each classroom, the focal participants are children isolated from their classroom social network with low pragmatic language skills. The primary approach to treatment for focal children is described here. Specifically, focal children in classrooms randomized to the treatment condition receive peer-mediated pivotal response training (PRT) per procedures detailed by Brock et al.. PRT procedures are facilitated by a classroom facilitator-a classroom teacher or teaching assistant-who receives ongoing training and support from research staff. First, investigators provide a one-on-one 1-h training session for each facilitator that focuses on how to identify, initially train, and then support peers on a day-to-day basis during center time. Second, investigators partner with the facilitator to identify two peers who (a) demonstrate good social skills; (b) respond well to adult directions; (c) have consistent attendance; and (d) do not have a history of negative interactions with the target student. The facilitator explicitly identifies the focal child (buddy) and asks the children to use three strategies to play with the buddy during center time: (a) offer your buddy some play options; (b) show and talk about how to play with your buddy; (c) compliment your buddy; and (d) show your buddy how to take turns. At each training session the facilitator describes one strategy, provides examples, and has peers practice the strategy through role play. After trainings, the facilitator provides ongoing support during center time to implement the strategies over 12 weeks during months 3-6 of the 9 months of study participation. The study measures the preschool language screener 5 (PLS-5) and developmental pragmatic profile (DPP) at baseline, 3 months, and 9 months. The study also measures teacher-child rating scale (TCRS), peer incoming talk, peer outgoing talk, and peer interactions at baseline, 3 months, and 9 months.

* Study Title: Dalfampridine Combined With Physical Therapy for Mobility Impairment in People With Multiple Sclerosis
* Study Type: Randomized Controlled Trial
* Study Design: Parallel Assignment
* Study Duration: 14 weeks
* Study Status: Active
* Study Sponsor: National Institute of Neurological Disorders and Stroke (NINDS)
* Study ID: NCT03111512
* Study Start Date: 01/01/2018
* Study End Date: 01/01/2021
* Study Contact: [Dr. David S. Kaufmann](mailto:david.kaufmann@ucsf.edu)

The study aims to test the test-retest reliability, responsiveness and interpretability of CLEFT-Q, a questionnaire on health related quality of life specific to patients with cleft lip and palate. The study includes 50 patients who will answer CLEFT-Q twice with 1-2 weeks in between, and again after secondary nose, lip, jaw or speech improving surgery. Additionally, 20 health care professionals will be interviewed about their experiences on working with CLEFT-Q. The primary outcome measure is the change scores in CLEFT-Q, while secondary outcome measures include photographs and recordings of speech before and after surgery. The study terms include CLEFT-Q, psychometrics, test-retest reliability, interpretability, and responsiveness.

The study is a randomized controlled trial that compares the effectiveness of core stabilization and dynamic stretching exercises in reducing the intensity, frequency, duration, and severity of pain in primary dysmenorrhea. The study is designed to measure the working ability, location, intensity, days of pain, dysmenorrhea, strength, quality of life, and pain, frequency, severity, duration of the participants. The study is conducted on unmarried young girls aged 18-25 who are nulliparous and voluntarily want to participate. The study is conducted for 8 weeks, and the participants are randomly assigned to either the stretching exercise group or the dynamic core stabilizing exercise group. The stretching exercise group performs 6 stretching exercises for 8 weeks, and the dynamic core stabilizing exercise group performs 6 strengthening exercises for 8 weeks. The study measures the WaLIDD (working ability, Location, Intensity, Days of pain, Dysmenorrhea) score, side bridge test, McGill Quality of life, and PFSD (pain, frequency, severity, duration) scale. The study aims to provide information on which exercises are more effective in reducing the intensity, frequency, duration, and severity of pain in primary dysmenorrhea.

===============

The study aims to measure non-invasively, easily and reliably the variations of cerebral perfusion in patients with or without cardiovascular risk factors during controlled variations performed during routine care to adjust the blood pressure level within the recommended safety standards during general anesthesia. The setting of the optimal mean arterial pressure (MAP) level will be achieved within the ranges of values commonly used, taking into account the patient's cardiovascular comorbidities. The main objective is to identify a significant linear relationship between the percentage change in mean velocity (Vm) and the percentage change in the 95% spectral frequency front (SEF95) during the MAP change. Cerebral perfusion and cerebral O2 adequacy will be compared and assessed by continuous and simultaneous measurements of cerebral blood flow by transcranial Doppler (TCD) and cerebral O2 adequacy by near-infrared spectroscopy (NIRS) and a brain function parameter by intraoperative electroencephalogram (EEG) - frontal EEG. The classification of patients in the cardiovascular risk group will be determined in addition to their history and treatment by an arterial stiffness parameter (pulse wave velocity) measured non-invasively before and during the protocol by MESI mTablet automatic digital sphygmomanometer (MESI ltd, Slovenia). The objective for a given patient is to look for a possible threshold value of pressure that could impact the blood flow velocity (Doppler) and possibly the EEG and cerebral oximetry. This clinical research work is performed on adult patients undergoing scheduled surgery at Lariboisière Hospital under general anesthesia. All measurements are obtained non-invasively. The monitoring routinely includes continuous electrocardiogram and blood pressure monitoring by non-invasive means (Clearsight®, EV1000®, Edwards Sciences) in anesthesia pulsed O2 saturation (SpO2), ventilatory parameters (FR, VC, FiO2), and anesthesia depth by frontal EEG. Patients over 18 years of age are eligible to participate in this protocol. During the anesthesia consultation, they will be given an information letter on the objectives and the course of

The PediQUEST Response to Pain Of Children With Neurologic Disability Pilot Randomized Controlled Trial (PQ-ResPOND) is a single site Phase II 2:1 RCT of the PQ-ResPOND intervention vs. usual care in 45 children ≥1 year-old & AYA with SNI and moderate to severe recurrent pain behaviors. The study aims to evaluate the feasibility of running a full-scale RCT that compares the effect of the PQ-ResPOND intervention vs. usual care in children and AYA with SNI. Specific Aims are to 1. assess study's feasibility and acceptability by evaluating recruitment (rates and suitability of screening/tracking), adherence to the intervention (by study participants and interventionists), and retention (dropout rates, reasons, and demographics); and, 2. explore potential for intervention's efficacy by estimating effect sizes and variability of the outcomes proposed for the full-scale RCT (child recurrent pain and symptom burden, and parent outcomes) and assessing intervention's acceptability through semi-structured interviews. Methods: Researchers will conduct a single site Phase II Pilot 2:1 RCT of PQ-ResPOND (intervention, n=30) vs. usual care (control, n=15) in 45 children ≥1 year-old & AYA with SNI and moderate to severe recurrent pain behaviors. After randomization, participants will answer weekly PQ-ResPOND surveys and monthly outcome surveys over 12 weeks via the PQ App, and a semi-structured exit interview. Intervention: participants assigned to this arm will receive the PQ-ResPOND intervention which combines (i) parent-mediated activation through weekly collection and feedback to parents and clinicians, via our PQ App, of parent reported child pain (Non-Communicating Children's Pain Checklist-Revised scale (NCCPC-R)) and other symptoms (PediQUEST-Memorial Symptom Assessment Scale adapted for children with SNI), with (ii) PPC team-mediated activation of primary clinicians and parents: through PPC consultation, and (iii) PPC team activation through training in a

===============

This is an observational study of MRD dynamic monitoring in first-line serplulimab plus chemotherapy in the treatment of extensive small cell lung cancer. Participants receive 6 cycles of first-line serplulimab plus chemotherapy and MRD testing was performed before treatment, after 2 cycles of treatment, after 6 cycles of treatment, 6 months after the end of chemotherapy, and 1 year after the end of chemotherapy. The primary outcome measure is progression-free survival (PFS) defined as the time from the first dose of study drug to tumor progression or death due to any cause. Secondary outcome measures include overall survival (OS) and objective response rate (ORR).

============

The ACTIVE-CaRe Pilot is a clinical pilot study that aims to evaluate the effectiveness of the Aktivplan Digital Intervention for supporting regular heart-healthy levels of physical activity following completion of a Phase II Rehabilitation Programme. The study is a randomized, parallel assignment, open-label study with two arms: experimental and control. The experimental arm receives the Aktivplan Digital Intervention, while the control arm receives usual care. The study measures primary outcomes such as recruitment rate, drop-out rate, data completeness, adherence to the Aktivplan Digital Intervention, usability of the Aktivplan Digital Intervention, user experience of the Aktivplan Digital Intervention, user acceptance of the Aktivplan Digital Intervention, technical stability of the Aktivplan Digital Intervention, use of alternative and additional strategies for supporting physical activity, experiences and perspectives of patients regarding their study participation, experiences and perspectives of rehabilitation professionals regarding the intervention and study procedures, exercise capacity, physical activity behaviour, weight, blood pressure, blood cholesterol, HbA1c, smoking, health-related quality of life, exercise self-efficacy, and patient safety. The study is designed to be conducted over a period of 10 weeks, with data collection taking place at the 10-week follow-up visit.

* Study design: Randomized, placebo-controlled, double-blind, 2-period cross-over study
* Study duration: Four weeks
* Study population: Youth with autism spectrum disorders
* Study objectives: Evaluate social and repetitive behaviors after four weeks of twice daily-doses of 24IU of intranasally administered oxytocin
* Study interventions: Oxytocin nasal spray and placebo
* Study outcomes: Social behavior, repetitive behavior, behavioral inflexibility, social cognition, repetitive cognition, vagally-mediated heart rate variability

This is an observational study with longitudinal follow-up to validate a scale created by the investigators for assessing the abdominal condition of premature infants. The study includes newborns born prematurely (before 37 weeks of amenorrhea) at least 3 days of life hospitalized in the neonatal intensive care units whose holders of parental authority are able to give free and informed consent to participate in this study. The study measures the clinical abdominal assessment scale for preterm infants (ECAP scale) and its validity. The primary outcome measure is the score on the ECAP scale between 0 and 20, and the secondary outcome measures include the indication for abdominal massage on the ECAP scale, the ECAP scale validity, and the impact of massage on the ECAP scale. The study is designed to assess the ECAP scale's reliability and validity in a population of preterm infants up to 18 months of age. The study is conducted in the neonatal intensive care units of the Clermont-Ferrand hospital center.

=================

This study is a randomized controlled trial comparing the effects of Empowered Relief (ER) to a Wait-List Control (WL) of participants with persistent pain when ER is provided by ER-trained ASPMN nurses. The study aims to assess the feasibility and acceptability of ER. Participants will be adults aged 18 and above years with self-reported or clinically diagnosed persistent pain. Participants will complete an online eligibility form to screen for inclusion and exclusion criteria. Inclusion criteria include pain >3 months more than half the time, English fluency, ability to attend a one-time web-based class and complete web-based surveys, and age > 18 years. Exclusion criteria include previous participation in ER class, cognitive impairment, non-English speaking, or psychological factors that would preclude comprehension of material or full participation in the study. Procedures include 20 ASPMN nurses receiving ER training facilitated by Stanford Pain Relief Innovations Lab, ER-trained nurse providers delivering the ER program in English, and a crossover intervention class offered to those patient participants randomized to WLC once the ER group has completed their class and follow up assessments. The primary outcome measure is change in Pain Catastrophizing, measured by self-report at baseline, and then at 2, 4, and 8 week timepoints. Secondary outcome measures include change in Pain Intensity, measured by a 0-10 Pain severity scale at the same timepoints.

The study aims to improve pain communication for patients' health. The study seeks information on patients' and health care nurses' mental effort when choosing or understanding, respectively, pain intensity ratings, and confidence in the accuracy of pain intensity rating patterns. The study will compare the mental effort of choosing and understanding pain intensity rating scales, patients' and nurses' perceptions of the mental effort of choosing and understanding pain intensity ratings, the relationship between perceptions of mental effort and the importance of decreasing that mental effort for patients and nurses, and the relationship between confidence in the accuracy of fictional pain intensity rating patterns and the importance of increasing confidence for patients and nurses. The study will use a survey as the intervention/treatment. The study will measure mental effort, importance of decreasing mental effort, and confidence in the accuracy of fictional pain intensity ratings as the primary outcome measures. The study will use ordinal self-report as the measure description for all outcome measures. The study will use a baseline time frame for all outcome measures. The study is a clinical trial of mesenchymal stem cells (MSCs) for the treatment of poor graft function after allogeneic hematopoietic stem cell transplantation (allo-HSCT). The study is designed as a single group assignment with an open label masking. The primary outcome measure is the hemogram recovery of patients with poor graft function after treatment. The secondary outcome measures are infection rate, graft-versus-host disease, and survival rate. The study includes patients with a KPS score >60 points, expected survival period >3 months, and no serious functional damage to important organs throughout the body. The patients are injected with 1×10^6/kg mesenchymal stem cells of cord blood weekly for 4 consecutive weeks. The study is conducted at Centre Hospitalier Valida.

The MOVIN' CARE for PD (Mind-body Interventions) is a 2-arm randomized controlled trial that aims to investigate the effectiveness of two mind-body interventions - yoga and arts-based therapies - in improving the psycho-social-spiritual well-being among individuals with mild-to-advanced Parkinson's disease. The study adopts a 2-arm randomized controlled design, with participants being randomly assigned to either the mindful yoga intervention or the arts-based therapy intervention. The study measures the change in perceived stress level, overall quality of life, PD-related symptoms, self-compassion, self-efficacy, perceived social support, constipation severity, bowel habits, gut microbiota composition, and user's satisfaction. The study is conducted in Hong Kong and recruits adults who are diagnosed with idiopathic, mild-to-advance PD as indicated by the Hoehn and Yahr Scale (19) Stage I to IV, aged 18 or above, able to give written informed consent, able to access to the internet and smartphone/ tablet/ laptop, and able to comprehend Chinese. The study is expected to be completed in 9 months, with follow-up assessments conducted at 3, 6, and 9 months after baseline assessment.

The study is a 2-arm, parallel-group, randomized controlled trial with 12-, 24-, 36-, and 52-week follow-up, to evaluate the effect of the treatment group (QG-A) versus a control group (MM) on alcohol use outcomes. The study is designed to assess the effectiveness of QG-A, which combines CBT based counseling with pharmacotherapy for alcohol use disorders (naltrexone), delivered via an mobile health app (QG-A), relative to usual care for adults with AUD, which comprises medical management with naltrexone (MM), in reducing alcohol use and associated psychological and functional outcomes. The study will compare the efficacy of QG-A, which combines CBT based counseling with pharmacotherapy for alcohol use disorders (naltrexone), delivered via an mobile health app (QG-A), relative to usual care for adults with AUD, which comprises medical management with naltrexone (MM), in reducing alcohol use and associated psychological and functional outcomes. The study will compare the efficacy of QG-A, which combines CBT based counseling with pharmacotherapy for alcohol use disorders (naltrexone), delivered via an mobile health app (QG-A), relative to usual care for adults with AUD, which comprises medical management with naltrexone (MM), in reducing alcohol use and associated psychological and functional outcomes. The study will compare the efficacy of QG-A, which combines CBT based counseling with pharmacotherapy for alcohol use disorders (naltrexone), delivered via an mobile health app (QG-A), relative to usual care for adults with AUD, which comprises medical management with naltrexone (MM), in reducing alcohol use and associated psychological and functional outcomes. The study will compare the efficacy of QG-A, which combines CBT based counseling with pharmacotherapy for alcohol use disorders (naltrexone), delivered via an mobile health app (QG-A), relative to usual care for adults with AUD, which comprises medical management with naltrexone (MM), in reducing alcohol use and associated psychological and functional outcomes. The study will compare the efficacy of QG-A, which combines CBT based counseling with pharm

The Seven Trial is an Investigator Initiated Trial (IIT) designed to test the hypothesis that increasing the dose of botensilimab in combination with balstilimab + triplet chemotherapy + chloroquine + celecoxib will lead to a higher rate of apoptosis in pancreatic cancer cells. The study will be conducted in two parts. Part 1 will be a dose escalation study to determine the maximum tolerated dose (MTD) of botensilimab. Part 2 will be an expansion cohort study to evaluate the safety and efficacy of botensilimab at the MTD + balstilimab + triplet + chloroquine + celecoxib in patients with previously untreated metastatic pancreatic cancer. The study will be conducted in accordance with the Declaration of Helsinki and Good Clinical Practice guidelines.

The study aims to compare the clinical pregnancy rate of embryo transfer in natural vs substituted cycles. The study will include women aged < 40 years old who have undergone either a frozen embryo transfer in natural cycle or substituted cycle IVF and FET cycles done at Clinique OVO. The study will exclude patients with egg or embryo recipient history of recurrent miscarriages, defined as ≥ 3 consecutive losses, patients that needed Viagra, Plasma-Rich Platelet (PRP) or other modalities to improve their endometrial thickness, uterine abnormalities, and abnormal hormonal profiles. The study will include patients with FET stimulated cycles and history of recurrent implantation failure defined as failed ≥ 2 euploid embryos transfer or ≥ 3 blastocysts. The study will be a randomized controlled trial with two arms: Frozen embryo transfer substituted cycle and Frozen embryo transfer natural cycle. The primary outcome measure will be the clinical pregnancy rate of embryo transfer in natural vs substituted cycles, which will be evaluated at 6 to 8 weeks after Frozen Embryo Transfer.

This is a randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled clinical trial that aims to determine the effects of intravenous vs. inhalational anesthesia on incidence of postoperative delirium and cognitive dysfunction, functional decline, and patient-reported outcomes in older adults undergoing non-cardiac surgery. The study will compare inhalational (sevoflurane) vs. intravenous (propofol) anesthesia on these outcomes. The study will enroll 200 patients aged 75 years and older who are scheduled for elective, inpatient, non-cardiac surgery requiring general anesthesia. The study will measure incidence of postoperative delirium and cognitive dysfunction, delirium severity and duration, blood phosphorylated tau 181 (p-tau181), postoperative functional decline, and patient-reported outcomes using a battery of neuropsychological tests, delirium assessment tools, and patient-reported outcome measures. The study will follow patients for one year postoperatively. The primary outcome measures will be incidence of postoperative delirium and cognitive dysfunction, delirium severity and duration, and change in levels of preoperative blood p-tau181 from preoperative baseline to 12 months postoperatively. The secondary outcome measures will be incidence of postoperative functional decline, patient-reported outcome scores, and change in levels of preoperative blood p-tau181 from preoperative baseline to one year postoperatively. The study will be conducted at Oregon Health & Science University.

The study aims to assess the nutritional status of children with congenital heart disease and to develop a protocol to avoid nutritional deficiency and achieve normal growth in these children. The study will include children more than one month and till age of 18 years that present to Assiut University Hospital Units with Cyanotic and ACyanotic Congenital heart disease. The study will exclude all pediatric patients with comorbidities other than congenital heart disease. The study will measure the nutritional status of the children using anthropometric measures such as weight, height, length, head circumference, mid arm circumference, and BMI. The study will be conducted at Assiut University Hospital Units. The study will be a cross-sectional study. The primary outcome measure will be the assessment of the nutritional status of the children with congenital heart disease. The study will be conducted over a period of one year.

The study aims to investigate the use of pH sensitive amine chemical exchange saturation transfer echo planar imaging (CEST-EPI) to visualize infiltrating tumor cells in glioblastoma. The study will carry out a prospective, randomized controlled trial of surgical resection of glioblastoma with pH sensitive amine CEST-EPI. Patients will be enrolled by the investigator at the UCLA Ronald Reagan Medical Center. The study will recruit patients with imaging consistent with WHO grade IV glioblastoma. The primary endpoint will be progression free survival and the secondary endpoints will be overall survival, surgical complication rate, and quality of life differences as measured by pre- and post-operative karnofsky performance scale scores. The study will use pre-operative amine chemical exchange saturation transfer pH weighted MRI to identify regions of interest that correspond to infiltrating glioblastoma and via intraoperative neuronavigation, guide resection of glioblastoma. The study will randomize patients to either the experimental arm, which will have CEST+ NE segmentations uploaded to intraoperative objects using the intraoperative neuronavigation software, or the standard-of-care arm, which will have standard MRI w/wo contrast sequences uploaded to the intraoperative neuronavigation software. The study will use the RANO criteria to determine recurrence. The study will have a sample size of 60 to provide a power of 95% to detect a meaningful 6 months difference in PFS at a 0.05 significance level. The study will compare clinical characteristics associated with survival using independent sample t-tests to assess for bias despite randomization. The study will use multivariate cox and log rank tests to compare survival outcomes. The study will use independent sample chi squared tests to compare differences in surgical complication rate and post-operative karnofsky performance scale changes. The study will have a median PFS of 6 months for the larger 10-year cohort of patients with newly diagnosed glioblastoma. The study will have a median PFS of 13 months for the preliminary data on CEST+ NE resections. The study will have a sensitivity of 100% and specificity of 71.4%

The study aims to investigate the patterns of urinary bladder cancer in Darfur, Sudan. The study is a cross-sectional, hospital-based study conducted at Nyala Specialized Hospital in Darfur. The study spans a period from 2020 to 2022. The study will focus on understanding the clinical outcomes, etiology, histology, and demographic distribution of the disease. The study will include all Sudanese patients who live in Darfur and present with urinary bladder mass, and the study will exclude patients who do not live in Darfur and those who refuse to participate in the study. The study will be conducted by a team of researchers from Nyala Specialized Hospital in Darfur.

The study is a cross-sectional study that aims to investigate the relationship between mental stress and the quality of bowel preparation for colonoscopy. The study includes 1000 patients who are to undergo colonoscopy at the Endoscopy Centre of the Department of Gastroenterology, Renji Hospital, from May 2023 to August 2023. The general information and the physical and mental stress test scale of the patients were collected by questionnaires from random samples, and they were screened for enrolment according to the inclusion and exclusion criteria. The correlation between physical and mental stress and the quality of bowel preparation for colonoscopy was analyzed according to the Boston Rating Scale (BPS), which is used by colonoscopists to assess the quality of bowel preparation for each patient. The primary outcome measure is the quality of bowel preparation, which is assessed by the BPS. The study is a cross-sectional study that aims to investigate the relationship between mental stress and the quality of bowel preparation for colonoscopy. The study includes 1000 patients who are to undergo colonoscopy at the Endoscopy Centre of the Department of Gastroenterology, Renji Hospital, from May 2023 to August 2023. The general information and the physical and mental stress test scale of the patients were collected by questionnaires from random samples, and they were screened for enrolment according to the inclusion and exclusion criteria. The correlation between physical and mental stress and the quality of bowel preparation for colonoscopy was analyzed according to the Boston Rating Scale (BPS), which is used by colonoscopists to assess the quality of bowel preparation for each patient. The primary outcome measure is the quality of bowel preparation, which is assessed by the BPS.

The study aims to examine the beneficial effects of a short playful interaction on the cognitive, social, and mood of older people. The investigators will examine changes in indices of mood, mental health, social functioning, cognition compared to an active control intervention. The study also aims to compare between online playful interactions to face to face. In addition, the investigators aim to investigate the mediating role of personality traits and cognitive functions in connection to the beneficial effect of playful interactions in aging. The investigators hypnotized that playful interactions will induce greater effects on emotional and social indices, as well as on executive functioning, compared to more familiar social interactions. The investigators will recruit 80 participants (up to 95, considering attrition). Procedure The study will take place in six sites including assisted living facilities, community centers and adults day centers in Israel. Participants will be invited by the research assistance to take part in the study. Participants who will be willing to take part in the study will meet with the research team and will read and signed an informed consent form before participating in the study. Following the informed consent signing, baseline measures will be collected (traits and cognitive measures) (T0). Following baseline assessment participants will be randomly assigned to four arms. At first, they will randomly assign to one of two conditions (online or face to face). The interactions will be separated in a week. A random half of the participants will be assigned to practice the playful interaction at the first week and control interaction in the second week, whereas for the other half this order will be reversed. One designated experiment assigned each participant randomly to one of the two interactions (playful or control), to keep the other experiments blind to the activity. For each participant, separate interactions will be conducted by a different experimenter. These are the four arms: Playful interactions operationalized by dramatic improvisation techniques based on verbal and non-verbal elements in a face to face setting Playful interactions operationalized by dramatic improvisation techniques based on verbal and non-verbal elements in an online setting An active control condition that involves introductory conversation and movement exercises in a face to face setting An active control condition that involves introductory conversation and movement exercises in an online setting The interventions will meet the following criteria: a) ease of implementation in an online system b) a short interaction between 15-20 minutes Both interactions incorporated bodily movement; however, the play

The proposed study aims to evaluate the efficacy of using the SkillFlix for Parents online video library to improve the sexual health communication skills of parents of teens with autism spectrum disorder. A randomized controlled trial will be conducted to assess the impact of the resource on parent skill demonstration and confidence, conversation frequency, and teen knowledge, attitudes, and behaviors. Participants will be parent and youth dyads, including parents over 18 years old and youth aged 13-17 with ASD, reciprocal communication skills, receptive language skills, who are in mainstream classrooms for at least one class during the school day. The study design will be a randomized controlled trial of dyads with pre- and post-assessment, and a 3-month follow-up assessment (6 months after start of study), each including a survey and audio recording. After completing the baseline activities, half (50) of the dyads will be randomly assigned to the SkillTalk ASD intervention group which will receive access to the SkillTalk ASD web site and the study mobile app. The control group will receive written materials with similar content. For baseline parents will take a survey, audio record a conversation based on a written conversation guide and upload it for analysis. Youth will take a survey. Intervention participants will have access to SkillTalk ASD for 3 months. During the three-month period, parent and youth participants will be asked to complete a bi-weekly conversation log. At the conclusion of the three-month period, they will participate in an immediate post-test which will again include a survey, audio record a conversation based on a written conversation guide and upload it for analysis. Youth will take an immediate post-test survey. During the three-month follow-up period, parents and youths will be asked to complete a biweekly conversation log. Three months after the conclusion of the access period parents will take a survey, audio record a conversation based on a written conversation guide and upload it for analysis. Youth will take a survey. At the conclusion of the 6-month period the control group participants will be provided with access to the SkillFlix ASD materials.

DDX17 Orchestrate Septic Vascular Endothelial Pyroptosis by Controlling Gasdermin D Pore Formation

Study Type: Clinical Trial

Study Design: Randomized Controlled Trial

Study Duration: 28 days

Study Status: Not yet recruiting

Study Location: Not specified

Study Sponsor: Not specified

Study ID: Not specified

Study Title: DDX17 Orchestrate Septic Vascular Endothelial Pyroptosis by Controlling Gasdermin D Pore Formation

Study Description:

The study aims to investigate the role of DDX17 and GSDMD in sepsis and their correlation with vascular endothelial injury, severity, and prognosis. The study will recruit patients with potential or clear infection and an increase in the Sequential Organ Failure score (SOFA score) of more than or equal to 2 points compared to the baseline value. Patients will be followed up for 28 days, and the primary outcome measure will be 28-day mortality. Secondary outcome measures will include the correlation between plasma level of DDX17 and vascular endothelial injury, severity, and prognosis in sepsis patients, as well as the correlation between plasma level of GSDMD and vascular endothelial injury, severity, and prognosis in sepsis patients. The study will be conducted as a randomized controlled trial.

Study Participation Criteria:

Eligibility Criteria:

* There is a potential or clear infection
* Sequential Organ Failure score (SOFA score) increases by more than or equal to 2 points compared to the baseline value
* Informed consent form is signed

Exclusion Criteria:

* Age<18 years old or>80 years old
* Pregnant women
* Tumor patients
* Diseases that may be complicated with vascular endothelial damage: hypertension, acute and chronic hepatitis (hepatitis caused by virus), liver cirrhosis, PT prolongation after liver transplantation, acute myocardial infarction, chronic tubular nephritis, chronic renal insufficiency/maintenance hemod

The study is a single-center prospective study of non-invasive methods for the diagnosis of postoperative complications in liver transplant recipients. The study aims to evaluate the accuracy of non-invasive methods for the diagnosis of early allograft dysfunction (EAD) in liver transplant recipients. The study will include patients eligible for liver transplantation following National and International Guidelines. The study will exclude re-transplant patients and patients with liver transplant in fulminant hepatitis. The study will include patients aged between 18 and 75 years. The study will measure the accuracy of non-invasive methods for the diagnosis of EAD using Olthoff criteria. The study will be conducted for 2 weeks from liver transplantation. The study aims to test the safety and efficacy of Elemene plus Stupp Protocol compared with Stupp Protocol alone for newly-diagnosed GBM patients. The study is a multi-center, phase II, randomized, controlled clinical trial. The study will enroll 120 patients with newly-diagnosed supratentorial GBM, IDH-wildtype, WHO grade 4 male or female adult patients < 70 years old, with a Karnofsky performance status (KPS) score higher or equal to 60, a minimum life expectancy of 12 weeks, adequate bone marrow function, adequate hepatic function, adequate renal function, and adequate coagulation function. The study will randomly assign patients to either the Ele-Stupp Protocol or the Stupp Protocol. The Ele-Stupp Protocol consists of maximal safe tumor resection, concurrent radiochemotherapy with TMZ, and adjuvant TMZ, plus Elemene. The Stupp Protocol consists of maximal safe tumor resection, concurrent radiochemotherapy with TMZ, and adjuvant TMZ. The primary outcome measure is the overall survival (OS) rate in the 12th month (12m-OS). The secondary outcome measures include the overall survival (OS), progression-free survival (PFS), progression-free survival (PFS) rate in the 6th month (6m-OS), and adverse events. The study will be conducted in accordance with the Declaration of Helsinki and Good Clinical Practice (GCP) guidelines. The study will be registered in the Chinese Clinical Trial Registry (ChiCTR) with the registration number ChiCTR1800019022.

This study aims to investigate and compare the effects of progressive relaxation training on pain characteristics, attack frequency, activity self-efficacy perception, and social participation in women with two different types of headaches, TTH and migraine. The study will be conducted in two groups of women aged 20-45 years with a diagnosis of TTH or migraine according to the International Classification of Headache Disorders (ICHD-II)(1), who express voluntary willingness to participate in this study. The intervention will be progressive relaxation training, which will be instructed and trained by a physiotherapist 2times a week for 30 minutes each over 6 weeks. The primary outcome measures will be occupational self-assessment (OSA), World Health Organization Disability Assessment Schedule 2 (WHO-DAS II), Pain Catastrophizing Scale (PCS), Headache Impact Test-6 (HIT-6), and Visual Analog Scale (VAS). The secondary outcome measure will be Migraine Disability Assessment Scale (MIDAS). The study will be conducted in a well-lit, clean and comfortable room with a temperature of 22-24 degrees. Women will be asked to stop eating and wear comfortable clothes at least two hours before the sessions. Before the training, relaxation exercises and breathing techniques explained to the women. The women will lie in the supine position firstly. Then the therapist will instruct them to contract and release different muscle groups. They will practice tensing a muscle group until they feel the slight contraction and then release it, simultaneously relaxing other muscle groups. During the session, women will be instructed to contract the muscles for 10-20 seconds during deep diaphragmatic breathing and to relax for 30-40 seconds while exhaling. The study aims to understand the microRNA response to opioid withdrawal and their potential use as biomarkers for Neonatal Abstinence Syndrome (NAS). The study will include infants exposed to in-utero opiates who meet the inclusion/exclusion criteria. The intervention will involve genetic testing of buccal swab saliva for microRNA quantification. The primary outcome measures will include neurodevelopmental outcome scores, maximum concentration of morphine required for withdrawal symptom control, and salivary microRNA levels of let-7a, 146a, and 192. The study will be conducted at Penn State Hershey Medical Center or transferred at <48 hours after birth.

The study is a randomized controlled experimental research design. The research hypotheses are H1: The postoperative pain level of the patients in the intervention group is lower than that of the patients in the control group. H2: The level of fear of postoperative pain of the patients in the intervention group is lower than that of the patients in the control group. The study group consisted of 52 patients who underwent elective surgery in the orthopedics and traumatology clinic of the training and research hospital affiliated with the Ministry of Health in Istanbul between December 15, 2021, and March 15, 2022, and were open to communication and cooperation, had no cognitive and mental problems, and volunteered to participate in the study. The study group consisted of a total of 52 patients, 26 in the intervention group and 26 in the control group, taking into account the possibility of data loss. Intervention group: Patients receiving patient education on pain management. Control group: Patients who did not receive training in pain management. Patients who met the inclusion criteria were interviewed about the study. Patients who agreed to participate in the study were asked to choose an envelope containing an intervention or control letter. The patient with an intervention letter on the envelope was included in the intervention group and the patient with a control letter was included in the control group. Thus, bias in group selection was presented in the study. Homogeneity between the groups was ensured by testing the gender, age, number of days of hospitalization, educational status, occupation, previous surgery, and regular use of pain medication. Data were collected using the Information Form, Fear of Pain Scale-III, and Visual/Visual Analogue Scale. The primary outcome measure was pain level, assessed by a Visual/Visual Analogue Scale. The secondary outcome measure was fear of pain, assessed by the Fear of Pain Scale-III. The study was conducted between December 15, 2021, and March 15, 2022.

The Patch BRIDGE Trial is a randomized controlled trial that aims to evaluate the efficacy of buprenorphine transdermal matrix patches for induction during pregnancy in women with opioid use disorder. Participants will be randomly assigned to either the bridge induction arm, which will receive buprenorphine transdermal patches, or the standard arm, which will receive a sham patch. The primary outcome measure is induction withdrawal severity, which will be assessed using the Subjective Opioid Withdrawal Scale (SOWS) scores collected during buprenorphine induction. Secondary outcome measures include induction success, treatment adherence, and recovery success. The study will be conducted at an opioid use disorder specific clinic at the institution.

============

The study aims to assess the usefulness of transcutaneous oximetry in the diagnosis of thoracic outlet syndrome. The study will compare the TcpO2 values recorded during dynamic maneuver with the estimated rate of compression of the subclavian and axillary vessels determined on dynamic angiography. The primary outcome measure will be the DROPmin according on the type of compression, and the secondary outcome measure will be the correlation between the severity of upper limb ischemia by TcpO2 measurement and the degree of arterial stenosis observed in diagnostic arteriography. The study will be conducted on patients suspected of having thoracic outlet syndrome who have undergone additional examinations as part of the diagnostic assessment, including venous and arterial Doppler or dynamic arteriography and venography. The study will be conducted on patients over 18 years old who are French speakers and have not expressed their refusal. The study will be conducted over a thirty-minute time frame.

The SmartCP study is a single-arm, unblinded, feasibility study, with an embedded quantitative and qualitative process evaluation. The study aims to determine if SmartCP is feasible in the management of patients with chronic pancreatitis, complementing current specialist clinical care. The study will recruit 50 participants with chronic pancreatitis, who will receive the intervention for 16 weeks, supplementing usual clinical practice. The primary outcome measures include feasibility of recruitment, acceptability of intervention, retention, incidents, user statistics, occurrence of crisis events, symptoms, quality of life, hospitalisation, use of communications features, and use of educational features. Secondary outcome measures include occurrence of crisis events: crisis phone-calls, attendances at Accident & Emergency, and urgent out-patient clinic attendances in Tallaght University Hospital. The study will be conducted in Ireland, and participants will be recruited from the investigators' out-patient clinics. The study will be conducted in accordance with the Declaration of Helsinki and will be approved by the Tallaght University Hospital Research Ethics Committee.

This is a retrospective cross-sectional study conducted over three months from September 2020 to November 2020 at Mansoura University isolation hospital on COVID-19 patients who were diagnosed with anal fissure. The study aimed to determine the incidence of anal fissure among COVID-19 survivors, identify risk factors associated with the development of anal fissure, and determine the outcomes of patients who developed anal fissure. The study included 176 patients who were aged between 20-70 years, both genders, with or without associated co-morbidities who received treatment for COVID-19 infection, were discharged home safely, and presented with anal fissure during the follow-up. The primary outcome measure was the incidence of anal fissure among COVID-19 survivors, while the secondary outcome measure was the risk factors associated with the development of anal fissure. The study was approved by the Institutional Review Board of Mansoura University.

============

This is a randomized controlled trial that aims to assess the effects of platelet-rich fibrin (PRF) on wound healing following palatal connective tissue harvesting. The study includes 20 patients who are randomly assigned to either the control group or the test group. In the control group, the incision line is sutured with 5/0 synthetic, nonabsorbable, sterile monofilament suture, while in the test group, L-PRF membrane is placed to the donor site before suturing. Patients are evaluated using an ultrasonography device at the Department of Oral and Maxillofacial Radiology. USG measurements are performed on days 0, 3, 7, 14, 21, 30, and 90 for palatal tissue thickness and tissue vascularization. The mean pulsatility index (PI) values of each patient are calculated and considered for statistical analysis. The study is powered for a sample size of 10 subjects per group with 80% power and 95% confidence. The data are analyzed with the SPSS 21 program. Continuous variables are presented as mean ± standard deviation and categorical variables as numbers and percentages. Shapiro-Wilk test is used to detect data's normality. For the comparison of the parameters of the study groups, independent samples T-test test is used for normally distributed data while Mann Whitney U test test is performed as non-parametric test. Within-group comparisons between the different time periods are tested with repeated measures of ANOVA. Bonferroni correction is performed for multiple variations. The statistical significance value is accepted as p < 0.05.

The ARRC III Trial of Advanced Recovery Room Care (ARRC) is a pilot registry study at Royal Adelaide Hospital (RAH) that aims to collect high quality data on the ARRC model of care relevant to consumers and hospitals. The study measures the primary outcome of Days at Home after Surgery, as well as secondary outcomes of in-hospital complications, mortality, and cost-effectiveness. The study is designed to pilot the ARRC II study database as an ongoing registry, with the aim of providing a robust mechanism to ensure outcomes are maintained and potentially improved within the institution, allowing for benchmarking across institutions, identifying surgical subgroups that receive benefit from ARRC, and generating and testing hypotheses as to how these benefits are achieved. The study is open to patients scheduled for elective or unplanned surgery at RAH, who are scheduled to stay in hospital at least one night after surgery, and have a 30-day mortality risk score of 0.5% to 8% by the US National Safety and Quality Improvement Program (NSQIP). The study is not open to patients undergoing cardiac surgery or those scheduled for postoperative Intensive Care Unit management. The study measures the primary outcome of Days at Home after Surgery, as well as secondary outcomes of in-hospital complications, mortality, and cost-effectiveness. The study is designed to pilot the ARRC II study database as an ongoing registry, with the aim of providing a robust mechanism to ensure outcomes are maintained and potentially improved within the institution, allowing for benchmarking across institutions, identifying surgical subgroups that receive benefit from ARRC, and generating and testing hypotheses as to how these benefits are achieved.

The study aims to assess the effectiveness and implementation of CAB-LA and oral TDF-FTC (both daily and event-driven) through comparison of uptake, retention in care, coital coverage, and participant choice. The study will be conducted in South Africa and Uganda and will recruit mobile men aged 18+ years who have travelled for work or to find work and spent at least one night away from home for work-related purposes. Participants will be randomized into two groups: Group A will receive oral TDF-FTC PrEP (using either event-driven or daily) and Group B will receive CAB-LA over 9 months. After 9 months, participants will be offered choice of PrEP for a further 9 months, with the ability to change choice as required. The study will use a hybrid effectiveness implementation type 2 trial design and will be conducted in a mixed method, multi-setting, multi-country randomized controlled trial. The study will collect data on HIV incidence, HIV drug resistance mutations, persistence in care, coital coverage, and participant choice. The study will also evaluate the implementation framework and will assess the total and average cost of oral PrEP and CAB-LA in South Africa and Uganda under study conditions from the provider perspective (Maintenance). The study will be conducted in a decentralized model of care for recruitment and persistence in ongoing study and will use the RE-AIM framework to evaluate MOBILE MEN's PrEP delivery preferences and patterns of use.

The study is a preliminary assessment of the psycho-emotional state of patients with TMD. The study group consisted of 130 patients diagnosed with TMD, while the control group consisted of 130 patients without TMD. The study used a questionnaire to measure the emotional state of the respondents over the past 4 weeks. The questionnaire included 30 questions, and the scores for each question were divided into four sections; A, B, C,D. The study aimed to assess the emotional state of patients with TMD and compare it with the emotional state of the control group.

The study aims to investigate the effects of affective touch, therapeutic touch (OMT), and static/nonspecific touch on brain connectivity and metabolic biomarkers in preterm infants. The study will be conducted in a randomized, double-masked, parallel assignment design. Participants will be preterm infants between 32.0 and 33.6 weeks gestational age, without comorbidities that could affect the stability of vital parameters. The intervention will be based on the specific assessment and treatment of the preterm developed by the team and validated through different studies. The primary outcome measure will be pre-post changes in BOLD levels among different brain areas, measured by functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI) at 1 hour. Secondary outcome measures will include pre-post changes from baseline in the EEG power in slow delta waves band at the end of the treatment period, as assessed by electroencephalogram (EEG), and pre-post changes in urinary metabolites as assessed by proton nuclear magnetic resonance spectroscopy (1H NMR) and mass spectrometry combined with liquid chromatography (CL-MS) or gas chromatography (CG-MS) at different time points. The study will be conducted in four time points (T1, T2, T3, and T4) and will follow up the participants for 40 weeks.

This is a phase I/II study of a non-myeloablative haploidentical peripheral blood stem cell transplantation with briquilimab and abatacept for patients with sickle cell disease. The study aims to evaluate the regimen success rate, defined as successful engraftment and absence of acute grade 3 or higher GVHD or moderate to severe chronic GVHD at 1 year post-transplant. The study also aims to evaluate event-free survival and overall survival, viral reactivation and disease, autoimmune and hyperinflammatory complications, and donor type hemoglobin at 1 year post-transplant in SCD patients who have not been transfused in the previous 3 months. The study is open to adult and pediatric patients with sickle cell disease at high risk for disease-related morbidity or mortality, defined as A, B, C, D, E, or F. The study is also open to patients with sickle cell disease at high risk for disease-related morbidity or mortality, defined as A, B, C, D, E, or F. The study aims to compare the effectiveness of two different sperm preparation methods, microfluidic chip and density gradient centrifugation, on the euploidy rate of pre-implantation genetic testing in couples undergoing in vitro fertilization (IVF). The study will recruit eligible couples who will be randomly assigned to one of the two groups. The microfluidic chip group will undergo sperm preparation using the Sperm Separation Device, while the density gradient centrifugation group will undergo sperm preparation using a discontinuous density gradient centrifugation method. The primary outcome measure is the euploid rate of blastocysts biopsied, and secondary outcome measures include live birth rate, positive urine pregnancy test rate, clinical pregnancy rate, ongoing pregnancy rate, miscarriage rate, multiple pregnancy rate, DNA fragmentation, and ectopic pregnancy rate. The study will be conducted over a period of 3 years, and the results will be analyzed to determine the effectiveness of the two sperm preparation methods on IVF outcomes.

The study aims to investigate the association of Brain-derived Neurotrophic Factor (BDNF) single nucleotide gene polymorphism and Nerve Growth Factor as risk factors that increase the severity of Allergic Rhinitis. The study will be conducted on chronic AR patients on anti-allergic therapy. The study will be a single-arm study with a diagnostic test of genotyping. The study will measure the BDNF gene single nucleotide polymorphism, Nerve growth factor serum level, IL-1 serum level, and C-reactive protein serum level for the risk of Allergic rhinitis. The study will be conducted for 2 months.

The study aims to investigate the effect of mindfulness-based intervention on EEG brain activity, cognitive and psychological well-being in the elderly. The study will enroll 60 community-dwelling older adults aged between 60 and 75 years with normal cognition. Participants will undergo cognitive and psychological evaluation and EEG. The intervention will consist of 8 weekly group 2-hour sessions program adapted from mindfulness-based stress reduction and mindfulness-based cognitive therapy protocols. The primary outcome measures will be change from baseline in dispositional mindfulness on the Five Facet Mindfulness (FFM) Scale, change from baseline in verbal memory on the California Verbal Learning Test (CVLT), and change from baseline in interoceptive mindfulness on the Multidimensional Assessment of Interoceptive Awareness (MAIA) scale. Secondary outcome measures will be change from baseline EEG alpha power. The study will be conducted in accordance with the Declaration of Helsinki and will be approved by the Ethics Committee of the University of Pavia.

=================

A study will be conducted to determine the prevalence of Mycoplasma Genitalium (MG) infection and associated antimicrobial resistance among HIV-infected male in Hong Kong. The study will recruit 750 HIV-infected male attending HIV specialist clinic in Hong Kong. An online questionnaire will be self-administered, and participants will self-collect urine sample, rectal and pharyngeal swabs for MG, Chlamydia trachomatis (CT) and Neisseria Gonorrhoeae (NG) screening by nucleic acid amplification tests, and MG genotypic resistance mutations detection. Clinical data will be transcribed from medical records of recruited subjects. The primary outcome measures will be the prevalence of MG infection and prevalence of MG resistance mutations. Secondary outcome measures will include the prevalence of CT infection, prevalence of NG infection, prevalence of syphilis, prevalence of HCV infection, and prevalence of overall STI. The study will be conducted over a period of 1 year.

18F-FES PET/CT is a non-invasive alternative to biopsy techniques for evaluating the expression of ER in various systemic lesions of the patients. The study aims to predict the efficacy of Dalpiciclib in combination with endocrine therapy for HR-positive and HER2-negative recurrent/metastatic breast cancer patients after CDK4/6 inhibitor treatment failure using 18F-FES PET/CT. The study will enroll 50 patients who meet the inclusion criteria and will be randomized into two arms. Arm A will receive the combination of Dalpiciclib with physician-selected endocrine therapy, while Arm B will receive chemotherapy selected by the physician. The primary outcome measure will be investigator-assessed PFS, and the secondary outcome measures will be ORR, DCR, and OS. The study will be conducted in accordance with the Declaration of Helsinki and will be approved by the Institutional Review Board.

The FISSION Study is a prospective, single-arm, multicenter study of XELOX combined with Fruquintinib and Sintilimab regimen conversion therapy for gastric cancer/gastroesophageal junction adenocarcinoma only with liver and/or retroperitoneal lymph node metastasis, a prognosis of 3 months or more, and good main viscera function. The study aims to evaluate the efficacy and safety of the treatment regimen in patients with gastric cancer/gastroesophageal junction adenocarcinoma only with liver and/or retroperitoneal lymph node metastasis, a prognosis of 3 months or more, and good main viscera function. The primary endpoint is progression-free survival (PFS) from randomization to disease progression or death from any cause. Secondary endpoints include overall survival (OS), objective response rate (ORR), disease control rate (DCR), duration of response (DOR), and translational rate. The study will be conducted in accordance with the Declaration of Helsinki and Good Clinical Practice (GCP) guidelines.

The study aims to evaluate the impact of alternative incentives on step count of older adults in the short-term and long-term. The investigators will recruit 200 older adults and randomize half of them to receive additional prosocial and personal incentives for their walking behavior. The other half will not receive these incentives. The investigators will track step count of these two groups for 8 weeks using a Fitbit device. The investigators identified 7,500 steps as an appropriate goal as studies show older adults walk 4,000 steps on average. For the treatment group, meals will be donated by the research team to Feeding America for each day they meet the step goal of 7,500 steps. They will also receive money for each day they meet the step goal of 7,500 steps a day, for up to 5 days a week. The control group will not receive these incentives for their walking behavior, but their daily step count data will be collected. Participants will receive a Fitbit upon enrollment. The investigators will collect their physical activity data for 1 week, as their baseline physical activity. After 1 week, individuals who on average less than 6000 per day, will be randomized to the treatment group, which receives the incentives for 5 weeks, or to a control group which does not. The investigators will also collect follow up data for 2 weeks. Individuals who on average walk more than 6000 steps per day during the 1 week baseline period will be dropped from the study. The study aims to evaluate the impact of alternative incentives on step count of older adults in the short-term and long-term. Exploratory analysis will also evaluate the impact on physical and mental health. The study will be conducted in San Diego, CA. The study will be conducted in San Diego, CA.
