=========

This is an interrupted time series study conducted at the Moi Teaching and Referral Hospital (MTRH) neonatal ward between April 2022 and June 2023. The study participants comprise of newborn patients admitted at MTRH during that period. The MTRH neonatal ward is arranged in 8 sub-units which comprise the comparison sub-groups. Newborns admitted from April-November 2022 comprise the pre-intervention arm and are not exposed to neoGuard, but receive existing standard-of-care vital sign monitoring. In December 2022, neoGuard was installed in 4 sub-units (intervention group), while the remaining 4 sub-units (comparison group) continued to use standard-of-care monitoring. The primary outcome measures are the nurse's response time to patients in distress and the percentage of actionable alarms. The secondary outcome measures are the incidence of patient complications, in-hospital mortality, and the frequency of key interventions. The study will be conducted for 16 months.

=========

This is a phase II study evaluating the efficacy and safety of pre- or post-operative hypofractionated radiation therapy in aged (≥ 70 years) or fragile (≥ 65 years) patients with limb or trunk soft tissue sarcoma. The study will include 2 arms: neo-adjuvant and adjuvant cohorts. The primary outcome measure is the rate of patients free of major surgical complications as defined by O'Sullivan within 6 months of surgery. Secondary outcome measures include disease-free survival, surgical complications, wound disorders, healing time, quality of life, patient autonomy, geriatric parameters, and toxicities of radiation therapy. The study will be conducted in France and will include patients affiliated to a Social Health Insurance in France. The study will be open to patients with histologically confirmed soft tissue sarcoma of the limbs or trunk, indication for neo-adjuvant or adjuvant radiotherapy, aged ≥ 70 years with a performance status ECOG ≤ 2 and/or aged 65 to 70 years with an ECOG of 2 and identified by the investigator as fragile, and able to participate and willing to give informed consent prior performance of any study-related procedures. The study will be conducted in accordance with the Declaration of Helsinki and will be approved by the Ethics Committee of the Centre Hospitalier Valida.

This is a retrospective study conducted at Shree Birendra Hospital, Nepal, to determine the prevalence of Head and Neck Cancer in the department of ENT- Head and Neck Surgery. The study collected data from the medical records of Head and Neck Cancer patients who underwent treatment between May 2022 to April 2023. The data was analyzed using SPSS version 22 and Pearson's chi-square test was applied. The primary outcome measures included age-wise distribution of Head and Neck Cancers, distribution of Head and Neck Cancers according to the subsite, histopathology of Head and Neck Cancers, Tumor, Nodes, Metastasis (TNM) staging of Head and Neck Cancers, and treatment provided to Head and Neck Cancer patients. The study terms related to the study are Head and Neck Cancer, Radiotherapy, and Chemotherapy.

* The study aims to test the impact of a health communication message on the number of children with OSA symptoms who receive a referral for a sleep study or to see a specialist.
* The study will involve 200 children aged 2-13 years who screen positive for OSA.
* The children will be randomly assigned to either view the health communication message or usual care.
* The primary outcome measure will be the rate of completed OSA referral up to 9 months after study entry.
* Secondary outcome measures will include the rate of OSA referral, rate of evidence-based evaluation, rate of OSA diagnosis, and rate of OSA treatment.
* The study will measure parent activation immediately after viewing the health communication message.

=================

The study is a multi-country, prospective, post-marketing study of UPadacitinib evaluating speed of onset and durability of effectiveness for patients with moderate to severe Crohn's Disease in real-world clinical practice for 3 years. The study will measure the time to achieve first clinical response per patient-reported outcome 2 (Daily CR-PRO) and the percentage of participants achieving clinical remission per Harvey Bradshaw Index (HBI) among those with Clinical Response-Harvey Bradshaw Index (CR-HBI) at end of induction therapy. The study will include participants with a diagnosis of moderate-to-severe CD who initiate upadacitinib at the clinician's discretion as part of their routine clinical care. The study will be conducted for up to 3 years.

The study aims to test the online version of QAPS, which is a tool used to assess prewriting skills in children. The study will involve children between the ages of 3 to 7 years old, who will be asked to complete a series of tasks, including drawing shapes on a tablet, copying shapes using a pencil in a paper booklet, writing letters, and cutting paper with scissors. The study will also include surveys and questionnaires about the child's development, including their emotionality, strengths and difficulties, and ego resiliency. The primary outcome measure will be the online QAPS assessment, which will take 5-10 minutes to complete. The study will be conducted in a randomized controlled trial design, with participants being randomly assigned to one of five age groups (3-4 years old, 4-5 years old, 5-6 years old, 6-7 years old, and 7 years old). The study will be conducted in a single center and will involve a total of 100 participants. The study will be conducted over a period of 6 months.

=================

The Critical Time Intervention-Peer Support (CTI-PS) is a 9-month intervention delivered by Community Mental Health Workers (CMHWs) and Peer Support Workers (PSWs) to individuals with psychotic disorders, schizophrenia, bipolar disorder, and schizoaffective disorder who have been discharged from inpatient psychiatric treatment facilities in the month prior to recruitment. The intervention has two broad objectives: 1) to collaborate with participants to develop durable connections to support systems, including both formal and informal supports, and 2) to provide practical and emotional support, helping the individual to overcome a critical period of transition during which they can feel especially vulnerable. The work of CTI-PS will focus on areas identified as crucial for strengthening the individual's continuum of services and forming enduring links with their community supports. The phases of CTI are Initiation, Try-Out, and Transfer of Care. The PSW-CMHW will collaborate with the participants to identify barriers to their recovery and develop a sustainable plan to engage in and use community supports and resources during and after CTI. They will also use their knowledge to increase participants' autonomy, strengthen their connection to health services, and expand their support networks. The role of CTI workers is specifically designed to avoid becoming the primary source of care for the individual. The study aims to measure the effectiveness of the CTI-PS model for individuals with serious mental illness discharged from inpatient psychiatric treatment facilities in Portugal. The primary outcome measures are health-related quality of life, assessed by the WHO Quality of Life Scale - Brief Version (WHOQOL-BREF), and unmet needs, assessed by the Camberwell Assessment of Need (CAN). Secondary outcome measures include psychopathology, level of disability, orientation toward recovery, self-stigma, substance use, and other relevant factors. The study will be conducted as a randomized controlled trial with a parallel assignment intervention model and single masking. The study will recruit 100 participants aged 18-65 years with a diagnosis of psychotic disorder, schizophrenia, bipolar disorder, or schizoaffective disorder who have been discharged from inpatient psychiatric treatment facilities in the month prior to recruitment. Participants will be randomly assigned to either the intervention group or the

Registry for Vascular Trauma and Follow-up Examinations is a study that aims to assess the long-term follow-up after vascular injury. The study includes patients over 18 years of age with isolated vascular injury and written informed consent. The study measures the primary outcome of graft/vessel patency using ultrasound, ABI-measurement, and clinical evaluation. Secondary outcome measures include reintervention rate and development of treatment patterns. Assessments will be performed at different time points, including 3, 6, and 12 months after trauma, with an average of 1 year through study completion. The study is related to trauma, vascular trauma, bleeding, ischemia, and registry.

The study will be a prospective randomized control trial consisting of subjects requiring ORIF of the distal radius. Subjects will be divided into two groups based on age, then subsequently be randomly divided into two groups following their inclusion in the study. Groups will be normalized based on gender. One group will undergo the normal rehabilitation protocol for the hand and wrist as determined by Dr. Liberman. The study group will undergo rehabilitation protocol for distal radius fractures modified by use of a tourniquet for blood flow restriction during selected exercises. On the day of the procedure, the surgeon will measure the subject's forearm girth, the location of the largest circumference. The subject will then undergo the normal operative fixation of the distal radius fracture. A subject will be excluded from the study if they have had any prior surgeries on their affected wrist. At the subject's two week postoperative clinic visit, the physician will measure forearm girth. Study group subjects will begin physical therapy instructed BFR exercises at two weeks post operatively. Study group subjects will be taken through normal hand and wrist rehab protocol as well as BFR exercises. Control group subjects will do the same exercises and formal physical therapy rehab protocol as the study group without BFR.

=========

This is a 2-arm randomized controlled trial to determine the effect of the Stand up for your Health® computer app on sitting time, musculoskeletal symptoms, cardiometabolic markers, and physical activity in office workers. The study will recruit 100 participants from educational establishments and will be measured at baseline, 3rd, and 6th months. The experimental group will receive the Stand up for your Health® computer prompt plus educational information, while the control group will receive only educational information. The primary outcome measure is sedentary behavior (occupational sitting time) at baseline, 3rd month, and 6th month. Secondary outcome measures include cardiometabolic biomarkers and anthropometric measurements.

=========

The study is a randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled study that investigates the chronic effects of low-load blood flow restriction and creatine supplementation in women. The study is designed to measure the effects of the intervention on strength, body composition, neuromuscular function, and endothelial function. Participants will be asked to attend 16 training days, two of which will have blood samples, and a 4-week follow-up assessment. The study will be conducted over a period of 9 months.

=================

The BIOANNA study aims to investigate the role of Growth Differentiation Factor-15 (GDF-15), Neurofilament light chain (Nfl), Glial fibrillary acidic protein (GFAP), and cytokines in Anorexia Nervosa (AN) and to evaluate their potential as novel targets for the treatment of AN. The study will include 8 adult male and female patients with confirmed diagnosis of AN restrictive type, non-exercising subtype, and 8 adult male and female patients with confirmed diagnosis of AN restrictive type, exercising subtype, as well as 16 control participants, sex- and age-matched to the individual AN patients. The primary outcome measures will be the comparison of GDF-15 (pg/ml) level in the plasma and cerebrospinal fluids of AN patients and normal-weight controls. The study will also assess body composition via Dual Energy X-ray Absorptiometry (DEXA) scans and energy expenditure via indirect calorimetry, respectively, to correlate GDF-15, Nfl and GFAP and cytokine levels with lean and fat mass measures as well as with energy expenditure, respectively, of AN patients and the matched controls. The findings of this study will hopefully challenge the viewpoint that AN is a condition which can be controlled by the individual but demonstrate that AN is a biological disease that should be treated by targeting the right biological players in addition to psychiatric treatment. This will also allow for a more tailored, individualized treatment approach of AN in the future.

The PROSPECT study is a prospective, observational study that aims to collect data on complications and other outcomes after pleural interventions. The study will collect data on demographics, smoking history, pre-procedure observations, radiological findings, and medical history. Complications will be objectively defined, and at least 20 centres will be approached to collect data. Patients will be asked to complete a visual analogue scale score for chest pain and breathlessness before and after their procedure and at a further time interval within 4 weeks. The study is extendable to non-specialist centres to achieve similar reporting standards. The data collected will provide a best practice standard against which new and smaller volume centres can benchmark practice, to ensure patient safety.

=================

The Artificial Intelligence for Preventing Heart Disease (AiPHD) study is an observational, single center, prospective and retrospective study aimed at developing a novel clinical-imaging AI-based model to identify and categorize patients at high risk of disease progression and provide a more personalized management approach to improve patient outcomes. The study will include two cohorts: a retrospective cohort of 2500 patients and a prospective cohort of 500 patients. The primary outcome measure is a composite outcome of death by cardiovascular events or non-fatal myocardial infarction, while the secondary outcome measure is a composite outcome of all-cause mortality, non-fatal myocardial infarction, hospitalization due to angina or angina-like symptoms, and late coronary revascularization. The study will use proportional hazards to analyze the data and will integrate all the data in order to select the most important determinant of CAD progression and to discard futile features, thus creating an agile and clinically valuable risk stratification model. The study aims to overcome some issues that currently hamper the widespread clinical application of AI in cardiovascular care, such as the integration of AI-based applications into the clinical workflow. The study will be conducted at Centre Hospitalier Valida and will be led by Dr. Alessandro Cappuccio.

The SIM0355-2019 trial is a multicenter, randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled exploratory clinical trial with the main study objective of evaluating the safety and tolerability of different doses of Edaravone Dexborneol concentrate for injection combined with conventional medical therapy in patients with cerebral hemorrhage. The study is divided into two periods: Period A is a dose escalation period, and Period B is a selection period. The study is designed to measure the incidence of serious adverse events (SAEs) up to 90 days after the first dose of treatment, the incidence of deaths up to 90 days after the first dose of treatment, the proportion of subjects with AEs, AEs leading to dose interruption or discontinuation, AEs related to study drug, AEs of special interest (AESls), and with abnormal vital signs, abnormal physical examination findings and abnormal laboratory tests results, the proportion of subjects with modified Rankin Score (mRS) 0-2, which assesses the degree of disability or dependence in daily activities, with scores ranging from 0 (no symptoms) to 6 (death), at 90 days after the first dose of treatment, the proportion of subjects with modified Rankin Score (mRS) 0-1, which assesses the degree of disability or dependence in daily activities, with scores ranging from 0 (no symptoms) to 6 (death), at 90 days after the first dose of treatment, the distribution of subjects with modified Rankin Score (mRS), which assesses the degree of disability or dependence in daily activities, with scores ranging from 0 (no symptoms) to 6 (death), at 14, 30, 90 days after the first dose of treatment, the distribution of subjects with Glasgow Outcome Score (GOS), which measures functional outcome, with scores ranging from I (Dead) to V (Good Recovery), at 14, 30, 90 days after the first dose of treatment, the change from baseline in National Institutes of Health Stroke Scale (NIHSS), which quantifies the impairment caused by a stroke, with scores ranging from 0 (no stroke symptoms) to 42 (the most severe stroke), the proportion of subjects with National Institutes of Health

=================

This study aims to evaluate the effectiveness and safety of Manzhi Guben granules in improving exercise tolerance and promoting body rehabilitation in patients with novel coronavirus infection. A multicenter, randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled clinical study will be conducted to determine the efficacy and safety of Manzhi Guben granules in exercise tolerance recovery and symptom relief in patients infected with novel coronavirus. The study will focus on the effect of Manzhi Guben granules on improving exercise tolerance of patients with novel coronavirus during recovery period. The study will provide reliable evidence support for the treatment and improvement of novel coronavirus infection with Manzhi Guben granules.

=========

This is a non-interventional fMRI study investigating the neural bases of decision-making and executive functioning in healthy individuals. The study aims to provide insights into the relationship between executive and decision-making skills, and their possible changes with ageing. The study will involve a behavioral assessment of decision-making and executive skills, and a multimodal fMRI session including data concerning brain activity associated with decision-making and executive functioning in social vs. non-social contexts, brain structural morphometry (grey-matter volume/density), and brain structural connectivity (diffusion weighted imaging). The behavioral assessment will involve the main metric of decision-making (e.g., risk aversion, loss aversion, delay discounting) and executive functioning (e.g., selective attention and inhibitory control). MRI data will unveil the neural bases of individual differences in decision-making and executive performance in terms of performance-related patterns of brain activity, structure and connectivity. Results will provide an useful baseline for investigating alterations of decision-making and executive functioning, and of their neural bases, in pathological conditions.

The Neutrocheck Summative Usability Study is a study that investigates the usability of Neutrocheck amongst healthy volunteers and healthcare professionals. The study is designed to measure the effectiveness of key information for safety and user satisfaction with the use of Neutrocheck. The study will be conducted over a period of 2 months and will involve two study groups, one using paper instructions and the other using app instructions. The primary outcome measure will be the identification of use errors, close calls and use difficulties associated with selected hazard-related use scenarios and participant's perceived root causes of these. The secondary outcome measures will be the administration of a questionnaire to assess the effectiveness of key information for safety and user satisfaction with the use of Neutrocheck. The study will utilise statistical software such as R to perform the analysis.

=========

The study aims to identify technical, attitudinal, and motivational obstacles and solutions for people with Parkinson's disease for adopting technology to improve gait and to quantify changes in gait biomechanics that will make participants better and safer walkers, ultimately improving physical function, physical activity, motivation, and quality of life. The study will use an individualized, blocked, stepped-wedge design, with participants being randomly assigned to receive the Heel2Toe sensor, training, and remote supervised use, at intervals of 3 weeks. The primary outcome measures will include angular velocity of ankle at heel strike, angular velocity of ankle during push-off, angular velocity of ankle during foot swing, and coefficient of variation of angular velocity of ankle during three phases of gait cycle. Secondary outcome measures will include motivation, apathy, walking behavior, health-related quality of life, self-reported cognitive ability, and cognitive performance test.

The study aims to investigate the effects of a laughter yoga programme on the mood, anxiety, and loneliness of adolescents with intellectual and physical disabilities in a special school. The study will use a randomized controlled trial design, with 40 adolescents aged 10-19 years old with mild to moderate intellectual and physical disabilities recruited from a special school in Hong Kong. The intervention group will receive a 4-week laughter yoga programme (8 sessions), while the control group will receive routine care provided by the special school. The primary outcome measures will be the Mood Scale, State-Trait Anxiety Inventory (STAI-6), and Loneliness Scale for adolescents. The study will use appropriate descriptive statistics and inferential analysis to compare the changes in outcome measures between the intervention and control groups. The study will be conducted in accordance with the Declaration of Helsinki and will obtain ethical approval from the Institutional Review Board of the Centre Hospitalier Valida.

=========

The study aims to investigate the effects of decision aids on the participation of South Asian women in cervical cancer screening. The study is a randomized controlled trial with three arms: a placebo comparator, an experimental arm with a printed decision aid, and an experimental arm with a mobile decision aid. The primary outcome measures are decisional conflict and cervical cancer screening uptake, while the secondary outcome measures are risk perception, screening decision: choice predisposition, and screening decision: choice question. The study will be conducted in Indian, Pakistani or Nepalese women aged 25 to 64 who have a history of sexual activity, can understand English, Hindi, Urdu or Nepali, and have not had a Pap/HPV test in the past 3 years. The study will be conducted in three centers in the United Kingdom.

=========

This is a randomized controlled trial that aims to investigate the additional effect of forward head posture correction on temporomandibular dysfunction. The study will include 60 participants aged 18-40 years with mild to moderate myogenic temporomandibular dysfunction and forward head posture with craniocervical angle < 50 degrees. Participants will be randomly assigned to one of three groups: conservative treatment, conservative treatment with Denneroll cervical traction orthodontic, or active comparator (teaching the patient the relaxed jaw position and stretching exercises for masseter and medial pterygoid muscles with hold of 20-30 seconds and 3-5 repetitions). The primary outcome measures will include anamnestic questionnaire by Fonseca, craniocervical angle - CVA, Boley Gauge, Visual Analog Scale (VAS), and mandibular opening. The secondary outcome measures will include range of jaw opening, pain, and orofacial pain. The study will be conducted over a period of 7 weeks, with data collection at baseline, 3rd week, and week 7. The study will be conducted in the dental clinic of the university of Sharjah.

* Study Title: Comparison of the Efficacy of Clindamycin Phosphate 1% Gel Versus Once-daily Dapsone 5% Gel in the Treatment of Moderate Acne Vulgaris
* Study Type: Randomized Parallel Assignment
* Study Duration: 03 months
* Study Design: Treatment
* Study Purpose: Treatment
* Study Population: Acne Vulgaris
* Study Intervention: Clindamycin and Dapsone gel
* Study Outcome Measure: Global Acne Grading Sore ( GAGS )
* Study Status: Not Specified

The study aims to investigate the relationship between rotator cuff tear severity and scapular and rotator cuff muscle activation patterns using surface electromyography (sEMG) assessment. The study will recruit participants with a confirmed diagnosis of rotator cuff tear and an MRI scan showing the size of the tear. Participants will be divided into four groups based on the size of the tear (small, medium, large, and massive). The sEMG assessment will be conducted using a wireless sEMG system with a sampling rate of 2000 Hz and a bandwidth of 20-500 Hz. The primary outcome measure will be muscle activation amplitude for the scapular and rotator cuff muscles during functional tasks. The secondary outcome measure will be the identification of differences in muscle activation patterns between varying tear sizes. The study will provide insights into the relationship between rotator cuff tear severity and muscle activation patterns, which may help in the development of personalized treatment plans for rotator cuff injuries.

=============

The SENIOR RCT is a multicenter study conducted in two North Italian Scientific Hospitalization and Treatment Institution in Pavia on older malnourished adults (≥ 65 years old). The study aims to evaluate the efficacy of a 6 months sustainable nutrition protocol on malnourished older adults participants in comparison to the hospital standard of care. The primary endpoint is the improvement of the nutritional status between pre- and post-intervention between experimental and control group measuring weight and strength (handgrip). Secondary objectives are the change pre- and post-intervention between experimental and control group for blood biomarkers, dietary habits, quality of life and evaluation of sarcopenia. The study will recruit older adults over 65 previously enrolled in the SENIOR cross-sectional study and willing to participate to the RCT phase or new enrolled patients from the two hospitals in accordance with the eligible criteria. Malnutrition will be diagnosed according to GLIM criteria, using Malnutrition Universal Screening Tool (MUST) as screening tool. The experimental group at the baseline will receive a nutritional assessment followed by the elaboration of a sustainable and personalized nutritional protocol by qualified dietitians. The intervention will last 6 months with a monthly evaluation of the dietary consumption of the previous 24 hour (recall-24h), followed by a final follow-up after additional 6 months. For both groups at the baseline will be measured blood biomarkers, anthropometric variables, Mediterranean diet adherence, quality of life, strength (handgrip) and locomotion (gait speed). At 3 months weight and strength will be evaluated. At 6- and 12-months baseline measurements will be repeated except for the nutritional assessment. Dietary habits will be evaluated through a Mediterranean diet questionnaire (MEDI-LITE), while quality of life will be measured with Short-Form Health Survey (SF-12) questionnaire. Anthropometric variables include weight, height (knee height and demi-span), waist circumference, and body composition (BIA). In addition, strength (handgrip), Appendicular Skeletal Mass (ASM) and locomotion (gait speed) are necessary to diagnose sarcopenia according to the European Working Group on Sarcopenia

This is a double-blind, multicenter, prospective observational cohort study that aims to investigate the dynamic changes of Torquetenovirus (TTV) load in Chinese renal transplant recipients during immunosuppressive therapy. The study includes 100 Chinese renal transplant recipients who receive ABO compatible renal allotransplantation from the initiation of the study to December 31, 2023, and receive tacrolimus /mycophenolate mofetil(or mycophenolic acid)/prednisone as maintenance immunosuppression after renal transplantation. The study measures the primary outcome of any biopsy-proven acute rejection (Banff criteria) and clinical diagnosed acute rejection from day0 to day365 after kidney transplantation. The secondary outcome measures include any bacterial, fungal (including PJP), mycobacterial, or viral (including CMV viremia, EB viremia, BK Viremia, BK Viruria, etc.) infection requiring hospitalization or prolongation of hospitalization, or requiring intravenous antibiotics or therapeutic use of antiviral drugs, or requiring reduction of immunosuppressive drugs, the development of de novo donor specific antibodies (DSA) or a 30% increase of MFI value in preformed DSA from day0 to day365 after kidney transplantation, and an increase in absolute or percent donor derived-cell free DNA from 1 month post-transplant from day0 to day365 after kidney transplantation. The study is conducted in China and is expected to be completed by December 31, 2023.

* Vitamin B12 vs B3 therapy for nerve regeneration and functional recovery after pediatric traumatic brain injury
* Non-randomized study
* Participants aged 6 to 15 years old with severe TBI
* Intervention: Vitamin B3 or Vitamin B12
* Primary outcome measure: Change in Stair Climb Test (SCT) score
* Follow-up: 3 weeks and 18 months

The study is a phase II, open-label, single-group assignment study evaluating the efficacy and safety of pyrotinib after adjuvant anti-HER2 therapy in women with high-risk early or locally advanced stage breast cancer. The study is designed to measure the invasive disease-free survival (iDFS) at year 2, disease-free survival (2y-DFS), overall survival (OS), invasive disease-free survival (iDFS) at year 5, adverse events (AEs), and serious adverse events (SAEs) according to CACTE 5.0. The study will enroll 100 patients and will be conducted over a period of 10 years. The primary outcome measure is the iDFS at year 2, and the secondary outcome measures are the 2y-DFS, OS, iDFS at year 5, AEs, and SAEs. The study will be conducted in accordance with the Declaration of Helsinki and will be approved by the Institutional Review Board.

=================
The study aims to assess the impact of pasta consumption timing on multiple health outcomes in a sample of normal-weight subjects. The study will be a randomized controlled trial with two phases of nutritional intervention: pasta at dinner and pasta at lunch. The primary outcome measure will be sleep quality, assessed by actigraphy. Secondary outcome measures will include weight change, body mass index (BMI) changes, fat mass changes, basal metabolic rate, fasting blood glucose changes, glycated haemoglobin (HbA1c) changes, total cholesterol changes, LDL-cholesterol changes, HDL-cholesterol changes, triglycerides changes, homocysteine changes, aspartate transaminase changes, alanine transaminase changes, gamma-glutamyl transferase changes, urea changes, creatinine changes, uric acid changes, gut microbiota changes, individual circadian rhythms, TBARS changes, ROS changes, leptin changes, ghrelin changes, insulin changes, IL-6 changes, and C-Peptide YY changes. The study will also assess the impact of individual chronotype on dietary habits and health outcomes. The study will be conducted over a period of 7 months.

18F-Fluciclovine PET/CT in Multiple Myeloma
=====================================================

This is a phase 2 study evaluating 18F-fluciclovine PET/CT imaging in up to 55 participants with multiple myeloma. Participants will be enrolled into one of two cohorts based on disease status; newly diagnosed multiple myeloma (NDMM) participants will be enrolled into Cohort 1 and relapsed refractory multiple myeloma (RRMM) participants will be enrolled into Cohort 2. All subjects will undergo an 18F-fluciclovine injection followed by a static whole-body PET/CT at three time points: Timepoint #1, Timepoint #2 (after induction for NDMM or at 6 months for RRMM) and Timepoint #3 (at progression or at 5 years). Results will be compared to 18F-FDG PET/CT imaging at those same timepoints. The primary objective is to determine the concordance between 18F-fluciclovine PET/CT and 18F-FDG PET/CT in participants with multiple myeloma. The study will also evaluate the efficacy of 18F-fluciclovine in measuring disease volume as compared to other indicators of disease volume such as serum M protein, serum free-light chains, urine M protein, B2 microglobulin, and bone marrow plasma cell percentage. The study will also evaluate the ability of 18F-fluciclovine to identify minimal residual disease (MRD) as compared to MRD status determined by bone marrow flow cytometry or next generation sequencing (NGS). The study will also evaluate the ability for 18F-fluciclovine to evaluate response after treatment as compared to the IMWG response criteria. The study will also evaluate the safety of 18F-fluciclovine as a radiotracer in patients with multiple myeloma.

=========

The study aims to evaluate the arm swing during walking in early multiple sclerosis patients. The study will measure the arm swing amplitude in the shoulder and elbow direction, step speed, and functional mobility using the Two Minute Walk Test (2MWT), Timed Up and Go (TUG), and Timed 25Foot Walk Test (T25FW). The study will be conducted in two groups: early multiple sclerosis patients and healthy controls. The study will be conducted over a period of 3 months, and the primary outcome measure will be the arm swing amplitude in the shoulder and elbow direction. The study will be conducted in accordance with the Declaration of Helsinki and will be approved by the Ethics Committee of Centre Hospitalier Valida.

===============

The study is a pilot randomized controlled trial (RCT) comparing video biofeedback and behavioral therapy in the treatment of Paradoxical Vocal Fold Motion (PVFM). The primary endpoint is the change in Dyspnea Index score before treatment and one month after treatment. The study will also collect data about patient expectations of treatment, reasons for pursuing additional treatment if applicable, and the perceived benefits of the specific intervention. The investigators hypothesize that no clinically meaningful difference will be detected between behavioral therapy and video biofeedback for the treatment of PVFM. The study will provide critical data for designing a fully powered trial comparing these two interventions and will advance the investigators' goal of providing clinicians with important evidence for guiding treatment.

=========

The study aims to evaluate the implementation of a multidisciplinary protocol to improve sleep quality in critically ill patients. The study is a multicenter clinical trial with a quasi-experimental design. The first step involves assessing the sleep quality in sequential patients admitted to the ICU and characterizing the disruptive elements. After this period, the second step will involve sensitizing and training the multidisciplinary team about the importance of sleep for critically ill patients and providing training for the implementation of a multifaceted protocol of interventions to promote sleep quality improvement. Once the multidisciplinary protocol is implemented, the sleep quality of the patients and the clinical impact of this protocol will be reevaluated. The study measures the change in the Richards-Campbell Sleep Quality Score, the Sleep in the ICU Questionnaire, the Confusion Assessment Method for the ICU, the Questionnaire on the patient's perception of sleep from the family member's point of view, the Questionnaire for assessing and perceiving patients' sleep from the point of view of the care team, the Pittsburgh Sleep Quality Index, and the Epworth Sleepiness Scale. The study is expected to be completed in 2022.

===============

The Pilot Study of PACHA program to enhance adherence to adjuvant endocrine therapy among breast cancer survivors is a cluster randomized controlled pilot trial using mixed methods (quantitative and qualitative). The study aims to support the adherence to adjuvant endocrine therapy among breast cancer survivors. The study will be carried out in approximately 66 pharmacies in the Quebec province, which include approximately 132 women. The study will be conducted over a period of 6 months. The study will measure the mean change from baseline to the end of 6-month follow-up in intention to adhere to adjuvant endocrine therapy, adjuvant endocrine therapy knowledge, attitude towards adjuvant endocrine therapy, perceived social support, perceived behavioural control, anticipated regret, coping planning, fear of recurrence, side effects, the cognitive representations of medication, percentage of pharmacists who used PACHA tools in the intervention group, percentage of women who used PACHA tools, mean number of interventions dispensed by the pharmacists to the participating women, proportion of days covered by an Adjuvant Endocrine Therapy (AET), proportion of women having an AET, mean change from baseline to the end of 6-month follow-up in quality of life, program acceptability and feasibility. The study will be conducted in accordance with the Declaration of Helsinki and will be approved by the Ethics Committee of the Centre Hospitalier Valida.

The study aims to investigate the effects of a formulated Melissa officinalis extract in phytosome form (Phytosome®) on sleep quality and duration. The study will use a randomized crossover design, with participants receiving either the Melissa phytosome or placebo for 14 days, followed by a 7-day washout period and then the opposite treatment for another 14 days. The primary outcome measure will be sleep duration, assessed using wearable smartwatches, while secondary outcome measures will include perceived sleep quality, anxiety levels, and quality of life. The study will also monitor any adverse symptoms using the DOTES scale. Eligibility criteria include age between 18 and 65 years, diagnosis of insomnia or sleep disturbances, and no use of anxiolytics, antidepressants, hypnotics, or sedatives within 10 days prior to the start of the study. The study will be conducted in Italy and will recruit 30 participants.

===============

This is a phase II study evaluating the efficacy and safety of lenvatinib and tislelizumab plus CapeOX chemotherapy as first-line treatment for advanced gastric cancer or gastroesophageal junction adenocarcinoma with positive PD-L1 and low TMEscore. The study is a multi-center, prospective, randomized study with two arms: experimental and active comparator. The experimental arm receives intensive treatment of lenvatinib and tislelizumab plus CapeOX chemotherapy, while the active comparator arm receives conventional treatment of tislelizumab plus CapeOX chemotherapy. The primary outcome measure is progression-free survival (PFS) at 3 years, while the secondary outcome measures include overall survival (OS), objective response rate (ORR), disease control rate (DCR), and duration of response (DoR) at 3 years. The study is designed to enroll 100 patients, with 50 patients in each arm.

The R61 phase is a single-arm trial of S-ENG plus eCAU (n=30) with 1 week of smartphone-based target assessment at baseline, 8-weeks and 16-weeks. Participants are 30 adults age 60 and older who report clinically significant loneliness and suicide ideation and reside in a senior living community (SLC). We will use ambulatory assessment via smartphones, including both active self-report (ecological momentary assessment, EMA) and passive sensing (audio recordings & GPS) to comprehensively assess indices of social connection. Subjects will complete EMA recordings using a smartphone daily following 3 personally-selected times for prompts (to enhance recall and ease of completion of assessments) for 10-days prior to starting study interventions, beginning the day after the baseline visit. Each EMA instance takes approximately 2-5 minutes to complete. EMA will be integrated with other smartphone technology to passively capture social behavior. The Electronically Activated Recorder (EAR) will passively measure social behavior (i.e., conversation frequency, duration, and valence). GPS- will track time outside the home. Subjects will be given a study smartphone designed for older adults to use during assessment periods. All subjects who successfully complete the smartphone assessment protocol at baseline will be assigned to S-ENG. S-ENG involves 10 individual coaching sessions over (up to) 4 months. S-ENG is a stepped, modular intervention that addresses barriers to action plan implementation and challenges in processing positive outcomes when exposed to socially rewarding activities. Psychoeducational materials address the importance of social connection. Subjects complete a values clarification exercise on aspects of connection most important to participants to inform personalized activities most likely to impact loneliness. Coaches are instructed to focus action plans on activities that foster social connection. The follow-up assessments at 8- and 16-weeks include baseline measures and smartphone measures.

The study aims to evaluate the efficacy, safety, and tolerability of higher doses of estrogen therapy in women with primary ovarian insufficiency. The study will be conducted in two phases. In the first phase, the study will compare the effectiveness of oral estradiol (2mg/ day) and transdermal estradiol gel 0.1% (Gel sachet 1.5mg/ day) as standard-dose estradiol hormone replacement therapy. The obtained results on the absence of a significant difference in the effect of the above therapy made it possible to justify the prescription of higher doses of estrogens without prior switching from oral to transdermal therapy in equivalent doses in all study participants. In the second phase, the study will consistently receive Transdermal estradiol gel 0.1% (Gel sachet 1.5mg/ day) and Transdermal estradiol gel 0.1% (Gel sachet 2.0mg/ day) (both with 200mg micronized progesterone administered vaginally for 14days per cycle) with an outcome assessment at each stage of the study. The primary outcome measures will be the evaluation of the severity of estrogen deficiency symptoms, changing the assessment of quality of life using the Short Form Health Survey-36 (SF-36), and changing the assessment of menopause-specific quality of life measured using the Menopause-Specific Quality of Life (MENQOL) questionnaire. The secondary outcome measures will be changes in the level of sex hormones after using higher doses estrogen therapy, changes in the level of FSH, E1, E1S, SHBG after using higher doses estrogen therapy, and bone mineral density (BMD) response to using higher doses estrogen therapy for 12 months. The study will be conducted in a non-randomized, sequential assignment design. The study will be conducted in a single center. The study will be conducted in a single center. The Symbiont-Restore Study is a randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled intervention trial designed to investigate the immunological effects of synbiotic supplementation with a L. reuteri strain that originates from Papua New Guinea and explore nutritional strategies to potentially enhance these effects by supporting the colonisation of this strain. The study will systematically compare the possible immunological effects of synbiotic supplementation with a probiotic, L. reuteri PB-W1™, and a prebiotic blend (comprising 50 % raffinose and 50 % xylooligosaccharide) with that of the probiotic and prebiotic alone and characterise the mechanistic and ecological foundations of any effects. The main objective of this study is to investigate the immunological effects of synbiotic supplementation with L. reuteri PB-W1™ and prebiotic blend and characterise the mechanistic and ecological foundations of any effects. The study will be conducted in adults with a BMI of 30-40 kg/m². The study will be conducted in a single-blinded, 2 × 2 factorial design intervention study to systematically compare the effects of the probiotic (L. reuteri PB-W1™), the prebiotic blend (comprising 50 % raffinose and 50 % xylooligosaccharide), the synbiotic (a combination of the probiotic and the prebiotic blend) and relevant placebo controls (maltodextrin in place of the prebiotic blend and placebo capsules in place of the probiotic). The primary outcome measure will be change from baseline immune profile at 8 weeks. Secondary outcome measures will include change from baseline faecal microbiome composition and diversity at 8 weeks, change from baseline metabolic profile at 8 weeks, change from baseline satiety rating over 8 week intervention period, and gastrointestinal tolerance to dietary fibre.

The study is a single-center, randomized, placebo-controlled, double-blind, dose-increasing study. The primary purpose of the study is to evaluate the safety, tolerability, and pharmacokinetics of AD16 tablets in healthy adult subjects after a single administration. The study will be conducted in 7 dosing cohorts, with each cohort receiving a single oral dose of AD16. The study will measure the number of adverse events, serious adverse events, number of participants with abnormal laboratory test results, number of participants with abnormal vital signs, number of participants with abnormal 12-lead electrocardiogram readings, number of participants with abnormal physical examination findings, concomitant medication, Tmax of AD16, Cmax of AD16, t1/2z of AD16, AUC 0-∞ of AD16, AUC 0-t of AD16, CL/F of AD16, Vd/F of AD16, λz of AD16, Mean retention time（MRT ）of AD16, Ae, Fe0-t, and Renal clearance. The study will be conducted in accordance with the Declaration of Helsinki and Good Clinical Practice guidelines.

This study aims to measure the effect of urolithin A supplementation on endothelial function, cerebral blood flow regulation, and serum biomarkers of NO bioavailability and mitochondrial function in middle-aged adults with obesity. The study will recruit 54 adults aged 40-64 years of age with a body mass index equal to or greater than 30 kg/m2 to participate in a double-blind placebo-controlled parallel study for 4 weeks. Participants will be randomly assigned to intervention or control group. Those in the intervention group will consume 1,000 mg of urolithin A daily in the form of softgel capsules, whereas those in the control group will consume a placebo. Data collection will occur at baseline (day 0) and endpoint (day 28). The investigators will compare outcomes between control and intervention group. Researchers expect that urolithin A supplementation in middle-aged adults with obesity improves endothelial function and cerebral blood flow regulation, and that this improvement is accompanied by changes in biomarkers of NO bioavailability and mitochondrial function.

The study aims to examine the effects of vibration applied at different frequencies with a percussion massage gun on joint range of motion, pain, functionality and kinesiophobia in individuals with cervical disc herniation.

The study will be conducted as a randomized controlled trial. Participants will be randomly assigned to either the control group or the vibration group. The control group will receive a conventional treatment program consisting of heat, TENS, and joint range of motion exercises. The vibration group will receive the same conventional treatment program in addition to vibration therapy.

The primary outcome measure will be the evaluation of joint position sense using the Laser Cursor Assisted Angle Repetition Test (LI-YATT). Secondary outcome measures will include the Neck Disability Index (NDI), Visual Analogue Scale (VAS), and the Tampa Kinesiophobia Scale (TKÖ).

The study will be conducted over a period of 3 weeks, with participants receiving treatment 3 days a week.

The study will be conducted in accordance with the Declaration of Helsinki and will be approved by the Ethics Committee of the University of Istanbul.

The study aims to create a register of patients with HFpEF for a comprehensive assessment of the influence of gender characteristics, clinical and anamnestic factors, body composition, topical characteristics of congestion, instrumental data and markers of cellular inflammation and stress on immediate and long-term outcomes in patients with acute decompensated heart failure with preserved ejection fraction. The study will assess gender, clinical and anamnestic indicators preceding hospitalization of patients in the hospital, characterize the features of comorbid status in the studied group of patients, study the features of drug therapy at the prehospital stage and during hospitalization in the study group of patients, assess adverse hospital outcomes and outcomes 6 months after hospital discharge and identify factors associated with them, assess body composition in patients with acute decompensated heart failure with preserved ejection fraction in obese patients upon admission to the hospital, characterize the severity and topical characteristics of congestion and compare with the phenotypes of acute decompensation of heart failure, assess adverse in-hospital outcomes and outcomes 6 months after hospital discharge and identify factors associated with them, conduct a clinical and instrumental examination of patients diagnosed with compensated and decompensated HFpEF, verified by echocardiography at rest, as well as in patients with HFpEF verified after an additional diastolic stress test with assessment of intracardiac hemodynamics, analyze the serum concentrations of biochemical markers associated with cellular stress (heat shock proteins) in these groups of patients, as well as in the control group of apparently healthy people, analyze associations of biomarker levels with clinical characteristics of patients, the presence of comorbid diseases, including obesity, as well as with data from instrumental examination methods, assess the diagnostic capabilities of HFpEF, defined by various criteria, based on the concentration of the new biomarkers studied. The study will be conducted as a descriptive, open-label, observational study, randomization procedure not planned. The study will be conducted in two stages: stage 1 - hospital and stage 2 - determining the nearest outcomes. The study will be conducted in a hospital in Moscow. The study will be conducted over a period of 6 months. The study will be conducted in accordance with the Declaration of Helsinki

The Brothers Building Brothers by Breaking Barriers (B6) study is a telehealth delivery (tele-B6) intervention for young Black gay, bisexual, and other men who have sex with men (YB-GBMSM) living with HIV. The study aims to adapt and pilot B6 for telehealth delivery within the context of an established community-based organization (CBO) as a strategy for enhancing feasibility and scalability prior to a larger efficacy trial. The study uses community-based participatory research methods to develop B6, a novel group-level intervention designed to affirm intersectional identities and augment social capital among YB-GBMSM. The goal of this current study is to adapt and pilot B6 for telehealth delivery (creating tele-B6) within the context of an established community-based organization (CBO), as a strategy for enhancing feasibility and scalability prior to a larger efficacy trial. The study is designed as a randomized, parallel assignment, open label study with two arms: experimental (tele-B6) and other (waitlist control - delayed intervention). The primary outcome measures include acceptability, change in the acceptability surveys, change in recruitment rates, change in retention, change in intervention fidelity, and safety (adverse events). Secondary outcome measures include change in perception of structural racism and discrimination, change in perception of discrimination, change in perception of HIV stigma, change in perception of internalized homonegativity inventory, qualitative description of intersectional stigma, change in intersectional stigma, change in logistical barriers, qualitative description of logistical barriers, changes in perception of individual resilience process: identity affirmation, qualitative description of individual resilience process: identity affirmation, changes in perception of community resilience process: social capital, qualitative description of the community resilience process: social capital, changes in perception of minority stress: depression, changes in perception of minority stress: general well-being, and qualitative description of the minority stress. The study is conducted in the Atlanta Metropolitan Statistical Area and is open to eligible participants aged 18-29 years.

The study aims to investigate the impact of parent/caregiver involvement on DTTC treatment outcomes in children with CAS. Participants will be seen in two groups: 1) Direct Training (DTTC + Home Practice + Direct Caregiver Training); 2) Indirect Training (DTTC + Home Practice + Indirect Caregiver Training). The study will address the following aims: Aim 1: Quantify the effects of direct vs. indirect caregiver training during a period of DTTC combined with home practice on whole word accuracy in treated and generalization probes at post-treatment and maintenance. Aim 2: Quantify the effects of direct vs. indirect caregiver training during a period of DTTC combined with home practice on phoneme accuracy in treated words and generalization probes at post-treatment and maintenance. Aim 3: Quantify the effects of direct vs. indirect caregiver training during a period of DTTC combined with home practice on speech intelligibility at post-treatment and maintenance. Aim 4: Quantify the effects of direct vs. indirect caregiver training during a period of DTTC combined with home practice on functional communication at post-treatment and maintenance. The study will use a multisite parallel-group randomized control trial (RCT) design. Participants will be seen for 16 weeks in total, for all participants. The study will use a multi-factor whole-word accuracy measure (Multilevel word Accuracy Composite Scale (MACS); Case et al., in press) of segmental accuracy, word shape maintenance, prosodic accuracy, and smoothness/fluency of movement transitions to measure changes in word accuracy. Percentage of accurate phonemes will be calculated for treated and generalization words to measure changes in phoneme accuracy. The Intelligibility in Context Scale (ICS; McLeod et al., 2012) will be used to measure changes in speech intelligibility. The Functional Outcomes on Communication Under Six (FOCUS-34; Thomas-Stonell et al., 2015) will be used to measure changes in functional communication.

The study aims to test and validate the creation of self-help and support groups for laryngectomized patients. The study will include laryngectomized patients who wish and can participate in these groups. The sessions will take place as follows: 1st: presentation of each, answers to questions; 2nd: intervention of the association of the mutilated of the voice; 3rd: questions / answers with a resource patient (laryngectomized for 13 years in Bichat); 4th: grouping of all participants to assess patient satisfaction. To assess the benefit of these meetings, a global quality of life questionnaire (WHOQOL-BREF) and an ENT-specific questionnaire (EORTC QLQH&n43) will be given to patients before the first session and retrieved beforehand. The patient will be able to participate in the sessions only if the questionnaires are submitted. The questionnaires are accompanied by a free text part, so that the person fills in the keys that the workshops have brought him. Patients who cannot participate in the exchange groups for geographical or personal reasons will constitute a control group. They will also complete the two questionnaires four months apart. The number of patients registered and the participation rate at each session will be evaluated.

MS-DETECT is a study evaluating the sensitivity and specificity of the MSCopilot® Detect application in detecting clinically meaningful disability worsening in patients with multiple sclerosis. The study will be conducted in 10 centers in France and will include 100 patients with RRMS or SPMS. The study will be conducted over a period of 24 months. The primary outcome measure will be the sensitivity and specificity of the MSCopilot® Detect application in detecting clinically meaningful disability worsening based on the revised-MSFC scores. Secondary outcome measures will include the sensitivity and specificity of the MSCopilot® Detect application in detecting disability worsening based on EDSS, the sensitivity and specificity of the MSCopilot® Detect application in detecting disability worsening earlier than the EDSS, the ability of the MSCopilot® Detect application to detect disease progression in absence of a relapsing activity, the ability of the MSCopilot® Detect application to detect MSFC changes over time, the association between digital and clinical scores, the reproducibility of MSCopilot® Detect individual scores and/or composite scores between in-clinic and at-home digital tests, the reliability of MSCopilot® Detect individual scores and/or composite scores at-home over time, the ability of MSCopilot® Detect individual scores and/or composite scores to discriminate between a relapse and a momentary disability worsening, the ability of MSCopilot® Detect individual scores and/or composite scores to detect clinically meaningful disability worsening based on EDSS, the ability of MSCopilot® Detect individual scores and/or composite scores to detect clinically meaningful disability worsening based on revised-MSFC scores, the ability of MSCopilot® Detect individual scores and/or composite scores to detect clinically meaningful disability worsening based on MSFC-3 or Revised-MSFC3 + SLCLAT scores performed in clinic, the association between digital and clinical scores, the ability of MSCopilot® Detect individual scores and/or composite scores to detect MSFC changes over time, the ability of MSCopilot® Detect individual scores and/or composite scores to detect disease progression in absence of a relapsing activity,

The PCOS Challenge Study is a study that aims to collect information from individuals diagnosed with PCOS, self-diagnosed with PCOS, or exhibiting PCOS symptoms, as well as a control population of people born biologically female who have not been diagnosed with PCOS and do not have symptoms of PCOS. The study measures information such as responses to survey questions over a one-year time frame. The study includes participants aged 12-80 years old and accepts both healthy and unhealthy volunteers. The study is designed to collect information to advance research and improve care for PCOS patients.

The study is a cluster-randomized trial of low molecular weight heparins (dalteparin and tinzaparin) in patients with indication for low molecular weight heparins. The primary outcome measure is 30-day all-cause mortality and bleeding requiring blood transfusion. Secondary outcome measures include 30-day all-cause mortality, 365-day all-cause mortality, blood transfusion during admission, 90-day risk of pulmonary embolism, 90-day risk of deep venous thrombosis, heparin induced thrombocytopenia, liver failure, length of hospital admission, and days alive out of hospital. The study is designed as a parallel assignment intervention model with a randomized allocation. The study is open label.

Title: Technological Balance and Gait Rehabilitation in Patients With Multiple Sclerosis: Effects on Functional, Motor and Cognitive Outcomes (ROAR-MS)

Background:

Multiple Sclerosis (MS) is a chronic, inflammatory, demyelinating disease of the central nervous system (CNS) that affects motor, sensory, and cognitive functions. Balance and gait impairments are common in patients with MS and can lead to falls, which are associated with increased morbidity and mortality.

Objectives:

The aim of this study is to evaluate the effects of technological rehabilitation on balance and gait in patients with MS.

Methods:

This is a randomized, controlled, cross-over pilot study. Patients with a definitive diagnosis of MS, aged between 18 and 65 years, with a Pyramidal or Cerebellar system with a score ≥ 2 on the EDSS, and with the ability to stand without support for 60 seconds, will be recruited. Patients will be randomly assigned to either the experimental group (HO, Hunova-Observation) or the control group (OH, Observation-Hunova). The experimental group will undergo specific rehabilitation treatment for balance disorders using the robotic platform Hunova® Movendo Technology srl, Genova, IT), for 4 weeks, 3 times a week for 45 minutes each. The control group will undergo 4 weeks of observation without rehabilitation treatment, followed by specific rehabilitation treatment for balance disorders using the robotic platform Hunova® Movendo Technology srl, Genova, IT), for 4 weeks, 3 times a week for 45 minutes each. The primary outcome measure will be the change from baseline Berg Balance Scale (BBS) scores at 4 and 8 weeks. Secondary outcome measures will include the change from baseline Modified Fatigue Impact Scale (MFIS), Fatigue Scale for Motor and Cognitive Function (FSMC), Timed Up and Go test (TUG), Ambulation Index (AI), Walking handicap scale (WHS), Functional Ambulation Classification (FAC), 10 Meter Walk Test (10mWT), Six-minute walk test (6MWT),

The primary outcome measure will be the time of diagnosis and treatment of TMA. The study will run for 24 months.

The study aims to evaluate the effect of an intermittent teaching unit on physical activity and its psychological mediators in students. The study is a cluster-randomized controlled trial with two arms: experimental and active comparator. The experimental group received an intermittent teaching unit twice a week for eight weeks aimed at promoting healthy physical activity habits. The active comparator group did not receive any intervention but carried out two Physical Education lessons a week during the intervention period. The study measures changes in perceived autonomy support, basic psychological needs, motivation toward Physical Education, motivation toward physical activity, intention to be physically active, and habitual physical activity. The study uses the Spanish version of the Multi-Dimensional Perceived Autonomy Support Scale for Physical Education (MD-PASS-PA), the Spanish version of the Basic Psychological Needs in Exercise Scale (BPNES), the Spanish version of the Revised Perceived Locus of Causality Scale (PLOC-R), the Spanish version of the Behavioral Regulation in Exercise Questionnaire (BREQ-3), the Spanish version of the Intention to partake in leisure-time physical activity questionnaire, and the Physician-based Assessment and Counseling for Exercise questionnaire (PACE). The study is conducted in a school setting and includes students in the seventh to tenth grade at the secondary education level. The study is conducted in Spain.

The proposed study aims to develop and implement a successful and effective digital care plan for post-secondary students in the Kingston, Frontenac, Lennox & Addington (KFL&A) region. The initiative will target a broad population of students ranging from those interested in learning more about mental health (online psychoeducation program) to those seeking additional help for their psychiatric symptoms (e-CBT program). The research team is experienced in designing effective AI-assisted online psychoeducation and diagnosis-specific e-CBT programs for various mental health conditions in diverse populations. The study will use a stepped-care approach and will be guided by a rigorous approach involving seven aims divided into three phases (pre-adoption, delivery, and post-adoption phases). The pre-adoption phase will assess post-secondary students' current mental health landscape through surveys and focus groups. The delivery phase will determine the efficacy and cost-effectiveness of the online psychoeducation and diagnosis-specific e-CBT programs by comparing them to treatment as usual. The post-adoption phase will use the collected data to monitor the success and fidelity of the programs using surveys and focus groups and to build capacity and scale the project to other Canadian municipalities. The study will use a randomized controlled trial design with a parallel assignment intervention model. The primary outcome measures will include changes in anxiety severity (GAD-7), depression severity (PHQ-9), depression severity (QIDS), stress severity (DASS-42), quality of life (AQoL-8D), resilience (RS-14), social anxiety severity (LSAS), and ADHD severity (ASRS). The study will be conducted in accordance with the Declaration of Helsinki and will obtain ethical approval from the Research Ethics Board of the Centre Hospitalier Valida.

The study is a randomized, parallel assignment, open label study. The study aims to assess the efficacy of letrozole in the treatment of ectopic pregnancy in comparison to methotrexate. The study includes 75 women diagnosed with ectopic pregnancy who are referred to the Obstetrics and Gynecology Center of Valiasr Hospital. The patients are randomly allocated to three groups: methotrexate, letrozole BD, and letrozole TDS. The primary outcome measure is the level of βhCG on day 14, and the secondary outcome measure is the level of anti-mullerian hormone 3 months after the treatment. The study is designed to measure the efficacy of letrozole in the treatment of ectopic pregnancy in comparison to methotrexate.

=========

This study aims to evaluate the effect of fenestrated closure compared to non-fenestrated closure to the left ventricular size at systole and diastole in patients with ASD secundum and pulmonary hypertension. The study includes patients with complete preoperative and postoperative echocardiography data and those with incomplete postoperative data but willing to present upon invitation to complete missing data. The intervention/treatment involves ASD closure with fenestrated/non-fenestrated patch. The primary outcome measures are improvement in left ventricular diameter during systole and diastole, measured preoperatively and postoperatively. The study is designed as a cross-sectional study and is conducted from January 2017 to October 2021. The study includes patients with ASD secundum and pulmonary hypertension who are willing to participate in the study and have complete medical records. The study does not accept healthy volunteers.

The study aims to investigate the role of oxidative stress and mitochondrial TERT in the progression and therapeutic resistance of papillary thyroid cancer. The study will be conducted in two phases. In the first phase, the study will investigate the role of oxidative stress and mitochondrial TERT in papillary thyroid cancer. The study will measure the H202 generation in papillary thyroid cancer and in corresponding normal tissues, and the TERT mitochondrial localization in papillary thyroid tumors. The study will also investigate the genetic characterization of tumor tissues and the expression profile of tumor tissues. In the second phase, the study will investigate the effect of exogenous oxidative stress and therapeutic agents on TERT nuclear to mitochondrial translocation in thyroid cancer cell lines. The study will measure the mitochondrial oxidative stress generation in cells lines treated with Src kinase inhibitors, proliferation, apoptosis, migration in cells lines treated with Src kinase inhibitors.

The COMET trial is a phase III prospective multi-centre open label two-arm randomised controlled trial with an internal pilot and masked outcome assessments. The study aims to compare the effects of whole-body hypothermia versus targeted normothermia on neurodevelopmental outcomes in babies with mild hypoxic ischaemic encephalopathy. The study will recruit 1000 babies born at or after 36 weeks of gestation with birth weight of 1800g or more with birth acidosis or requiring resuscitation at birth. The babies will be screened for eligibility using a structured neurological examination performed between 1 to 6 hours after birth. The babies in both arms, who are born at a non-cooling centre (LNU or SCBU) will be then transferred to the nearest cooling centre (NICU) for continued care at earliest. Whole-body hypothermia (33.5±0.5°C) will be initiated within 6 hours of birth and continued for 72 hours using a servo-controlled cooling machine. The duration and depth of cooling will be as per the current standards for babies undergoing hypothermia with moderate or severe HIE in the NHS. After 72 hours of whole-body hypothermia at 33.5±0.5°C, the baby will be rewarmed at 0.5°C per hour to reach 36.5±0.5°C over 8 hours. Two hourly rectal temperature data will be collected for the first 80 hours. For babies randomised to normothermia, the rectal temperature will be maintained at 36.5±0.5°C using servo-controlled incubators for the first 80 hours and any hyperthermia will be treated with a standardised protocol. Rectal temperature will be recorded every 2 hours for the first 80 hours. Conventional MRI using standard 3D T1-weighted and 2D T2-weighted sequences and diffusion weighted imaging will be performed in all babies prior to discharge home. The follow-up assessment will be done for the recruited babies at 24 (±2) months of age by a central team of 2 to 3 examin

A First-In-Human, Phase I/IIa Trial of the Novel T Cell Immunotherapy pTTL in Patients With Advanced Colorectal Cancer

The study aims to investigate the role of serum amyloid A (SAA) in clinical decision-making concerning sarcoidosis patients. The study will compare the mean serum concentration of SAA in patients, newly diagnosed with intrathoracic sarcoidosis to mean value in healthy controls. The study will also determine whether serum concentrations of SAA at the time of diagnosis of intrathoracic sarcoidosis correlate with serum concentrations of other biomarkers of granulomatous inflammation and pulmonary interstitial disease, pulmonary function test results, radiologic extent of disease, changes in lung function tests after 3 years of follow-up, changes in HRCT disease extent after 3 years of follow-up and need for recent/ongoing therapy in patients, assessed at a 3-year follow-up. The study will be conducted in an intrathoracic sarcoidosis cohort and healthy controls. The study will be conducted over a period of 4 years for patient enrollment and 3 years follow-up.

The study aims to evaluate the benefit of early intrauterine transfer of blank culture medium prior to transfer of a thawed embryo from 1st in vitro fertilization. The study is a randomized, single-blind, multicenter controlled trial. The study includes 100 women aged 18-39 years who have had a first fresh or frozen embryo transfer, transfer followed by pregnancy failure, and have at least two embryos eligible for transfer or freezing during a 1st IVF attempt. The study has two arms: experimental and sham comparator. The experimental arm receives blank culture transfer, and the sham comparator arm receives an intermediate transfer step with an empty catheter. The primary outcome measure is the clinically progressive pregnancy rate between groups, measured on first-trimester ultrasound. Secondary outcome measures include the occurrence of pregnancy, biochemical pregnancy, clinical pregnancy, early miscarriage, and live birth. The study also evaluates the cost per additional live birth and the budget impact analysis over a one-year time horizon.

The study aims to evaluate the prognostic risk factors and long-term health impact of immunotherapy patients based on a special disease cohort registered by patients. The study is a multicenter, observable and controlled cohort study in multiple clinical centers including the First Affiliated Hospital of Xi'an Jiaotong University. The study includes solid-tumor patients who received immunotherapy for the first time. The baseline information before treatment was collected, including demographic characteristics, tumor and anti-tumor information, gene testing information, blood sample collection information, and questionnaire evaluation information. The outcome indicators are mainly disease free progression survival (PFS), the secondary indicators were the total survival period (OS) and the scoring results of various questionnaires (PHQ-9, etc). The study is expected to provide high-level evidence-based medical evidence for the selection of immunotherapy schemes for these patients, the precise prevention and health management of adverse reactions after immunotherapy, and the further improvement of survival prognosis of patients.

The study aims to examine the effect of acupressure on back pain in the late postpartum period after cesarean section. The study is designed as a randomized controlled experimental study. The population of the research will consist of participants who have had cesarean section, who have back pain, who are in the late postpartum 1st week and 4th week, and who are registered to family medicine units in a Family Health Center. The sample size of the study was calculated using the G*Power 3.1.9.2 program and the mean, standard deviation values and effect size of the back pain variable in the related article (Akgün & Boz, 2020) were taken into account. The effect size was calculated as 1.025136. The minimum number of individuals to be included in the sample of the study to be done was calculated by taking G*Power 3.1.9.2 and effect size: 1.025136, α= 0.05, power: 0.90, and the sample size was determined as 23 in the acupressure group and 23 in the control group. A total of 70 (Acupressure group: 35, control group: 35 participants) participants will be included in the study, taking into account possible data losses. In which group the participants included in the study will be, will be determined from the website of the random number generation program Research Randomizer, and they will be divided into two groups. Data will be collected by the researcher through face-to-face interviews at the family health center. VAS (Visual analog scale) will be filled in by the participants to evaluate late postpartum back pain. VAS (Visual analog scale) in which back pain is evaluated will be filled in the acupressure group and control group for the first time in the postpartum 1st week and the second time in the 4th week before and after the application. No application will be made to the control group and only routine care will be given. An environment where privacy can be protected and away from external stimuli will be prepared for the participants. * Index clients: Clients who are referred for HIV testing.

The study is a randomized, placebo-controlled trial that aims to evaluate the effects of paroxetine on cardiovascular function in septic patients. The study includes 2 arms: a placebo comparator arm and an experimental arm. The primary outcome measure is time to vasopressor discontinuation, and the secondary outcome measures include cumulative vasopressor dose in the first 48 hours after randomization, variation in cardiovascular sequential organ failure assessment score score 24 to 120 hours after randomization, cumulative vasopressor dose for 120 hours after randomization, total sequential organ failure assessment score score variation 24 to 120 hours after randomization, and length of stay in the ICU. The study is designed to be a parallel assignment with a quadruple masking. The study is a single-center study. The study is a phase 2 trial. The study is a randomized, placebo-controlled trial.
